school: St. croix valley area learning center

comments: This year I have had a total of 88 Monarchs roost in my yard and have tagged 58 of those.  Last year I had 2950 butterflies roost in my yard up to 8/27/01, and had tagged 550.  The most onany one night this year is 58 versus 900 last year.

For the second year in a row, we found monarchs roosting by my auntie's workplace in St. Paul. Last year we saw about 200 butterflies, but this year we saw about 30 - 40. It might be the early part of the migration, plus we went during the afternoon. I'm going to check this evening again to see how many there will be in the grove. The butterflies all appeared to be new for they were very bightly colored. I wish I have some tags.

Migration Highlight

We have found the migration to be late also. We saw our first small group roosting (25) last night, Sept 2nd, and last year we had tagged 950 by now. There are a lot of larva that have just shown up also. This is the first we have seen of catapillers in numbers this year. Could this point to a later migration? They have stripped all my milkweed seedling.

Migration Highlight

Yesterday about 6 p.m. while walking 1 mile along the NW side of Lake Waconia I counted 19 monarch butterflies heading south, one-by-one. About 7:15 close to 100 monarchs in two clusters were on our nextdoor neighbor's mature sugar maple tree. Clusters up about 8 to 10 feet and on east side of the tree. In the afternoon a cool front arrived and the wind was from the NW.This morning (Tues. Sept. 3) about 9:00 the monarchs were leaving their night roosts. Clear sky and temp. in low 60s.

Migration Highlight

We have been seeing Monarchs since Sunday, the 8th and it is the usual time when we see them. The only difference is other years we usually see thousands of them but we first noticed them the outside temperature was in the nineties and there were only a couple hundred. They usually roost in our cedar trees and are so heavy that you can't see the green of the cedar. This year they are far and few between, but it's early and a couple of hundred are better than none. We will keep waiting and watching. A cold front is supposed to go through later this week. We will keep you posted.

Jim Gilbert reports from the Gustavus Adolphis campus in St. Peter, MN:

Last week (Wed., Thurs., Fri.), I had tagged 50 monarchs with students. Every day, we kept seeing the same ones hanging around the gardens. They?d roost in the trees at night and come nectar in the garden during the day. Even a couple of days later we were still seeing some with tags on. BUT what?s interesting is that there?s a new group of about 25 there today. We?re not finding a single one with a tag-?the old group is gone! A cold front came through yesterday evening and we have a north wind today. (What I don?t know is what time the old group left. It could be that they took off this morning, or late yesterday. I?m a commuter so I wasn?t here in the evening or early morning.)

A cold front came through on Tuesday (09/10/02).  I noticed a few monarch while driving from Council Bluffs to Sioux City. Then Wednesday (09/11/02)  I noticed more flying around and we had more than 60 roosting in our trees. Before this day only a few were flying around the house or roosting.

After a lull last week, seeing only 1 or none each day, this evening the 15th, I observed good numbers. Anywhere from 3 to 8 per minute cruising into my tall cedar trees to roost. I was able to tag 6, all were fresh and bright.

Sept. 17
Counted 17 on my 30 minute drive home yesterday from Osawatomie to Richmond, monarchs continued roosting in tall cedars although not as many as the evening before. I tagged 12. Today at school we tagged 4, they paid no attention to the flowers but were resting all through the day on sugar maple trees in the shade.

Saw one monarch fluttering in a stand of elm & hackberry trees in the RiverBend Golf Course near the Washita River.  Last year there were 50+ monarchs roosting there about the same time of the year.  The single monarch landed to roost for the evening about 6:00 p.m.  If there were more monarchs, I didn't see them.
We observed the largest roost ever in elm tree on our property this evening.  We estimate about 200 Monarchs.

Hammon Elementary's Third Grade class caught, tagged and released 100 Monarch butterflies as they were roosting in trees this morning. The temperature was in the upper 50's or low 60's so they were not ready to fly and that made them fairly easy to catch. As the temperature rose to the 70's they became more lively and were more difficult to catch. We estimate that we caught 20 that got away before being tagged. :) We also caught a Black Swallowtail--Oklahoma's state butterfly. :)

This evening my wife and I counted 15 Monarchs. The most we haveever seen since we have been living here. We live 12 miles west of Minco OK. They are roosting in our Cedar trees for the night.The word got out that we have food and water for them.

As of September 26: We see 15 to 20 a day at least, if not more, from daylight to dark. Wecan't tell if they are new ones each day, they are definintly roosting inour trees, we saw them roosting in our oak and cedar trees tonight. Some arefeeding on our butterfly bushes, and some keep on flying right on by. Wealso have sources of water, and other plants that may possibly attract them.We will be looking for them tomorrow. We have 10 acres mostly wooded andwild.

Friday I checked a roost that was close to 250 in Oklahoma City. The roost we tagged at Saturday morning was 200 yards south of the Friday roost and contained about 400.

Sunday we checked the two roosts, they contained between 1500 to 1700 combined. Only tagged at one of the roosts on Sunday starting at 7 AM. After running out of tags we walked through the second roost. The temp had warmed and the Monarchs were moving off the roost through the trees. It was a wonderful sight to stand underneath with hundreds flying off the trees only a few feet overhead!

Two observations: The roost we tagged at Sunday was the same one I tagged at in 1997 and that year it contained over 13,000 on 9-27-97. Also, we noticed that about 200 monarchs continued to stay in the dense undergrowth of the roost all day Sunday even though it was sunny, 90+ and a major nectar source available only 150 feet away.

A cold front is expected through Thursday/Friday and the temp will drop 20 degre

33 observed by student and father roosting on honeysuckle, late evening 9-27-02.10-3-02 We have been tagging Monarchs for two week now, and today saw a sharp decline in numbers.  We only saw about 3 today.
In my backyard on a Monterey oak tree I saw at least 100 Monarchs.
Tons of buttreflies all monarchs and all together on one tree.

Approximately 3,000 monarchs were present in the pecan orchard early Sunday morning and we tagged 23.  A cold front passed through later that evening and I have not been able to return to the location all this week to see if the butterflies left with the passage of the front.

Saw about 30-40, maybe more, swarming around a large flowering plant outside our school near downtown Dallas.  The kids went crazy! I saw one or two small monarchs a couple of weeks ago but nothing like this.  Wow!
We have several monarchs in our yard laying eggs on our milkweed. We have caterpillars as well as pupae on our plants. Great sight.

Came home from Big Bend (no monarchs) to find 1500 monarchs congregating in the trees around my house. 50yds./10 trees. Heavy predation occuring from 6 scissortail flycatchers. Neighbor says they showed up first on Oct. 14.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: I have seen an increase in the number of Monarch butterflies in my yard in north San Antonio and found some roosting in a nearby park. There are also a large number of Queen butterflies. Linda Shavano Park

After watching thousands of monarchs crossing Lavaca Bay yesterday with loose clusters starting to form about 5:30 (clear, light northeast wind, almost calm at sundown ... about 5:45), we didn't get back until after 5:30 today.  But there they were again ... more clusters, only about half the monarchs as yesterday.  Clusters that must have formed earlier this afternoon (very overcast, light rain expected, same light northeast wind) along the shell beach road.  For as far as we could drive and binoculars see ... clusters had formed on tall grasses, seaside goldenrod, and shoreline brush and small trees that grow in the tidal area.  Our daughter and family went across the causeway before noon yesterday and said they saw "tons" of monarchs "following the causeway" across the bay SW to Port Lavaca.

past two weeks, daily observation of three Monarch Butterlies observed nectaring, on Lantana, Zinnas, mexican sunflowers, and milkweed. Noticed one large caterpillar about 1" long.Temperature unseasonably warm 75 to 80, overnight about 66 degrees. Cold front due.

As we watch, count, and net monarchs on the peninsula to the Lavaca Bay causeway we see clustering starting about half an hour before sundown.  Tonight, just a few loose clusters of three, four, and five started on brush and small trees just above the high tide mark and a few minutes after sundown they had tightened up to about the size of a softball with six to ten in each.  We counted about 300 monarchs in two hours this afternoon, netted about 75 for tag and release, most nectaring on wildflowers on the peninsula, a few approaching from the NE.  There were many singletons that were down in the salt marsh grasses and weeds that would flush like quail when we walked by.  We have seen no better clusters at the roosting trees near the edge of the bay than the seventy-five last week.  We still wonder what it might be that causes that second, then third, and so, monarch to gather on the same leaves and cluster for the night, a scent?  If so, how far can others detect it?

My annual visitors from Canada began showing up this evening.  They seem to prefer to camp in a 1/2 acre site of pines located to the south of my deck.  Word of mouth must advertise it as a good place to stay overnight, as each day more and more new arrivals apparently replace those that have moved on.

Our CTV television network reported last night (8/17/03) that thousands of migratingmonarch butterflies had gathered near Piney, Manitoba - about 5 miles northof the Manitoba/Minnesota border. From the map I have, the closest U.S.town in Minnesota is Roseau. The area appears to be fairly rural andundeveloped - no major roads or towns for many miles. Resident NeaHwanndal, age 88 years, first noted the monarchs 2 weeks ago. Film clips ofNea and the monarchs confirm the report.

Reported by Don Davis for a friend who saw story on CTV television network.

(Editor's Note: Estimating date of first roost as 8/3/03, two weeks before 8/17/03.) This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present. We are estimating a minimum of 2000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “thousands.”
One of my students who was visiting Toronto, Canada this week,reported that on Monday, August 18, thousands ofmonarchs were roosting in the trees there.  (It waseven on the local news.)

Mr. Paul Viger counts monarchs daily at his site in Campbell, Minnesota. The first 18 butterflies appeared on August 17 this year and numbers had climbed to 82 butterflies as of August 27.

At any overnight roost, the number of visiting monarchs tends to rise and fall from one night to the next.Take a look at the data he collected during the Fall 2001 season. What relationship do you see between wind and migration? Why do you think monarchs behave this way? See: Analyzing Data From a Fall Migration Roost

How many tagged monarchs can you see at this roost?

Over the last 6 nights, we've tagged 1025 monarchs in the Monona Butterfly Garden. This is the first time the monarchs have been in this area for this long in these numbers. Usually they stage elswhere and are here only during migration. We have been recovering many of our own tags each night from previous nights.

The groups have been getting larger every night. Last night (9/3/03) there were well over 20 limbs of 50 or more monarchs!! This is the best we have seen. We are also getting several calls each day about other large group sightings in the area.

They are not picky this year in which trees they set in. They are using Ash, Maple, Cherry, Boxelder, Cottonwood, Oak, Willow and Walnut.

One of the neat byproducts of doing this in the city park is that a lot of people get to interact with us and a lot of kids get involved. Sometimes this does lead to unexpected events. One night a tagger found a very large group in a tree and called down for another net. A little 1st Grader grabbed a net and went running into the area sending the monarchs into flight!! There had to be at least 500. What a sight!! Tagging that night was done but as I sat there lamenting the loss, I remembered the glowing little face and decided that a glowing little face on a child is indeed worth a thousand monarchs!!

Happy tagging. There are a lot of monarchs in Northeast Iowa. They are staging now but will be moving south soon.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

Dawn waking, tingling - you feel connection to the divine madness of Emerson, Thoreau & Ewell Gibbons! Time to count the butterflies! Accompanied by my  Dalmation Ying & Yang; hurtling through a waking palette of goldenrod yellow, aster purple & white lace stars, I giggle thinking how a Honda dealer would react if told how wonderful this huge, noisy brute is for hunting butterflies!    Scanning the catalpas underskirts using the telephoto lens of my camera, I'm rewarded a snuggle sleeping monarchs, perfectly spaced for counting -132! Checking the tulip poplar, a "popular" roost, adds 2 more just as a mourning dove drops lands on their branch & launches them into flight.    Jouncing on to Coyote Junction hoping to locate it's butterfly tree startles Mama & the Twins white flagged down the dry creek bed. Ol' Honda points way down & then uppppp! the rough terrain.    Hoping upward in several spots, with the sun just right to tickle orange wings awake, I prowl fruitlessly.  135 i
Observed approx. 100 Monarchs roosting in our grove at 7:00p.m.

Sunday 7:30 am - a check of the catalpa grove & tulip poplar - finds 5 overnighters in the grove & 3 on the poplar's east tip. Fussy strangers, they roost singly, far apart on private branches. The catalpa grove is always warmer than the area around the single poplar - poplar campers rise early, those in the grove sleep late. The hungry wave of monarchs counted (150) at 5 pm swept on further south. Cool night, 50 degrees at sunrise. The little "microclimates" of our meadow's hills are very definate, low spots were really cold. At sunset, a front moved in from the west, a seamless pearl milky overcast that overtook the swirls of dancing mare's tails that feathered Saturday's sky. A brillant sundog, focused bright like sunlight thru a prism glowed in clouds edging the front over Lake Michigan. Sundogs usually mean stormy weather in 3 days time. This morning's sky, is gray with translucent, milky layers, breaks open into stipples of fleecy clouds near the sun's rising - Gramps "mackerel

6:30 pm, 70 degrees: sky still odd milky overcast. All day, tall gray cumulous clouds formed below it in rows. Rain is being pushed way north by the Gulf of Mexico's hurricane.  Saw 1 monarch in garden & 1 crossed the road definately southbound. 3 monarchs flew up from south edge of catalpa grove, there were none in the whole meadow!  2 circled back with 1 heading south. It rose high & vanished. In the grove clearing, monarchs dropped steadily thru the trees from north/northwest singly or grouped. Often overshoting the roost, they quickly circled back,searching. How quickly they realized they had missed & how quickly they homed in! Scent, vibration, sight? Landing, they turn into "dead leaves" almost immediately using the same tree as last nights monarchs! Arrivals continued for 30 minutes. There was much wing flashing from "roosters" to warn incoming of from coming too close. Early dark? Changing barometer? What warns them to seek protection beneath big leaves?

Went out to check meadow & roost later - 8:15 am, 58 degrees, with light rain during the night. This morning started like Sunday, with sun struggling with an overcast sky. North, a wide, shallow bay of robin's egg blue glowed at the trailing edge of the front stalled above us. Only a single Monarch nectared on meadow flowers. In the catalpa grove, 73 Monarchs still slumbered.    This afternoon at 3 pm, 2 Monarchs were nectaring & 1 flying around. As light rain began to spatter, the trees came alive with orange wings of incoming Monarchs. There were 18 on the roost which flickered with wing flashed warnings, as those airborne circled to land. Another butterfly question answered! That's what butterflies do on rainy days!  New arrivals or last night's campers? Did gloomy weather convince them to linger?Without tagging them I can't be sure & it's 15' to the roost.

8:30 am, 58 degrees - last nite dipped to mid 40's. Mist & fog patched the landscape as the sun came up. Golden shimmering weather, clear sky vivid colors. No butterflies nectaring in the meadow. Grovecheck finds 51 slumberers. They like a group of freshly deceased bare branches on the northern edge of the center glade of the catalpa grove. The favored east edge branch has been dead long enough that the finer branches are gone. They split the difference last nite, making for easy counting! Several grouped close  with as many solo sleepers. Nearly missed 51, so it began to wriggle to get my attentionl Actually it was very high & suntouched warm. While quite a sheltered place, it was really damp & chilly, with loud plops of moisture falling from the trees. Must take till almost 10 am for the sun to filter thru the main grove's thick leaves east of the butterflies favorite spot.
Kevin Shram who farms near Plato, observed hundreds of monarchs aggregating on his farm today.

We have recently moved to Michigan from Colorado and were happy to find literally thousands of monarchs in our maple trees.  Today's date is 9/01/03 and they have been "roosting" in our trees for about 2 days.

We observed around 50 to 100 monarch butterflies roosting in some oak trees on  the evening of 09/01/2003.  They were in trees around the 30 to 50 foot high range.  There are still a few stragglers left around this morning (09/02/2003), but the rest of them appear to have left.

One of our teachers lives in a rural area close to Sauk Centre and they have an old driveway that isn't being used with lots of trees along the drive.  On this day, Aug 28th, she saw at least  300 monarchs roosting high in these trees all along  this driveway.  Then the next day we went back to the same spot and there were only about 50 monarchs roosting and flying between the trees.  We were able to tag 5 of them. The rest were flying too high to reach.  She went out on the following day and there were no monarchs at all!

At sunset tonite, the group of 25 Monarchs that had been nectaring was still restlessly prowling around the grove. They landed in solo arrangements. settled for a few moments & popped airborne pacing in circles. They had seemed unusually aggressive while nectaring competing hard for flowers. They moved out west to the poplar, settled, then went airborne again. Occasionally 1 would just fly under some leaves & close it's wings on any old tree. At dusk, there were still some doing circles in & out of the grove's foliage. It was 62 degrees at sunset, not cool enough? What a restless bunch! I'll check in the am to see how things ended up.

6:15 - 6:40p.m.  18 butterflies were seen to roost individually on the ends of oak/elm leaves after flashing 2-3 times.  The roosting site in each case was approximately 10-15' from the ground.  Each butterfly faced E/SE.

3:30 - 6:45p.m.  1 butterfly sighted at 5:30 clearly heading south.  It roosted, facing south, without flashing, on a bare maple tree branch approximately 15' from the ground.  Turned out not to be the final roosting site for the night - it took off 30 minutes after roosting heading SE.  3 butterflies were seen chasing each other in circles at 6:15.  The 3 of them roosted (no flashing) together on the bare branch of a different maple tree, approximately 10' from the ground - all facing south.

6-6:45p.m.  6 butterflies seen to roost individually on the ends of leaves of one large elm tree within 20 minutes of each other.  Each flashed 1-2 times after landing.  Each butterfly faced E/SE - roost site was approximately 10' from the ground.
This is from our first report in the area... 46689 Highway 38, Sioux Falls, SD 57104
There are maybe 100 or so monarch butterflies in our maple and hackberry trees tonight, Sept. 4. I had seen a few Monday and Tuesday evenings, but not like tonight. It's a wonderful sight.

I live in a subdivision in Brampton, Ontario, Canada. For the last few days I have noticed Monarch's coming to rest in a very large Popular type tree in my back garden, behine which is a small wooded greenbelt beyond which are factories.  They land starting at about 7.15PM and are still landing at 7.45PM.
I observed one monarch roosting in a tree at 5:30 pm.

Friday evening, Sept 5th there were literally hundreds of Monarch butterflys roosting in my trees.  They were still there this morning (10:00).  I was able to take digital photos of many of them.  Awesome sight!!!  Valorie Richards

We have a large migration of Monarch Butterflies in our backyard. We arelocated in Leipsic, Oh.  There must be 100's of them.  I've tried tocount, but more and more keep flying in. I've counted close to 300. I'venever seen so many butterflies.  They have been here a few days.  Howlong will they stay?  Do they take the same route every year?In the  spring I planted  what was to be a Humming bird mix of flowersaround my home, but the flowers didn't seem to be suited for Hummers.Also, two large beds of  Zinnias.  We have had many types of butterfliesall summer.At dusk the Monarchs circle in and have taken to one our maple trees andan evergreen bush.  I've seen them come in from all directions.  Across thecornfields, beans and what was a wheat field.  I'll watch one go out and seeseveral come in.This morning I went out around 8:00 am to see the display of butterflies andwithin minutes they started to move, then into the fields they went. Whata magnificen

We were called to a home in Bronson, Iowa, (about 5 miles east of Sioux City) with the report that their grove was full of butterflies.  We must have seen close to 1,000 Monarch butterflies.  They told us that Saturday, Aug. 30, 2003, there had been more than there was Sunday evening.

A lady in Sergeant Bluff, Iowa had hundreds of Monarchs roost in her pine tree grove over a 4 day period, August 30 & 31, 2003, September 1 & 2, 2003.  She has had Monarchs returning to this grove over the last several years.

Samll groups of monarchs roosting in mostly Jack Pine in an area of several acres. Maximum in a clump was 26. Observed between 6:45 and 8:30 pm. wind speed 8-15 miles southwest. High of 75 and overnight low of 66 degrees. Because the groups were so scattered and individuals moving around a lot were not able to cound but would estimate 150.

We revisited the roost site of 9-6-03 just north of Muskegon MI on 9/13/03.This time we went in the morning and started surveying as soon as it was light enough, which was 7:15 since it was overcast. We surveyed about twice the area than before. The temperature overnight was 70. Total survey time by 2 people was 4.5 hours finishing at 9:45 am. While the wind had been out of the southwest for a couple of days on the previous survey, this time it had been out of the southeast for a couple of days. Wind speeds were very similar both times. We did not find any clusters. Only put up a butterfly or two at a time with a total of 61, fewer numbers than before in a larger area and with a southeast wind which we thought might concentrate them on the lakeshore. Had the peak of the migration happened earlier than expected, we are wondering. There were a couple of days of north wind between the two surveys.

We have noticed more monarchs all summer--and "our's" seemed to have left only a few stragglers last week.  Last night we had several hundred roosting in trees.  This morning the students reported seeing "lots" of monarchs outside flying away.  My class went out  and counted over 100 flying by in 10 minutes!
Just walked out to thelocal lake and most trees were playing host to monarchs.  I would say there were probably at least 20 or so butterflies on at least 10-15 trees.
approx 100 monarchs resting in our walnut and hackberry trees

After checking roosts daily in the morning, I've decided the really big groups of monarchs are past this area. The most I find in the morning are 5. They don't roost together, choosing totally different trees in the catalpa grove. Is it for safety or independence, I can't decide. These single monarchs are much more skittish & sensitive to sounds, startling easily. Perhaps that also is a protective device, they seem much more aware of what's happening around them. The larger groups (100-150) paid no attention to my passing or sounds of the golf cart or 4 wheeler.
Emma, one of my St. Joseph school fourth grade students, sited a roost of 25-50 monarchs in her backyard trees.  It was early evening and they were flashing their wings.

We've seen the Monarchs almost every year since we moved to this Farm House in 1996. I didn't seem them last year but this afternoon on my way to the mailbox in the drive there is a line of trees and the Monarchs were floating around the trees as I walked by. It is such a beautiful site and there are thousands of them but they are only here for a few days and then they are gone. It is always in the early to mid September that we see them. And they are here today.

A cool front came through on the 2nd of September and about 200 Monarchs arrived to roost in our trees.  We have had southern winds since then and the butterflies have stayed here.  They do not tend to feed at the flowers, most tend to flutter about in the trees and roost on the north side of the grove.

We noticed our first fall roost in our backyard on Sunday!  There were about 12 Monarchs on a single branch of our birch tree, and a few more scattered about.  On Monday there was a tree in the common ground with roosts totaling about 25 butterflies.  On Tuesday there were perhaps 40 - 50 butterflies scattered around the trees.  This evening, Wednesday, I could find only two butterflies.  We had heavy rains all day.  We have not had the many hundreds of butterflies since the fall of 2000, and wonder if it is because of construction in our area, or weather patterns.  I have images of Monarch roosts posted on http://home.neb.rr.com/monarchrose/monarchs.htm
Our backyard grove of trees has been covered in beautiful, fluttering monarchs for the last 3 days...what a treat to see so many at a time!

My grandson was climbing a tree about 6:30 pm. About 10 feet in the air, in the tree next to him, were about 20 monarchs hanging from the lower limb. He called us out to see, and there were many more flying in the air seeking the spot to settle for the night.  Having never seen them in groups before, we checked again by flashlight later in the night and they were still there.  We expected them to be gone the next morning, but as of last evening they were still coming back to roost in the same spot.  There are more now than at first sighting.  I have milkweed, New England asters, goldenrod and many other wildflowers in my yard, and did see larvae feeding on milkweed a few weeks ago, but I don't think this many were raised  here.
First monarch sighting here in Sunnyvale. About 15 have gathered in the closest overwintering site at Natural Bridges in Santa Cruz.

I observed approximately 20 monarchs roosting in a large oak tree in my backyard.  They were clustered together on one branch and seemed to stay together.  A few monarchs were flying around, but mostly in the area of the branch.  It was an amazing sight to see!

The monarchs have arrived in Sidney, IA and the Loess Hills area near Sidney.  The first large groups were spotted the evening of Sept 8th.  Each evening there seem to be more monarchs hanging in the trees. They are in the same groups of trees as the last two years.  On Sept. 11th we saw approximately 150 monarchs on two trees.  It has been unusually cool this week.
We have the most monarchs in the trees tonight that we've seen so far this fall!!  Also, there have been articles about monarchs in the papers we take.Beth, Creston, IA

Several thousand roosting in meadows/forested areas of Swan Lake National Wildlife refuge on 9/11/03. Not sure however if these are residents or early migrants.

Migration Highlight

Tonight we sighted the Monarchs overnighting again this year in our back yard. The trees are covered with them. It is again an impressive sight to see. Too bad we weren't prepared and only had a part of a roll of film to snap away. Around dusk they all started flying in. I look forward to seeing how long they stay-- usually it is only over night.

We live on a former Air Force base and had been told by long-time teachers here that they often brought students out to see the monarchs. This fall is the first time I have noticed them roosting here. Looking out my kitchen window I saw dozens of monarchs flying around the patio. Later we saw them clustered on low hanging branches of an elm tree and a maple tree. I would say that there were at least 50 and probably more. We saw them again the following 2 nights. I observed them "flashing" to each other and attempted to get a picture, but I don't think that I was successful with that.

There were 5,000-10,000 monarchs clustered in the tree island off the boardwalk in the wetlands. Because of the rain they stayed in the trees rather than scattering to feed on the nearby Bidens flowers. They were easy pickings for the taggers, if they could reach them with their nets. Almost everyone was successful and many tagged 20 or more monarchs before they got so wet they had to pour water out of their boots, wring out their clothes or head for a warm drink and a change of clothes. We won't know the number of monarchs tagged until the data sheets are dry enough to handle but the number was probably in the range of 400 tagged. Not a bad day considering the conditions and that we are still 3-6 days from the normal peak of the migration.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 7,500 monarchs based on observer’s comment that the number ranged from “5,000 to 10,000 monarchs.”

Today I took 100 seventh graders to the Baker-Haskell wetlands in Lawrence. The weather was misty early on, after a rain last night, but no rain by the time we arrived. The wind was calm, the skies cloudy. We tagged 280 Monarchs in about 2 hours. They were roosting in the trees along the south treeline/ waterway. I would shake the trees and the Monarchs would fly. The kids were catching a few this way. One student netted 11 clustering low on a treebranch. We had our greatest luck among the bidens off the boardwalk along the northern part of the area. Our will send another 100 kids on Wed and another 100 kids on Friday.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
For the first time that anyone has ever noticed, we noticed several hundred Monarch butterflies roosting in trees around our Elk enclosure at our Zoo.

Sunday 7:00am I noticed monarch activity among the trees that canopied the auto tour road. It was overcast but not raining.I scanned the trees with binoculars and found clumps of monarchs roosting in the trees. Suddenly it began to sprinkle and the sky became filled with monarchs. It was fantastic. I estimate 200 monarchs in total. The next morning they were gone.
about 120 monarchs in my apple trees
Trees along SR427 and CR60 full of monarchs Sun. 9/7/03 and 9/8/03, South of Auburn, IN.
On Sept. 15 and 16 I have noticed a roost of about 100-150 monarchs in my neighbors maple tree and lilac bush. It is an awesome sight to behold.  I captured one to tag for Project Monarch Watch.

I noticed many Monarchs flying and roosting in our trees yesterday and today during the late afternoon.  If I walked about the area the butterflies moved from one place to another, but settled back on the leaves.
We tagged 25 at home in 40 minutes.  They were not roosting in large groups as they were several weeks ago.  Today is 09/16/03 and we haven't seen any roost since 09/12/03.

The monarchs arrived at our place just north of Enid Oklahoma on Sunday evening, September 14, 2003.

They arrived with a cool front that quickly changed to strong winds out of the South. They are still here but we are expecting a couple of fronts to come through from the North this week and so they may leave.

It's very hard to judge the number, but some observers have said there may be a thousand.

Thursday, Sept. 18
We had a cool front come in from the north Thursday morning about 9 A.M. Very cloudy and windy. The monarchs are gone!

Today would be a great day for their migration. Cool, sunny and a mild north breeze. If any more straggle in, I'll let you know.

We sent our second Team of 7th graders to the wetlands in Lawrence today with 214 tags and they ran out in less than an hour. The skies were partly cloudy with fairly strong south winds. It was reported to me that the Monarchs seemed content roosting in the trees along the boardwalk. One student caught 8 in a single swoop of his net.We will send our third Team of 7th graders on Friday.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
I saw hundreds of Monarchs in the linden tree in my back yard.  They started to come at about 3:30 P.M. and they kept coming.   Will H.

Wow!  For the first time of my life I sighted 100's & 1,000's of Monarchs roosting on the north eastern sides of several trees by the Port of Newcastle on the west side of the Graham Creek.I sighted 11 RED BREASTED MERGANSERS, 2 BELTED KINGFISHERS, 1 GREAT BLUE HERON, 1 RED CRESTED CORMORANT in and above the Graham Creek.

Today is cooler, with cloudy and sunny periods. Thesky is filled with large white clouds, probably theaftermath of Isabel. It arrived at Pelee as a tropicalstorm, with winds about 75 kph. Gusts at Torontoreached 72 kph. No major damage but many trees andbranches down across the province. Lake Ontario ragedyesterday and today, the strong southerly winds arekeeping the monarchs here at Cobourg on shore andtaking shelter on the north side of trees and shrubs.At the Cobourg Ecology Garden, there are two clustersof 50 monarchs in the trees and many monarchs restingon the north side of the garden. I quickly collectd 30for tagging and will check other sites as well.Lovely, newly hatched specimens! Perfect!

We tagged 274 monarchs on Sunday despite the few rainshowers that were around. Large clusters in my treesand my neighbors trees.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
I live next to an abandoned schoolhouse and every year since 1998 (when I first moved here) the monarchs roost in the treeline behind it.

Was able to tag a number of Monarchs seeking  hackberrys and elms to wait out some of the stronger winds from the south. I would not call it a true roost but I will check tomorrow morning early in hopes of a real roost

Hundreds of Monarchs roosted Fridaynight in a pecan tree in Fayette, 15 miles north of Boonville. The tree is used every year.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
It's Wednesday, and at 5:30 P.M.  we seemed to have more Monarchs that ever.  As I write, a cold front is coming through so they may all be gone tomorrow.Elbert Wheeler
Six monarchs were sitting on a purple butterfly bush at 5:30PM. A few were feeding, but several were hanging with folded wings. The sun was close to sinking and the air was cool.

Around 5:00p.m. I noticed monarchs gathering in two elm trees in my back yard.  They continued to gather until dark.  There are 1000's roosting in the two elm trees as well as an oak tree in the front yard.  They are mostly on the limbs facing west.  They remained there overnight and were still there this morning after a nighttime shower.  The weather is cool and damp today.
Dozens of Monarchs were sited roosting in our big maple tree in our backyard for the night.  They were gone in the morning when we looked for them at 7:00 AM.
Monarchs 8-10in one tree during a 5 minute observation time.

After last weekends large migration wave I only saw afew scattered stragglers from Monday throughWednesday. Yesterday afternoon however, I counted adozen on the way home from work and when I checked mytrees in the evening there were several good-sizedclusters totaling about 150 monarchs, I tagged 30. Definitely more than just stragglers ! We also haveabout 30 eastern black swallowtail cats on our parsleyat school in various stages.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
about 58 Monarchs roosting in pine trees near house.

Monarchs started arriving September 27, 2003. Almost every year they arrive on Sep 25, just like clockwork. We had thunderstorms and a wind shift to the north on Sep 24, 2003. Today is Sep 29, 2003, and there are a lot here now. Not sure but it seems to be more this year last year.

I just found time to visit a traditional resting spot at Abilene Christian U this afternoon and found several thousand monarchs clustering in the pecan trees by the Admin building. I later visited a traditional spot in a pecan grove in Clyde and found none. Several I observed while I was on the way to Clyde today were flying straight into the wind. Wind is strong out of the E/SE.Abilene is 180 mi west of Dallas and Clyde is 15 mi east of Abilene.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We received a call from S. Throckmorton who lives on a ranch 19 miles north of Abilene, TX. Susan reported that thousands of monarchs began to cluster in a grove of oaks near the ranch house on the 28th and that large numbers are still present due to the southerly winds.

Contributed to Monarch WatchMigration Highlight
I live in Carrollton, TX and we have a small park across the street.  Thereis one bush in particular which has hundreds of butterflies on it--They're also  resting in trees, bushes and ground.
50 + monarchs roosting in a pine grove approx. 50 miles north of Ft. Worth, Texas

At the Abilene Zoo, next to theduck pond, are two trees with perhaps 200 Monarchs. The trees are cypress. This is next to thenorth wall, so they have got themselves a nice micro climate, as the temperature is dropping.It was 57 f at 9:05 am and still dropping with a big cold blast coming down this morningfrom the north.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Audubon friends of mine have been having 30-50 monarchs roosting each nightin their pine trees. This is a reliable sighting asI went up last fall and tagged after they called me.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

On the University of Dallas campus, we have over 200 acres of wonderful, basically original bluestem prairie/post oak savannah woodland.  For several years I have noticed monarchs using the post oaks as roosts for resting, and today,Oct. 2,partly cloudy, temp about 69-70 degrees F.very light breeze, I noted about 18-20 monarchs either resting, or flying down to rest about 1pm in a number of post and blackjack oak trees on a south facing slope.  Our campus is essentially a lovely island  surrounded by freeways and development.

October 2Observed approximately 400 Monarchs pass through our yard over a 1 hour period just prior to sunset. We are located in a rural area on top of a ridge approximately 50 miles north of downtown Dallas. Most of the Monarchs were flying south, some were flying north and south looking for a roosting tree. The temperature was in the mid to low 70s and there was a light north/northeast wind. We have various tree types - ash, pecan, poplar, oak and are lightly wooded with lots of pasture land. Very exciting to watch them fly through and around the trees to carefully search for just the right tree to roost in. A small group of approximately 20 landed in our yard for the night.

October 3Observed 64 fly across our property this morning at 9:30 a.m. over a period of 22 minutes - about 3/minute. Weather is fair with temp 59, winds SE 7 mph.
There are hundreds  of monarchs behind our office resting in the trees by a small creek in Plano, Texas.  It's quite wonderous.
Hundreds were migrating.

We tagged 25 monarchs in the pecan orchard 30 miles SE of Midland today. This morning, about 11:00, the butterflies were too active.  We netted only 2 in an hour.  Frustrated and hot, we adjourned until 6:00 PM and were then able to net and tag the other 23 in half an hour.Probably 1500 monarchs were present at sunset.  Hopefully that number will increase as in years past.

This is the first time we have noticed monarchs roosting at our butterfly garden. We had three this morning on our milkweed.  It was still cool (lower 60's), sunny, calm.  All three were females and appeared to be fairly fresh.

I was in my backyard and noticed a small group of Monarchs together above me, resting on some tree branches. It got my attention immediately...and when I looked up higher each branch was littered with dozens - perhaps hundreds of them - all perched comfortably on each limb...it was a glorious sight...our back yards are very wooded with old, mature trees.We live near the White Rock Lake area of East Dallas ...

this past week there havebeen dozens of monarchs on my oak trees. I mean a ton. Just wanted tolet you know that we are seeing them in large bunches in our area. Burleson is just south of Ft. Worth on I-35.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Well, I thought last week represented the peak migration of the monarchs through North Texas, however yesterday (10/5) from 2:30 pm to 4:30 pm I observed non stop monarch movement through the North TX (Mc Kinney) area-- literally hundreds of monarchs (in good condition) were passing through; the sky was overcast, and there was not much of a breeze and weather was warm/humid following am rains. In evening a woodland roost site looked orange from a distance it was covered with so many roosting monarchs!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Also reported in PEAK.

I found hundreds roosting in my oak trees on Sunday the 5th, I have other trees in my yard, but they were most fond of the oak.  They spent the night in my yard and then mid morning began thier journey south.  It was foggy and drizzly on Monday and it was as if they waited til the day was more clear to move.  They left on 10/06/03.
We found approximately 100 monarchs roosting  West of Mangum.   The location is closer to a small community called Reed.

Thousands (millions?) roosting in a yard of an empty old Victorian home. Every tree limb is covered with hundreds of Monarchs. When they are flying around you can hear the rustling of their wings throughout the yard.This yard must be a great feediing site for them. It is covered with flowering bushes.A stunning experience!

After two days of near constant drizzling rain, I did not expect to see so many butterflies in our trees.  But, this afternoon the rain stopped and I see they have come to roost in huge numbers.  Two days ago, I estimated their numbers to be a few hundred; today I am seeing several thousand.  I wish I knew a better way of determining their numbers, like we do for deer and turkeys.  Anyone know a method?We are hoping for a sunny day tomorrow so we can do some observing and oohing and aahing, before they move on.
Mrs. McRay's kindergarten class found hundreds of monarchs roosting west of Mangum.  Mangum is located southwest Oklahoma.
We were weeding the gardens about 6 PM when we noticed a few Monarchs flying among the Pecan trees. We watched as dozens flew in and literally formed clumps of butterflies! What an awesome sight!

3000 monarchs this time.  After a heavy rain on Saturday morning, 10/11, a brisk north wind zipped through and all the butterflies were gone from the pecan orchard by that afternoon.  The owner called on Monday and notified us another group had arrived.  More were tagged in this group.

Report from Balcones Canyonlands National Wildlife Refuge northwest ofAustin.

Oct. 11- temp in the 70's. few monarchs around until 2:25 pm - 3:00 whenaround 1,000 Monarchs came to roost. a steady rain began at 3:00 pm.

Oct. 12- cloudy- saw dozens of Monarchs migrating south. Monarchsnever came down to feed all day. temp around 80.

Oct. 13- thousands of Monarchs on Refuge. did not see them feed inafternoon- they were in the trees. breezy day from the south.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

1st night of the invasion 10-14-03: 250 across 50 yards2nd night of the invasion 10-16-03:I drove around Quemado Valley yesterday evening at sunset looking at the north face of trees along the roads and near irrigation ditches to discover that monarchs were loosely scattered throughout the area, a distance of 12 miles by about 2 miles wide. Nowhere were they clustered in great masses,but rather ones and twos, then branch tips covered with 15 to 20. But come up out of the Valley/riverbottom and look for tall trees (here that's 20-40') on the slightly rolling uplands where the brushcountry spreads back away from the Rio Grande and the clusters are denser. I swiped my net a single time last night and netted 78 butterflies from a single clump. That hackberry tree was covered with perhaps 10 more similar clusters. My front yard trees have around 250-350 butterflies. Back trees only have about 100. Temps last night went down to 57.4F. Night before was the coolest of the sea
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments:
En el camino de Nadadores a Cuatrociénegas observamos algunas mariposas, durante el resto del día vimos más en todo el valle de Cuatrociénegas, principalmente en la intersección del Ejido La Vega a Antiguos Mineros. Al día siguiente de regreso las vimos en mayor número desde La Muralla hasta casi llegar a Saltillo. Cerca de la Muralla estaba un nogal con cientos de mariposas perchadas, se podían notar desde la carretera. Los días nublados.

Courtesy of Correo Real

In the years I have observed monarch migrations in Florida, although I had heard of them, I have never witnessed the group behavior common to the migrating butterflies elsewhere. The monarchs are present, but more dispersed, arriving in small groups or singly. Charlotte Petersen sent me photos taken in Vero Beach, on the east coast of Florida 2/3 down state of a migratory, I assume, roost of butterflies. I have attached one photo and her husband checked the sun angle, lat. and long. for the record.

After walking out into my front yard (in Vero Beach) I discovered hundreds of Monarch butterflies on my tree a few days ago. The numbers seem to be doubling daily. I snapped this picture and discovered your site so that I could find out more about them. Are they just stopping off at my tree on their way to Mexico?

Despite the poor showing (of monarchs - only 9 counted) the morning of St. Marks' Monarch Butterfly Festival (when some 2,500 - 3,000 human visitors were counted), held last Saturday 18 October, the first real pulse of migrants is now coming through Florida's Gulf Coast. Yesterday/Wednesday 22 October our counting/tagging team counted 417 on early morning roosts and tagged 251.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Yesterday in Novillo Canyon, just west of Victoria in Tamaulipas,Mexico, there were thousands of monarchs roosting in the treesoverhanging the canyon. It was cold and rainy, so the bugs were mostlyhanging in the trees. Some of the branches were orange w/monarchs. We were there for afew hours from about 9 am to 11:30, and at times there were clouds ofmonarchs above us. We saw very few other butterfliers, but the monarchswere great. This is the only time we have seen them in Novillo in thesenumbers.

Te reporto que aunque por encima de mi colonia no se ven muchas monarcas, en el área de Estanzuela me tocó ver algunas ayer. Pero donde vi cientos fue el domingo 19 en García NL, había cientos en los nogales, y entre el pueblo y las Grutas volaban cientos también.

Courtesy of Correo Real
5 Monarchs have been roosting for the last week in my backyard bush called a golden dewdrop or duranta repens. This is fairly late in the season. And it is wonderful to have them here.
There seems to be a good sized number of monarchs overwintering on the eucalyptus trees in Admiralty Park, Marina del Rey. They have been here since late Fall.

On August 26, 2004 my husband and I surveyed the area near, Muskegon Michigan that we surveyed last year on Sept 6 and 13.

Under similar weather conditions and about the same time of day as Sept 6, 2003 when we found some clusters, we did not find any this year although we did count about 20 monarchs flittering among the pine trees and roosting singly. It was likely too early in the migration but it was good to see that some were present in the area.

One of the resons for going earlier was to confirm the presence of nearby nectar plants. The steeplebush that was past blooming last year was still in bloom this year and very abundant - likely due to a wet year. We already knew other criteria for roost sites - good protection from weather in pine trees nestled among dunes and the proximity of the higest point inthe area - a dune. Also the Lake Michigan shoreline concentrates migrating monarchs.

We hope to survey another area of similar habitat at about lat 42 in the next week or two when we have another wind out of the south and see if we can find another roosting area.

Monarchs are gathering at Tom and Julie Murphy's farm in Cannon Falls, Minnesota, but in smaller numbers than past years. The Murphys attract thousands of butterflies every fall by planting the monarch's *favorite* nectar source, Liatris.

"You can do this too," says Tom Murphy. "Just plant Liatris and they will come!"

See "Taggging Monarchs With the Murphys."

8-27-04, Friday was a warm and humid day with several hundred monarchs nectaring. The evening turnned cool and the monarchs roosted the night in medium density clusters (roosts). Today 8-28-04 cool, 60's deg f, only 20 to 50 monarchs. Warmer temps are predicted for later in the week perhaps their numbers will build again.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 300 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “several hundred.”

I am counting monarchs roosting in my yard again this year. Unfortunately, itdoesn't take long to count them. The numbers are way down. Through Sep. 1st, I have had only five monarchs in the trees, where last year, I had 177. (See graph below.)

I have another spotI go to tag monarchs that will normally have hundreds to thousands ofbutterflies. So far this year, I have only seen two small clusters of about 30 - 40butterflies. I am hoping that there are more to come, but all indicationsare that the numbers are way down.

Over the weekend, several people reported seeing groups of 15 - 20 monarchs intheir trees. These are people that let us tag in the yards each year. We get a lot of monarchs (from 100 to several thousand) roosting inthese yards for 1 to 2 weeks before the migration starts. Although thenumber oif butterflies of all species are way below normal, thesemonarch numbers seem to be quite normal for this time of the season.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I stopped onthe north shore of Lake Ontario near Oshawa. About 7pm, over a period of 1/2 hour, I saw 4 monarchs intypical early evening flight, flying high towards thewest and towards trees, looking for a site at which toroost for the night.

I spent some time earlier on Saturday scouring Presqu'ileProvincial Park (on the north shore of Lake Ontario,about 150 km east of Toronto) for monarch eggs, larvaand adults. The situation remains grim. I only found 3fully developed larva, one second instar larva, andspotted 4 adults. Flowering plants and milkweed areabundant. Goldenrod is blooming.

6:15-6:30pm - Sighted 4 individual monarchs flying southeast through the yard.  They nectared on bee balm and butterfly bush in the garden for a short while before flying from tree to tree to select a roosting spot for the night. After checking out oak, maple and elm trees they finally roosted tightly together on a branch of a birch tree approximately 15 feet off. There was no flashing observed.

7:30a.m.  The 4 monarches that roosted in the yard overnight were observed to flash several times before departing from their roosting site this morning.  They, again, nectared on the bee balm and butterfly bush in the garden before flying through the trees - definately heading south.

Migration Hotspot: Cape May, NJ

September 23, 2004 Update
Numbers of monarchs seen per hour are on the Cape May Monarch Census website for first 3 weeks . . . .As of this date, this year is the lowest 3-week running average for the study.

The last several days (with northerly winds) have actually been productive and we've been able to tag 100-200 monarchs/day.

Now in its 13th year, this annual migration census is providing a long-term record of migration patterns along the Atlantic Coast.

Located at the tip of a peninsula, monarchs funnel into Cape May where they often congregate in high numbers until the wind is right to make the over-water crossing.

Data for the Cape May Monarch Road Census is postedon the Cape May Monarch Census website.

Migration highlight from Cape May (September 28, 2001)
"A major coldfront with winds from the north and northwest triggered one of the most dramatic MONARCH concentrations in several years. Bushes in the dunes at Cape May Point were vibrating with roosting Monarchs that had settled in and stopped migrating because of the strong winds. That evening and dawn the following day (September 29) were times to remember. Pooled sightings documented at least 70,000 monarchs."(More...)
The location of the monarch overwintering sites, deep in central Mexico.
6:30p.m.  Five monarchs (2 females/3 males) found roosting on the top of a dead jack pine approximately 8 feet off the ground
Monarchs are starting to roost in my maple trees.

Although only ONE butterfly, I saw a monarch settling down for the night in the tall hickory tree out in the yard.

I also saw a monarch yesterday in Norwich, Vermont, in clear directional flight, headed southwest to Mexico.

Other than these, I saw only TWO monarchs all summer, and I didn't see the first one until late July. My office looks out on a field of clover and alfalfa so I'm able to watch continually for nectaring monarchs.

We went to Maine last week on vacation. We went to Pemaquid Point on the coast where I had a report of monarchs lastyear. Talked to a man who lived there who said usually hundreds gather inthe trees there this time of year, he has seen maybe three of four thisyear. We saw none on September 11th, and it was a gorgeous sunny day about70 degrees.

Last year tagged a few up there butthis year saw absolutely none, except the one chrysalis I brought thathatched out. Hope she was a migrant because I don't think she would find amate!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We have had sporadic sightings of singleton Monarchs flying at treetop level to the south for the past 2 weeks, but Sunday, September 12th was the first time there were roosting Monarchs in our conifers.  We had 35-40 Monarchs here for 5 days during a hot spell with southern winds predominating.  Last year I had tagged over 500 by this date.  So far I have tagged 47 this year.  Yesterday a front came through and the winds shifted to the North and the Monarchs are gone this morning.

Finally!! Over 50 monarchs in our hackberry tree tonight. There may be more, I'll look again early in the morning. I've seen a few arriving late afternoons for about a week, but not enough to even find where they were roosting. They are a welcome sight.

I just heard from a friend in Ithaca, NE, north of Lincoln. She described a tree in her orchard covered with 50 or 60 monarchs. She said they were floating around in the "magical manner of migrating monarchs!" Nice to know of some that are moving toward Mexico. I raised a dozen monarchs from eggs this month, tagging and releasing them during the first week in September. I hope they make it south.

3 individual monarchs (1 male, 2 females) observed roosting in hackberry/ eastern red cedar treed area.  Weather was clear and in the 70s; and there was a light southern breeze.  So far this migration I have seen about 1 monarch a day trickle through North Texas, and this was the first time I saw 3 together and saw a roost site.  Jill

Hello,I am not an avid butterfly watcher however last week (09-10-04 thru 09/20/04)a very interesting sight is in mine and my neighbors backyard. I have a hedgeapple tree that is full of Monarch butterflys.  I would have to say that I probably have at least 100 of them on a tree and I can see a lot of them in both my neighbors backyard.  I decided to do a little search on the web to see if they were migrating or what and I'm going to assume they are migrating, I remembered a little bit about the monarch butterflys from elementary school(I'm 37 years old now).  Just thought I would share the information with someone because it is a lovely sight to behold.  Thank You,VernEsther HatmakerOverland Park, KS

My husband and I took a bike ride from the 84th and O Street parking area in Lincoln Nebraska to Eagle, NE on the Missouri Pacific bike trail Sunday, September 19, 2004. Along the way, we passed through a wooded stretch of the railroad bed trial cut through a hill.  It was quite windy in Lincoln on Sunday.  This area was protected from the wind.  Perhaps because of this, there were approximately 50 Monarch butterflies along this part of the trail, which we estimated to be about 100 meters in length.  We stopped and walked our bikes and saw two roosts, one with about 10 individuals and another with about 5.  The butterflies in the roost 'flashed' their wings when approached by another butterfly, which is a beautiful sight.  The other butterflies were resting alone on branches or floating back and forth among the trees.

I saw 5 to 10 monarchs roosting on an oak tree outside of the city. Occasionally they would fly to a different branch, I think they were trying to find a good spot to spend the night. There are a lot of milkweed plants in this area so it is a good place to find monarchs.

The Monarchs arrived later than usual this year.  For the fourth consecutive year, the Monarchs have roosted at a farm in Sgt. Bluff.  There were hundreds of Monarchs roosting in the understory of the grove on the north side of the house.  The monarchs have been arriving for the last 3 days.

Today I was delighted to find a small "roost" of about 30 Monarchs resting in the birch trees in Washington Park, Crown Center area of Kansas City, MO, at 12:45 p.m.  Since there are strong breezes coming from the South/Southeast, flying is difficult today.

Today,in the shelterbelt of trees surrounding my home, I noticed about 150 - 200 Monarchs resting on the Ponderosa pines and also the Chinese elm trees.  There were clusters of them on the trees and also many fluttering from tree to tree.  I took several pictures of them using my telephoto lens.

It appears the first few migrating monarchs havearrived in Kansas. I observed two roosting in my tallcedars last evening. Today, I counted 4 on the wayhome from work and saw 7 cruising the cedars thisevening. I was able to tag three, all of which werefemales.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

A half dozen Monarchs, both fresh and quite faded and worn were taking nectar atthe Doug Blachley Butterfly Garden in Zilker Park in Austin, Travis Co., TX,today 23rd Sept. They appeared to be feeding rather than passing through.

Isuspect the worn ones are new arrivals but the fresh ones may be local-grown.

Isee about one a day in my own yard located in streamside gallery woodland justeast of and paralleling the Balcones Escarpment. These appear to be on themove.

Contributed to Monarch Watch.

After a 1" rain, a cool front and sunny skies, 5 monarchs were observed in about an hour flying south across our yard.  Later, when visiting their usual roost, about a dozen were counted.  We expect more to come in today in cool, sunny weather and quiet winds.We have been observing hundreds if not thousands at about this time for many years.  If I get a good photo, I'll send it.Elbert Wheeler
Before school one of my 4th grade students saw 10 to 15 Monarchs roosting in fruit trees.

50-100 monarchs spent last week end in our trees, then moved on Monday or Tuesday. Tonight I counted about 75 in oak, hackberry and maple trees. I watched from 7:10-7:15 and counted 20 coming from the north, I don't think they were just flying around. Weather very calm, much better than last week end.

My Monarch count proceeds it's its singular quanity! Another lone Monarch dropped from the evening sky to settle quickly high in a catalpa tree. My eyes have always sensed movement mindlessly. Terribly distracting in some ways but a blessing for butterfly counting and deer dodging. One more southbound traveler noted and cherished. I miss seeing them approach like an orange cloud, wings backlit by the setting sun. It's been two years since a large flight of them settled into the catalpa grove! I miss the jostling and wing talking about accomodations. Last night's traveler struck a melancoly note that echoded back to the last passenger pigeon. Do butterflies feel lonely?

Tempwas around 70* and time was about 6:15. Another cloudless, sunny daywith highs around 78. Conditions extremely dry, even the golden rod isdrying up. You can almost hear the brown lawns and meadows crisping. Duststirs in even grassy areas when you walk. My garden flowers are lingeringonly because of the silver touch from the hose.

Sunset is around 7:30 right now, so I was a little surprised to see thegolden bug going to bed so early. Another quick drop and stop,no gliding nor investigating. That seems different from past migrations. Mymigrators are probably having a hard time and probably going to bed bothhungry and thirsty. Western Michigan is becoming a desert!

We are seeing an influx of monarchs in the Oklahoma City, OK area today (9/28/04). I checked the butterfly garden at the Oklahoma City Zoo around 5:00 p.m. and counted about 75-100 trying to settle in along a nearby hillside in the elms, cedars, and hackberries.

This photo is of 2nd grade students tagging on Wednesday, 9/29/04 in in the Oklahoma City Zoo's Butterfly Garden.

At approximately 7:30 p.m, we noticed a lot ofMonarch flying around in our yard.  After lookingmore closely at the trees, we observed severalclusters on the tips of our Maple tree branches.I would guess there were about 200 Monarchs.

Denton, Nebraska (Lancaster County) have roosts in Cottonwood trees - today dispersed (9/28).

Approximately 400 Monarchs roosted in same Mapletrees last night, compared to about 200 the nightbefore. There is a large flower garden near wherethey seem to be feeding.

The monarchs have been arriving all week on northern breezes.  Location:  About 7 miles north of Enid, Oklahoma.  Same roost as in years past.  Perhaps a thousand or more, spread over six acres but concentrated in pecan, hedge and elm trees. just south of our house.
Saw first Monarchs Sept.30 on my miniature asters-there were about 20 of them. So beautiful and full of grace.
school: Am a nurse-but have a butterfly garden

comments: 20-30 Monarchs in large Live Oak in front yard not seen yesterday

The number of Monarch butterflies has increased in our area on Hwy 158 between Bronte and Robert Lee and on Hwy 277 between Bronte and San Angelo. The small cold front that has been making its way through has pushed the butterflies ahead of it.  I noticed Sunday night, some butterflies spending the night in the trees on the Kickapoo Creek in the North East corner of town, a favorite stop-over for them.  We have not seen the large numbers of "visitors" yet, maybe soon.

several hundred in trees in yard, still arriving at 7pm.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 300 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “several hundred.”
Thirty monarchs roosting in two trees. Wind out of the east about 5 mph, currently 70 F.

Yesterday at 5:00 in Robert Lee, huge Monarch Butterflies were coming over the top of the Courthouse at about 5-10 every 5 min.  They looked very healthy.  Today in Bronte, about several hundred Monarch's are at their favorite "stop-over" on the Kickapoo Creek in the Pecan Trees just "hanging-out" waiting for the rain to stop and the next cool breezes to come.  They are very bright and beautiful. I can't wait to see what happens tomorrow.
Three monarchs flying in and around trees in back yard [7 pm ].

Amazingly these guys have come in all week long in spite of downpours and flooding, and along with the coolest cold front of the season as yet. My trees are a living cathedral of sunset- colored, living "stained glass" not made by human hands! Beautiful season tribute!

Migration Highlight
10-05 1830 rechecked same roost area counted 71 .  It was easier to count when the temperature had dropped as the monarchs were not moving as  much.

10-06 1900 wind out of the south and east about 5 mph. 120 roosting. I like watching mommy countin' the monarch butterflies.  My favorite part was seeing the color inside the monarchs' wings. (Elise-5)

Finally ventured out to ACU yesterday and found around 250 monarchs clustering in front of the Admin building. However, they were scattered around the pecan trees unlike previous years when they concentrated in three or four of same trees every year. I found two, three, four together and then 30 to 40 in a couple of clusters. We are seeing a steady stream heading south but not in the significant numbers we have seen in the past. I am still counting around 30 to 50 when I make a trip 15 miles west of Clyde to Abilene.

Sunday, October 3, we had at least 100 monarchbutterflies settle in our live oaks for the night. Acold front came through on Friday night. On the sameday we had 30 or so Nashville Warblers working throughthe trees.

5:45-6:30 a.m.59.7dF, heavy dew, no wind, sickle moon, Venus brightcoyotes in full chorus, tenor leading the packbumblebees irate,monarchs tranquil and scattered through huisache (yellow acacia).

Someone had disturbed the gathering place in the cul-de-sac of ash trees late into the clustering, probably between 7:30 and 8:30 last night. I found one butterfly on the ground covered with dew. Trees were basically empty. I netted about 30 from the 3 clusters I swiped at, and they were in periphery trees. The cul-de-sac empty explains why there were at least 350 in the trees behind my house and small roosts and singletons in the mesquite trees across the street from the primary gathering place. I'd estimate at least 500 in the half-acre wood.

My wife and I watched 5Monarchs pass our location at 5 PM, they started to settle into hosttrees at 5:17, the last settler was 6:36. We counted 27 Monarchs settledin, 5 flybys. 200 monarchs were present on Wednesday afternoon. When I went out on Saturday to tag, they were all gone. We saw 1 butterfly and were not able to net it. The pecan orchard 30 miles southwest of Midland usually hosts 20,000+ every fall, but evidently our rainy September caused them to bypass us this year.

Monarchs began arriving at the traditional roosting site on September 27. There are approximately 200 at this time in the 3+ acre Eucalyptus grove which surrounds our home. It has been foggy and low to mid 60s F for the past 3 days. We are located approximately 1/2 mile from the Morro Bay National Estuary.

Thousands of Monarchs spent the night up in the trees, next to the cattle tank on Friday, October 15th. This is in south Texas, Carrizo Springs. All vegetation is native so they must be nectaring au natural.

I mentioned to a friend in New Mexico that the monarchs were "roosting"in our Texas ash tree on their annual migration. This was the early partof last week - about the 4th, 5th, and 6th. There were not as many,although the tree was full for a couple of nights. The migration did notlast as long - usually we can count on seeing them five or six days.This time - only three days. We live on the north side of LakeArrowhead in Clay County, Texas. This seems to be a regular stop on thebutterflies' migration and it is always great fun to sit and watch them.

A friend of mine has a ranch in Del Rio. She said there "hundreds ofthousands" of monarchs clustered in pecan trees on Oct. 10th to 13th. She saidthat she has 2000 pecan trees and every tree she looked at was loadedwith monarchs.

She said that there were more monarchs this year than the previous 3 years. They cluster at her ranch every fall. The monarchs stay 10 to 14 days and then head south.

Ayer empecé observar a las mariposas monarcas en el jardín del Museo de las Aves. Como cada año, llegan a dormir formando sus racimos en el fresno y el troeno de este lugar. At the Cumbres of Monterrey, we saw one million monarchs !!!!!!!!! It was just absolutely phenomenal. Here are some pictures. They just don't do it justice. They miss the layer upon layer of butterfly as you refocus your binoculars. They miss the whole sky full!

I photographed at least 100 Monarchs at St Marks yesterday

The Monarchs have begun to appear at the Huntington Beach Central Library Overwintering Site beginning October 23, 2004 (this is the date that I first observed their return—I noted six that day and saw several flying toward the park that day as well). Today I was there and witnessed at least 75 roosting and flying about the trees by the amphitheatre. I also witnessed and photographed a pair mating in one of the Eucalyptus trees.
November 9, I spotted a monarch butterfly soaring overhead at I-45 and Loop 336 at the Kroger Signature store on the east side of I-45 at 3:30 pm

The Finish Line!
This is where the monarchs go for the winter.
They travel here from across eastern North America.

I see the Monarchs here every summer at this time, clinging from the trees. This location is relatively high, on a hill over a river valley. They show up on the maple trees more than the others. Today I saw up to 22 butterflies per branch.

Ontario butterfly enthusiast John Powers reportedtonight that he visited a 5 acre field of alfalfa andclover near Cambridge, Ontario - about one hour west of Toronto.

Johnestimated that there were approximately 2,000 adultmonarchs nectaring in this field. At the south side ofthis field was a row of pine trees, upon which themonarchs were roosting as the day ended. Hecontacted his friend, a well known nature filmphotographer, who will visit this site in the earlymorning hours to capture footage.

Temperatures are cool in Toronto tonight - about 13 cor in the mid 50's F. That should send a few monarchsscurrying southward! Temperatures will warm up as theweek progresses.

Reported by Don Davis, Toronto, Ontario

I have had a lot of butterflies in my yard the last few nights. Last night (8/23/05) I had about 550 roosting in the trees surrounding my house. Tonight (8/24/05) there were about 900.

I have been keeping track of the number in my yard each night (except when I'm out-of-town) from about August 15 to Sept 20 for the last several years. Here is the number of butterflies roosting in my yard from Aug. 15 to Aug. 24 from 2001 to this year.

Butterflies Roosting Aug. 15 - Aug. 24
2001 - 2700
2002 - 59
2003 - 69
2004 - 1
2005 - 2080

The Monarch population has certainly rebounded in my area. So far they don't seem very interesting in heading south (even on calm nights or North wind they are clustering in my yard). I expect that as soon as the wind comes out of the north again they will be off towards Mexico. It is sure fun to see numbers of butterflies again.

More monarchs floating in around dusk tonight.  Overcast but warm and humid.  Counted 12 over a short 3 minute period landing on plants.  A few others I flushed out of  various trees, (white pine, oak, and cypress).   Most interesting to me were the two I spotted roosting together high up in a young oak....mating.

Approximately 40 monarchs spotted in small roostings on oak and birch trees this morning.  It was raining heavily when I checked on them at 6am.  Each group had chosen branches well protected by the canopy, and some distance into the woods rather than on the perimeter of the yard where I usually find them.

08-15-05Evening of 08-14-05 and early morning of 08-15-05 Many small roosts of 5 to 25 monarchs. Still many monarchs just single in the trees. Many monarchs nectaring on flowers durring the day. Estimate 400 to 700. It is a good year for monarch in this area.
evening of 08-21-05 Strong roots. Tight groups of 50 to 1000 monarchs. Was 45°f on my thermometer 6:00 AM on 08-22-05. I estimate 2000 in the trees. In 9 different roosts.

Strong, tight roosts on 08/21 through 08/24 each night it was 55°f or lower. 55°f and lower seems to really encourage the concentrated roosts. Each day there are thousands nectaring on the flowers but on the warmer nights they roost in the trees as singles or groups of 5 or less. I've been experimenting with finding roosts. I have found several by looking for overgrown fields or ditches with many flowers blooming I then  look for the nearest groups of trees. Then I return in the evening or early  morn. So far I have had success 4 out of 5 locations. I think the key to finding roosts is very much dependent on finding the nectar source. Even when migrating hard they seem to stop for a sip.

For the past few days we have observed thousands of monarch butterflies in our windbreak and grove.

Migration Highlight

We first noticed monarch butterflies on Tuesday, 8/23/05 and they are gone this morning (Saturday, 8/26/05). We had rain and cooler weather last night. There were hundreds of butterflies in our shelter belt. They stayed in one area and always returned to the same trees. I have some good pictures!

August 28
I am uncertain what they are doing here, but I sighted over 100 and possibly more monarchs in our trees. We have many trees on our property and my husband notice them 2 days ago (8/26/05). As of tonight they were still here. I don't know their flight path and if they have been here before. We have lived here for sometime now and haven't noticed them before. I was so excited about it that I wanted to learn more about what they really are doing. So I searched on the internet and found this web site.

August 29
I really do not know much about this. I just knew that it was unusual to see this many monarch butterflies at one time in your yard. I even came home at lunch today to see if they were still here. Which they were. Tonight it is around 6:00 PM and I was outside one time and did see a decrease in the number. I would imagine as of right now about 1/2 as many. I am going to go outside and try to observe them again.

08/28/05 many monarch nectaring, they retreated to the woods in the evening and most were singles or groups less than 5. It predicted to get down to 54º F but the evening stayed fairly warm, and I didn't feel the dew come on. 08/29/05 Sunny warm day easily a thousand monarch nectaring. The low tonight is also predicted to be 54º F, but this evening I could fell the chill and the dew came on strong and the grass was very wet even before total sunset. The monarchs are in fairly tight roosts of 50 or more.

Tonite's monarchs were very young ones & restless, flitting in singles & dancing pairs. They inspected a polar grove,then the pond's straight willows. As the sun set, they whirled out over the meadow and back.  12 picked a limb on the east side of the willow & positioned themselves close together. Others flew circles around the surrounding trees, weaving in & out of the branches without landing. By scent or sound, they are somehow able to locate a roosting group. This willow limb is an old roost, quite popular several years ago, but not used in the last 3.  Others from the group settles singly in the surrounding willow leaves. Upon landing each butterfly in this group opened & closed it's wings slowly several times, before quieting for the night. They wandered as darkness fell, dark silhouettes against the fading light. Somehow, they are able to find one another even without much light.
Monarchs roosting in Aberdeen.

We're seeing hundreds clustering in a few familiar sites in the Sioux Falls/Harrisburg, SD area.

We are finally seeing numbers of migratory monarchs again here in easternSouth Dakota. Our "drought" of the last two years is apparently over.

In the last two days we tagged nearly 600! We aren't getting the calls intown like we used to (West Nile spraying?), but nearby towns and rural areas are calling and it's like the old days when you could easily get 20 or more in a single sweep of the net!

Observed one small group of monarchs roosting in a young ash tree's branches. There were 60 to 70 monarchs roosting at dusk with a few more straggling in out of the northeast.  All of these migrants were roosting together on the same branches and the east side of the tree.  This tree was in the midst of many large pines and located adjacent to the same nectar-laden field where my kids had been netting and tagging earlier that weekend. We have had high temps in the 70's and lows at night in the upper 50s.
Approximately 60 monarchs are roosting in our grove. Tagged 25. Many appear young, fresh color and wings.
20-30 monarchs are nectaring on Rough Blazing Star (Liatris aspera) during the day, and roosting at night on Bur oak and maple trees
Hundreds of monarchs roosting in our shelter belt again today. nice day, wind from the south.

I live in the country outside of city limits. I discovered hundreds of monarchs randomly flying and choosing a roost for the night in my grove of trees (ash, maple, & Black Hills Spruce).

Weather facts for the day:
Sunrise 6:49am
Sunset 8:05pm
Low temp 53
High temp 84;
0 precipitation,
Wind North.

I have never seen so many on the property before. I do have a large flower garden. Could that be the attraction? They remain on the property this morning - randomly flying. They were amiable to my photography efforts.

Last week Monday evening (the 22nd) I got a call from a friend in Nicollet, MN (44:16 N, 94:11 W). She told me there were hundreds and hundreds of monarchs in the trees near their farm. We didn't get down there until Friday after work. We only tagged 26 wild monarchs, the biggest netful being around a dozen in the only roosting clump I saw.Hoping we had been early or somehow missing a big group, we ran down again last night August 30. Sigh. 13 tagged monarchs. In years past I have tagged those "hundreds" anywhere between the 28th of August and 3rd of September. I had such high hopes for similar fun tagging this year, even had it penciled in on my calendar for this week!

Contributed to Monarch Watch
We got a call this morning from Gerald Kraft, 7 miles south of Wessington Springs, South Dakota, saying they had over 100 butterflies gathering in the evening along their cottonwood and willow trees.
Report from Mary Devany, Harrisburg, SD: hundreds roosting in trees next to her house nightly.

This was AMAZING! There had to be thousands of Monarchs roosting along an alfalfa field. The field also has clover. The roost was all along about a 1/2 mile grove of trees. We don't know the kind- some were box elder but some were maybe 40-50 foot tall with cherries on them also.
