At first we thought thre were hundreds--but the roost went on, and on, and on--with hundreds in each tree. How beautiful. I took lots of photos and some short videos on a digital camera.

They were all on the south side of the trees. Little wind- maybe 10-15 miles or so. I can't wait to get home and go look again tonight. My husband saw them about 6:30, don't know when they arrived, hadn't been in that field lately before last night. Will report daily. YAY!!!

August 31
Saw Monarchs roosting again. Saw more in range of 600 total in the 1/4 mile stretch of mostly choke cherry trees.

While driving past one of my old regular tagging locations, I dropped by after 7 pm while en route elsewhere and noticed a number of small clusters of roosting monarchs as well as many individuals in the trees overlooking Oakville Harbour, on the NW shore of Lake Ontario. The town has many plantings of Butterfly bush here. There were some still nectaring.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Saw Monarchs roosting again. Saw more in range of 600 total in 1/4 mile stretch of mostly choke cherry trees. Arrived 6:30 p.m., all were settled into trees by then.Will observe 9-1 in a.m. to see when they leave, if they leave.
Report from Janelle Tripp, farm just north of Lennox, SD: They have hundreds of monarchs in their shelterbelt for the last two evenings.

On the 31st starting at 7 AM we checked the area at Muskegon State Park that we have checked the last 2 years for overnight roosts. The wind was N 8-11 mph, 63 degrees. In 1 hour 30 minutes we found about 325 monarchs, with clusters of 32, 28 and 20. At about 8:30 AM they seemed to leave the roost site (several acres of mixed pines and deciduous trees) and start migrating. We stopped in Grand Haven and again in Saugatuck/Douglas on our way south that morning and counted but the numbers migrating were smaller tha the previous evening (reported for 8/30/05), but then it was earlier in the day.Highest number seen roosting for the 3 years of observation.

Monarchs have begun to increase in numbers each day. Went out last night to check the areas where they usually roost and finding several monarchs getting ready to settle in for the night. I would think that in the next few days the peak of migration will be here. Nancy Newlon

Over a period of 20 minutes, around 7 p.m. with a temperature of 54 degrees and a wind speed of about 2 mph, in an area of about 15 maples and six other trees, I counted the following clusters: 7, 2, 23, 11, 3, 2, 1, 2, 1 and four flying about that I didn't see land (56 total).  All of those counted were on the lowest branches, where I could see; and I was perhaps most likely to see the monarchs that had landed on dead or dying branches.  I managed to take a couple of nice pictures, too.

Over a period of 30 minutes around 7 p.m., in the same area that I reported from yesterday (15 maples, 6 other trees), with a temperature of 57 degrees and wind speed of 5 mph, I observed the following clusters: 16, 7, 6, 5, 5, 6, 7, 4, 1, 11, 2, 12, 7, 1, 16, 3, and 32 flying about that I didn't see land (109 roosted and 32 flying to total 141).  Again, I was only counting those that I could see on the lowest branches.  Earlier in the day, around noon, I simply looked out my window and saw 9 roosting on the locust tree.  Last year I didn't count, but it seems like there are more monarchs this year.
Saw quite a few, only on certain bushes and trees (none on our lilac bushes, for example) on Aug 24-26. 2005.  Another group appeared on Sep 4, 2005.  Almost as large as the first, maybe larger.

Many Monarchs seen today. We saw many on Aug 24 through 26 also. A photo and a .MOV movie from the August sightings can be viewed at:http://www.davelevasseur.com/images/100_0835.JPGandhttp://www.davelevasseur.com/images/100_0836.MOV--- Dave

September 13
They left a few days later.
There have been 100-200 monarchs roosting in ash trees in my front yard for the last 2 weeks. Was curious to learn more about their behavior and why they were here, so I found your site.

We have a one acre woods on our NE Iowa farm and for the last 2 days (since 9/3/05) have observed thousands of Monarchs roosting on the north side of the woods where they can feed on a nearby patch of red clover. The temps are still warm here, in the 70's at night and 80's during the day. There is a slight breeze from the south.Like other observations there are a few dragonflies in the same area.

Monarchs rest overnight in the scrub pines on the property [located about 1000' from the ocean] during their annual migration south.  9/05/05 near sunset, I saw the 1st one fly from the ocean into the pines for an overnight stay.

I mountain biked the Bronk unit of the Richard Dorer State Forest  just north of Stockton and overlooking the city of Winona starting around 6:00 Monday evening. The best part of the outing was probably the 100 to 200 Monarch butterflies I think I startled out of their roosts in the trees adjacent to the open field full of, I think, Blazing Star flowers that they assumably had been feeding on.Many of their companions were still feeding out in the field.

We tagged 68 monarchs in an hour in the alley by our home. We could have had more but they were easily disturbed from their roost and the mosquitoes challenged us as well. On Friday, September 2, my father tagged 75 in a ditch just outside of town.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

I leave for work at 6:20 a.m. so I asked my mom to watch the Monarchs this morning. She and my daughter saw hundreds again this a.m. about 8 o'clock. They had not left yet, still gathered in trees. Saw about one thousand total during the day in early afternoon and again about 6:30 p.m. also.

At about 9 a.m. and again in early evening (6:30 p.m.) saw hundreds roosting along this 1/4 mile long grove of trees. Still beautiful but not nearly so many as we had seen on 8-30-05 when there were thousands of them.
Saturday - only saw about 50 to 100 Monarchs in the tree line today. Perhaps they've moved on?
Sunday, 9-4-05 cloudly, looked like possible rain all day. Only could see about 50 Monarchs total all day in the tree line where on Tuesday there had been thousands roosting there.
Labor Day. Only saw maybe 100 Monarchs along roosting area all day. Feeling sad they must have gone.

Tuesday, 9-6  At about 5:30 p.m. drove along the 1/4 mile long former roosting sight. One week ago saw thousands of Monarchs here.  Tonight there are many more than over the weekend and last night.  Very active up in the tree area but not over the alfalfa field nectaring. Did not ever see very many of them nectaring but there is alot of rotting fruit available in the choke cherry trees they roost in.  Saw about 300 Monarchs again this drive by.

Brad and Keith observed a couple hundred Monarchs roosting on Bradford Rd. just east of Reese. We noticed them for multiple days in a row clustered on trees approximately 10 feet up.

September 13
No new sightings since the day we saw them.
Approximately 60 monarchs are roosting in our grove. Tagged 25. Many appear young, fresh color and wings.

I mountain biked the Bronk unit of the Richard Dorer State Forest  just north of Stockton and overlooking the city of Winona starting around 6:00 Monday evening. The best part of the outing was probably the 100 to 200 Monarch butterflies I think I startled out of their roosts in the trees adjacent to the open field full of, I think, Blazing Star flowers that they assumably had been feeding on.Many of their companions were still feeding out in the field.

09-07-05This evening observed 5 good monarch roosts. Estimate total of 500 to 700 monarchs. Many larva still on milkweeds. No eggs as of late. In my classroom the last few days students have been bringing in larva. I now have 60 pupa and around 100 larva.

Carold Mettler called to report 500 to 1000 monarchs roosting in her elm trees in the evening near Menno, South Dakota. She said she had many 3-4 years ago, but not nearly as many in the last couple years.

Sighted a roost of 10 monarchs (8 females/2 males)on the lower branches of a maple tree on the perimeter of the yard this evening. The branch was approximately 12 feet from the ground - they appeared to be well settled for the evening when I located them - no flashing.

September 13
No recent roosts sighted in the yard. I'm still seeing single monarchs on a daily basis flying through.

Located 4 small roosts deep into the woods this evening - groups of  3/5/2/7.  All roosting on interior branches 10-12 feet off the ground on heavily leafed maple branches - good protection/cover.  Storms are due in late this evening or early Thursday a.m.

While on vacation along the coast of Lake Michigan, we observed 50 -100 Monarchs roosting in a tree near our cottage.  They were there for several days.  There were also dozens of Monarch sightings on the beach.
Tonight there are more than I have seen for a while.  I counted about 650 Monarchs. Little wind, beautiful weather, upper 80s daytime, upper 60s night time.

We had about 500 Monarchs here, the first time we have ever had them stop on their way south. They took off, and we have only about two dozen left. While roosting and I assume eating on my Butterfly bushes, they kept fighting off the Hummingbirds who also wanted a bite to eat. Pretty Awesome sight.
Approximately 50 monarchs in our hackberry and pin oak trees this evening. First noticeable sighting this fall.

This morning (7:30 a.m.) while placing fresh food at the feeding station for Ruby-throated Hummingbirds and any late Baltimore Orioles, I observed approximately 50 Monarch butterflies roosting in a stand of north facing trees that are adjacent to a prairie garden. It was Partly Cloudy, 74F with winds south at 10 mph.

They were in a tree in our shelter belt and as I approached a huge cloud of them arose and flew abour for a while. .  A few days later I saw another group of them in another tree in the yard.  They also arose and flew about for a while before settling back onto leaves of the tree.  Also there have been a lot of Monarchs just flying around in the yard.The Mitchell, S.D. Daily Republic newspaper had a brief article about the fact that they were all over Mitchel  this year.  I do not recall seeing Monarchs in Fulton or Mitchell in great quantities like this ever before.  Every summer we see a few of course.  The weather has been very dry and windy for the past two weeks.  Perhaps the butterflys were just resting from the strong winds.
Over one hundred in yard.
Hundred or more roosted in a grove a tree that offered much protection from the weather. They remained there until after a shower of rain at nine this morning.
Between twenty and fifty monarchs flew out of a bush in my backyard about 2PM today.  I've never seen so many before and we've lived here since 1973.

Many monarchs roosting in the trees around 7:30 tonight on the edge of a clover field. Many more than 2 days ago. We pulled around 35 from the trees and tagged them. I am looking forward to going out tomarrow in the daylight to see how many there are, and hopefully tag more.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

We are seeing a few more here everyday and they are starting to group up and roost at night. We are hatching some each day with many to hatch by the weekend. The weather is changing here this week. We predict that it will bring migration to a peak too. The students have observed over 50 chysalis this year and we are tagging them upon release. What a great learning time!
Hundreds of monarchs reported 2 miles north of Hull, Iowa since September 8. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Reports of three trees full of monarchs nightly. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.

Report by Mary Rogers, Worthington, MN. Hundreds of butterflies congregating at her place for the last week. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Report of thousands near the SE corner of Lake Madison, SD. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Main Street in Humboldt, SD reporting hundreds of monarchs. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Report of hundreds near the railroad track in Corson, SD. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Report of tens of thousands in a shelterbelt north and west of Salem, SD. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.
Thousands of monarchs hanging on maple trees in central park in Sibley, IA. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.

Report from Jim Bridge, High School Principal in Alexandria, South Dakota of thousands and thousands of monarchs in his trees and yard. They were there Sept. 8-12. Reported to Outdoor Campus in Sioux Falls, SD following a newspaper article in the Argus Leader on 9/11/05.

A friend of mine just called and told me to take a look outside, if I wanted to see a lot of butterflies…apparently just over the Karls TV and Appliance Store, here in Huron, there are literally thousands of Monarch butterflies…and then I remembered that you might want to know that!Jennifer OehlerGFP-Secretary895 3rd Street SW-PO Box 915Huron, SD 57350Office: 605-353-7145Fax: 605-353-7196 Jennifer.Oehler@state.sd.us
Roosting sites every evening since 9/5/05. Several hundred each evening up to and including last evening (9/13/05).

We have had several monarch roosts in our shelterbelt since Aug 23. When the weather is warm and the wind is from the south they will stay for several days and move on when the weather and wind changes directions. They are roosting day and night. We have had 4 seperate groups of monarch roosts with the last group leaving on Sept 12th when we had a big storm. Lots of very strong wind from the south in the morning(over 40mph) and them another storm in the evening. The breeze is now from the north and the monarchs are gone. I will be watching this weekend as the weather warms up again to see if more arrive. There were a few less monarchs in the last group that came through, and yet each of the groups had approximately 400-500 monarchs.

I noticed many Monarchs traveling north to south as I drove east to west across Lincoln this afternoon.  When I returned home around 6 PM, I looked in the common ground behind our house and saw roosts of as many as 30 individuals on one branch.  The total in the common ground area was probably a couple of hundred spread over many trees.
At least 50  Monarchs at sun set cruising south west and settling for the night.

WOW! In our rural town park at about 7:15 pm, after a wonderful cold front came through bringing a north breeze, several HUNDRED monarchs! The orange beauties were everywhere in the park. Most where already settled down to roost, but many were trying to find just the right spot. I had not seen that many in quite a few years! It was an incredible sight!
Approximately 100 have landed here on the farm in the pine tree's. Just beautiful!

Yesterday several hundred Monarchs roosted at my flower farm, Frozen Creek Floral Farm, in Belmont MI my. My nectar flowers were loaded with them. We place cut orange slices out and passion Fruit Gatorade in champagne cups out as extra nutrition what a sight. They stayed over a day. Winds were high that day from the SW. I am a breeder of Monarch's they roosted on the flyway habit that my stock is in. Talking to their cousins no doubt. My genetic stock is from MN and FL.My release date on my butterflies is the third Saturday of Sept. At Fallsburg Fall Festival in Lowell This happens at my farm every year. That started me in the breeding for release of Monarchs as well as stock for cycle of life program for schools.
There are at least 100 plus Monarchs in 2 of our trees.  We have put out sugar water for them and have taken many pictures and a short video.

First report of clustering monarchs in KS -05

Last evening around 5:30 I stopped by in our president's backyard. It was a beautiful evening and the Monarchs had started to settle in - there were probably a couple of hundred butterflies, both males and females, but quite flighty. I noticed there were many more coming in. So this morning I stopped by again around 7:45. All of the butterflies were gone - a likely result of the severe thunderstorm. I do not know if that's it. Maybe wewill have some more coming here tonight and tomorrow?

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Observed a few dozen monarchs cruising my cedar trees this afternoon and evening. Was able to tag eleven.

Contributed by Texas Monarch Watch
Today they are fluttering in to stop in my trees. Sometimes 1, 2's,3's up to 6 and a time,, its amazing. I have seen them flying all around our neighborhood,, up too 2 to 3 miles away from my house.

September 18, 2005
We expect several hunderd if not a thousand or more monarchs to arrive this year. To date, number of monarchs is much lower than in past years. Cannot suggest a reason for this. If more come later, I'll let you know.

September 15, 2005
We noticed Monarchs in the air yesterday evening. There was a cool north breeze and sunny skies.

Monarchs have roosted in our yard which is 7 miles north of Enid, for many years in the pecan, hedge, mulberry, and cottonwood trees that are thick on our property, spread over six acres but concentrated just south of our house. I have reported roosts many times.
Small numbers of roosting monarchs were discovered in Hastings, Nebraska, on September 16, 17 & 18.  We tagged about 90 monarchs.
Because the winds are strong there are approximately one thousand monarchs roosting here.
They began arriving in our back yard on Sunday, September 18, and by late evening there were several hundred.  They are still here as of the morning of September 20.
I counted over 150 monarchs. A south strong south wind with rainwas approaching and the monarchs were roosting on the north sideof maples, sweetgum and cedar trees.
30 roosting monarchs
After a heavy day of migration along the north shore of lake Erie approximately 450 to 500 Monarchs spent the night sheltering in several sites on trees out of the wind

Just had a report that on the coast at Pemaquid Point in Maine, about 20 monarchs were seen roosting together in trees or feeding on goldenrod. Haven't seen a lot of monarchs around in Maine this year, but there are some!

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Last night I tagged 12 Monarchs as dusk approached. Few Monarchs are left and the ones which were still here, were soaring around the trees as dusk fell. There were small clusters of them in the trees, 30-40 feet high. I counted about 100 in one cluster.

Contributed to Monarch Watch
counted 40 monarchs roosting in sweetgum tree. southweststorm was approaching.

September 20
Spectacular arrival of Monarch Butterflies! At their peak they hung so thick on the trees it looked like frosting on a cake!

September 21
Monarch Butterflies continue to linger; larger numbers today.

September 22
We have an overnight Monarch roost here on our historic property in Saint Joseph Missouri. We have had anywhere from 200 or so Monarchs to perhaps 1000 roosting overnight now for 3 days. Very Exciting!! The Monarch Butterflies filled the trees this morning and this afternoon they are gone.

On my way back from lunch on my bike, I decided to take the path less travelled and went off-road behind some back buildings.  I had no idea that the block-long row of bushes would be filled with Monarch butterflies and as I rode by slowly, they took flight all around me.  What a great experience with nature.  They were there on my way home so I got to see them again but by the next morning, they were gone.

On Sunday 9-18-05, we had over 1,000 monarch in the trees in our yard. The day before, we thought 100 was a large amount of butterflies but by Sunday it looked like an invasion. Every branch on the two trees on the north side of our house was covered with the beautiful butterflies. During the day they would go out into the clover field of our house then return before sunset to roost in the trees. By Thursday, 9-22-05 we were down to just a dozen. It was a wonderful experience while they were here.

They're here! I thought Tuesday was a good day for them, but you can't go outside anywhere in town today without seeing monarchs on the move. A co-worker found many overnight clusters with "hundreds of monarchs" in the SE part of the metropolitan area. We had a mild front come through within the last 24 hours, so they may be riding the wind on the back side of that. It's nice to see, since we have not had a highly visible migration here in several years.

Look out Oklahoma, here they come!

Contributed to Monarch Watch
There are approximately 300 Monarchs roosting in our Hedgeapple trees. The trees are near a stream.

A huge gathering of migrating monarch butterflies - up to several thousand a night - occurred over the last few evenings in a grove of trees in Jerusalem Township. Doris Stifel, Toledo's renowned Butterfly Lady and monarch authority, said the clustering was beyond expectations. "This is the best thing I've seen in this part of the country. It is the closest thing to what I've seen in Mexico, ever" The migrant monarchs, likely having completed a crossing of western Lake Erie from Ontario, clustered to rest in the grove of trees. It is probable that other roosting monarchs have occurred in trees throughout the region.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

September 16
Approximately 50-100 monarch clustered in trees which shielded them from the wind for about 3 days.

September 28
They've mostly gone now although I did see about 10 on Monday. They mostly stay in a group of trees north of my college. I think it is a good windbreak for them.
We had our first wind out of the north today in more than 10 days. 380 monarchs roosting in our cedar trees.
The Monarchs were in an elm tree on the south side of the house this morning around 9:00 am.  Abeautiful sight to behold.  Got some beautiful pictures.
Around 50 monarchs clustered in a group of trees north of my college. They were there for about 3 days.

Have been tagging around 4-8 per evening the last 10 days or so here in eastern Kansas. Observed an increase in monarch numbers on Sunday the 25th and tagged 28. On Monday, I saw quite a few but had none in my trees, which was strange. Today, monarch numbers increased both here (Richmond) and at Osawatomie, Ks., had largest groups roosting so far with numerous clusters of 15-30 monarchs. Was able to tag 83 this evening.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

Have been tagging around 4-8 per evening the last 10 days or so here in eastern Kansas. Observed an increase in monarch numbers on Sunday the 25th and tagged 28. On Monday, I saw quite a few but had none in my trees, which was strange. Today, monarch numbers increased both here and at Osawatomie, Ks., had largest groups roosting so far with numerous clusters of 15-30 monarchs. Was able to tag 83 this evening.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

This evening at about 6pm I caught and released a tagged Monarch, it was a monarch watch tag GML 904. I also tagged 4 others and had 12 altogether around the end of Wise Point (the northern end of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel. I did see 4 monarchs moving in and out of the roosting sites, the others were nectaring on tall white flowers. Our total Monarchs seen today was 28.

Contributed to Monarch Watch

My family left Houston on Wednesday 9-21-05 to escape the threat from hurricane Rita. We drove to Canton Lake, Oklahoma to spend the weekend with family. My two children along with three nieces and a nephew were very excited to discover a Monarch roost while we were there! Thank goodness I brought my tags! We estimate anywhere from 100 -200 Monarchs were roosting in a protected group of trees near the lake. Hanging in clusters of 2-10 on Saturday 9-24 they hung low to the ground so tagging was easy. On Sunday 9-25 the Monarchs were harder to tag because they were clustered higher in the trees, and seemed more active and faster to fly away. The entire weekend Monarchs floated across the sky at varioius altitudes... all heading South!

Tree line along both sides of a church property with brush growing underneath. Property is mowed regularly. Walking the perameter, We discovered on each side an area of about 5 trees with a lot of monarch activity.  Easily saw 15 monarchs at each side.  Many were seen resting in the trees, many flew out of the trees as we passed by. There is no abundant food source on the church property.

Last night at sunset as I was walking at Hammonassett State Park in Clinton, CT I observed over 70 monarchs on their migratory route. I also made a few other observations. I noticed that most of the monarchs were flying in groups of two like they were "couples". I also observed that the monarchs roosted in PINE trees and that surprised me. Perhaps they rest overnight in pine trees. This has been the best monarch migration season I have witnessed for the last 18 years. My hope has been restored. Also, my class has observed many monarchs in our courtyard this week. There are at least 5 monarchs on our butterfly bushes at all times today. We finished all of our tagging last week so we are simply observing and it's amazing how many monarchs are here this year!

150 monarchs at 9:30 pm roosting in the double row of windbreak cedar trees. They were on the north side of the cedars and the wind was out of the south.  It took them much longer to roost tonight after  the sun went down. The temperature we in the 80's at sundown.

9/28/05 unable to find any Monarchs roosting.  Wind gusting out of the North all evening and into the night. We saw 5-10 all day long.9/29/05 10 Monarchs roosting in Sycamore tree7:30pm.  Wind out of the North all day.  They roosted earlier tonight the temperature was 68F.
I saw about 20 of them at my house in a tree.

Several students and teachers have reported monarchs roosting in area trees.  We had a cold front yesterday, and here they are today!  I had a student who brought in a videotaped observation of the monarchs roosting in her aunt's trees.  Beautiful!

We have a Ranch in Fisher County, Texas, about 22 miles NE of Sweetwater or 40 miles NW of Abilene, with a couple of miles of Chyna Creek running through. The creek banks are lined with mature willow trees. We have had Monarchs roost in a specific 1/4 mile section of the creek for the past 4 years in a row, approx the first week of October each year. They spent the night there on Wednesday night, Sept 28th, 2005. Early that evening we went and saw them, thousands and thousands. In the trees and grass, they flew up as we slowly walked through, creating a truly surreal experience.We took a few video clips and about 40-50 good digital photos. We would love to share them if you would like, just let us know! --mike--

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 5000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “thousands upon thousands.”

The monarchs and a few other butterflies began roosting Thursday evening and again Friday in all my pecan,live oak trees and my neighbors about one mile away.  We live out in a farming community. I took pictures to share with my third grade students since we are beginning to study life science.  On Saturday morning they did not leave until noon or a bit later.  Maybe because of the wind or the cool morning.
school: Fort concho elementary, san angelo, tx

comments: we had over 100 monarchs roosting in our elm tree for 3 days.  what do they feed on?

My husband and I went birding for early evening bird migrants and were pleasantly surprised by seeing a Monarch migration. It appeared that the Monarchs were coming into the top of some Tulip Poplar trees for their evening roost. It was quite a site to behold. Neither of us have ever seen anything like this here in South West Indiana.

Hundreds landing in Live Oak and Pecan trees in back yard at this time (7PM)

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 200 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “hundreds.”

Spending the weekend on our property we took a walk through our woods this afternoon and as last year the woods were full of floating Monarchs. There were some trees where they were bunching up together. It was impossible to count the floating ones, but it was a wonderful sight seeing all those floating and fluttering butterflies. I am going back in there in the morning. There was a fairly powerful storm system last night it might have been part of this sighting as there are many more then last year.

Last p.m. (9/29) I observed many monachs coming into roost around Zoo grounds. This a.m. (9/30) probably had over 1,000 roosting about the zoo. We were catching them 2-5 at a time.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
First time they have stopped by here!  Amazing!

This is a FIRST of Ms. Wight!!!   Hannah Wright (5th grade) saw 30 monarchs roosing in her trees in her front and back yard throughout the weekend. They were flying 20 ft above the ground. They flew from one oak tree to another and another. They are also in the fields. They stayed Saturday afternoon through Sunday night. They may still be there I have not checked yet. I think most of them are females. This made me feel special to think that I'm the chosen one. E-mail me if you see any roostings.

Butterflies roosted for 3 nights - estimated at 1500-2000 per night. Not sure if these were the same butterflies or different ones. I have photos if you can accept those digitally. The butterflies appeared to be drinking water from water sprinkled grass - stayed out of wind by tree windbreak.

On Wednesday (9/28/05), after noticing monarchs in our area, about 90 fourth graders at Santa Rita Elem. searched the Journey North website as they learned about the monarch migration. In all, 12 children reported that hundreds of monarchs had roosted in their trees the night before (9/27/05) and were gone the next morning. This was prior to the cold front that passed through Wednesday night with high winds and cooler temperatures. Now all these young 4th grade scientists are on the watch for our annual visitors.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 200 monarchs based on observer’s comment that 12 students saw trees with “hundreds.”

Zillons of Monarchs have been roosting at my mother's home out in the country since late last week.  Sunday, after church, my children and I drove out to see the multitudes of butterflies.  One of her pecan trees was just covered with Monarchs.  However, the majority of the butterflies were in her backyard garden.  When we stepped out into the backyard the Monarchs would take flight and there were so many flying up that the sound of the fluttering wings was louder than you might think a butterfly flap to be!  The children were thrilled to see so many!

My grandsons were playing outside and called, excitedly, for me to come out and see ALL the Monarch butterflies. I assumed that they were exaggerating but I went out anyway. Was I surprised!! In two of my trees there were a huge amount of Monarch butterflies sitting on the different limbs. On one bare limb were at least 20 and they were opening and closing their wings in unison. It was breathtaking. I got my camera and took some pictures but it was dusky out and I'm not sure if they will showup or not. The other limbs were full too and the Monarchs were flying all over. I am 50 years old and have never seen anything like it. Later that night, in fact 1am, I made my husband come out and showed them to him with a flashlight. He was also amazed. Very awesome!

I just pulled up a letter in the Odessa American that said that they haven't spotted but a few stray Monarchs here in west Texas but I have to report that right now as I write this letter, I have a thousand or more nesting in my oak trees. They starting flying in two days ago and I expect more before they move on. Now the last time we have seen this many, was in 2003. I had planted Lantanas in the front flowerbed, hoping that we would see them again and I am not disappointed.

I wrote in 2003 about the butterflies that would nest in our trees for days. I guess they were mapping the migration route.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I'm not much at estimating numbers, but today in Sonora, I visited twoplaces that get roosting monarchs every year. George has aapricot tree in his backyard and today it was appoximately 35-40%covered in thick monarchs - I will send the pictures when I get them.The tree is about 20 feet tall, and pretty wide in diameter. At the ranch, there were hundreds flying around beneath and a fewbranches were full, but not quite as many as he'd seen yesterday & theday before. I will try to do some counts. We did get to watch themstreming in from the north, so tomorrow may be a good day. This isexciting!

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

For the past 2 evenings (Oct. 3rd and 4th)we have had hundreds of Monarchs roosting in the trees in our yard.  Don't know how long they stay.  We have had Monarchs come to asters and butterfly bush before, but never this many and have not seen them roosting before.  It is a wondrous sight!  I have taken pictures.  Hope they turn out, as the light is dim.  Seems a little late for them, thought they were usually here mid to late Sept.  Wonder if anyone else here in central Missouri has them roosting?m
Monarchs were everywhere on Saturday. Several locations within a 30 mile radius reported hundreds. We tagged 25 monarchs in a pecan orchard about 30 miles from town that had 20,000 roosting.

A friend told me about finding around 200 Monarchs roosting in her fruitless mulberry and silver maple trees this evening about 51/2 miles NW of Kingfisher.  She stated that she had not noticed a roost like this in years.
A friend told me about seeing at least 25 Monarchs roosting in her Mother's elm trees about 4 miles NE of Okarche this evening.

While walking in Cape May Point at 6:40 pm we happened to notice at least several dozen monarchs flying overhead.  Upon further inspection we realized that they were picking their bed and breakfast location.  There were hundreds of them (perhaps even thousands--not too good with estimating #) in three trees; 2 were deciduous trees--unsure what kind, and one was a pine.  The second evening we went back again around the same time and there were monarchs going to roost in the same location.

Several dozen monarchs were in the trees and flying around the creek that runs in front of my house on Saturday morning. The temperature was in the mid 70s and the wind calm.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 36 monarchs based on observer’s comment about “several dozen monarchs.”

On a beautiful Sunday afternoon, October 2, 2005, my husband called me to come out to the back yard. I saw the most beautiful sight, a plethora of Monarchs! Probably 150 to 200 of the beautiful butterflys flying in and out of our trees. Above us they seemed to be just floating above our heads. We saw small ones, just smaller than a quarter flying in an out of our honeysuckle that grows through our wrought iron fence. I took a few good pictures until my cat followed me, and then the Monarchs seemed to be bothered by all the movement, even though I tried not to scare them. Early evening, I saw many, about 50, flying into and around the privet and honeysuckle.
About 20 roosting in a red tipped willow on the east side of the tree. See also sighting on 9.Sept.05

Greater than 18 Monarchs roosting in red tipped willow (same tree as report for 25Aug05) on the east side of tree. They were very flighty that night if approached too close. Also saw a few in neighboring white birch on the NE side of the tree -  the side closest to the above willow
20 butterflies sighted on one purple flowering bush by the beach at about 4:00p.m.. Wow!

I accidentally stumbled into the resting place of 1000's of monarchs10/2 8:30 a.m. in Lee Pfluger Park, Eden (Concho County) Texas. Iestimate that there were in excess of 20,000 butterflies and perhapsmore on the live oaks, the ground, the brushy area at the park'ssouthern boundary (approx. 100 meters.) I did not attempt a count andthis is a very rough estimate. On 10/3 I found another monarch restingplace on the park ground hosting probably 1000 butterflies.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Yesterday's high for Kingfisher, Okla. was 50, overcast, wind N16. I have about 25 up in my pecan tree. I was shocked to see about 7 Monarchs venture out about 3pm, 5 continued going SW, and the other 2 turned around and came back to the tree! I found 3 Monarchs on some Trop. mw in a turpor, not moving an inch, So, I cut some flowers, put the Monarchs and flowers in a popup hamper, and brought them inside. They gradually started moving around once they started to warm up.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

This is my third sighting of a Monarch fall roost at this specific location in Carthage Missouri where I lived for twenty years.  These sightings have been scattered over a period starting in the late 1950s, then once in the mid 1960s.  This years sighting was a a grouping of about 1500 to 2000 Monarchs. Each time before they have only spent one night and are gone the next day.

Our hundreds of migrating Monarchs were here Mon. 10/03/2005 to Wed. 10/05/2005.  They weathered quite a thunderstorm Wed. night and dropping temperatures with strong North winds.  They all departed yesterday 10/06/2005, which is a good thing, because we had temperatures in the 40's last night and are to get 30's tonight.

We've got monarchs! I checked the skies between 8:00 and 8:30 p.m. and there were monarchs settling into the trees well after sunset when the sky was still fairly light.

We had wind from the north all day yesterday. The front had blustered in at 12:42, Thursday afternoon, and cool winds persisted all Fridayfrom the north. This morning until 11 the air continued to move in from the north, but skies cleared. Temps went to 52.7 last night and back up to 82.3 today.After 11 the air began to drift back in from the southeast.

I just checked 8 trees and found scattered singletons in all of them. Two trees had clusters. One of 12, the other of 5. Total # of monarchs sighted:36 of which I netted 10.These sightings were in an area 30 yards by 60 yards.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

at least 6 huge clusters of monarchs on my oak tree limbs -  clusters looked to be at least 50-100 each.  We noticed them in the late afternoon & they were mostly gone the next morning with a few stragglers taking off then.

Our first migrants of the fall settled into the trees a bit after sunset between 8-8:30 p.m. on the evening of the 8th. I went out the morning of the 9th and was able to net 15. They were in 2 clusters, one of 12, the other 5-6. All those sighted were about 36 in number.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: Sighting: 11:00 a.m., Monarch rising from roost in circular movement then moving south.

Started seeing butterflies (Monarchs) at dusk. They were landing high in second growth Pines on Beards Bluff above Beards Lake in Hempstead County, AR. There were hundreds of them. Most lit adjacent to others but some clung to each other in huge groupings. The next day (Sunday 10 09 05) they flew just as the sun touched them. They left one at a time and in explosions of dozens of individuals against the brilliant blue of the morning sky. It was a gitf to share the morning and evening with them.

Did not know what type of tree it was in West Texas, but there were probably over 1,000 butterflies in the tree. It appeared to me to be a significant roost located west of Throckmorton Texas. The tree was heavily leaved and the butterflies blended in well.
I have a confirmed monarch picture

On the evening of Sat. Oct. 8, we saw 20 monarchs sitting on the branches of our dad's pecans trees north of Burkburnett near Red River.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I spent the weekend near the community of Old Glory in Stonewall County, just off Highway 283.

We were outside most of the time, and individual monarchs flew past steadily. Occasionally groups of 3 or 4 flew past. There was one roost in a mulberry tree and it included several dozen monarchs -- difficult to count accurately, but I believe it was about 125. Also, one group of about 40 monarchs flying more or less together.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Even though the big roosts have moved on south, we are still seeing a steady stream of migrants over the county. I learned of 2 other locations that had large roosts, 1 site just south of I-20 within the Midland city limits and the CAF [Confederate Air Force] garden near the airport reported hundreds for several days before the cold front last Wednesday night.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 200 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “hundreds.”

This evening we had hundreds of Monarchs roosting on a large pecan tree in our front yard. We live 18 miles north of Bonham Tx, in the Red River valley.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

When we got back to our regular home in Grapevine 10/9/05 about 3 pm my butterfly weed, salvias and tropical milkweed were covered in nectaring monarchs - tagged 25 in 15 minutes. It was great!Monday 10/10 there were a lot of monarchs coming thru when the sun warmed things up.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We were in Hext, Texas (Menard County) this last weekend and tagged about 125 monarchs Saturday night 10/8/05. Got up early Sunday morning to try to find some before they warmed up and moved on - had very good luck because the wind had shifted and was coming out of the south and the butterflies seemed to want to stay in our "bottom" - a mixture of cedar elm, live oak and pecan trees along the San Saba River. They stayed under the tree canopy while the winds were high.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Just a note to let you know I had about a hundred monarch in my yard Monday Oct. 10. The first ones came about a month ago. We have had lots of queens and one caterpillar also. No monarch caterpillars yet.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

On October 7-8, I was bowhunting about 12 miles east of Menard on a property that backs up to the San Saba river. We walked down to the river after an unsuccessful hunt. There were thousands upon thousands of Monarchs on the trees lining the river. By noon on Saturday, all of the Monarchs were gone, just the occasional butterfly flying through.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 5000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “thousands upon thousands.”

Last two days, have seen hundreds of monarchs drinking nectar from white flowered bushes at Carrollton/Farmers Branch ISD Turner field parking lot. Occasional blue swallow tail will try to chase the monarchs off the bushes. This is in the North Dallas area.

I work at Heart of the Hills Fisheries Science Center near Ingram/Kerrville, Texas. Last week we had hundreds of butterflies here- just before the front came through. Most were feeding or resting.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

This weekend, I went up to a ranch on the Llano, south of Mason, and saw several groups between 10-30 whenever I went into a calm grove of trees.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Finally used up the last of my tags over at Infirmary Mound Park near Granville OH --- caught 21 of them on October 5th, what fun!

I got down to my last tag about 630 pm when they were beginning to settle down for the night in some small trees in the middle of this huge field. I didn't want to leave with my LAST tag unused so I ended up chasing monarchs from tree to tree until one finally landed where I could net it! I found out that they will "unroost" even if they are twenty foot up if you just stand there and wave the net around but they are SO wary afterwards that I must have gone up and down the row of trees three or four times before I finally snagged one - talk about obsessed!

Normally I wouldn't harass them this way but it was my LAST tag for the YEAR!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I started looking up at clouds to focus my binoculars for observing high flying birds, like the chimney swifts, whe I sawMONARCHS!  I couldn't see most of them with unaided eye, but they indeed were soaring with their little wings out stretched to Mexico.  Lower flying Monarchs were easily identified.  We easily saw about 20-25 in a 10 minute period (about 5 PM) Then about 6 PM several (5-6) were seen flying lower through the trees to land, I assume, for the night.

We have at least 30 Monarchs just now flying in and roosting in our Pecan Tree in our backyard. They seem to be either on branches that have few leaves or dead leaves. They seem to blend into the tree especially near the dead leaves which are an orange. Most of them are roosting in clusters. This is from 6-6:30pm. I also sighted quite a few this morning. Again they were in the pecan tree.

Seventh graders started searching for monarchs this morning (8:15-9:30) since they were reported to be roosting in the trees behind the headmaster's house.  Temp was 67 and conditions were overcast and misty.  Monarchs were seen flying high overhead.  We caught one coming off an oak tree roost.  Most of the others were too high to reach.

Today started out slow with it being mostly cloudy and windy nearly all day. When I arrived at the Monarch Roost on Wise Point I figured I saw 150 Monarchs, tagged 31 of them (43 for the entire day). I'm looking forward to the morning to see what flies out at Wise Point and on Fisherman Island, that is if the morning isn't rainy as predicted.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Around 7pm we saw about 20-30 flying around some huge trees and many appeared to be settling down for the night.  We wished them luck on their journey!
These look like the last of some scragglers.  There came in a small wave (couple of hundred) right in front of a cool front.  They were roosting in our live oak trees around 4:30 p.m.

Got a call from friends living in Fredericksberg, west of Austin, that their pecan trees had begun to have clusters of monarchs forming late this afternoon. Best clusters were just above six feet from the ground. They had no idea of the total but were going to get up at daybreak and try to get some photos.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
About 100 monarchs found roosting in our giant mulberry tree.  We noticed them about 11:00am

I have seen my first true clusters for the year. This morning we had one goodly sized cluster on a branch 10' off the ground with 36 in it and very nearby another cluster of 11. I was able to net 18 of the large cluster and then went round and collected the others as singletons.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
We are pecan growers and our home is in one of our orchards.The Monarchs have stopped in our orchard on their way south for several years.  I look forward to their arrival each year.

In earlier migrations we have found hundreds of monarchs in single trees. This year there seem to be smaller roosts under the canopies of almost every large live oak or live oak grove. It's hard to get a good count, but we normally see several dozen per roost. They are still there late in the morning and don't seem to be in any hurry to move on.

Friday morning, Oct. 14
I knew the roosting monarchs were in trouble when I awoke at sunrise and looked out my window. The back and side yards of my rental house on Chincoteague Island were already under several inches of water.

Concerned that I might be stranded, I left before the incoming tide couldflood the driveway. I raced to the beach road on Assateague Island to accessan interdune area where thousands of monarchs had roosted Thursday night inthe seaside goldenrod along the shore of Tom's Cove.

To my horror, there was no longer a beach road. The hard-packed oyster shelllane that paralleled the ocean's edge had been washed out during the nightin what the NPS naturalists called "a nor-easter with a tide higher thananyone on the staff had ever seen in all their years of working there".

Contributing factors were:
the continued raging ocean from the stalled stormin the northeast Atlantic,
5" of rainfall the previous week, and ,
theapproaching full moon and accompanying higher-than-normal tides.

I parked mycar at the causeway and trekked the mile over quicksand-like conditionswhere the road used to be. Several deep gullies were still awash with ocean water making it's way overthe sand, through the salt marsh and into Tom's Cove. My heart sank when Icame to the first small patch of seaside goldenrod-- it was flattened andchoked with sand. I searched for dead monarchs but, thankfully, found none.

Finally at the south end of the "road", I approached the area where most ofthe monarchs had been clustered late Thursday evening. They were stillthere! They had crawled up to the tips of the goldenrod flowers, some withina few inches of the flooding tide. I stayed until the tide ebbed to make sure they would make it. They couldnot take flight; the winds were NNW at 20-25 mph with higher gusts. Anymonarch that relinquished hold on the flowers was immediately caught in thewind and blown out to sea. They will be trapped on the goldenrod flowers allday if the winds continue, and will have to survive the next two high tides,which are predicted to be even higher than this past one. I looked withbinoculars to see if the monarchs were just perched or if they were takingadvantage of their situation. Most monarchs had their tongues extended andwere nectaring on the peak-bloom flowers. I allowed myself a moment withoutworry to admire their beauty. These I believe to be the Mid-Atlantic monarchs; they are pristine, with nowear or scars on their wings. Their wings are huge and their abdomens fat.They have not traveled far to arrive here.

I wonder if they sense how perilous the next 24 hours could be . . .

Excerpt from Denise Gibbs' field journal of the Chincoteague MonarchMonitoring Project at Chincoteague NWR on Assateague Island, Virginia.Contributed to Monarch Watch.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 2000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “thousands.” This report is dated October 13, the evening the roost had formed.

It looks like our westerly winds are socking in our Monarchs, a thousand were at roost this morning! This was our largest roost so far! See the report with photos at http://www.rlephoto.com/monarch2005/monarch_10_17.htm

October 25
Yesterday was very windy and cold, then about 11am it became rainy, and stayed nasty ever since. I did get 100 Monarchs on the roost, 12 on the island and 5 at the hawkwatch. Not bad finding 127 Monarchs on a day like yesterday. Oh, while watching 2 Monarchs leave Fisherman Island to make the 16+ Mile water crossing I had the fortune to watch 4 Bottle-nosed 16+ Dolphinsright of shore playing.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I went outside into the courtyard of the building where I work in South St. Louis City on the morning of Oct. 5th to take in a few breaths of the cool morning air, as I had done for the last few months. This was not a typical day, however, as I suddenly found myself amidst a swarm of fluttering Monarchs. I stood in awe at this spectacular sight not believing what I was seeing. I stood still as the fluttering wings abated, it was at this moment that I noticed that there were not merely hundreds of these beautiful butterflies around me, as I originally thought, but thousands. There was at least one monarch resting on every leaf in the tree-filled courtyard as well as each leaf on the thick vine that drapes the fence dividing the property line behind the building. I have never seen anything as anomalously beautiful as this before in my life and feel grateful that I was there at the right time to be graced with such beauty.

I walked Camp Bullis from Legend Ln to Babcock just now and it is loaded with monarchs. I counted about 24 on one (and smaller groups on other) flowering evergreen sumac. There was one group of 12 on a dead oak tree limb and another group on a hackberry tree. There were other smaller groups along the way. I think I saw at least 50 in all. Also of interest is that the large group had smaller monarchs with them. This is not scientific but I thought it was interesting.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

We experienced a very significant change in monarch numbers in the lastday:

On Wednesday night/Thursday morning we had thousands roosting in our trees. - the skies were full of monarchs morning to dusk.

Startlingly, last night-this morning there were none to been seen roosting or flying. This afternoon and evening I have seen NONE. Was that the "end" of the migration- (I think way too abrupt) or maybe just a shift in the path? I thought you might be interested in the extreme contrast.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

I saw several hundred monarchs gathering in my backyard pecan treesaround dusk this evening. It was fascinating how they grouped togetherin hanging bunches. I am inside the Kerrville city limits. I have more than a dozenpecans & some are over 65 years old. There's also lots of lantanaaround the yard.

In Oct. 2001, we had several thousand here for 7 to 10 days. That's theonly other time we've seen them & we moved here in 1940.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Monarch Watch

Editor’s Note: We are estimating 300 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “several hundred.”
In our school courtyard we counted 16 different monarch butterflys.  Three were flying around and 13 we resting on tree branches.

On the 12th of October we motored southward from the San Antonio, Texas area, crossed the border at Columbia, Nuevo Leon and camped the first night in Bustamante Canyon near the desert town of Bustamante. We arrived late and therefore were not able to see whether or not monarchs were present. The following morning we were delighted by groups of up to 20 roosting mainly in, but not restricted to, Huisache trees along the water course. The canyon is maybe three miles long and choked with riparian forest - at least along the stream.

We estimated about 5000 total in the canon, but this was a guess and not arrived at very systematically. The night of our arrival, it had rained lightly; the day itself was cloudy with winds coming up the canyon. The monarchs were not moving and did not resume their migration that morning as is usually the case.

160 butterflies in 7 trees in 4 loose clusters of 20 to 30.The rest were singletons nearby, with a few widely scattered ones.

The trick was not being carried away by mosquitoes that were almostthe same size as the monarchs.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Another massive flight of MONARCHS came through this week on October 17-18. 3,000 were counted at roost sites/shelteredspots in Cape May Point in the dunes and in backyards. Many of them migrated out of the area on the 19th, but some can still be found in gardens with blooming Butterfly Bushes and in the dunes where SEASIDE GOLDENROD is still blooming.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We were guests at a fall festival just outside of San Angelo on Sunday afternoon and while we were watching the talent show we realized that the trees were covered with monarchs. It was interesting to see that even though there were hundreds of people and the music was very loud, the butterflies did not seem to be disturbed at all. After discussing this with some of the folks that belonged to the church there we found out that the monarchs come to these same trees every year.

This weekend while canoeing up above the Rappahannock, we spotted a batch of butterflies all over what I believe are gall bushes. As we took pictures, we noticed one of them had a sticker or something on the wing. Upon closer inspection, we discovered a tagged monarch butterfly of all things.

I have contacted the email address and await any reply. I provide two pictures, FYI, one of the banded/stickered critter and the other a general picture of the monarchs. The approximate GPS coordinates of the spotting are Lat: 37-41-19 Long: 76-18-24 at 4:45 pm on Sunday, 10.23.05.

Contributed by Judy Molnar

October 2008
When I followed up with Monarch Watch later in 2005 or early 2006 they said they had no data sheet for this tag! They had no idea when it was tagged or where. Iï¿½ve emailed Jim Lovett at MW again to see if they have subsequently gotten a data sheet or any recovery data for it later in its journey.

El frente frio numero 7 hizo llegar a Saltillo, Coahuila, cientos de miles de mariposas, el dia 25 y 26 el cielo y los arboles se cubrieron de mariposas, las mariposas se encuentra por toda la ciudad y el campo. Ya he recibido reportes de San Luis Potosi y del estado de Zacatecas.

Courtesy of Señora Rocio Trevino, Correo Real

With the two cold fronts this weekend, we saw large numbers of monarchs migrating from the Point Comfort side of the Lavaca Bay Causeway southwest across the Lavaca Bay towards Port Lavaca.  Hundreds would stop on the peninsula at the north end of the causeway where there are blooming wildflowers and False-willow to nector on.  On the 25th we counted over 600 monarchs that had stopped to nector.  At sundown most of these were still on the peninsula and were in loose clusters for the night.  This had been going on since the 21st with the monarchs spending the nights roosting in loose clusters on the False-willow and many clustered on the taller Seaside Goldenrod.
The Monarch was roosting on the wall around our playground area. It looked very healthy. We believe it was a female.

we saw several hundred monarchs at fort island gulf beach in crystal river, fl citrus county. they flew around us for a half hour or so, and roosted on goldenrods and small mangroves. they were still there when we left soon after sunset. we took some digital picture, which did not come out well. we could not determine which direction they came from.

En Saltillo se siguen viendo muchísimas mariposas durante todo el día: 6-8 por minuto pero hoy recibi el siguiente reporte:

“En la mañana al llegar a la planta ensambladora de autos de la Chrysler que se localiza en Derramadero (20Km al sur de Saltillo) encontramos grandes racimos de mariposas en los árboles de los estacionamiento y el pasto estaba cubierto de mariposas que durmieron en el suelo. A las doce del día, con una temperatura de 17° C y un viento suave del norte empezaron a volar por entre las naves de la fábrica cientos y cientos de mariposas a una altura de 2 a 12 metros. El espectáculo era realmente hermoso y único”.

Courtesy of Correo Real

The Finish Line!
This is where the monarchs go for the winter.
They travel here from across eastern North America.

Directly from the monarch's winter home in Mexico,
Estela Romero sends these notes...>>

Towards sunset approx. 75 monarchs gathered on a couple of south facing branches of our maple trees. The day had been clear and sunny, 25 C with a very light breeze. Temp. was 12 C at sunset.I have lived here for 23 years and never seen monarchs gather like this before. BeautifulMid morning I had noticed  20 or so butterflies in flight in the back yard even though I do not have many flowers to feed them and am not near a significant food source.

Last night, at about 6:00 p.m., I noticed about two to three hundred monarchs resting in my pine trees in the front yard. Although I have several pines in the yard, they were clustered in two or three trees only with their wings closed at the ends of the branches, well camouflaged. This morning, as it became warm and sunny, many of them flew off leaving about thirty still resting in the trees. How exciting!

Tuesday Aug 15th: noticed 6 monarchs fluttering about in our forest. They stayed for the rest of the week.

Sunday Aug 20th: my husband and I started to notice them gathering in our backyard about at 10:00am. By noon there were many of them, and they kept coming! About 20 of them were clustering on a dead branch of a maple tree and stayed there for most of the day. They sat on the branch with wings folded up, but when one would come to roost, they would all start fluttering their wings. All in all we counted anywhere from 30 - 40. Weather here was very cool, windy and felt like we were going to get rain, but it never came.

Monday Aug 21st: only two monarchs were left fluttering in our garden. Weather was much warmer and sunnier.

August 24
We thought that we had seen the last of the monarchs, but yesterday evening we saw many more! Again, they were roosting on the same dead branch of the same maple tree. It was rainy and starting to get dark, so we didn't take a picture. I would guess there were another 30 butterflies. They were all gone when I checked at noon today.

Tonight there must have been about 500 Monarchs in clusters all over the maple trees around my house. They've been gathering for a week now, each night a bunch more. They choose different branches each time, but cluster tightly together in groups of 10 to 200.This is the first time in 23 years that I've lived here that I've seen Monarchs gather like this.


It was a clear warm day, slightly breezy and about 8:20 pm. (15 min. before sunset ). The butterflies gathered in groups of 10 to 200 on the lower branches on the south side of the maples around my house ( there are 27 large trees in 3 rows running east / west and the house is in the middle) On this day they gathered mostly on the middle row of trees. Some preferred branches with leaves but a group of about 40 preferred a bare branch.

Through the day I don't see as many butterflies, although some seem to stay on their roosts all through the day. Around 6:00 pm I notice lots of them flying around the trees and as the evening progresses they start to cluster on the ends of branches. They don't seem to keep to the exact same branches each night, although they seem to prefer the same specific trees. In the morning they disperse before I get out the door at 8 or 8:30. A few hang around the trees and stay on their branches.

Tonight ( Aug. 22) there didn't seem to be as many - maybe only 200- 300 but I didn't have time to really take note.

As for sources of nectar - my flower bed has a bunch of white phlox in bloom right now, but I don't see butterflies on it much. Right next door is a field of alfalfa hay that is in bloom and 1/4 mile down the road a field of corn in tassel ( don't know if this is a nectar source) This is fairly well cultivated farm land, so not too much meadow or marginal land with Joe Pye Weed for at least a mile from here.

We can`t remember a year with so many Monarchs.For about 2 weeks they have been migrating south .My husband saw a whole Roost while golfing Sunday morning .Hundreds where waiting for the warming sun .He did see them all take of .Awesome . Anybody we talk to has the same thing to .SOOOOOOOOOOOO many Monarchs going Home .

Today I was contacted by Dennis Barry, who has seen large numbers of monarchs ("thousands") roosting in Thickson's Woods on the north shore of Lake Ontario at Whitby. They are roosting in a "hole"or clearing in this small but ecologically significant remenant of forest (http://thicksonswoods.com/, a spot favorite with birdwatchers. I recall hearing a few years ago of monarchs roosting in such a habitat by Dr. Kingston Leong of California.

Fortunately, my work took me past Whitby to Oshawa today, and on the way back to Toronto to visit this site. At 2:30 pm, scores of monarchs were flying inside this opening in the forest (the sky was becoming overcast and they may have been looking for a site to rest). There were many trees and tree branches in this opening, and the monarchs were settling on these as well as on tree leaves.

The property on the lake side of the property is privately owned and there are a number of homes.I came across one amazing garden filled with flowering plants and a few buddleia shrubs. There were many monarchs nectaring here.

These are the pictures I took on Aug. 14th starting about an hour before sunset.On Aug. 14th I took my first round of pictures of a smaller group which collected on the south row of maples. This group grew over the next few days to the bunch on Aug. 21st.This shows the flashing behaviour while the others are mostly with folded wings.

This is a view to the east and slightly south. The 3 maple trees spread across the middleground are not part of the tightly grouped bunch around the house. The Butterflies prefer the south side of 2 particular trees, with a few smaller clusters in adjacent trees.

The biggest group was spectacular, but the pictures didn't turn out because of the fading light and all I got was silhouettes which didn't show the difference between leaves and butterflies.

Aprroximately 7pm I spotted dozens of monarchs roosting in the lowest branches of a black walnut tree in my yard. I have several photos and video of them. Within 1/2 hour, there were hundreds of them. I checked again at midnight and they were still all there. It was raining all last evening, over night and this morning. By 8:30am this morning, only a few stragglers remained.

Wednesday 23rd Yvette saw the same thing regarding Monarchs as reported at Thickson’s Woods at Whitby, Ontario - scores, if not hundreds of fresh looking monarchs settling to roost in openings in hedgerows along a trail near Sandbanks where she walks the dog. It was late afternoon but it was clouding over. Should be lots around for the next couple of weeks.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I had to drop off my son near the Oakville Harbour and took a quick look this morning before temperatures rose above flight threshold.I counted 7 small roosts of 5-25 butterflies each. There were others just leaving the roosts and returning to the nectar sources.We are approaching what my records show to be the peak (around Sept 3-5) for such behaviour. Taggers may want to visit this location which is the south west pier of the mouth of 16 mile Creek entering Lake Ontario.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We saw the first few monarchs roosting on our trees last week Monday, the 14th. We thought that was a bit early. We have had increasingly more of them since, and have had a lot of them in our yard all day today. It is very cool today- around 60 degrees. We had a couple of storms come through, with a total of 1  3/4 inches of rain, winds and some hail. We were worried about the monarchs, but they clung to the tree, and seem to have come through it fine! We don't remember ever having this many monarchs roosting in our yard, we are excited!!
school: Not a school, a mother and 2 children

comments: We are starting ro see the Monarchs gathering in the trees.
hundred of butterfly are in our trees this year. We have never seen it before. everyday more and more are here.

We've had a cabin here for 8 years and this is the first time we've ever seen them roost.  As a member of Journey North and a teacher that is dedicated to monarch preservation and education, I am excited beyond belief!-Val PrestonThis is the first experience of monarch roosting I've ever seen and I enjoyed every second of it--Micaela Preston

We have sighted the monarch butterfly consistently during the last 2weeks in east end of Hamilton.  That location is approximately one miles from the city of Stoney Creek. It has only been during the last couple of days when we have seen increasing numbers; in the hundreds in our backyard.

Spotted clusters of Monarch butterflies clinging to pines needles of both an Austrian pine and White Spruce tree at our house around 5:30 PM (8/25/06) in the evening. They stayed until 8:00 the next morning when all but a few were gone. This was only a partial shot of our Austrian pine. There were maybe twice as many in the tree.

This one was taken in our White Pine tree.
Several hundred monarch butterflies roosting in black-walnut trees at approx. 7 pm. in evening. Also feeding at the butterfly bushes throughout the back yard.
Aprox 1000 in my yard roosting on a cloudy ovecast day

I live in a small village called Port Dalhousie which is part of St. Catharines, Ontario Canada.

I spotted a couple of monarchs yesterday in my back yard and said to my husband I hope they land in our yard by the hundreds as they did a few years back. Well,this time,( today....4:31PM, August 28th, 2006) they picked the neighbour's back yard and they are there now by the hundreds. Why Port Dalhousie? We assume because it is the first land they can light at after flying across Lake Ontario!? It's too bad that Monarch watch doesn't have a site that someone can access without being a MEMBER! OR I COULD HAVE ADVISED THEM HOURS AGO and sent them photos.
100's of butterflys are roosting in our pine and maple trees - they have been here for 3 days/nights.

Sunday morning they were flying around in large numbers.  during the afternoon they began to roost in a black walnut tree on the south of the house (but on the north of the tree).  By evening they numbered above 100, possibly 200 and had moved to other black walnut, maple, & beechnut trees, still south of house & on north, low hanging branches.  This morning 8/28/2006 they moved to a Norway maple & pine on the east of the house.  This afternoon to a bunch of black walnuts on the north of the house.  Roosting & occasionally flying.  Damp cloudy humid both days.

As my wife and I rode down the Genesee Valley Greenway about 2 miles south of Scottsville we were suddenly surrounded by thousands of Monarchs Monday evening 8/28 we went back last night with a camera since it had rained all day and they were still there the evening of 8/29.  Magical!

It's 8:00 p.m. and this is the first evening this fall that we have observed small numbers (5) of monarchs coming to our oak trees to roost. (Each year we observe monarchs roosting in both our red and bur oak trees. The monarchs seem to prefer to roost on the long thin leafless branches that face west and that receive the last light and warmth of the sunset.) We'll be watching for more coming to roost in the days to come

The sun finally came out & we thought they had left.  By tonight they are back in full numbers.  Some are still in the black walnut trees to the north of the house but the majority have moved to a group of maples to the south of the house.  The roosts(?) are facing the west where they could catch the last of the sun.
At least 75 stopped by the farm tonite and roosted on the tree's.

September 13
No increase in this area. I only see one or two a day at my place. Far fewer larva on my milkweeds both here and at school. At school this year we will raise and tag maybe 30 (all found by teachers or students) where usually we would raise 200 or so.

We are still finding a few larva just far less than we usually find. Many years we find a little flush of larva the 2nd week in Sept. still hoping this might happen.

August 30
Lowest monarch numbers in 11 years that I have been at this location.

Today is perfect weather for monarchs--80ºF, sunny and low winds--yet I just walked out to my flower patch and there were only 15 or so.

For this season, 15 is pretty good. Most years I would have hundreds or thousands.

I hesitate to make generalizations as there are so many variables, but I feel this has been a very poor year for monarch production in my area.

I went out and walked my tree-line at dusk yesterday and found only two monarchs roosting. I have yet to tag a single monarch this year.

We did have quite a drought in this area, virtually no rain for over 4 weeks and many days in the 90's. About half my liatris died as we were gone during a critical period when it needed water.

The loss of 1/2 of my most important nectar plants makes it more difficult for me to compare this year to others. (I still have some plants in fact probably more than I had the first 3 years we lived here

We are looking forward to a busy season. A friend of mine, who lives in NY near Rochester, called and said that there are thousands of Monarchs along the lake shore up there. He was very excited that the Monarchs were already roosting in large masses.

Contributed by Louise Zemaitas, monarch coordinator on Cape May, NJ.
First day to see monarchs roosting this year.  Approximately 500 in the trees.  Wind of 20 mph from the south.

At 7:30pm on Aug. 30, 2006 I observed a large number of monarch butterflies roosting in trees along the edge of our woods.  Several butterflies were swooping and fluttering overhead as well.  It was cloudy and also starting to get dark so it was difficult to estimate the number of butterflies.  I observed clumps of 8-10 buterflies on several lower branches.  I am guessing that many more butterflies were present, but it was too gloomy for me to see them .

Monarchs were roosting in the lower branches of the very tall cottonwood trees in the yard After crossing Lake Ontario from Canada. Aprox. 400. Previous years they have roosted in the  pine trees on the same property

We went to mow our back yard and noticed as we came upon the trees there are thousands of monarchs perched in the trees!  We have NEVER seen anything like this in our lives!  It is the most amazing and beautiful thing!  We have 4 or 5 trees that they seem to favor and they are just clustered in them.... this started about a week or so ago when we noticed a few and thought, "how nice!"  Then gradually more and more came and we realized something amazing was happening!  We are hoping this in not going to be one of those 'once in a lifetime' things as this is the first year we have lived in this home.
On 8/31/06 we watched group after group of monarchs landing in a tree. This continued over the next two days. Then on the morning of 9/3/06 they all flew off.

Although they've arrived about 10 days earlier than normal, I have seen hundreds of monarchs resting in tall evergreens on the cloudy days and feeding on tropical milkweed on the sunny days. I've tagged about 50 so far and am now expecting one of the biggest migrations ever to pass through Central IL. Perhaps they have arrived earlier because there are are so many this year, or maybe they know something about the weather that we don't - like maybe an early winter?

We were visiting in Lakeville, and some young kids were excited because of all the Monarchs that were roosting in a nearby Ash tree.  We could count about 15 in the roost with many more flying around.

There are literally THOUSANDS of Monarchs in a variety of trees in my aunt's orchard! They are beautiful! I first thought they were bats because they are so numerous. What an AMAZING sight to see! Wow...My three young sons were mesmerized as well. What a blessing of beauty!

We observed tons of Monarchs on the branches of our trees. I don't really know how many there were, at least 100? They were on the trees in our front yard and back yard. This is first time we've seen them migrating and my 2 year old son was so excited. He loves watching butterflies flying around the yard.

The monarch roost was in a silver maple by our house.  There were approximately 80 on one branch.  Binocular sightings showed smaller groupings on other branches of a nearby tree.  They were still gathered at 7 a.m., but left by 8 a.m. today (9-4-06)

There are hundreds, perhaps a thousand Monarchs, but less than last year. Though I only saw them in the morning last year as I just had moved here. The area is mostly farmland so there are not a lot of areas with clusters of trees, but there happens to be a small wood lot next to this school (on the west side) They seem to like certain trees better than others, I'll have to check out species once they leave.

I first noticed the monarchs last week when I was mowing around the trees. As of today, 9-5-06 they are still at our farm and we estimate them to number several thousand. They roost in the cedar trees and pine trees at night and when they get warmed up in the morning they fly. They have come to this farm for many years but this is the first time we have noticed so many.

September 18
On the 18th I was mowing by the cedar trees and the monarchs were starting to settle down for the night and I noticed that there were not as many as the previous week. I would say there were approx. 1 to 2 thousand on the tree(s). On Tuesday, they were gone and I haven't seen a monarch since. It has been cool and rainy. We will anxiously wait for their return next year.

This was the last day that I saw moncarchs roosting in my maples. The week before was cooler than normal with winds out of the east and southeast ( not usual for around here ). The butterflies changed their roosts to the north sides of the trees around my house, still choosing lower branches and clustering in groups of 10 to 200. Then, as the wind returned to its usual west, north west direction, the butterflies were gone.  Since then I have only seen a couple of stragglers.One confused fellow joined the moths fluttering furiously on my kithchen window for a couple of hours after dark and spent two nights roosting under my front porch. On Tues. Sept 5th there was a solitary butterfly around 6:30 pm, searching the regular roost sites, almost landing then moving on.

I observed several Monarchs roosting in a maple tree all day today.  It has been a slightly breezy but sunny day, with a high temperature of about 77 degrees F.  There were about 100 butterflies, some roosting and some flying just nearby.  I saw them this morning, and then again this afternoon at about 4 pm central time.
Cluster of monarchs resting in tree, probably after flying across Lake Erie to shore west of Cleveland. Reported to me by a neighbor.

Today in the portlands (Toronto waterfront) here in Toronto between the hours of 9am and 11am I watched in amazement as 1700 Monarch Butterflies moved though the city !

Some stop to nectar on blooming Bamboo which got me thinking of the mess my next door neighbour here in High Park has in his back yard (which is full of Bamboo). When I got home, the back yard had 57 monarchs flying and now going to roost for the night .....

Edit's note: Contributed by Don Davis:Craig McLauchlan is an outstanding birdwatcher and Toronto naturalist who lives in the High Park area ofToronto
Folks,Wow; walking the dog in our back yard tonight I stumbled on a roost of several hundred (~300) monarchs in the trees and flying about.Awesome! Thank you for your work!Royal

It's been extremely active for the last two mornings. Counted nearly 200 between 9 and 10 am. Many of the trees are covered with monarchs in clusters of a few to 10 or so. They seem to favor a shady part of the property with a number of english walnut trees. I noticed that the dead leaves look a lot like the roosting monarchs...interesting.

There were 100s of them all over the maple and oak trees.

September 10
I spoke with the neighbor, and they have been there each night since the 7th! Amazing!!

We saw thousands of them last night for the first time in my life. IT was a special moment that was shared with my two boys and their great-grandmother, who had never seen anything like it either. They were in here trees just north of Sidney, Ohio. When they were running around the trees and stirred them up it turned the sky black. We played with them for over an hour catching them and releasing them.
