IT was really special because one of my boys' favorite movie is the "Little Einstiens" video about the migration of the monarch butterflies.

We had rain for most of the day and the sun just now came out (3pm). I went out for the daily count and there are hundreds, maybe thousands on the apple, honeysuckle, and walnut trees. I took lots of photos and some movies. It's staggaring to see so many and I couldn't be happier!

Here is a video clip of the "wing-flashing" behavior seen when a new monarch joins the roost:
A woman in Rosemount reported (to Jim Gilbert) that she had over 300 aggregating Monarch butterflies in her yard in Rosemount

Just a quick note to let you know that I was at Presqu'ile last Saturday and Sunday to catch the bird and Monarch migrations. Monarchs were collecting at several points, particularly Owen Point and the Lighthouse in their hundreds. There are some large flowering bushes (vibernums?) near the lighthouse that had dozens nectaring on them. Saturday was overcast and windy, so only a few butterflies were trying to fly out over Lake Ontario. They didn't get far and mostly turned back. Sunday morning was bright and relatively calm with a northerly breeze, so they were flying out from the two points heading across Lake Ontario.

Contributed by Don Davis
Monarchs roosting on Ontario Lake shore - in willow trees - approximately 3 dozen roosting in one section of the tree

This is the first time I have monarch clumping at night in my trees. Saturday the 9th I must have had a least 400. Then the tempature dropped and we have had a lot of rain. Today, the 13th is the first sunshine and I went out about 6:30 pm and have maybe 200 roosting. This is one of the coolest things I have ever seen.

Last night was the first time I'd seen enough monarchs coming in to roost to report them. After some rainy days and clearing skies, they came to spend the night. They were too high in the tree to count.

A friend's brother who lives about 1/2 hr from my home in Oxford, Ohio called to say they were seeing lots of monarchs arriving in their back yard around 4pm on Sept. 13. We arrived about an hour later to see monarchs flying around everywhere we looked. We counted a few clusters of 100 monarchs already roosting with multiple other clusters forming on  a pine and 2 ash trees. We estimated at least 500 to 600 already roosting and another few hundred flying around looking for just the right tree or branch. The migration is definitely here and right on time. Our peak dates start on Sept 14.

I live on Toronto Island where there seems to be a particularly large migratory group this year. It may be I just got lucky and had a viewing that has been consistent year to year or the group is bigger than normal. I saw several clusters in all approximately 100 butterflys. I made a short video of them nibbling and flying about a cluster of golden rod. If you would like I will try to make it a quick time email for those interested. I will show it to my students.

Camped with horses in a large 35 acre field in Newbury, NH on Sepetmber 8-10, 2006, which was covered with second cutting red clover.  The monarchs were everywhere and accompanied by a smaller all yellow butterfly that I did not recognize.

I went up to NW Ohio this last weekend to see a roost of monarchs near Ottawa OH. The home is in the middle of acres of farm fields, two fields of which are in red clover this year. Great nectaring for the butterflies! Two weeks ago, they had thousands of butterflies sheltering in his heavily-treed back yard, last week they had hundreds. I visited on Friday night when there were perhaps 4-5 hundred (and tagged 85 of them). Monday night when I last visited, the roost was down to about a hundred.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Greetings from St. Joseph's School  Several students have seen 15-20 Monarchs. Our art teacher has sighted at least 50 Monarchs roosting in her backyard.  One of our maintenance workers sighted "thousands" in the trees near his farm about ten miles south of Lincoln.

Estela Romero with her daughter.

Directly from the monarch's winter home in Mexico, Estela Romero sends these notes:

Dear Friends from Journey North:

29 octubre
It seems that today was the first day that butterflies "officially appeared"! Mr. Germán Medina was at "El Cerrito" --the small forest where butterflies make a halt before climbing up to the Sanctuaries--and could see small groups of 5, 10-20 butterflies flying around. and in town, we could see exactly the same quantities and distribution overflying us. So the big arrival will take place over the days to come now. The raining seasons seems to be over now. Since yesterday, and after very cloudy, windy and rainy weeks, we have deep blue sky and sunny days. We do have very icy cold mornings and evenings, though.

25 de octubre
Apart from the two Monarchs we saw overflying our area last week, there are still no Monarchs arriving formally. Yesterday, Mr. Germán Medina came after a visit to "El Cerrito." El Cerrito is the first place we see the monarchs settle once they arrive to the region and before they go up to the Sanctuaries. He says that there are no Monarch there on the trees. We continue to have clouds and medium-heavy rain every as "spectrum" of hurricanes affecting the Pacific Coast. So it may still take some days before the monarchs appear.

Next weekend, we are celebrating our Patron Saint in town "San Simón", it is a religious fest where processions, services and some live typical classical Mexican music (beautiful music) in the evenings take place. Firework, typical Mexican food and candies are sold too.

Many, many years ago, when the town was founded (in the late 1600's --1690--), the mining town was not called Angangueo, but "Real de San Simón". Angangueo was an Hacienda about 5 km.away from town, and none knows when and why the name Real de San Simón disappeared and the name Angangueo was taken for both Hacienda and town. For us, the word "Real", is given to a mining place, town or village, and most of them from the ones existing in our country, take the name of a Catholic Saint after.

Next week we will be celebrating our "Death's Day" which is a National Festivity. Then I will tell you about what I could get for you of this in town. In between I will make contact if there is any news of the Monarch's arrival.

23 de octubre
I was with Germán this morning asking him about any news of the monarchs' arrival, but he tells me that he thinks that there are still not an important amount arriving. However, I feel very anxious about it because the "official date of arrival" is almost here and other people also tell me that Monarchs are not yet here. So, Germán promised me that he would personally go to "El Cerrito", --where they settle on arriving-- and he will come and tell me tomorrow. I am sure there must be some groups already here, maybe not so numerous, because we've had inestable weather, in this moment, since yesterday, we are having a Hurricane passing by, after some days the last one had gone away, so for two or three days more it will be foggy, windy and rainy, which might delay arrival a little bit. I will contact you depending on the news Germán gets

18 octubre
"The very first monarchs seem to be arriving! Yes, it seems to be that it is so!" announced Estela Romero. "Today, my youngest brother saw a Monarch flying at the yard of our house!" Today the television also reported the first manadas of Monarchs arriving to overwinter with us!More...

12 octubre
One more week, and no butterfly at sight. It seems that it will continue raining for some more days, and this might be a reason not to have any sign yet. I asked a couple of people coming from up the mountains and Mr. German Medina but they have no news either. The town is very, very quiet. People directly involved in the butterfly season, are preparing themselves manufacturing crafts, a restaurant owner reopened his restaurant one week ago, seems to be. Children at school know now that the time is coming closer to receive your letters and we are all happy that they will arrive days earlier than in former years.

5 octubre
I am not in Angangueo for several days. I'm writing from a city about 200 km away called, Querètaro, which is the capital city of the State of Querètaro. I phoned Germàn Medina to hear about any possible news about Monarchs seen. He told me there is still no sign of them!

28 de septiembre
No big news here. It seems as if the rainy season will be over in three to four weeks now. We start to have some sunny mornings.

21 de septiembre
We have no Monarch butterflies in sight yet. The whole region around Angangueo is having heavy rain, but we are lucky that we are not heavily hit by hurricanes as people are on the coast. Temperatures are ranging from 10 and sometimes reaching 20 Celcious degrees when it gets sunny.

14 de septiembre
Up to now, there are no signs of Monarchs here. Actually today I was asking some people coming from el Rosario about the monarchs' return. They say it is still too soon to see any; they say that perhaps in a couple or weeks or even a little more. Germán Medina is also continuing to see after the monarchs' arrival. I will let you know!

7 de septiembre
Up to now, nobody has seen any butterflies here. It is raining really hard, as we hadn't seen in some years anymore. It is most of the times cloudy, and very rainy, but not cold at all.

I was walking my dogs about 6:00PM on Sept. 1 and noticed 2 monarchs flying around.  I had not seen many all summer. Suddenly there were 3 more and then as we walked closer to a weeping willow tree, a large bunch of monarchs took to wing. Without being able to count them, I would estimate several hundred butterflies were scattered in the trees. In all, they were roosting in about 10 large trees.  They were hard to spot when they were roosting, but the minute we walked under the trees, they would fly around.  The weather was cool - upper 50s over night.  On Saturday, Sept. 2, we had cool, rainy weather.  The monarchs stayed around all day.  On Sunday, there were less, and then by Monday they were gone.  Interestingly, on Wednesday, Sept. 6, a friend who lives about 1/2 mile south of me had a very large group of several hundred monarchs roost in trees around her house and stay until Sunday, Sept 10.
I noticed last night we had about 50 monarches in one of our walnut trees, and decided to search out some information about their migration

Sunday (Sept 10th) was without a doubt an amazing sight to behold at the park (Holiday Beach Migration Observatory ). The entire day was cloudy, winds from the South at 10-15mph and temperature remained between 55-60 degrees F. Every Monarch that flew into the park, remained at the park in small roosts between 100-200 butterflies per tree: every other tree in the SW corner of the park was filled with Monarchs. This was amazing to see but the bad news was that ALL of the Monarchs were out of my reach! Yes, these Monarchs were gathering in the cottonwoods 50-60 feet above the ground. An occasional five or ten would flutter off the leaves, then return to their roost - always beyond the reach of my net. If I only had a cherry picker or one of those machines the hydro workers use to maneuver about the lines and trees.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Have seen only about two or three monarchs each day this week therefore I was surprised when there were about fifteen in my cedar trees this evening. I was able to tag seven.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
Thousands of butterflies in the hedge trees and along the dry creek bed.

10 Monarch butterflies spotted roosting overnight in a tree on the north west side of my yard.  Overnight temp 63.  Wind Speed: 10 mph  Wind Dir: 150° (SSE) at 9/16/06 sunrise.  First light came over north edge of house to roosting spot.

Sorry this is so late but we were on a trip.Saw a monarch roost of about 50 monarchs at 9Am just outside of Kempton, Illinois in a grove of pine trees surrounding a home. Owner said they roost there every year. Agricultural fields all around in the area with roadsides mostly mowed. But there is a restored prairie of about 20 acres about 1 mile away.

A friend's brother who lives about 1/2 hr from my home in Oxford, Ohio called to say they were seeing lots of monarchs arriving in their back yard around 4pm on Sept. 13. We arrived about an hour later to see monarchs flying around everywhere we looked. We counted a few clusters of 100 monarchs already roosting with multiple other clusters forming on a pine and 2 ash trees. We estimated at least 500 to 600 already roosting and another few hundred flying around looking for just the right tree or branch. The migration is definitely here and right on time. Our peak dates start on Sept 14.

This is the first time I have monarch clumping at night in my trees. Saturday the 9th I must have had a least 400. Then the tempature dropped and we have had a lot of rain. Today, the 13th is the first sunshine and I went out about 6:30 pm and have maybe 200 roosting. This is one of the coolest things I have ever seen.

I found several clumps of roosting monarchs today in some silver maple trees near a long clover rich strip that borders a farm field. About 7 feet up, 3 small branches in one tree had an estimated 60 monarchs roosting on them! This evening I went to some white pines in another area where I saw maybe 20 monarchs last night but tonight there were none there. One of the ones I saw there last night was easily half the size of a normal adult!!

I am familiar with the Painted Lady but the one I saw was definitely a miniature monarch. I checked to see it was a Viceroy but it wasn't. It was just out of my reach clinging on a white pine branch in the cool of the evening.

There was a normal sized adult monarch within a foot of it and others nearby. I carefully compared it with the normal one closest to it. I don't want to estimate the inches but to be as accurate as I can it was no more than 60% normal size and probably more like 50%. I have seen small adults that came from caterpillars that went into the chrysalis stage early, always because they had been captured and didn't have absolutely fresh leaves after that. This one was a little smaller than the smallest of the captives I've ever seen though. It may have been a captive that was released.

9/13/06
I saw over 100 butterflies near Geist Reservoir. They were fluttering and fanning their wings. They were on bushes, not feeding. The weather was humid and had rained the night before. Later at home I saw the monarchs. They were gathering on an ash tree in a sheltered area near Fort Harrison Park. They seemed to congregate on two branches of this tree. Again fanning and quiet. Occasionally fluttering in the small secluded area of my back yard.

9/14/06
It rained overnight. I wondered "Where do butterflies go in the rain?" Sure enough the next morning there they were, on the same two branches. Coloration dull. At around 9:00 saw some fluttering brighened wings but no sun to reflect.

9/15 - 9/16
The monarchs have gone. Saw only one butterfly on the 16th.

On Saturday, 9/16/06, there were Monarch Butterflies in the hundreds roosting in my hedge row and flying around my yard (1 acre at the edge of town.  On Sunday (9/17/06) many were still there...some had left.  Today (9/18/06)after a large rain there were a few flying around my yard.  It was a beautiful sight!  The first time I have seen it happen.

September 17: Another migration pulse.
Today a moderately big migration brought in at least 100 monarchs to our garden at home (and at Sweet Briar College). At 7 PM, as the sun went behind the mountains, at least 60 monarchs were clustering for the night in an oak and a Magnolia up on the hill behind the Buddleas. Really pretty to see them......

We went up near Mt. Mitchell (got there about 4 p.m.) to see if we could see the monarch migration, and sure enough, there it was. It was pretty cloudy and overcast, but the monarchs kept coming in. Many of them stopped off to nectar on the flowers next to the overlook. My friend Judy and her sister showed up after about half an hour (we'd agreed to meet there) and Judy had brought her tags, so Doug and I netted 25 and we tagged them. We could have netted hundreds if we'd been there all day and had enough tags. The butterflies were easy to catch because they were nectaring.

But the most interesting thing was that for the first time ever, we saw monarchs roosting in clusters down here in NC. There were some dying hemlocks downslope from the flowers, and the monarchs flew down there after nectaring, and roosted in clumps on a few of the branches. They were also roosting in a few places on the big leaves of what looked like a frazer magnolia. When they had their wings closed it was almost impossible to see them but when a new one would approach, the ones that were already roosted would open and flutter their wings, and then you could see the orange, and the movement. We estimated that there were hundreds, perhaps 1,000 (maybe more) monarchs roosted there when we left at 6 p.m. and there were still monarchs nectaring on the wildflowers (snakeroot, goldenrod and purple asters, with the snakeroot the favorite). It was a wonderful sight. There were so many flying around before they settled into the clusters that it looked the way it does around a beehive--just constant motion against a backdrop of trees. I am SO glad we went up there. Another monarch memory to store away. (Location: Three miles north of the turnoff to Mt. Mitchell State Park, on the Blue Ridge Parkway.)
Several hundred monarchs roosted in the old maple tree in our yard.
Many monarchs in local trees.

Observed hundreds of Monarchs sunning themselves on trees on the south edge of my timber area.  Located 2 miles south of railroad line that is on the South side of Red Oak.  There were mature butterflies and most of them looked younger or smaller.  There were a sight to behold!!!
I believe there was 1000 to 3000 that were in the treeline down the edge of my yard. I checked again on 9/18/06 and most were gone but they chowed down on my leaves.

The Monarchs arrive in my yard every fall. The last two years were the most populated years. Sometimes the Monarchs stay for 2 to 4 days, roosting in my trees. I would estimate that there were between 500 to 1000 monarchs roosting this year. I first noticed them on Saturday, September the 16th. The weather turned cooler late on the 18th and, the next day, the monarchs were gone.

I have had them in this same area of my yard every year for at least the last 6 years. It is an overwhelming sight that I always love to share.

Each year the monarchs roost in hemlock trees and this year they were also in nearby cypress, willow, flowering crab, and pin oak trees. The only flowers close by are zinnias. I always notice that when the roost is disturbed in anyway or by a new arrival of a monarch they flutter their wings for a short time and then settle back down with only closed wings.

(I took this picture on Monday, September 18th.)
Small clusters of Monarchs (5) roosting in butterfly bush

We were the absolute luckiest people on the planet this evening! Several hundred monarch butterflies decided our yard was an ideal roost. With several large trees and tons of ziennas and mairgolds and spider flowers the monarches spent more than 1 and 1/2 hours landing in an ash tree. It was amazing, they came in from every direction and waltzed around looking for the perfect spot. I have seen roost trees before, but not in my yard! It still leaves me breathless, even got a few pictures!

Yesterday was a beautiful day in our Smithville area although the temperatures were cooler. We were experiencing temperatures in the low 60s. Our sixth grade class is approximately 105 kids and last night's numbers were pretty high...over 200 monarchs were spotted. Kids saw a lot on their way home from school which is between 2:30 and 3:30 which would have been in the heat of the day. Most they saw were flying and one girl noted a southerly direction as indicated by her grandfather. Another boy noticed over 100 monarchs roosting on a tree in a nearby woods. Many are dining on the fall flowers such as Mexican sunflowers, morning glory, zinnias, butterfly bushes, hostas, milkweed, and among the cornstalks. Unfortunately, we are finding some that are dead due to car grill accidents or otherwise. Some have been seen near water. Today is windy and much cooler...not out of the 50s. We will report our findings for today tomorrow.
Roost lasted for nine days, filling the surrounding pine trees. Roost ended with unusually cold night temperatures.

Began tagging here on the 14th but only occasional monarchs the last several days. Today saw a definite increase in numbers despite strong breezes. Multiple clusters of (10-15) this evening in my cedar trees, I was able to tag 57.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Approximately 100 monarchs were sighted at Gilgo Beach in Long Island, New York. The butterflies stopped and roosted before crossing the Atlantic Ocean. I assume they try to stay close to shorelines? (Take a look at the Atlantic Ocean at Gilgo Beach: Link to Web cam)

September 23
After roosting last night, many stayed this morning to wait out the storms. Strong southerly winds are keeping them on the north side of the trees. I estimate 650 on one tree and there are many more places they are roosting around the yard. I counted 30 more landing in 5 minutes. The sky is swirling with them.

September 22
Strong storms started to move in late afternoon and we had a lot of monarchs stop and roost for the night. Wind is coming from the south and they are roosting on the north side of trees. Here they survived the large thunderstorms that dumped 1.5 inches of rain in 5 minutes not far from here. I'm having a hard time counting. I'm guessing around 700 last night on this one english walnut tree.

We had warm weather that suddenly turned cool, we noticed several hundred to a thousand monarchs clinging together and at the tops of our spruce trees and in our woods, they remaind there for two nights then this morning the weather turned warmer and the sun came out. They became more active and are flying around. This is the first year we have noticed this and we have lived here 17 yrs.

There were literally hundreds of monarchs in the trees in the nature preserve near Cape May Point, waiting for the right conditions to cross the Delaware Bay. Saw 20-25 monarchs coming in off of the ocean at 10:30 a.m. through 11:30 a.m.; it got quite windy for the rest of the weekend.

Although we were to have a wet weekend, the rain was light and the temperature warm. In addition, it did not rain the whole weekend as was forecasted. My students saw a lot of butterflys this weekend. If they weren't flying, they were eating on butterfly bushes and other nectar producing flowers. There was a pretty good wind on Saturday and many were fighting the updrafts to get to the flowers. Once individual saw approximately 23 roosting in a tree and another saw a fairly large group flying together. Altogether, my students and I saw over 100 monarchs this weekend. I still have a female hummingbird eating on my butterfly bush and feeder. I was suprised that it was still around.

I was in Cape May on Saturday and Sunday and was amazed by the roosts! I had never seen that before- I can't imagine how great it would be in Mexico or even California. I met monarch enthusiasts, even some monarch watchers. I would say there was between 500-1000 butterflies on one empty lot- Louise said they were there for the English ivy that was in bloom- they were also hanging out on the cedar trees.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We have been seeing groups of monarchs now for two - three weeks.  We have just noticed evening roosting spots here in  Sidney and 15 miles away in Nebraska City, NE. we're still finding caterpillars and eggs on the milkweed plants.
Approximately 100 monarchs were roosting in my cedar trees.  Still a few left

This morning, I received a call from a woman in Keller, Texas, just north of Fort Worth. She reported counting between 50 and 60 monarchs in her hackberry tree this morning.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife

There were thousands of monarch butterflies in the largest tree on the back of our lot.  They literally covered the branches.  Some fluttered around the tree but most rested on the tree.  This was the most awesome thing we have ever seen.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Beverly on Rt. 97 just past the Wenham line in thevicinity of Beverly Municipal Airport and nearby Wenham Lake

Here Icounted 1,000 or more Monarchs. Many were roosting in trees and manymore were nectaring at asters and goldenrod. Some individual asterplants had 10 to 15 Monarchs clustered upon them. This had to be thebiggest congregation of Monarchs in many years in Essex County,especially in areas near the coast. In one of my previous posts Ireported a huge abundance of them in Maine and so predicted this greatinflux we are witnessing now. As long as the days are still mellow andwarm and nights cool but frost free, we should still see theseimpressive aggregations for at least another week or so.

Reported to the MassLep listserv:

Not only are there the thousands reported for Gooseberry Neck and other places, they're still up here on the North Shore too!

This evening 9/26 Joe Stichter walked out across the marsh road to the end of Nelson's Island in Rowley (part of Parker River NWR). Between about 5:45 and 6:30 p.m., as the western sun warmed the area, he saw 2,000 to 3,000 (estimate) Monarchs, all clustered on every available stalk of seaside goldenrod which lines the edge of Nelson's Island. There were more on the many asters in bloom. An amazing sight. Then, as the sun began to set, he saw them all begin to rise and move en masse toward the tall oak and other trees back on the land---presumably they are now there roosting in the trees overnight.

Oh, my gosh! I have never seen monarchs roost before! It was amazing. This really makes you realize how many times that our busy work schedules make us miss the treasures in this world.

We live in the Ozarks and our house is surrounded by woods. The roost occurred in two trees - a red oak and a white oak. The numbers started off small and even as I type continue to grow. There are hundreds now! I have pictures if anyone wants me to e-mail them some. 5:50 PM

At our house we counted 63 monarchs. They were circling our hackberry tree. They cluttered together to sleep.  I caught a monarch butterfly by swinging my net back and forth. I was so excited.We had been watching for a whole month and only seeing 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 9.  These butterflies were flying south at car height because the wind was from the south.written by second grader

At approximately 6 PM we counted 400 monarchs flying west to Cupsogue Beach (the most western part of Dune Road), Westhampton Beach, Long Island...We then counted approximately 100 very slow moving monarchs settling in the trees nearest to the path aprroaching the boardwalk...The follwing evening 9/26/06 we traveled just half an hour earlier and none flying west...We found about 50...quite active compared to the previous evening, getting ready to 'roost?'..When we drove back east we saw about 50 approaching the same trees at Cupsogue Beach...On Thursday evening 9/28/06 we saw none at the same spots

There were 80 to 100 groups like this in a quarter mile stretch!

My wife and I have owned our ranch 20 miles northeast of Sweetwater, Texas for 6 years now. We have experienced the fall roost every year and have been excited this week anticipating the Monarchs arrival. We have a creek that runs about one mile though the property with huge willow trees lining it. There is a very grassy area with abundant milkweed mixed in on the north side of the creek. It is like a custom made roost environment for our traveling friends, and they continue to come back and roost at the exact same place every year, and always within a day or two either side of October 1! It is one of our favorite features of our ranch. I checked for their arrival last night at 7:00 pm, and saw about 300 early arrivals. By 5:00 pm today (9/29/06), the trees and grass were litterally filled. Last year I submitted pictures and estimated as many as 20,000 roosted for two nights with us. This year I estimate the same number although it could easily be twice that many. It is amazing. I would be happy to take digital pictures in the morning (I'm assuming they will still be here) and submit if you would like! Just let me know! Thanks and thanks for your excellent web site.

A group taking flight when I walked by!

Another group taking flight!

Another group just "Hanging Around"!

Just a close-up I liked

I counted 5 Monarchs in 5 minutes today on the trip back to work from lunch.  Monarchs were nectaring on the butterfly bushes in the backyard this afternoon.  I counted 7 at one time.  Later in the afternoon Monarchs were going to roost in the oak, pine, hackberry and sweet gum trees.  I noticed that even the Monarchs that were nectaring on the butterfly bushes flew almost to the tops of the trees to pick out a roosting spot.  These oak trees are 60-70 feet tall.  The majority of the Monarchs seem to prefer the oaks for roosting.  The butterflies were arriving at an average rate of about 2 per minunte.  This went on for about 45 minutes.  A strong cold front came through yesterday.  Our morning low temperature was 45 degrees.  Today has been mostly sunny with increasing high clouds and light winds.  My observation ended at 6:25PM CDT and the temperature was 63F.

I observed approximatley 1000-1500 monarch butterflies gathering on trees at Gibson Island Maryland, on Mountan Bar Point. Mountain Bar Point is the very tip of the island where the Cheasapeake Bay and the Magathy River meet. My mom told me when she was a little girl my age (10) the butterflies were always there at the end of September and then began their migration.

About 5:30 PM, I noticed monarch butterflies arriving to roost in a butterfly bush on Allen Road, Bayville, NJ 08721There may have been about 20 at this time; did spot other single monarchs flying around in the neighborhoood

Approximate 1,000 monarch butterflies where clinging to the stalks of the Wild Golden Rod behind the dunes at the sound end of the Stone Harbor beach.  Not fearful to up close observations. At approximately 11:00 AM.  Mild breeze and sunny, great for photo's.

Observed hundreds of Monarchs on our property here at Camp Grady Spruce. Only the larger Live Oak groves and Gum Bumelia groves have the huge "Monarch Fall Outs". They hit two tree clumps harder due to the proximity of the food (Sunflowers, Salt Cedar and Milk Weed.)

I saw about 50-75 Monarchs is the trees and along the natural springs area of Turtle Creek Blvd! It's an area that is off the beaten path so only a few of us are able to enjoy this secret sanctuary. Absolutely breathtaking!

I noticed a large number of Monarch Butterflies (hundreds) in the late morning of 9/28/06. They swarmed into the woods adjacent to my house and began to cluster on the tree branches. By nightfall there were thousands in the surrounding woods which comprise the Ozark National Forest. After spending the night, they left the next morning after the temperature rose and presented a spectacular sight as they flew through the forest and across a deep valley.

Around 9:00 am, my class counted 6 Monarchs flying past our weather station during our weather observations. We recorded a temperature of 78 degrees at the time. Later in the afternoon, I recieved a report from my mother in Wynne, AR (about 20 miles south of Harrisburg)that her pecan tree limbs were loaded with hundreds of Monarchs around 11:00 am. The temperature was in the low 80s. At about 5:00 pm, she reported that many had left but she could count about two hundred or so still resting on the tree limbs. Several Monarchs were also flying about the yard.

The Monarchs are roosting in the woods behind our property.  The woods are on U.S. Army Corps of Engineers land.  There are quite a number of them congregating on understory trees along a dry creek bed.  We first noticed them Oct.1st and they are still there today, Oct. 5th, 2006.  They have roosted in this same area in years past.
Heavy migration this morning. The oak trees were loaded with Monarchs. A little cooler than it has been in the other mornings.

They are HERE! Our visitors came a few at a time and them on Thursday, 10/05/06, the Monarch Butterflies came by the 100s to their old Roosts north and north-east edge of the city of Bronte on the Kickapoo Creek (which is dry now). They come back to the same places every year. We have taken beautiful pictures of them. How long they will stay is anyones guess? Probably until the next cool front begins to send cooler gentle winds our way which may be this week end or the first part of next week. But for now, we are enjoying our visitors passing through. They look large and healthy, but seems like there are not as many as have been here before.
I saw about 10 monarch in a tree in my front yard and about 3 in my back yard flying low to the ground.

I saw only two monarchs during this week, however, a woman I visited with 20 miles to the east in Lane, Kansas, had around 40-50 on Monday and Tuesday evening, Oct. 2nd and 3rd, in and around a large pear tree. We discovered 3 larva in Waystation #148, all 4th instars, on the 2nd at Osawatomie, Kansas. This morning I have already seen three coming back from Ottawa, Kansas.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

10/7/06, 4-5:30 PM, Ft Griffin State Park, on nature trails by the river. Approximate temp: 80-85 degrees. Wind approx 2-10 mph, but no wind on trails where sighting occurred (drops down about 15-30 feet below the level of the park). Slightly overcast.

Approximate count: 2 to 3 thousand Monarchs (conservative estimate), roosting in trees within 50 feet from the shore. Seemed to have an affinity for American Elm and Hackberry trees, on lower branches, about 50% roosted on trees less than 10 feet tall. Other types of trees with only a singleton or two roosting included cedar elm and pecan. I believe I saw one tagged Monarch, but cannot be sure as I didn’t have a net. I lost sight of her/him in the flurry of a few hundred that took flight as I slowly walked down the trail. Looking back as we passed, all resumed a new roosting spot within a couple of minutes. I witnessed this roosting behavior at this site about 10 years ago, but there were many more the last time.
For several days now the monarchs having been roosting in our backyard trees. Beautiful sight to see!
There is some roosting in the trees, but they are spread out, and not clustered.
There are about 200 Monarch roosting in this particular area.  But they are spread out, and not clustered.
Heavy migration this morning. The oak trees were loaded with Monarchs. A little cooler than it has been in the other mornings.
We saw about 6 groups of about 30 monarchs were roosting in pine trees at Jones Beach.
The Monarchs were flying around the beach and the dunes in Fire Island, New York, about 40 miles east of New York City. They were also alighting by the dozens in pine trees.

Just recaptured a monarch that was tagged in our butterfly garden here at the Oklahoma City Zoo yesterday. Today (10/10) weather has turned cooler with off and on rain through the a.m. Cloud cover thinned slightly at around 1:00 p.m. until about 2:00 p.m. temp warmed to 62-64 f. While strolling through the garden I saw about 10 come out of the trees to nectar in the garden. No directional flight observed even after I disturbed them, they were determined to nectar.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

This morning at 6 a. m. there were 2 monarchs in the trees behind my rent house. None anywhere else that I could see. I will take a short drive to see what kind of movement we have scattered through the thicket after the sun comes up and the monarchs have a chance to warm up a bit and take to the air.

Temps this morning 65.7. Light fog. No wind.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I have noticed Monarchs trickling through this area on their journey south for the last two weeks.  Today, however, a steady stream of these amazing and beautiful creatures moved over our 100 acre, undeveloped property. They are roosting in a semi-dry creek ravine among the leaves of centuries old Live Oaks and Cotton Wood trees.  Such a joy to see!

Estimate 100+ in gardens in Meredith, N.H. village  center.Unfortuneately,gardens next to highway{large Inn},some being hit.Educational opp. re; planting of flower gardens along highways in migration paths?-John S.
about 200 roosting in hackberry trees
about 400-500 roosting in hackberry trees

I was on the University of North Texas campus when I saw the monarchs. I have seen sightings posted for the UNT campus near the Environmental Science building, but this is not where I saw them. I was actually looking near the Coliseum, up in the shade, where there are lots of trees. I didn't think there would be any since Tuesday the 10th was rainy and it was beginning to get cold. There weren't a countless amount here, but I saw a pretty good small group of them! They all flew away before I could get any pictures :(  I think they are heading out of this area now.

By Dr. Chip Taylor, Monarch Watch:

The Jeffers had discovered a field of goldenrods that was covered with monarchs. It was not just a field but 1000 acres of CRP land (Conservation set-aside) in which the monarchs numbered in the thousands. In the email the text read ""hundreds of thousands" monarchs on a 10 acre field of goldenrods. The density is at least 100 monarchs per square meter." Given the email statement about 10 acres, I asked V three times about the size of the area and she assured me each time that it was a thousand acres. When I asked about the estimate of the number of monarchs, V told me that their best guess is that 40-50 thousand monarchs were using the area at one time.

The monarchs arrived on Saturday the 7th and V and Carl have been making trips to the location each morning and evening since then. V gave this description of the exodus from the field each evening.

About 6:15 the monarchs begin to leave the flowers and head for the hedgerows to the north and east of the field. They do not appear to be using the hedgerow to the south (there are no trees to the west). Movement of the butterflies toward the trees accelerates by 6:30 and by 6:45 there is a virtual cloud of monarchs seeking places to roost in the trees - so much so that to observers they look like flocks of birds coming to roost. By 7PM all but a few of the monarchs are at rest in the trees.

This spectacle will probably end as a cold front moves through the area. The weather for tomorrow is expected to be in the low 60s with showers so the butterflies may not be able to leave the area until the skies clear and the temperature hit the low 60s on Friday.The Jeffers informed me that Jim Edson is on his way to the location so maybe Jim will be able to provide some clarifications and additional details.

There are two fields consists of about 1,000 acres of goldenrod, asters and a few other wildflowers. A drainage ditch with a tree line divided the fields. The monarchs were moving out of the fields to the trees by thethousands. I don't know how to estimate the numbers, but the tree line isabout 0.5 miles long and all of the trees were full of monarchs. I haven'tseen anything like it except in Mexico. There could have been anywhere from10K to 100K butterflies.This is the largest aggregation of migrating monarchs I've heard of in several years.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We took a walk in our neighborhood in Northeast San Antonio tonight around 7:30 (dusk)and we discovered 1000s of monarchs flying in the lights of our neighborhood tennis court.  We watched and they began to settle in the dark trees nearby.  We returned awhile later to find the trees full of the monarchs roosting for the night.  A fascinating sight!
We have seen fewer monarchs coming through this year than the past four years, but the last two nights 10/11/06 and 10/12/06 they have roosted in my pecan and live oak trees.

I've been seeing monarch singles for about 10 days. A friend reported that on the eastern edge of Sutton Co., beginning October 11th, they are roosting in her large oak tree as they always do. Definitely in the high hundreds at least.Also seeing increasing numbers in the city limits of Sonora.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Have had multiple sittings over the last several days. Cold front came through last night. Several hundred roosting in large pecan trees in back yard. They have been here every year for the last few years.

We observed the migration all during the day.  Toward evening, the roost was found in a grove of oak trees, which was in a quiet area protected from strong winds.  Several hundred Monarchs were in the roost.
Several hundred roosting in trees in town.

Cape May PointAmazing roosts here in Cape May these last two weeks. The largest I saw was on 10/3-10/4;  I went at dusk on 10/3 and then at day break on 10/4. During the day I went back and the numbers were actually increasing rather than decreasing. I am not good at estimating but there had to be thousands.  I have pictures but do not know how to upload them here.  Will send a few along to the webmaster for posting.

We arrived in Maverick County to a phone call from Keith and Lettie, telling me that their trees were "full" again this year. We went over at 6 and found about 3000 in their yard. They are on a bluff above the Rio Grande with large trees. Multiple houses in the neighborhood were being used: hackberry, pecan, Japanese Yew.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Came home to the Radar Base and found at least 300-400 in one tree by the road and at least 300 in my front yard. The shelter belts around the runway are also being used but only 100-200 there.

We were unable to get over to the 300 yard long shelter belt at the end of the taxiway where there were many thousands in past years.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Yesterday, Oct. 15, I still had about 100 in my yard. Today, it's 60 degrees with a light rain, and more forecasted. Wind from the SE at 16. They are hanging in the trees. No large clusters, just 2-3 per cluster. I easily counted 60 without binoculars.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Phone calls coming in from all over town about 1000s in trees. There are probably 80-100,000 in Eagle Pass right now. Heavy overcast and warm.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Thousands of Monarchs in residential gardens all over Eagle Pass.

The Monarchs don't seem to be in any hurry to leave, and the weather report has forecast of sun on Tuesday, with 30 percent chance of rain today, 80 percent tonight and scattered isolated showers all over. The rain stopped around 1 o'clock and the snouts and sulfurs are flying in the roads. Some Monarchs confused by these flights and get down too low on the road, and get hit, but not many.

Another resident, here in Eagle Pass invited us to view their visiting Monarchs last evening. They had about 3000 in their garden yesterday evening.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I sighted Monarchs at our ranch on Saturday Oct. 14 and Sunday Oct. 15. The ranch is at N29deg 48.979 min 58.74s, W100degrees 29.439min 26.34s In the evening several of the large live oak trees along the road were full of Monarchs. Other trees off the road may have also had butterflies.During theday there were 5 to 10 in sight at all times as we drove - just fluttering around.This occurred over the entire ranch (1184 acres). There didn't seem to be any general directional movement.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

The monarchs arrived at our rance 10 miles west of Uvalde on the Nueces River about noon on October 13. There are THOUSANDS OF THEMin the native pecan and hackberry trees along the river. It's a beautiful sight.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

I live in Hudson Bend on Lake Travis. Yesterday, Saturday 10/14, I saw a massive number of monarchs in the air during my 5 mile walk through the hills of Hudson Bend. This is the first time in my nearly 15 years of living here, that I've seen this many monarchs. Friday evening I was out in my backyard around 6:45 p.m. and noticed them coming down to roost in my trees overnight.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game
Monarchs by the dozens in Ozona, Texas the weekend of October 8, 2006.  Many resting in the pecan trees.

In Southwest Texas, near where Independence creek flows into the Pecos River, there is a gorgeous, crystal clear spring that flows into a pool, that then flows into Independence creek.  This place is called Oasis ranch. We spent the weekend of Oct 14 there, and there were thousands of Monarchs flying around and roosting in the huge Pecan trees right next to the springs.
Down by the Pedernales river on a ranch near Cypress Mill, there were hundreds of Monarchs flying around and roosting in the large Cypress and Pecan trees by the River.

A cold front moved through the Lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas this afternoon bringing the first of the monarch migration to Weslaco and Mercedes. I watched until dusk when monarchs began to land in my mesquite trees only to be chased away or snapped up by birds.There were about 20 per minute.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

A massive monarch roost along the Rio Grande. Charlie estimated the roost at ~1000

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

It was very warm, mid-90s, with a strong south wind blowing.  I walked outside to be sure water was in the birdbath and was engulfed in a monarch snowstorm.  They were fluttering and floating, also many were resting in the deep shade of the old trees that provide a canopy in our back yard.  There were probably 100-200 of them.  They were fewer in number the next morning but many were clustered together in the trees, roosting I presume.  Diminishing each day, we had them in our yard for a week or so.  A gift!

Today, right outside the Courthouse in La Salle County, I stepped outside and thousands of monarch butterflies were resting on the trees, I stepped outside and it was like paradise with the butterflies soaring above us. We are 65 miles north of Laredo. The butterflies are almost home. October 16, 2006 Joel Rodriguez, Jr. La Salle County Judge

October 17th:
German film crew began filming on bluff above the Rio Grande in Eagle Pass---1000 in the group of big trees on Simpson St.

October 18th:
A few hundred still in trees on Simpson St.

October 20th:
60 monarchs in trees at my house. 12 mi. N Eagle Pass.

October 21-23:
No monarchs in my trees at Radar Base. Breeze from north for several days now. Cool.

I am surprised at the sudden drop off in numbers. In past years there would have been a few small clusters 40 to 100 night after night, after the leading edge passed. We're still seeing many more queens drifting around, than monarchs in dedicated flight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

For the first time I found small clusters early this morning as the monarchs had the same idea last night to stay out of the north wind ... loose clusters of about a dozen in several places on the back side of false willow.  Then late this afternoon I found clusters trying to form at several places along the peninsula at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway.  When I left, the largest cluster had fourteen, but other monarchs were still trying to join it, several coupled pairs.  There was a small but steady steam of about one a minute heading out across Lavaca Bay from 5:30 and 6:30.  Before noon there had been a larger flow before the wind changed from the N to the E. Good numbers dropping in to nectar on goldenrod and lantana today.     http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct23clusters.html

monarchs have been sighted on a regular basis all up and down the central coast for the last month, from Santa Cruz to Pismo Beach. The largest gatherings are places that have large eucalyptus groves, which seem to be a favored as roosting sites. On our class outings at San Simeon State Park, near Cambria, California, we see monarchs daily, especially around the seasonal wetlands that are hosts to abundant milk weeds. Even though there are not thousands roosting at san simeon, its obvious that they like the location. The temperatures along the central coast have been in the mid 60's F to high 70's of late. Last week it actually hit 82 deg. F in Cambria and San Luis Obispo.

The Monarch butterflies arrived to Monterrey! We saw them passing by our playground on Friday, October 20th and then on Saturday I took pictures of them resting on trees. We are excited because we keep seeing them flying over us.

Monarchs - several scattered in the mesquite trees in early morn, 7:30 am, then later in the morning, flying to the yellow flowers in photos. There were many, many all day long, but never saw a large concentration of them. However, we have 200 acres on that side of Hwy 36, and not enough time to seriously look for a large concentration of them.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

Just came from an afternoon of checking out clustering sites.

The row of trees just before one arrives at the Kickapoo Nation's pecan orchard 10 mi. S of Eagle Pass was loaded with monarchs at 1 this afternoon. I'd estimate at least 200 there.Heavy nectaring on a white aster and lantana.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Just came from an afternoon of checking out clustering sites.

Over at the cathedral grove of old growth pecans on Salvador Gonzalez' place in Hopedale there were at least 400 in the trees and nectaring on the Antigonon vine at 3 p.m.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Just came from an afternoon of checking out clustering sites.

Out at the Cunningham Ranch in Quemado Valley we drove along the big canal for a mile and had more than 500 in the trees: hackberry, mesquite, huisache, blackbrush, even forming clusters on river cane. They were nectaring on blue boneset, false willow, false broomweed--all at dusk.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Jesï¿½s Valdï¿½s Reyna a university teacher saw about 2,000 monarchs roosting in an old tree in front of his house, and today october 26, at around 16:00 it got cloudy so we saw thousands of monarchs lowering its fligth. Then at around 5:00 oï¿½clock he called to the office and told us that the tree was fillin again with monarchs.Cecilia Ochoa Blackaller

El viernes 20, con una mañana fresca 10°C y neblina, salí a un lugar llamado Estación Mariposa ubicado a 40km. al norte de Saltillo, a las diez de la mañana se empezaron a observar docenas de mariposas monarca saliendo de los arbustos y emprendiendo su vuelo en dirección sureste. Caminé por aproximadamente unas tres horas por el lugar y solamente vi unas cuantas monarcas entre cientos de pieridos y docenas de reinas.

Por la tarde la temperatura se elevó hasta los 20°C y se empezaron a observar en los árboles del centro de la ciudad algunos racimos de 5-10 mariposas.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Se movieron de lugar siguiendo la carretera 57 y cerca de Arteaga, Coah. en el Fraccionamiento El Llano vieron cientos de mariposas volando desde el nivel del suelo hasta el cielo, en vuelo alto. y contaron un racimo de mas de 100 mariposas en un fresno. Sus observaciones fueron en las faldas de la Sierra de Zapalinamé.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Hoy domingo 22, el clima volviï¿½ a cambiar: a las 8 de la maï¿½ana el cielo estaba nublado y fresco 16ï¿½C me dirigï¿½ hacia el sur de la ciudad al Jardï¿½n Botï¿½nico de la Humanidad, lugar donde se encuentran unos nogales muy viejos y en los que las mariposas forman sus racimos para dormir. Efectivamente ahï¿½ estaban las monarcas, ya se estaban levantando algunas docenas, otros cientos que posiblemente venï¿½an de oeste de la ciudad, ya daban vuelos en circulos tomando las termales, durante unas dos horas se veï¿½an pasar a cientos de mariposas al sureste en vuelo alto. Pero, de pronto empece a observar que empezaron a descender del cielo y buscar otra vez los ï¿½rboles, al mismo tiempo la temperatura empezï¿½ a descender, la neblina bajï¿½ y se sentï¿½a una brisa muy humeda. me retirï¿½ del lugar y empezï¿½ una lluvia ligera que aï¿½n perdura hasta ahorita que son las siete de la tarde.

Espero que cuando mejore el tiempo se vean otra vez por miles en la ciudad.

Rodrigo Canales, las vio la mañana del domingo 22 en grandes cantidades en La Chancla, frente a San Miguel, Ramos Arizpe, Carretera antigua Saltillo - Monclava, km. 29 fuimos por la tarde y ahí estaban posadas aunque en menores cantidades, eligieron para dormir un aguacate y un níspero, también había algunas en tejocotes y en fresnos. Entre todas juntaban algunos cientos.”

Ayer las mariposas monarcas nos alegraron la vida al ta´pizar el cielo de Saltillo.Despues de dos días de neblina y fresco, ayer 24 de octubre de 9 de la mañana a 12 de mediodía levantaron el vuelo miles y miles de mariposas que se habían perchado en las zonas arboladas de toda la ciudad. El espectáculo fue bellisimo¡¡.

Durante la tarde ya en vuelo alto se vieron pasar un numero constante de mariposas en dirección sureste, 30/min aproximadamente.El día de hoy durante la mañana se han visto un poco menos, pero en cada alto de semaforo puedo contar unas 20, desde el nivel de las casas hasta vuelo alto.

El día 23 por la tarde recorrí varios sitios donde generalmente se forman los racimos y las encontré en nogales, pirules y huizaches, tanto en Saltillo com en la vecina ciudad de Ramos Arizpe. Calculo que en cada árbol había un de 2000 a 3000 mariposas.
