Well, I feel a bit better about the overall migration numbers since my second tripout this morning.

40 monarchs in 4 trees in the back yard of the rent house west of me. Therewas a single cluster of 12 or more, then the rest singletons scattered throughout. That makes 50 monarchs in 100' of trees. More typical of this time of year. Andcould indicate that kind of scattered distribution throughout the region, whichwould indicate a reasonable number of migrants. I'l try to do a passing over count if it clears and they begin to move.

Only 9 butterflies in the trees last night. 8 in one cluster and a singleton nearby.

Light mist was all we got from the tropical depression moving through. I saw no monarchs migrating, just singles hanging around and circling in the wind sac allday yesterday.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
This late!!!!  We have been in the 40 F's several nights in the last couple of weeks!  Wouldn't they die!

We camped out at Baker's Crossing north of Comstock on the Devil's River from Wednesday through Sunday morning. The first night, Wednesday the 18th of October, we had approximately 15 Monarchs fly into the pecan tree above us just as it grew dark. Around midnight the cold front came through with a fierce blow and howl and the next morning Ron saw five take off from their branch from the previous night. How they withstood the wind is a mystery to us. After that we only saw singles flying either across US90, or along the Comstock road, or through the campground or along the river.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

1 November 06
For the past three days, Monarchs have been trickling in...flying high, they seem so solitary and steaming from the north...first one or two and then a small cluster of 5-10...and then I loose count...the stream is constant!

But the best part of all is that they are roosting in my gardens....settling in the Alamos (birchlike trees) and sipping the nectar from the last of the flowers...what a sight right before my eyes...right here....

2 November 06
I went for a long hike this morning and didn't see one monarch! The blue morphos are all about however. I can't believe that after the last three days I couldn't find a one this morning!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Today thousands of monarchs have arrived in Tequisquiapan. They began to arrive around five o'clock in the afternoon. The butterflies were arriving from the north. This is the first large group to pass through this fall. It is such a wonderful sight! All the neighbors were out. Our subdivision is surrounded by pines and eucalyptus trees. The entire subdivision is full of the butterflies tonight. This is the latest we have seen the butterflies roost in the fall. Here is one of the photos my husband and I took.

My property has hundreds of trees. I noticed Monarchs chose one oak tree in particular with dense foilage. The entire tree literally "Fluttered" because of the number of monarchs on it. This particular Oak is pretty unique to my property. Why they chose it, I don't know. But while they could have chosen from hundreds of other less unique trees on my property......they chose this specific Oak. It had a good breeze and water in a nearby trough.

I am amazed with the Monarach Migration this year. In the 10 years I've lived in this region I have NEVER seen the quanity of monarchs. By and large most of them are very tiny but there have been some large ones. They have come in WAVES this years. Millions....perhaps Billions. I have been worried since the freeze in years past about their survival but this year certainly eases my mind. They have rembounded in an amazing way.I would guess that this is the FOURTH WAVE of Monarachs in the past month's time. And they still come. They will be arriving in Mexico for a great deal longer. Tell the citziens of Michoacan to be prepared to be amazed by the numbers this year!!!!!!!!

More monarchs arrived to Tequisquiapan last night.There were thousands arriving at 5:00 in the afternoon. The temperature was 26 degrees C. As the sun went down it started to rain. It rained all night. My husband and I went out at 7:45 today, (Nov.11) to see how they survived the rain. The butterflies were still asleep in the trees. We didn't find any on the ground. The temperature was 14 degrees C.  By 7:20 some of the butterflies were starting to wake up. It was still cold and drizzling. Many of the butterflies fell to the ground and they were wet. We went to pick up two of my students who live in the subdivision to start a rescue. We picked up the butterflies that couldn't fly and put them in bushes so they wouldn't be run over by cars and trucks. By 9:00 many of the butterflies were flying and many were still asleep. The temperature was still 14 degrees C.  By 11:00 the temperature had reached 18 degrees C and the skies were full of butterlies. Some of them are still asleep. The rai
I saw seven monarchs along a one mile stretch of road leading from the lighthouse at St. Marks National Wildlife Refuge. I do not think they were migrating.

The Finish Line!
This is where the monarchs go for the winter.
They travel here from across eastern North America.Here's the news! >>

In a grove of maple trees, next to Grey Couny Road #1, approx 3 km west of Owen Sound bay, a collection of approx 700+monarchs. We visited in the early morning, and my husband photographed the clusters.We witnessed "cascading" as the sun warmed the clusters, about 7:30 a.m.I found about 33 on the ground tagged and released them.Early for migration in our area.
Thousands's of Monarch's roosting each night in a park on the bluff overlooking Lake Huron in Goderich, ON.  Peak date appears to be 08/19/07.

On August 5, most of the recently emerged monarchs in extreme northern Minnesota were exhibiting southward migratory behaviorand evening clustering behavior:

Photo #1
Photo #2

Just would like to report a large cluster sighting that I observed in Enosburgh, VT. Have never seen this before and have a wonderful digital video of this sighting. It was one of the most beautiful things I've ever experienced.

We were on the crest (very top) of our land, with a 360 degree view and sooooo quiet. You could even hear the butterflies landing and fluttering. I don't know how to put a number on them. They were all over and it appeared they were eating (something) on the maple leaves, and roosting on the pine trees. They were roosting on the south side of the trees.

We went up to the site 1 week later and they were no longer there. Not one!

Several tens of thousands of Monarchs overnighted in large old Maple trees just south of Charlevoix last night. The sight was an old farmhouse renovation project on the corner of Ferry Rd & U.S.31 south near Atwood Michigan just north of the 45th parallel.
Absolutely amazing!  Hundreds of monarchs are roosting in our Maple and Birch trees. They have been here for 3 days. This is something new for our rural school!

Spotted approximately 100 butterflies at 7:30 pm within city of Syracuse.  They flew in singly or in pairs and appeared to be choosing a place to land. They settled over three city lots, in both evergreens and deciduous trees. The process took approximately 30 minutes. The next morning's temperatures remained in the high 50's to low 60's.  Watched carefully from 7:30 am to 11:45 am. First departure was after 8 am. Observed only 5 other departures prior to 11:30 am.

Our area is bordering on severe drought conditions, so my gardens are probably a better source for nectar than wildflowers. I see 10 to 20 Monarchs every day and have noticed them gathering in groups in favorite trees like the old poplar above the gully. This is the first year I've noticed this behavior and I've had other people mention seeing Monarchs gathering in their trees, too. This activity has been happening around here for two weeks already. Early migration or just group mentality?

This has been a beautiful butterfly summer around here! Each day, regular Monarchs visit my flower gardens seeming to favor the various species of Flowering Tobacco that have spread via self seeding. One in particular is always busy flitting around till sunset. Out in the meadow, the purple flowers of the Brown Knapweed seem to be their favorite nectaring spot close to sunset. This plant seems to be blooming very early and many of the flowers, 50% of the blooms are already turning brown today.

Dozens -- probably hundreds -- of Monarchs roosting in our out of town yard. One of our Monarchs we have been watching inside our house just emerged today. We will release it in the yard with the hundreds of others. We see these each year. This year they have chosen a different tree than in previous years.

Hundreds of Monarchs flying and checking out flowers in the garden then and  all finding each other and landing and roosting in a silver Maple tree on the same branches closing their wings, and looking like the keys or dried leaves. It was spectacular to witness and watch. Many pictures were taken.
At about 6:30 pm, over one hundred (more are arriving every minute) roosting on our white pine tree approximately 20 feet up. Very exciting!

Our family just returned from a sea kayaking trip out of Killarney. Monarchs were abundant throughout the area. In particular, we found a staging area on West Fox Island that had between 400 and 500 individuals in an area of about 15M x 15M.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
The sightings started in Cobourg 5 miles north of Port Hope.My Husband also noted a roost on the Golf course in Port Hope. The steady stream has been going south for more then 2 weeks. Lots of them.

Last night there were hundreds of thousands of monarchs roosting in my trees, Ms. Cherry told reporter Valerie MacDonald of Northumberland Today. They covered trees, shrubs and filled the air. The monarchs are roosting in trees, feeding and waiting for the sun to come back and warm things up before they move on, added monarch expert Rod Parrott of Port Hope. Staging along the north shore of Lake Ontario like this is typical during fall migration. The monarchs come down from the north and often pause when they reach Lake Ontario. Depending on winds, they'll either cross the Great Lake or continue travel along the shoreline.

Temperature is about 25 Celsius. Cloudy. Rain and lightning last night. 50 metres east of Lake Huron shoreline. Local Ash trees and white cedar trees are filled with Monarchs. They have been arriving over the last 3 days. The number is very high this year compared to other years. 2-3 years ago it was also heavy. Monarchs are not moving far today. Just fluttering around the trees. Beautiful to see.

Yesterday morning (8/23) I observed many Monarchs at Forman Park in Pultneyville NY. This small village is located on the South shore of Lake Ontario approximately 30 miles east of Rochester. During a period of time from 10:15 AM until 11:00 AM I saw 30 Monarchs heading west along the lake shore. Also small groups of twenty or so Monarchs roosting in three trees close to shore and many nectaring on small flowers in lawn.

I am also seeing Monarchs every day in our newly established Way Station in Penfield ( eastern suburb of Rochester NY). Yesterday we also had a Giant Swallowtail. First time I have ever seen one!

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Around 6:30 pm monarchs started arriving in our heavily treed back yard and gathering on about 4 tree branches. The temperature was about 26°C, no wind, light clouds. Guessing about 100 butterflies gathered over a 30 minute period, mostly arriving from the South. We are in the middle of a subdivision. This is the first time we have seen this.

Amazing!  I work in my dining room and over the course of the day kept noticing movements over the pool and around the shrubs behind our pool.  At about 4:30 today, I went out only to see about 50-100 monarchs fluttering around all of the shrubs in our yard.  Further to that, when I walked by the shrubs along the back perimeter of the yard, they lit from the trees to the air.  It was at that point that I realized how many were in the trees.Truly a sight to behold.  It was magical!
Monarchs seemed to be stopping to rest on their migration. About 500 were in our trees about sunset.
About 75 or more monarchs in shelterbelt.  Some are roosting

at first we were quite surprised to see so many butterflies near the beach, but as we went for bike rides along the trails, we also observed clusters of Monarchs near milkweed and on some tree branches.  My estimate of the largest cluster we saw was approximately 35 or so.
Thousands of monarch Butterflies landing in trees.

I had 300 to 500 monarchs nectaring in my Monarch Waystation yesterday (8-24-07)Looks like about the same today. Last night many roosted in the woods in ones or twos. I did find one small roost of about 50. It looks like the migration has started.

I believe this year that monarch numbers are below the average of the last 12 years for my farm. Certainly much better than last year, but the numbers I’m seeing now I often see in the first half of August.

Approximately 40 Monarch butterflies are roosting in two groups in a Bur oak and Red cedar tree adjacent to a prairie garden. Time is  7:30 PM CDT. Current conditions scattered clouds, 74°F, wind SSE 17 mph, humidity: 58%, dew point: 62, visibility: 10.0 mile, barometer: 29.88

We had a lot of monarchs roosting in a couple of maple trees in our yard on this evening. We estimate that there may have been about 200 of them, maybe more! I counted about 50 in the largest cluster and there were a number of smaller clusters. We have never had this many in one evening. It was wonderful!!  This is earlier than when we usually have roosting monarchs. I would estimate about a week and a half early.
school: Not a school, a mother and 2 children

comments: The Outdoor Campus received two calls this morning from area observers west of town saying they had thousands of butterflies in their trees last night. We will be sending a crew to Buffalo Ridge, SD this evening to check out the reports.
100-200 roosting in maple tree in back yard. Humming birds are in the area also.

Observed hundreds of monarchs flitting around a cedar and poplar ( and oak) clearing after a rainfall, 08/24 and 08/25. They began leaving the site in the am 08/26/07, and the very last ones were seen heading south around noon. Occasionally a few stragglers were ween during the afternoon. A fascinating display, which I and a few relatives had never witnessed before in this area !

Thursday, August 23 Thickson's Woods Monarchs

As happened last August, monarch butterflies arecongregating in sheltered areas in the centre of thewoods, particularly in a clearing where a large silverpoplar blew down two years ago. Numbers have reachedseveral thousand. Last year at the peak estimatesplaced the numbers at perhaps 100,000. Thebutterflies are very sensitive to any sounds, soplease be considerate. If you move slowly andsilently, you will have a much more rewardingexperience and the butterflies will be lessdisturbed.. Look for twigs and branches covered withwhat look to be dead leaves.

Contributed by Don Davis

Today when passing through the park that runs from the rear of Toronto's "Fort York" to a set of steps giving access to Strachan St. Bridge, we were stunned to be surrounded by nothing less than flocks of Monarchs (literally hundreds). It was so beautiful I had to find out if people "in the know" knew. They flew above and about us as we walked along the path to the steps, and alighted and festooned various branches of the trees overhead.

Contributed by Don Davis

On Friday of this week, I encountered hundreds of butterflies along the lakeshore specifically in the Tuck Creek creek bed located between Walkers Line and Guelph Line north of Spruce in Burlington. It wasn't a huge roost but there were branches with more that a dozen sometimes two dozen Monarchs hanging off of them.Today, the migration has been steady as well with many butterflies migrating along the lakeshore.

Contributed by Don Davis

Once again Thickson's woods was one happening place this morning. It was easy to see 10,000 to 12,000 Monarchs roosting in the trees from 7:30 to 8:00 am this morning. By far the most I have ever seen at one time ..

Contributed by Don Davis
Lots of monarchs migrating westward along the north shore of Lake Ontario. About 1:20 pm, dark clouds moved in for a short time and some monarchs began to roost in clusters of 20 or so.
Wind from the South~ Approximately 150-200 Monarchs are roosting in trees.  This is the 2nd day they have been here.
Observed many hundreds of monarchs roosting in the trees the past couple days. Roosting mainly in maple and ash trees. Strong south winds are holding them in the area.

We were vacationing at Keuka Lake in Penn Yan, NY. While my dad was mowing the lawn, about 20 monarchs came out of the pine trees and fluttered around. I took many pictures and there was one particular butterfly that loved being photographed by me. He/she fluttered around to different places and slowly opened/closed its wings while I took pictures. What a great experience. Afterwards, my parents, nieces, and I read about monarchs and made a scrapbook page of them. Now, we want to learn more.

Too many to count! They stayed over night in the maple and elm trees. They were fantsstic to see. Some were on branches with no leaves but, after they had settled, it looked like the leaves were back. This is the first time that they have gatherd at our farm. I hope they will return.

We have spotted a few butterflies in our backyard during the pastcouple of days, and this morning there were a dozen. Last yearour neighbour had hundreds of them in their backyard and wereported them. We are directly across Lake Ontario on a smallPeninsula.

On the 27th, I saw a fewon the 28th (yesterday) at 7:00 pm inthe neighbours yardthey increased to over 40-50, I assume after flying overLake Ontario and then after about 20 minutes they were allquiet and resting in the trees. We assume it was becausedusk was coming.
We observed 6 monarchs the past two nights in our back yard around dusk. They seemed to be about 20 feet high in our maple tree and were grouping up.

Monarchs have been gathering at my farm grove. (Pine,ash and box elder trees)On August 28th a.m. hundreds were here. As a gentle rain began to fall they were drifting/floating around in the rain. A cool front moved through last night but the monarchs are still here this morning, sunny and 60*F.
At least 200 monarchs roosting in oak trees on the east side of the John Michael Kohler Art Center in Sheboygan, WI.  5pm.  Was the 6th straight day of overcast skies and much rain.
An abundance of butterflies have been in the area. They are thick in the trees.

Starting @ around 4 pm hundreds of monarchs came to 1 elm tree, congregating largely on the N side of it. Day was sunny, clear, windy. I'd say we watched about 3 hrs. with about 50/hr coming from every direction. Most were gone the next a.m. I mentioned it to our butterfly curator @ local zoo. She & others sighted the same behavior around cottages @ Lake Ontario the same day.
Approximately 120 monarch butterflies seen gathered in trees in Toronto park on Lake Ontario
Many butterflys again this year - like our pines and maple trees

This morning my daughter and I saw over 50 of them hanging in our maple tree at 6:30am just as the sun was rising you could see the colors like changing leaves in one section of the tree...absolutely amazing...batteries were dead in the digital...as the sun rose higher they all left.

We observed and took pictures of a fall roosting in our backyard. Hundreds of Monarchs "flashed" to indicate to others that this was their overnight rest and the sight of such beautiful wings opening and closing was one I shall never forget. This is two years in a row that we have had the pleasure of the Monarchs choosing our backyard and we hope to see them again next year.
In the last week the numbers of Monarchs roosting in the trees in my front yard has been growing...this morning there had to be hundreds...15 or more at a time clinging to a tiny branch...

At 7:30pm I started spotting six or seven monarchs per minute in my backyard, and for the next 30 minutes an increasing number showed up -- thousands landing on branches of trees in my yard and throughout my neighborhood, which gave the effect of beautiful orange fall leaves on the trees. It was such a spectacle and we are hoping to spot more!
We are in Lakewood, Oh. South shore of Lake Erie. Hundreds of Monarchs have begun roosting in the trees in our backyard. Really COOL!!!!!

Got to the catalpa grove about 20 minutes before sunset,70 degrees, light west breeze. The U shaped glade within the grove with the open end to the west. It is always much warmer in there than the open fields. As the sun got lower, Monarchs drifted down from the sky, whirling and chasing. Rising up and down, from the bottom of the trees to the tops,a distance of 60 feet; they swirled. Zipping in and out of the wide leaves like playful children trying to surprise each other. They also played follow the leader flying in line following each other. It wasn't a large group, only about 12. But busy, lively and hard to count because of their activity. A mix of new, faded and several who seemed to have underdeveloped wings - withered but workable. Just after sunset, a group of three settled in with some wigwagging of wings till spacing was established. The branch they chose a dead under story one, is one that gets used every year!

August 31
Beautiful warm gold evening, soft air, temps round 70, no breeze. Only two Monarchs tonite, they want to roost and fluttered about trying to decide rising and falling around the branch where the group of 12 roosted just a few nights ago. They tried and tried to feel comfortable but finally one following the other, flew north across the gully into the woods. You wonder what motivates them, what conditions and temperatures help them decide where to roost for the night.

Finally - after several days of watching I am seeing small groups of monarchs roosting in the treeline.  They started to appear in the yard at 6:15pm and, after what appeared to be much chasing about, started serious roosting and flashing behavior by 6:30pm.  By 6:45pm I located 4 small groups of butterflies (4-8 per group)- all facing east yet still catching the rays of setting sun.  Each roost sight was 12-15 off the ground under good canopy.  One group of 4 was clustered together on a bare branch of an oak tree, while the others were on fully leafed branches of a sugar maple nearby.
We saw probable about 500 out in our back yard and the barnyard.

Late this afternoon, there were probably 200-300 monarchs gathered in a wooded area near a local school. It was a sunny day, mid-70's, no precip. I have been seeing a few monarchs here and there throughout the day, more than usual, by this is a first for me to see a "roost"...very exciting! They were mostly all resting, with only a few in flight. I am SO thankful to my friend for telling me, and I got some nice pics and video.
Observed numerous monarchs flying around our yard this evening and roosting in a large walnut tree.  Estimate around 50 butterflies roosting in the tree.

Sighted the butterflies in the early evening like last year.  The temperature in the day was in the mid 70's.  The night time low last night was 57F.  The weather this Summer has been extremely dry.  Unlike last year when most of the Monarchs roosted in our white spruce and Austrian pines, this year they preferred the silver maple trees.  I took several pictures and uploaded them to my Picasa public web gallery >http://picasaweb.google.com/vburolla/MonarchsRoosting2007< if anyone is interested.  My guess is they numbered in the hundreds, maybe a little less than last year, but as they were spread out more, the quantity could be wrong.

My back yard near Eglinton and Kennedy Road was inundated with Monarch for a space of 2-3 days. Walking out into the yard them flying out for every direction. I counted 70 at one time hanging on a dead branch
The butterflies made a stopover in a neighbour's backyard on the Tamarack trees on Saturday, and rested in the cool damp and were gone within an hour the next day.

I was visiting my neighbor lady and we spotted several hundred Monarch butterflies. We started investigating and they were all over her trees and bushes. It was truly a phenomenal sight. I truly can't explain just how awesome it was. I took some pictures and they turned out really well.
Approximately 200 monarchs were roosting in a Maple tree near Elora gorge at 7:00pm. Beautiful sight!

Our home is surrounded by a 160 acre hay field in full bloom. The monarchs began appearing on 8/22/07 and the number grew to the hundreds by 8/26/07. They roosted in our maple and birch trees. The numbers began to diminish on 8/29/07 and on 8/30/07, almost all were gone.

We have seen several hundred Monarchs in our trees around the house for a couple of days. The first day that we observed the Monarchs was 8/31/07.  They seemed to be gathering in the trees in several masses to keep warm for the evening.  Yes there was a cool front overspreading the area on that night.  We also saw the butterflies early the next morning and then the next evening at about sundown they began to gather in there masses again.  We see them all summer long because we have quite a few butterfly friendly bushes in the yard, but it is usually just a dozen or two at a time.  This was an incredible sight to behold seeing so many at one time.  So, we had butterflies, en masse, for two consecutive nights, 8/31 and 9/1/07.

Several hundred monarchs are roosting in our maple trees tonight. This is the first ones I've seen migrating. We cater to the monarchs every summer by allowing milkweed to grow and also planting a good sized flower garden for them to feed in. Many of them have pupated here this past summer and there are still caterpillars in the milkweed.

This is the second year we have seen the Monarchs gathering in the trees at Linwood Park in Vermilion Ohio. We are right on the shore of Lake Erie and we assume they are resting after crossing the lake. There is a grove of very large Oak and other trees. We notice them often in a Birch Tree. Although we saw thousands last year, this year so far only around 100 or so.
There are thousands of these butterflies here. In 35 years I have never seen such an amazing sight and as the days go by more and more keep coming.....
I couldn't count all the monarchs fluttering by in the yard. Everywhere we turned the treed area was moving.
Hundreds observed in trees in alley one block north of our home.  In one-half hour my children, mother and I tagged 75 with tags from Monarch Watch.

am so excited because I went outside tonight and I saw many many monarchs! I was trying to count them but it was hard because they were fluttering all over the place. I know that I had to see and count at least 30 or 40 of them. I tried to look in the trees to see if they had roosted and count them that way, but it was difficult to tell what was a butterfly and what was a leaf on the tree. I am fairly certain that today was their first day here.

I found it to be quite amazing because when they were hear last year, it was almost exactly the same kind of weather. It was really sunny, warm and very little breeze. I don't know if this has any direct correlation or not. I will check again tomorrow night and keep you updated.

Aug 27th
Peninsula Point, south of Stonington, 45.669 N, 86.965 W, 2-5 pm, lots of monarchs nectaring on mostly goldenrods on spit of land extending beyond lighthouse. Saw one leave and fly southwest over open water until we lost it in the binoculars despite south wind. 7:30 pm looked for roosts in cedar trees around the lighthouse but only saw a few monarchs coming in from the point and they moved farther into the trees.

Aug 29th
7 AM, back at Peninsula Point to see if we could find roosting monarchs on the vegetation out on the point beyond the lighthouse since the cedars by the lighthouse had not yielded any on the evening of the 27th nor this morning. As we were scanning the point with binoculars from the lighthouse area, a bear appeared about 100 feet from us and we decided to let him do his round of the point instead of contesting our right of first arrival :) We did watch him and he scared up many monarchs. Very cool experience!!!

Aug 30th
3-5 pm, back at Peninsula Point. Russ and I each took an edge as we walked along one of the vegetation strips on the point and counted monarchs nectaring. We counted about 300 and are sure we missed some. There were 2 other areas where we could see monarchs flitting about the flowers.

Aug 31th
yes, back at Peninsula Point (were camped half-way down the peninsula at Nat Forest campground) 8-10 AM, even though the temperature was in the 50's the monarchs were already moving around and nectaring, so saw no big roosts, max 12 in one of the few small saplings out on the point. They were definitely out on the peninsula and not in the cedar trees and there were lots of them. We saw 2 monarchs take off and fly southwest over the water with a very slight southwest wind. They were on a mission- first arrivals get choice of camping spots or maybe they were males on a dare.

Aug 28th, Garden Peninsula, little north of Fairport. We were trying to get to the point of the peninsula but no roads or at least not for our vehicle. At 1:30 pm we drove through a small woodlot (45.646 N, 86.654 W) and saw some monarchs flitting about. We stopped and saw some roosting as well. Counted about 50 from the road only, as it was private property.

Sept 2, 6-7 pm, Muskegon State Park (43.232 N, 86.336 W) where we have checked on roosting monarchs in years past. Light wind from southwest, temp 82, surveyed the dune area of mostly evergreens and counted 96 monarchs roosting or moving about the trees. They were concentrated in the southwest corner of this wooded area. Walked .65 miles. Area of concentration maybe 5 acres.

Ashbridge's Bay Park sits on Lake Ontario in the east end of Toronto. Several trees in the west end of the park this morning were thickly covered with Monarchs. All over the park the butterflies were on the move.Fantastic sight.Some pictures athttp://liaslc.blogspot.com/2007/08/ashbridges-bay-august-31-2007-monarchs.html

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Near Grafton/Cobourg area, it was quite windy yesterday, but the monarchs enjoyed nectaring on clover in a nearby farm field. Also collected about 20 large larva and tagged 50 more monarchs. The elderly property owner described with great enthusiasm how, last Thursday night, hundreds of monarchs that had been nectaring in the clover field and on the large field of goldenrod adjacent to it clustered on her small sugar maple tree.

Contributed by Don Davis
Spotted two monarchs roosting in my backyard tree.  Have also spotted several monarchs flying around my neighborhood.

I live in Cleveland ohio on the shores of Lake Erie.  We have many huge oak trees in our front yard.  Within the last couple of days, September 1st-2nd 2007 , there were HUNDREDS if not thousands of Monarchs in our oak trees hanging onto the leaves  and flying all around the yard.  It was a wonderful sight to behold.

A neighbor reported seeing hundreds of monarchs on Monday Sept. 3rdin the late afternoon, roosting on fields of goldenrod and boneset.I was out of town.  When I visited the site the next day, it was cooler and cloudy, the monarchs had already moved on.However, I just found half dozen monarch caterpillars on the milkweed in my garden, as did my friend in her garden.So there will be monarchs on the move for awhile from up here inN.Y. State, 100 miles north of NYC.

Hundreds of Monarchs arrived and roosted in my back yard trees on Saturday Sept 1st 2007 here on the north shore of Lake Erie. Most of them stayed all week-end and this morning, Tuesday Sept 4th, a few dozen remain. The daytime temperatures over this time period have reached 22 C and nighttime temps have dropped to 8 C. Winds over the long week-end have been light, but sometimes gusting to around 15 kph from off the lake (so from the south).

On September 3, 2007, while sitting on the balcony of our upper level condo on Lake Michigan in Brevort, MI, in the Upper Peninsula we first saw a flock of perhaps 30 monarchs headed west late in the morning. During the noon hour and into early afternoon, we saw individual monarchs pass by, headed west, at the rate of perhaps one per minute.

Also, although I did not see this firsthand, a friend living on nearby Brevort Lake told me she had seen a tree covered with monarchs on her property the same afternoon.

A friend of mine and another monarch nut was at the Edwin F Hulbert Nature Preserve by Good Hart (zip code 49737) when they saw at least 100 monarchs on 8-21-07 from about 3 to 4 PM. They were in a wooded area and the butterflies were either roosting or flying about through the trees. Good Hart is real near Lake Michigan, where we would expect monarchs to concentrate.

Monarchs clustering in trees just before dark along the Harrisburg, PA Greenbelt - a green necklace that circles the city - used for walking and bike riding, etc. They witnessed many Monarchs in one particular area the last two evenings, so I went out to check it out with them tonight. (9/04)

Sure enough, about 7:15 to 7:35 p.m., the air resembled a Monarch airport - coming in from every direction - floating thru the air, checking out various trees - lighting, then taking off again. It was like standing in butterfly confetti. Mostly they seemed to be interested in the Hackberry trees. The Hackberry trees are looking rather beat up this late in the year, with many leaves already dropped, and the remaining ones curled and turning brown, with many galls. But when the butterflies landed on the branches, they looked just like another leaf, and we would never have seen them there, if we hadn't been watching them land. While I know this spectacle takes place in many locations during migration, this was the first time I had heard of it happening in our area, and it was quite a wonderful sight. There were maybe 100 butterflies or so - an estimate.

Last year the monarchs started showing up around the same time.   This year they are gathering at our farm, like last year.    I don't see them arrive, but they gather in the cedar trees (two in particular) and flutter around until they leave.   The trees are on the north side of the grove and last year when they started gathering to move on south they started gathering in the Ponderosa pine trees that are on the south side of our grove.   It was quite a show and I took many pictures.   If they continue to gather this year, probably this next week,  I am calling the school to let the science teachers know as they may want to bring the kids out to see.   I will post another update after this weekend.   Last weekend the weather was warm, 90's.   It has cooled off today and is supposed to stay in the 70's for the next week.
Many butterflies again roosting in same spot as two days ago . . . some the same as I caught some previously tagged. Tagged 40 more.
I observed 100+ individuals in my maple trees on the evening of Sept. 5th. Many stayed in the trees and quite a few came and landed on me as I stood nearby observing them. What a fantastic event!
I saw this butterfly in front of my house hanging off of a tree.
two dozen or so in backyard.neighborhood is populated residential but with unusual amount of mature oaks elm and maple etc...

In a hardwoods, across from my house there have been hundreds of monarch butterflies roosting in the trees. Did they hatch from the woods? There really are very few milkweeds there. Or is this a stop on their migration route? It certainly is a beautiful sight!! I've seen them for about three weeks now.
A few monarchs were roosting overnight on our evergreens.  Perhaps 50 or more.
school: Aea267 school - 4 oaks at mason city

comments: More monarchs roosting overnight on our evergreens; it's quite warm today, so most were above out reach.  We were able to tag 10.
school: Aea267 school - 4 oaks at mason city

comments: There are approximately 50 monarchs roosting in my trees this evening (Sept. 7th). It's the first time I've remembered to watch for them. Our weather is cool and calm after storms in the night Sept. 6.
Hundreds of monarchs were roosting overnight; more on low branches, and leeward side of a windbreak grove.

A local newspaper reported on Sept.5 a story with a picture of Monarchs roosting near Celina, Ohio which is just a few miles away. My students and I would all like to find a tree like we saw in the picture. 111 Monarchs were sighted by 54 4th grade students last evening (Sept. 5).
The monarch butterflies have been roosting in our trees for over a week now. There are at least one hundred maybe more. They roosted here last year also.

The Monarch Butterflies are migrating across Nebraska.  We have noticed many of them flying across the roads and highways and Sunday night I went out in the common ground and saw many flying high around the trees.  I followed one with my eyes and it joined a roost of 25 individuals.  There were several roosts high in the Maple and Cottonwood trees.

About six o'clock in the evening, I was outside in my backyard. I noticed quite a few Monarch butterflies and then realized they were all flying to one particular tree in our backyard. They were hanging in bunches on the ends of several branches. I got my camera and took many pictures, which I have to share with you, if you'd like. (Because it was cloudy, they aren't as good as I would like, but aren't too bad either.) We had a rain last night and I was afraid they might be gone this a.m., but when I looked, many remain, although not all. It is still cloudy and wet, but if it clears, I will take some more pictures. Estimated count: 500-1,000?

September 23rd Update
Because of the rain, I think many of the Monarchs left duringthat first night (9/9/07), but there was still one branch that was full most of thenext day. After that, they all left and although I've still seen quite afew in the area, I haven't figured out if any are staying overnight aroundhere. They haven't been in any of my trees...

Monarch's roosting for night (only around 10) 09/09/07

100's of dragonflies (green darners?) in the evening at my address 09/08/07

Roosting for the second year in a row on several trees in our back yard.  Last night there were 50-70 monarchs, but this is how it started last year and we eventually ended up with approx. 250-300.  Many mature trees and a great field behind us with clover and other plants to feed on.
Group of perhaps 100 monarchs gathering around late flowering bushes in All Faiths Cemetery during the late afternoon hours.

We were playing on the playground at Lakeside Park and I was just about to do something when I noticed 5 or 6 monarch in a tree, then more just kept on coming, leading to 20.  It was in the afternoon.

First time for this sighting. Our new principal has reported thousands of monarchs in a tree in his backyard. We had storms this past weekend - the monarchs blew in the wind together like a cloud and then regathered on the tree.

The real highlight today was the 100's if not 1000's of Monarchs that were taking shelter in the trees surrounding the hawkwatch. They were everywhere!! Between the Monarchs and the hundreds of large dragonflies it made spotting the birds very challenging at times.

Contributed by Carolyn King

We saw monarchs gathering in red maple trees between 7:15 and 7:45pm two nights in a row (9/9 and 9/10) near our home in Canaan Valley, WV. There are large fields around our house with lots of blooming goldenrod and asters. The valley is at a high elevation (at least for the east) at 3200 feet and has large areas of fields and open wetlands in a stretch of the Appalachian Mountains where forests are dominant. The butterflies were gathering in large maples in at least two areas. We had had many days in a row of hot calm weather. Yesterday and last night a strong cold front passed through bring winds from north and I suspect we will not see them roosting tonight!

We have two roosting sites, consistent from year to year, on the campus of Kansas State University.  Both now have modest numbers of roosting Monarchs -- up from yesterday. At each site there is a bit of "clumping" -- Monarchs roosting very close to each other, but in what are still small groups (roughly 10 insects per clump).

What an incredible sight to witness. We became an airport with  Monarchs flying in from every direction, landing in only one of our many ash trees. Twenty seven years living here on our acreage in Giltner, NE., and  this has been our first sight of a gathering. It is the morning of Sept.10th and our leaves are turning colors and when the butterflies fold their wings they match the color of the leaves. I hope we see them again next year.

Tonight i saw what seemed like hundreds of monarch butterflies resting in my neighbors oak tree. What a sight. I had no idea why they were there until i googled. I was pleasantly surprised to see this.
I saw about 50 monarch butterflies in my backyard.  I stayed in my backyard for two hours and more came.  A few came from the north and a few came from the west. I have a few flowers in my yard.

On a warm sunny day, Sept. 13, there were hundreds of Monarchs in the ash trees and cedar trees here.  We are 50 meters from the east shore of lake Huron.  Today, Sept. 15, windy and cooler, there are few visible.
i saw hundreds of monarchs landing in my cedar trees just at dusk last night(9/13) . took a few pics. mostly just watched them land and settle down.

Only the second time I've ever seen monarchs roosting and this was in the same location I saw them maybe, 5 years before. I counted 50 on a soft maple branch and multiplied that by the 12 other spots they were covering.

Monarchs began to gather on the Wednesday (about a dozen) then over the next few days the weather was unsettled(rain and overcast).  By Saturday at sunset their numbers had increased to at least two hundred.  On Sunday morning the weather cleared and shortly after 10:00 all but about five had departed. I described the scene on the Saturday evening to be like a monarch airport as the butterflies drifted in a couple at a time and joined the roost.  In the back of my yard there are a variety of trees but the monarchs preferred the tamarack trees.  I took many pictures of this and it was a great thrill.

Found our visitors hanging on our two willow trees between the barn and the house. This is a sheltered location from the wind. Rain was forecast for later in the evening and I guess they were looking for a safe place to spend the night. There were quite a few thousand of them. It was fun watching them jockey around and exchanging positions. Getting ready for the evening, I guess. It didn't rain much at night, but there was a cloudburst around dawn. I went out after the rain stopped but they left without even eating breakfast. I'm glad I was able to see them this year, as I've missed them since I last saw them in Cape May about 15 years ago. A marvelous sight!

I walked to the back of the farm Friday evening 9/14/07 along the tree line. What I found there were swarms of monarchs, flying back and forth, and in the trees, they were gathering and hanging there! Bunches of them! In many trees! They appeared to be preparing to spend the night there. I've never seen this before.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Monarch activity has definitely picked up here in Kansas. Has been hot and dry for weeks with not as many monarchs as usual for early September. This morning however, I observed about ten cruising mycedar trees. This evening I was able to tag 54 asthey came in roost.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

All day yesterday (9/15) and then again today (9/16), large numbers of monarchs came into town. Found several roosts yesterday; one in my rear garden in the city of Cape May, the rest were at Cape May Point. This evening (9/16), I counted 15 large roosts (I am really bad at estimating), but the numbers were BIG. Very exciting; might even surpass last year, which was really impressive!

For daily migration counts from Cape May see the Cape May Monitoring Project.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present, although the roost appears to have been very large.

I received an email reporting large clusters of monarchs in Walton, Kentucky, about 25 miles south of Cincinnati. They were roosting in sycamore and pin oaks.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present. We entered 'one' in the number field only to mark this record for future consideration.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We arrived in Cape May, New Jersey around noon and immediately started seeing many monarchs making their way westward along the beach from Cape May to the staging area at Cape May Point, New Jersey.

They were fighting a strong northwest wind (to avoid being blown over the water). Quite a few monarchs were blown out over the mouth of the Delaware Bay before they could make it to the point. We also saw many flying backwards as they fought the wind and blowing sand.

Many monarchs took advantage of the dune and bushes near the bay to get out of the wind. Others landed on the sand just out of reach from the surf to rest before pushing on.

At any one point in the afternoon you could see 3 or more monarchs at a time in any direction on the beach. Along the bushes and inland from the beach were groups in twenties or more resting out of the wind or nectaring on the flowers.

At about five pm we found a large group of monarchs roosting in an area out of the wind in the woods on or near a cedar tree in Cape May Station.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present.

The students in Cincinnati  have seen a number of monarch's in the area. One student even saw a roost of monarchs late in the evening in one of our local parks. There was so many in the roost that it was difficult to count just how many. Most students are seeing maybe one or two at any given time.
We had about 50 as it was getting dark last night. This morning there were about 100. Light southerly wind and lots of wild flowers and sedum blooming for feeding. I'm happy!

The monarchs pass by frequently this time of year on their migration south to Mexico. On 9/15/07 I observed several monarchs flying past the window all day. At dusk, I expected the 'lion's share' of them to have passed by. Instead, I discovered that there were 100+ monarchs resting in scrub pines.

I did get up at dawn on 9/16/07 to observe the butterflies departing from their overnight resting place, but the temperature was in the 50's so they remained at rest. Later in the day - around 10am--I saw a cloud of monarchs fly off a bough all at once. I wondered why they all decided to depart at the same time and with such urgency as the other monarchs on other branches were not leaving. I realized that a squirrel was prancing down towards a green pine cone to eat that was near where the monarchs were resting.
100+ butterflies resting on trees in our yard. First sighted around 6pm on 9/17. Still here at 9:30am on 9/18.

This weekend at Holiday Beach, the Monarch movement has not waned. Every day last week up to and including Saturday & Sunday the movement of Monarchs has been incredible. At times on Saturday, some of us down at the passerine station had difficulty distinguishing Broad-winged Hawks with Monarchs. Always, Monarchs, Monarchs and more Monarchs in the mix of our binocs! On Saturday and Sunday night, Carl & I counted many roosts of several hundred on the cottonwood and poplar tree-tops. The movement of monarchs along the shore is unlike any I have seen.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 1000 monarchs based on observer’s comment of “counted many roosts of several hundred”

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

A week ago (approx. 9/11)I saw the arrival of about 50 monarch to our yard.  They seem to like the hard maple, sweet gum and bushes in the shade.  Today early in the a.m., I spotted about 100 roosting andcircling in my yard. After notifying the local school, students who came earlier in the day were encircled with the monarchs.  As I walk through the yard, I feel like it is a fairyland and I am blessed to be able to share this wonder of nature with the children and adults in the community.

My first migration sighting!!!! In the park outside of the Japanese Garden on the UI campus. Butterflies were roosting on the shady side of trees all over the park. Met a woman and her child there and she said she was an entomologist from Turkey and she called them "King" butterflies. I almost corrected her until I realized that of course that would be a proper name/translation for them. Went at 13:30 and again at 18:00 today (9/18/07). Seemed to be more in the afternoon, and another lady said there were even more there the previous day(9/17/07). It was very cool here this last weekend (37 F) and not it is back in the upper 80s. It was an amazing site.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present, although the roost are appears to have been large. We are estimating a minimum of 1,000 since she said they were "trees all over the park." We are marking this record as a JN staff estimate.

Joy abounds. This evening, 9/19 from 5:30 to 7:30 pm, we counted roughly 300 monarchs sailing through Tunnel Gap on the Blue Ridge Parkway. This is milepost BRP 415.6; around 25 miles southwest of Asheville, NC. Most were just beyond netting reach, sailing, gliding SSW through the gap right towards the beautiful Looking Glass Rock. Nice photo of the rock at: http://www.ncwaterfalls.com/prints/brp31_print.htm

As expected, many roosted in the old Northern Red Oaks and Chestnut Oak trees at the overlook. Roosting time for the ones in our view at 7:30pm; temp 64dF; winds stiff from the north. A glorious warm sunny day brought to a close with beauty. Wish everyone everywhere had access to this.

About 5:00 I saw one monarch land in swamp maple tree in my backyard on Peaksail Drive,Bayville, New Jersey -- it landed - then apparently decided it didn't like the location and took off -- was I ever disappointed.  I had hoped to see the hundreds that I had witnessed in 2006.Still looking.

We live on a farm in South Central Nebraska (Gosper County). We have had what seemed like millions resting in our tree claim on our farm. This is the first time we have had so many. They do not venture into my yard with flowers or anything, just in the trees (elms and evergreens) in our windbreak. WHAT A LOVELY SIGHT THEY ARE AND SO ENJOYABLE TO WATCH!

I saw about 100 monarchs roosting in our neighbor's tree and lilac bush.  Last year monarchs had roosted in trees in our pasture nearby.

Just returned from a week on Mt. Desert Island, Maine. Monarchs in good numbers were seen migrating every day from Sept 15-21. On Sunday Sept 16, with a north wind, monarchs by the hundreds were dropping from the sky at the southern tip of the island at Bass Harbor Head Light (44 degrees 13.3' N, 68 degrees 20.3' W). They were nectaring in a small meadow on the hillside above the lighthouse. Prime nectar sources were seaside goldenrod, Rand's goldenrod, and 2 other unidentified goldenrod species, red clover, calico aster,and purple-stemmed aster. Each plant supported dozens of monarchs.

Around 5PM monarchs perched on spruce trees to bask. I'm sure there was a roost that night somewhere in the spruces. On Sept 20, north of Mt. Desert Island at Petit Manan NWR, monarchs were seen migrating against a southwest wind, hugging the rocky coastline and stopping to nectar on asters and goldenrods growing in rock crevices. Winds were from the south for the remainder of the week, but monarchs continued with powered flight, pushing onward against the wind.

This evening I saw my first monarch overnight roosting spot. Between the hour of 6:15 - 7:15 pm I saw over 50 butterflies landing on a large oak tree. Their primary branch was about 20 feet off the ground. The sun was starting to set. A fall day and a warmer evening with a breeze.  Predicted rain overnight and tomorrow. Wow...

Sunday afternoon on the Blue Ridge Parkway near Grandfather Mountain in North Carolina (Lat. 36.08 N ), the sky was blue, but dotted with orange and black. My friend, Aubrie, and I tagged 125 monarchs in four hours before we ran out of tags. Our friends, Carolyn and John were able to count 1033 monarchs during that time. John looked out from the ridge through his binoculars and could see lots more flying. So we know there were many monarchs passing by that were not counted. Around 5:30, while Aubrie and I were still tagging, John and Carolyn noticed that the monarchs were beginning to alter their behavior. Rather than moving on through, the butterflies began to circle back and remain in the area. When our tags were depleted (and most of our energy!) we sat on the grass and enjoyed watching dozens of monarchs nectaring on the goldenrod and asters six feet in front of us. As the light faded and the temperature dropped we watched intently, hoping to discover where the monarchs would roost for the night. The leeward side of a nearby oak tree seemed to be the favored spot. As the chill began to affect us as well, we decided to end our wonderful day on the Blue Ridge and head to our own roosting sites. What a glorious, fun day!

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present. We entered 'one' in the number field only to mark this record for future consideration.

From Sat. Sept. 22 through Monday Sept. 24, we had those strong south winds and warm temperatures that kept the Monarchs from traveling. the numbers built steadily over those days. On Sat., there were several dozen. By Sunday evening, there were over 100 roosting in the trees.

Monday, during the day, the New England asters, zinnias, and cosmos were covered with them. Approximately 300 roosting that night. Over night, a cold front came through, bringing a breeze from the north. By 9:00 Tuesday morning, the butterflies were gone. This morning, I saw a lone Monarch nectaring at an aster.

9-24...thru 9-26I observed my first roost on 9-23.{previous report}The next morning..about 1 hour after sunrise they began to flutter...and most left.The eve. of 9-24...and thru 9-25 has been much cooler. we had a much neede rain..then cloudy. There were about 40 monarchs roosting the eve of 9-24 same branch..oak tree.The eve was windy...they "rode" those leaves...much like a surfer would ride the waves. The morning of the 25th was rain.a drizzle alternating w showers/thunder.letting up some in the afternoon....Ii checked them frequently that day...about the same number stayed until later afternoon.{about 330 pm}watching them in the rain...all hanging...w wings folded..not moving much at all. There were proably more..as when still with closed wings they look like dead leaves.i did not see most of them leaving...I saw only ..about 10 that eve.This morning {26}was clear and cool. Not a single monarch on any visible branch in my location. This eve  I saw 2 flying .

Went out in an attempt to tag more monarchs, and walked a trail in to a sunflower field.  We did not see any monarchs, until walking out on the same trail.  At ~7PM, we started seeing monarchs flying in to a large grove of trees.  We counted over 30, and it appeared they were heading in to roost.  Amazing sight!!  We could only imagine what this same phenomena would look like at the over-wintering sights, but were thrilled to see this in our own neck of the woods...

Over the past couple of weeks I have sighted just a smattering of Monarch. But the wind turned strongly out of the north here on Monday night and on Tuesday I spent the whole day wandering about the ranch and saw literally hundreds of Monarchs, all traveling with a purpose on that strong northerly breeze.

Late Tuesday, the wind laid and Monarchs by the dozens gathered in the oaks, mulberry and shrubbery here at the ranchheadquarters for the night. It was quite a sight. The temperature dipped to about 55 degrees up here last night (9/26/07).

I took the other fork of the trail back an hour later, so I don't know if they were still there. During two days of birding there, I was really impressed with the numbers of Monarchs, especially in the Sand Creek Bay area. I hope this may help...George-Tulsa

Today, Sunday was another stellar day for monarchs arriving in Cape May.  All day long monarchs dropped out of the sky and many stopped to nectar or rest.  Around 5 pm we went down to the point and hiked around; found one large roosting area--at least 15 trees had many monarchs flying in (well over a 1000 is my guess though I am not good with the numbers). Alot of walking to check out all the favorite roosting areas.  Found several smaller roosts 12-30 and by the time we got back to the large roosting area, it was getting dark  so we couldn't clearly see the size of the roost; they were, however, from low to quite high up into the trees.  Magnificent!  The next day, most seemed to have moved on.

After having large numbers here last weekend on the 22nd and 23rd things slowed down this week. I tagged zero on the 25th, 10-26th, and 6 on the 27th. Tonight, (9/28)however, another large wave has arrived in my trees. One large cluster of about 50 and smaller clusters scattered around the trees.

My husband and I garden for birds, bees and butterflies. We keep a healthystand of New England Asters so that the butterflies will have this beacon every year for the flight South. Every late September we watch the skies for the Monarch to just marvel at the beauty and determination of migration.The Monarchs roost in the trees around the yard -- maples, tulip poplars, etc, and we watch in the early mornings as they begin to emerge to linger to soak up the warm sunlight on the turning leaves of dogwoods. My goal is to just see the Monarchs each year and know that they are still there.

It was sunny, in the mid-80s, on Sept 30 but windy, with wind mostly from the west, northwest. Thunderstorms were predicted for the night.

In the morning, at table, looking out, the sun was falling on Dogwood leaves that were turning a rusty color, I saw two Monarchs on the leaves warming up and drying out from the dew. On the Buddleia, which is in the sun most of the day, six to eight Monarchs were on it throughout the day gathering nectar. On the New England Asters, where Monarchs usually gather, there were none but bees gathering pollen covered the flowers. Monarchs that were flying seemed to fly randomly because they seemed to be floating around the lower tree branches.

Between 3:00 and 3:20 pm, on 9/30/07, I was carrying a bucket of water to some plants and passed under an allee of Silver Maples, Dogwoods and Redbuds with under shrubs Purple Spirea, Forsythia and Common Mock Orange. Sun filtered through the leaves. I may have disturbed a resting or roosting area because 30 to 40 Monarchs swarmed out of the branches and softly flew in swirling patterns over my head then spread out. About 10 minutes later, I walked back into the area and several Monarchs had settled back on the Mock Orange shrub.

Around sundown, about 6:30 pm, three Monarchs flew into the lower branches of Silver Maples

1000's of Monarchs. The sky is filled with Monarchs. The tree branches are lined with Monarchs. They started coming into our yard on 9/29/07 and are still here on 9/30/07.

I went out the next night to get more pictures but they were gone. We live in Springfield, MO, a city of 120,000 people. Pretty cool for living in the middle of town!

Spectacular migration day!

9 AM to 10 AM
Wind NW 10 - 15 MPH
Approximately 2,280 Monarchs per hour flying southwest along ocean shoreMost were flying low < 10 feet off the ground and fighting the wind to avoid being blown out over the ocean. At over wash areas - where there is no dune or vegetation to provide any protection from the wind - about one out of three were being swept out over the ocean. Some were able to make it back to shore with great effort.

10AM to Noon
Wind N 10 MPH
Monarchs soaring very high (with migrating hawks and eagles) and not visible with naked eye. When scanning with binoculars you could see 30 to 50 monarchs within a binocular view.

5PM to 6PM - at Tom's Hook, the southern most tip of Assateague Island.

I had a great experience yesterday (9/30) which I would like to pass on to you. A local farmer called me approximately at noon and indicated that he had seen a huge amount of monarchs adjacent to a field in the Neosho river bottom. I went to the location with the presumption that I might see a few hundred or even a few thousand monarchs. The population was much greater. Obviously, I cannot give you an accurate amount or even a valid estimate. I do know that it was very large. The monarchs were located in a woods adjacent to a field of sunflowers that I would say was at least 400 acres. The sunflowers were in full bloom. The wood circles the entire field. In addition, there is a levee which is approximately 15 feet tall.

Sunday, we had a strong southerly breeze that was probably 20 to 30 miles per hour with stronger gusts. I don't know if the monarchs had congregated because of the nectar source, the strong southerly winds, and the protection provided by the woods and levees, or for some other reason. Regardless, it was one of those once in a lifetime experiences. Many were clinging to the leaves of the trees and many more were flying in the wood and the open fields to the North of the levee and tree line. As indicated, it would be impossible to estimate the total. As you probably now I have been to Sierra Chincua and Rosario. While these butterflies were not that dense, there certainly was a large concentration. I know at least in the tens of thousands. I followed the tree line around the sunflower field for approximately ï¿½ mile in both directions and the concentration seemed to be uniformed the whole 1 mile distance. Many of the trees had a dense concentration of butterflies. The butterflies were not hanging from each other in a curtain effect but they were dense. The trees located right on the levees did not exceed15 to 20 feet in height.

While my amateur observation may be incorrect the butterflies appeared to me to be in fairly good shape overall. They appeared to have fairly plump bodies, fairly large wing spans, and overall there wings appeared to be in fairly good shape. Quite frankly, I was a little worried at least about the monarch local population. I did not have nearly as many caterpillars this year in my Waystation stations as last year. I was hopeful that this was due to the fact that we have had lots of rain and lots of wildflowers so they were not concentrating on flower gardens as much. Regardless of that issue, I certainly saw a huge amount of monarchs yesterday. I don't know how long they have been there or how long they will be staying. It rained last night, a front is going through, and the wind may change. I am going to check the location tonight to see if they are still there.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 20000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “ten's of thousands.”

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Roost of 100+ Monarchs found in a treeline of blackjacks north of Dover, Okla.- 9 miles north of Kingfisher.
My sister in Elk City, Oklahoma, said today that a tree in her back yard was covered with over a thousand monarchs.

This past weekend, Sept 29-30, I anticipated huge numbers of monarchs passing through Waystation #182.

Despite many hours in the landscape and really prodigious numbers of asters, goldenrods, zinnias, marigolds, verbena, eupatorium and tithonia in bloom, I saw a single monarch. The weather was warm with daytime highs in upper 70s, full sun and little wind. From Chincoteague, perhaps 150 miles to my southeast, Denise Gibbs was reporting thousands of monarchs feeding.

Last night (10/2), getting home on a day when the temperatures were in the mid 80s and the sun again without clouds blocking its heating, I found 8 monarchs feeding in a single clump of tithonia. They looked fresh; none were tagged. Additionally 3-4 monarchs were visiting other plants at our waystation. By dusk, the tithonia feeding monarchs headed towards a nearby row of large white pines to roost.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

On Wednesday October 3rd, we saw approx 100 Monarchs in their annual roosting location on our ranch just North of Sweetwater.  They come every year without exception to roost in the tall willow trees along a 1/2 mile stretch of a creek that rust through the property. It is always within the first week of October. On Thursday there were about 400, and last night (Oct.5) we estimated 2000.  We usually peak out within 3-5 days of the first arrivals with anywhere from 100,000 to 500,000!  We will head out again today to see if more arrived overnight and report back. Even the 2000 here last night was a spectacular sight! --mike--

At Monarch Waystation #182, 6 miles east of the Blue Ridge crest, today, October 7, was a major day of change. Since Tuesday, Oct 2, we've had from 6 to 14 monarchs in view at once in a large Tithonia planting between 6 PM and dusk each evening. This evening there are none despite very warm temps and nearly calm winds.

This morning, activity was as it's been around the Tithonia with as many as 8 monarchs nectaring. At about 9:30 AM, under rapidly warming conditions and a slight wind from the southeast, we walked through pasture and meadow nearby. We at first could see small numbers of monarchs coming off roosting trees and beginning to move ssw 50-100 ft from the ground. Within about 20 minutes, we began to see monarchs passing above us at the rate of 10-15 per minute. Some of those lower in the air column were coming to ground level to feed at bluemist flower, Conoclinium coelestinum. Others, by 10:20 AM, and with a rapidly changing wind pattern that swung around to WNW and picked up to 15-20 mph, were up riding thermals with black and turkey vultures at 500-perhaps 2000 ft. Over the next 30 mins, we continued to see many migrating monarchs and with perhaps every 100 monarchs, 1-2 buckeyes, flying in the same direction but with a really different flap pattern. We got back home from our walk at 11:30 AM and had 4-5 monarchs at the Tithonia until perhaps 2 PM. The winds had died down, the temps neared 90 degrees and we haven't seen a monarch since.

It is likely that thousands of monarchs passed through our neighborhood this AM; this was certainly the biggest push we've witnessed since Sept 12, 2001.

Despite the monarchs departure, the abnormal warm and abundance of remaining flowering plants kept hundreds of other butterflies, numerous bee species, moths, flies and wasps well-fed. Oct 12 is my traditional frost date here. It may reach 65 for a low tonight.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Saturday night (10/13) about 7:30 p.m. my husband called me to come to the yard. There they were. Literally hundreds of Monarchs on our 70 year old Junipers. As many as 5-6 were clustered on one small branch as well as on many, many other branches. They were also fluttering and landing quite high in Pine trees , pecans and crepe myrtles. I would say Monarchs have definitely arrived in large numbers to eastern Dallas County. Couldn't check today (10/15) for we had an inch of rain early this morning. We even lost a huge limb on an old red oak tree. It has been cloudy all day. They are definitely east of 35, south of 80 and north of 20. We will check again tomorrow as the weather is predicted to be clear. This is so much fun. We do all we can to have a natural yard, no pesticides, don't rake leaves as they fall. Later we mulch them and add to compost. We grow lots of butterfly attracting flowers in containers under our old trees.

Tuesday (10/23/07) saw 20-25 monarchs, the first day this fall I have seen numbers. Yesterday morning (10/24/07) just as the sun was first hitting my yard, I walked along the outer edge, checking butterflies that might be sunning. The trees and high shrubs contained 120 to 150 Monarchs, most perched with wings spread, warming their bodies. Very few other butterflies were active that early. Within a half hour or so the Monarchs begin to move to my numerous crucitas shrubs (Eupatorium odoratum) to feed. At any one time I could see 25-30 individuals close together on a couple sunny sites. Within the next couple hours they began moving about, sampling nectar on my numerous crucitas and/or white mistflower shrubs (Epatorium wrightii); few also utilizing duranta shrubs. This action continued until about noon. Gradually, apparently after adequately feeding, individuals began to move off, all seemingly heading southward, some fly low but most 20 to 50 feet above the ground. This southward movement continued for much of the afternoon. But more individuals appeared from the north, flying over the adjacent treeline to drop into my yard to feed. It seemed that at no time all day did I have less than 100 (est) individuals visible at any time. By late afternoon, with the sun still highlighting a number of crucitas, feeding activity continued at a high pitch. It seemed that fewer individuals were moving off; the vast majority of the activity was centered around the sunny patches of crucitas. During the last ten years that I have been paying attention to my yard butterflies, yesterday's Monarch numbers represented an all-time high. I will repeat my visits again today. Other obvious "migrants" included Cloudless and Large Orange Sulphurs, both American and Painted Ladies, Red Admirals, and Queens.

Report courtesy of Mike Quinn, via Texas Butterfly Listserv

"The Rio Grande Valley (southmost Texas) usually does not get lots of monarch reports," wrote Mike Quinn, Texas Parks and Wildlife as he forwarded this report: We estimate 125-150 Monarch butterflies are roosting in our neighborhood in Edinburg tonight (10/24/07). I counted 75 in an Anaqua tree in the back yard, and we saw another roost across the street and enough butterflies on the wing to make up the difference. Also seen in Edinburg today were Queens,Sicklewing skippers, a Mimosa yellow, a Pipevine swallowtail and a Fatal metalmark. Photos of some of today's goodness can be seen athttp://www.flickr.com/photos/annetoalP>Report courtesy of Mike Quinn, via Texas Butterfly Listserv.

October 24Got a call before six from a farm west of town of a large cluster in a hackberry tree. On the causeway, my wife Altus said there were more monarchs than she had ever seen. Fantastic numbers between 2-4 pm falling out in the area. I started out across the causeway when I went back and counted 89 monarchs coming at me in the first mile and then just quit counting. We saw clusters forming up on everything that could support monarchs, starting about 3:30. Some clusters two to threehundred and still growing. You couldn't drive along the beach road at more than a crawl because of the cloud of monarchs in the grass and dead sunflowers along the edge. Some snapshots from earlier in the afternoon that just didn't do justice to the event! Salt cedar and false willow are both blooming. Some queens in the clusters, to be expected, but I could see some buckeyes in with the monarchs ... not sure about that!One of my ex-students with TxDOT stopped by at the causeway to be see if I was over there or he was going to call me to tell me the monarchs had arrived. The wind really stiffened from the NW after 1:00 and is out of the NE right now, not sure what that means for tomorrow. At least we had two great days.October 25Flow continues…Best hourly avg 800+. Best 5 min 331 at 1:30Really large cluster/roost. The morning warmup took quite awhile and new arrivals were there before yesterday's crowd wanted to go. By noon it was a parade of monarchs coming by and over. The times I went across the causeway I wondered why there wasn't a wreck. There would be what I would estimate to be a hundred monarchs in a space the size of my bedroom enjoying a pillow of air. I've only seen it like this one other time ... Some really nice clusters/roosts formed just before sundown.Altus is really good when it comes to spotting a large amount of orange! Not sure why most had their wings open, just did.Biggest cluster we have ever seen, in the middle of a "round", formed by mostly salt cedar, a couple of mesquite, and a hackberry ... that amphitheatre we always hear that they will find ...The wind is changing and so may be the fun, may be one more day ... October 26Early liftoff of clusters ... area cleared before 8:00 but new flow had already opened. Best count so far 12:00 to 12:30: half hour of 1,156 for hourly of 2,312. Best 1 minute count was 43. Best count crossing the 3.1 mile causeway, 194 in 5 minutes. It was like this at 8:00 and was getting better at 12:00, the calm wind may make a difference this afternoon. Same location near TX35, Alcoa Bluff, and north end of peninsula to Lavaca Bay Causeway, ... same place, same way as last year.I can see a width of about 300' and an altitude about 200'. I crossed over to west side and got into the stream ... they were coming from 65 deg and leaving out across the bay to245 deg. I could see twenty coming and twenty lined up out across the bay. Checked with binoculars, there are a few above 200', the most action is in the lower 100' and I can see that without binocs. Many other butterflies showing up today now that it is calm. Calm, slight whisper out of NW, 76 dF, 18 % humidity, deep clear sky. This is all about to change. Wind switched from NNW to NNE to E then to SE between 3:30 and 4:30 and the monarchs went away on the east side of the peninsula. There was still a river of monarchs coming off Alcoa bluff, crossing TX 35, and going down the west side. Altus drove over there just before sundown and found that the monarchs were heading across the bay and then returning ... clusters started forming on the west of almost every tree/shrub along the high tide line as far as she could drive. *We went back after dark and the clusters were the largest in size and coverage we had ever seen. * We only drove along about half a mile of the shell road but the clusters kept going on trees/scrubs back towards Point Comfort. Next front Monday, couldn't be any better? October 27With the wind turning turning more to the NNE and then NE the monarchs have slowed down or are somewhere's else. Liftoff of the clusters started about sunup this morning and was finished by 8:30. Best hour flyby would avg to 250. Best drive across the causeway/peninsula was a count of 50. Counted 150 nectaring on the peninsula about noon.Predicted to be a stronger NNE to NE wind tomorrow, up to 25 mph, still crystal clear, low humidity, 23% mid day, temp mid 70's.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present, although the roosts appear to have been very large. We are estimating 10,000 butterflies and are marking this record as a JN staff estimate. This estimate is based on fact that this is a very experienced observer in Texas and this was the most he has ever seen. He saw “clusters forming up on everything that could support monarchs” (See the wide variety of snapshots provided.) He witnessed strong migration on the Causeway that went on for 3 days with a flow of 2,312 per hour on one count. Clearly this was a major migration event with a spectacular number of monarchs.
All photos taken on north end of Lavaca Bay Causewayhttp://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2407.htmlhttp://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2507am.html http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct2507pm.html

We have had thousands of monarchs on the Island. I live very close to the Gulf of Mexico and have many palm trees near my house. The monarchs roosted last evening and this evening (10-24 & 10-25) in the hundreds on the palm fronds. I have taken several photos of this and would be happy to share. What a grand sight this has been. (October 26th update: They have left now, and I don't see many flying. For two days it was the best. Wednesday & Thursday were prolific. Wednesday evening they roosted in my trees and then again on Thursday evening.)

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 200 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “hundreds.”

October 25
I would not even hazard a guess, but I do think I've seen thousands of them today. I am assuming that this is part of the peak in their migration. Some monarchs are spending the night in my neighbor's palm trees here in West Galveston, right near the Galveston Island State Park. My neighbor took pictures, but the monarchs are folded up and hanging from the brown ends of the leaves and are very hard to see. The neighbor said, "it is absolutely thrilling what is happeningin my area. I have lived on the coast for 7 years and never have I seenthis many monarchs. It truly is breathtaking." They had slowed down a bit (5:30 pm), but they are still very dense. Please note there are many small butterflies--not monarchs--also in this group.

October 26
It's almost 9 am and the monarchs are almost gone today...just a few small ones going by our house so far this morning.

Editor’s Note: We are estimating a minimum of 2000 monarchs based on observer’s estimate of “thousands.”

The monarchs were swarming and roosting in my trees around 6:30pm CST October 25, 2007. A few stopped over last year. This year there are 10 times more. I have photos that I can send.

While taking a break at work downtown Houston Continental Airlines Headquarters, I noticed some monarchs flying towards the park accross the street. It just took seconds to realize something special was going on as a monarchs were descending out of the sky every 15-20 seconds from high altitude towards the park. It reminded me of a busy airport. I followed a few of them to one tree where to my surprise - the top of the tree was covered with them.
Time:evening - sunset
Activity: Monarchs were going to roost.
Numbers: Too many to count, arrival rate to tree every 15-20 seconds. Not sure how long, as I had to go back into work.Wind direction out of the North, becoming variable, to calm after sunset. merc 2997 millibars 1014.9. Temp 65F, forecasted low 44F.This is the tail end of the cold front that blew through for past 3 days.

Editor's Note: This observer did not specify the number of monarchs present, although the roost appears to have been very large.

Today we went to South Padre Island and saw well over 100 monarchs at the Civic Center. There is a landscaped area there that attracts birds and butterflies. The monarchs were roosting although it was after noon, a sunny warm day. A few were flying away, but mostly the flying was short-lived as they tried to settle back on the roosts quickly after being disturbed. I caught a mating pair on camera. Then we went to Estero Llano Grande [SP] in Weslaco and saw dozens of monarchs, all nectaring on the Crucita and White Plumbago there. No monarchs roosting at Llano Grande.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn, Texas Department of Fish and Game

At 11 am this morning monarchs were sighted in the city of Queretaro, Queretaro by Raï¿½l Zubieta! "We saw a lot of monarchs in the Queretaro downtown, and the Alameda (a small Park) could be another overnighting site."Raï¿½l Zubieta is a student of Drs. Isabel Ramirz and Lincoln Brower.
