They took their sweet time getting here: After the major push of Monarchs apparently went through W Texas and the western Hill Country, only today did I finally see substantial numbers of Monarchs moving and nectaring in the I-35/Balcones Escarpment corridor.

I spent a long day birding in western Bell County and adjacent parts of Burnet and Lampasas Cos. This morning at Stillhouse Hollow Reservoir west of Belton, many Monarchs got up and started moving about 10 a.m. Many of these Monarchs undoubtedly came into the area on the NE winds the previous day but they did not make it far as Austin as of yesterday evening. (I was on my roof watching in the late afternoon and saw only 3 or 4.)

Today's numbers were gratifying but not massive. I probably saw 1000 Monarchs today in an 11-hour field day. The early morning was calm, but by about 10 a.m., winds at Stillhouse Hollow Lake picked up strong out of the SE for a time. Monarchs were struggling to move SW in those headwinds or crosswinds. After mid-morning, just about anywhere I was in the Belton-Temple-Stillhouse Hollow area, I would see 2 to 10 passing per minute at any location. Any scan of the sky with binoculars would detect 10 to 20 in the air. By mid-afternoon, winds were actually calming a bit and most Monarchs in the air were powering S or SW with little difficulty.

Nectar resources are limited in the region. There was a smattering of Liatris blooming in upland areas of western Bell and Lampasas County but I did not see Monarchs visiting that. The major resources were primarily only in the immediate floodplain of the Lampasas River and the margins of Stillhouse Hollow Lake. These included patches of Marsh Fleabane ((Pluchea purpurascens) which have grown on the exposed mudflats and the male False Willows (Depression Weed; Baccharisneglecta) which are patchy but fairly numerous along the lake margins and river banks.

By late afternoon, numbers of Monarchs were gathering to roost in willow groves along the Lampasas River and also in the big oak groves in Lampasas (City) at Hancock Park.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

I noticed individual Monarchs flying throughout the neighborhood during my morning walk. But dozens have been congregating and roosting in sunny areas in my and my neighbor's trees for the past few hours.

Editor's Note: We are estimating the roost size as at least 36 butterflies since the observer counted "dozens."

My husband & I noticed lots of Monarch Butterflies flying around our yard this morning (10/19). Upon closer observation, we saw that there were many on our mesquite tree & oak tree branches. I tried to count them, and it appeared that throughout our yard there were over 150 perched in our trees. It seemed as though they were resting as there were several flowering plants that didn't interest them. It was quite a sight when more butterflies flew in and the sky was filled with a flurry of these beauties! It's the first time we've ever seen this as we are relatively new to this area of Texas. I hope they stay awhile! :-)

¡Las mariposas se ven por cientos ya en la ciudad de Monterrey!. Por la mañana observamos alrededor de 500 perchando y alimentándose en 3 árboles de Sombrilla china o Melia azedarach. Y en el camino al trabajo, logramos contar 5 mariposas por minuto en un tramo de 6 kilómetros. Todas aprovechando el viento del Noroeste. Un día fresco y despejado, al parecer, ¡favorable para la migración!

Courtesy of Correo Real

¡Anoche las mariposas durmieron en mi escuela!

Esta mañana al salir al recreo a las 10:30h, vimos muchas mariposas monarcas volando por los jardines y encontramos como 500 formando racimos en un pirul y un pino, ahí durmieron anoche igual que otros años. Mi escuela se llama Benemérito de las Américas y está al oriente de Saltillo sobre el Blvd. Fundadores.Ayer a las 7 de la tarde las vimos 32 volando al oriente en el Parque Maravillas. Tibio y con viento ligero.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Ayer 17 a las 18:30 hs. en el "Rancho Los Cuijes" (Km. 20 carretera antigua a Monclova), con viento suave del NNO, comenzaron a llegar a razón de 5-6 por minuto, buscando abrigo en los árboles del rancho como en años anteriores, sólo que hoy no encontraron el eucalipto gigante que les servía para ello, pues las heladas de febrero pasado lo mataron y las ramas secas no sirven para protegerlas por lo cual se conformaron en racimos en un cedro y los mezquites que hay en el lugar.La temperatura era de 17 ° C.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Before Monday monarchs were the local just hatched 5th Generation monarchs and scattered out among the trees. My net scooped up 24 in a single cluster and I missed others from that same group. Only saw about 45 all told. These were above a lateral canal in dense trees beside the Cunningham Ranch. I had to stand in the back of the jeep with a long-handled net. I'd estimate they were about 14' off the ground.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: At our local walking area right on Nueces Bay. A mile long nature walk. Hundreds were flying all around our heads as we walked. They were beginning to find roosts in the short trees right along the paths!  It was absolutely incredible!  Our house only about a couple of miles away but still on the water have only seen one or two at a time. The one time I walked without my phone! Other people were taking pictures from just inches away!  Very little wind last two days to move them along but wind will pick up out of the SE later today.

On Monday (10/10/11), Tuesday (10/11/11), Wednesday (10/12/11) 800 to 900+ monarchs were observed (each day)roosting at Wise Point, which is the very bottom tip of the Delmarva Peninsula on the Virginia Eastern Shore. Coastal Virginia Wildlife Observatory Monarch Biologist Anna Lisa Diaz has been doing roost site counts each day.

after 3pm, my garden gets shaded & most of the monarchs I thought took off today.. to my delight there were 25 monarchs feasting on these yellow flowers by our waterfront. they weren't very organized.. meaning they didn't go up to one single tree to roost.. some went to the top of our hickory tree (very big tree) some to the red oak & others to a sweet gum.  this is a small roost compared to most reported, another first for me to witness.

October 24
The location was the same as I reported. Approx. 12-20 monarchs refueling/resting/roosting on a 10 ft tall butterfly bush. The time was from 4:00 - 5:00 p.m. This location is a riding stable close to where Irmo and Columbia city limits join. We have had some lively and informative talks about monarchs both yesterday and today. I will look for the monarchs at the same place and time today.

October 21
I had seen a large monarch (approx. 50-60) migration when I lived in southeast Iowa 4 years ago (in late September), so I knew that the monarchs were gathering to refuel and rest for the night here in SC on 10/21/11. They roosted on a butterfly bush (about 10 ft tall, dense foliage and lilac colored flowers). There were about 10-20 monarchs. I was there for about 1 hr. (4:30 - 5:30 pm.) I returned the next day about noon and there were about 6-8 monarchs on the same bush......When I saw the monarchs in Iowa, I was accompanied only by my German Shepherd dog and I was so excited but had no one to share this experience. It was so amazing to see 1 or 2 monarchs arriving every few minutes from the northeast pasture to join the large group in my 2 maple trees. It was as though the group was waiting for the stragglers. How exciting! I wish I had seen their departure but I did not. I love monarchs and am happy to be a small part in watching and learning about them.

October 26
I went down to Lighthouse Field today (it is about 100 yards from the ocean), and saw a bunch of beauties. I will attach a few photos of them, but I also video taped them for a couple minutes so you could see a few of the clusters in the trees. I've put the video on youtube so that you can see it. Its title is, "Monarchs 10-26-11." I was standing in one spot and filming part of one of the eucalyptus trees. The area is only about 1 acre, but provides a home for a bunch of monarchs. Two miles south of this spot is Natural Bridges State Park. I'm told that there are about 100,000 monarchs there. Pretty cool!

October 23
We have observed many monarchs flying over our schoolyard. Some of them are going north and then turn around to fly south towards Natural Bridges State Park. As of this evening, there are 100s of monarchs fluttering around the eucalyptus trees of Lighthouse Field in Santa Cruz.

Photo taken on October 26th!

With clearing weather finally arriving late yesterday (10/22), Monarchs began tomove at Point Pelee.

This morning at the extreme Tip there were 120 clustered on bushes, whichwere yesterday's arrivals. But today with even nicer weather themigration intensified, with Monarchs everywhere all flying south.

In total today I saw about 400-500 individuals, including the original120 at the Tip.

Likely tomorrow morning there will be a significant concentration at theTip, especially since rain is predicted with strong SW winds ---conditions not suitable for leaving the Tip.

Courtesy of Don Davis
They were so pretty and when it was getting nightfall they went to the pine trees to rest.

In the ten years that I've been working as a naturalist at Point Pelee National Park, I have never observed roosts of more than two or three hundred later than the 9th of October. So I was surprised to see a roost of 900 monarchs yesterday (23rd Oct.) Then today, a migration rate of 10 monarchs per minute flying southwards through the park with a roost of 1300 tonight (24th Oct.) And with a sunny day tomorrow, this may continue.

It is true that the last half of August and the first week of September has been warmer than normal, allowing late caterpillars to complete their metamorphosis to the adult stage, giving us this late migration.

In addition, we have experienced October weather in September this year with 7 extra days of rain above the normal for September. Add to this 8 days of rain from the 12th to the 20th of October and you get a total extra migratory delay of 15 days. Here at Point Pelee we usually get a pulse of migrating monarchs in the first week of October with roosts of about 1,000 butterflies. The extra rain this year could easily account for this late pulse to arrive here two weeks later than normal.

The danger for monarchs migrating in late October is strong winds (as we've seen from last week's report on Journey North) and the first frosts of the fall season. We have had our first frost this past Saturday the 22nd October. So these monarchs are really living on the edge. We wish for them a steady breeze from the northeast and sunny days to speed them on their way to join their friends who are already in Mexico.

Today I saw at least 200 monarchs nectaring and roosting in small trees in our woods. I had been seeing bright monarchs flying this past week one at a time, a couple each day. But it was a wonderful surprise to walk into our woods this afternoon and see this abundance of monarchs. There is one particular type of tree that they are feeding from, but I do not know what it is. The trees are about 15-20 feet tall with slender grey trunks. The favorite trees sometimes held 25 monarchs, some of which appeared to be resting while most were nectaring. There seemed to be a continuous sporadic movement of monarchs through the woods.
The wind was brisk today in advance of another predicted cold front coming through on Thursday. We have seen many Monarchs the last three days.

Nine monarchs heading  south gathered on  locust tree . First two arrived with in minutes of one another and flew about the tree line before settling on high roost.  Seven others arrived over next 10 - 15 minutes.  An incredible experience since each of the lone flyers seemed to know just where they were going.

At a minimum 100 monarchs were observed roosting in a juniper tree located in the sinkhole entrance to Natural Bridge Caverns. A second roost was sighted approximately 200 feet from the cave entrance. This second roost contained an estimated 30 monarchs.

Over Friday, Saturday and Sunday I spotted about 100 monarchs. The three days were sunny, low 60's in the daytime and 40's at night with a light westerly wind. The monarchs seem to be roosting much earlier in the day(4-5pm) compared to their predecessors who migrated through a few weeks earlier. They also appear to be flying more over the water now, then the earlier migrators who flew over the land.

Absolutely beautiful between 250-300 butterflies, were in my Mesquite trees which they preferred to the other trees in my yard.

we have been pretty dry, but my neighbor and I have water out of the birds and also hibiscus and Pride of Barbados blooming right now, so perhaps that was their water/ nectar source. They seemed to be attracted to my mesquite trees, I also have oak, hackberry, and ash trees in my yard, but they mostly were attracted to the mesquite. I am not sure when they left, but they seemed to have have come in around 4:30 in the afternoon and were still there after dark, so not sure if they stayed the night.

We had just had a cold front blow in and wind changed from south to north the day they arrived and we had a pretty strong wind from the north. I live right across the street from Baffin Bay( salt water bay) on the coast of Texas.

The Matagorda Bay Natural Science Center has been witnessing the migration for over a week, but yesterday evening (10/28) the monarchs roosted between the dunes and behind the center in attempt to not be blown into the Gulf of Mexico. Strong North winds have the insects hanging on for dear life as many are blowing off shore. We have awesome video again this year but unable to upload. Please see picture attached.Thank you,Rhonda

Desde hace tres días, hemos tenido a las monarca revoloteando por todas partes en los alrededores deQuerétaro.En la zona norte de la ciudad (Jurica y Juriquilla) en las mañanas -que ha estado haciendo frío-, se vengrupos de 50 ó más individuos y grandes concentraciones durmiendo en los fresnos. En el transcursodel día se ven a baja altura en los jardines y parques, sin rumbo fijo.

Courtesy of Correo Real

El miércoles 26 de octubre a las 6:30pm observé un grupo de aproximadamente 50 monarcas que sedisponían a descansar en árboles de casuarina en un parque que se encuentra al sur de la ciudad deQuerétaro. Había poco viento y la temperatura era de aproximadamente 17 grados centígrados.

Courtesy of Correo Real

PRIMEROS INFORMES DE LA RESERVA DE LA BIOSFERA MARIPOSA MONARCA

Las monarcas se acercan a su palacio de inviernoYa se comenzaron a registrar grupos de mariposas sobrevolando la región oriente y poniente de los estadosde Michoacán y Estado de México, respectivamente. El día 26 de octubre alrededor de las 14:00 horas seobservaron mariposas a la altura de la pequeña propiedad de Rancho Verde, en el municipio de San Josédel Rincón, Estado de México. Las mariposas tenían un rumbo que sugería desplazamientos a sus sitioshistóricos de hibernación en las localidades de El Rosario y La Mesa.

Por otra parte el día de hoy 27 deoctubre se detectararon mariposas en el tramo carretero que va de San Felipe Los Alzati, Municipio deZitacuaro hacia los municipios de Ocampo y Angangueo, Michoacán.Aún no se tienen evidencias de conformación de colonias, pero en la próxima hora personal adscrita a laReserva estará realizando recorridos de campo para corroborar esta posibilidad.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Me pasaron su correo para que les diera el dato de las monarcas que visitaron mi pueblo:
Fecha 16 de octubre de 2011Aproximadamente eran unas 5,000 mariposas posadas en varios árboles ubicados en un cañón cercano.Temperatura aprox. 22 ºC. El día estaba despejado con un poco de viento.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Altus and I saw at least 10,000 monarchs coming along the peninsula at the north end of the Lavaca Bay Causeway and across the causeway on Saturday (Oct 29th). One time we "counted" four hundred in the five minute trip across the causeway ... there were some drivers that certainly noticed them. Altus managed to capture 135 for examination. Today, Monday, Oct 31st, we made a 10 min drive across Lavaca Bay, the peninsula, and back and counted 144 monarchs flying hard from ENE to WSW. Today is clear, calm, and 78. Some big clusters formed late in the afternoon on Sat along both sides of Lavaca Bay and up and down the Tex Gulf coast. Altus finger picked 71 out of one cluster Sat night. Some photos of Lavaca Bay Clusters: http://mcmc.homestead.com/oct292011b.html
Photos from the night of October 30th. Totally unreal. There were more than 100 monarchs in the roost. All were gone the next day.

We were in a garden very near the beach, 50 ft.  It was about 6:00PM. Saw approx. 30-40 Monarch's feeding on flowers.  Then as the sun began to fade they began roosting on the sunny side of a pine tree next to the garden.  At first just three or four fluttered and settle in the sun on the pine needles.  Then more and more came and settled near by always in the sun.  As the shadows covered the tree some moved to the tree nearby that still had some sun.  Could see groups of them as it became dust.  In the morning soon after sunrise it was windy, cool (40's) and rainy and they were gone.  I did  not see them go.  Today (Nov 1, 2011), at 9AM saw four feeding on the same flowers. Left area to return to Mebane, NC so no further opportunity to observe.
On Monday 10/31/11 - 11/2/11 I have observed 40+ Monarchs each day nectaring in the nectar garden especially on the Eupatorium odoratum (Crucita). Roost each evening in an oak as the sun sets.

El Camino Real Park in Ventura has long been a fall roosting place for the Monarchs. I'm not sure if their destination in Mexico or if they are west coast natives. I plan to visit the Santa Barbara preserve next week and hoping to see thousands roosting.

Altus and I went across the Lavaca Bay Causeway at 4:30 on Thur, 11/10/11, and saw 4 monarchs flying very high to the WSW over the bay.  Wind was from NW at 10 mph, clear, 61 dF. On the east side of peninsula to the causeway, Altus and I saw that the monarchs were already finding places to roost for the night.  Found some doubles and triples on the short seaside goldenrod and even a triple on one sunflower as soon as we started driving along the bay's edge.  We could pick out four clusters in the saltcedars, I watched one tight cluster thru binoculars and decided there were at least a dozen monarchs in it ... a few still flying around in the saltcedars.  Two loose clusters on the thorntrees at the edge of TX35 again.  There were still some singletons flying around looking for that special place to hang out before they took off to fly acros the bay to the WSW in the morning.

There are thousands of Monarchs clumping in the eucalyptus trees along the creek at Camino Real Park in Ventura.  They are here all year round.  I have never seen so many Monarchs. They are flying South from the Santa Barbara reserve along the coast and come into Ventura.   I recently released 10 Monarchs that I raised in my yard. I released them all at the park.

So randomly run into this chick Abby out in the midst of Ocean Avenue Park who keeps saying she wants to play tennis some day. Well instead she turns me on to this totally hush-hush secret monarch hot-spot. Sure enough, right overhead in the eucalyptus trees along the sewer, a fall roost in a flurry. This was the first roost i'd ever seen, so i was pretty stoked. Thanks chick.

We had hundreds and hundreds of Monarchs stay over in our yard in NW Lower Michigan over the course of a few days last fall (estimated date of September 7). That prompted our search for Monarch migration information.

We tried to recall exactly when it was, but the closest we could get was late August/early to mid-September? We live in Atwood Michigan, about 12 miles north of the 45th parallel, close to Lake Michigan. We just moved there last summer, and it seems we're on a migratory path of sorts for birds too. It's very exciting!

Editor's Note: We are estimating "hundreds and hundreds" at 300 monarchs.

First sighting of roosting monarchs this year.  Only about 10 tonight in the usual shelter belt where they have come for the last several years.  Slight east wind. High temp. here today was 87 degrees.  Hope to see more roosting in the next several days/weeks.

Noticed, they are flying in groups of. 3. Landing, seem on many types of treesAt night the roosts are groups of 5 or 6. A this time of year, roosting sites are normally in the hundreds!   THIS lack, must be the fallout of the drought.

I had a small cluster of monarchs this morning in the lower branches of an ash tree near my garden, 1 block from school. I counted 12 for sure, but there may have been a few more. Not a huge roost, but definitely a gathering.

August 27
There have not been any more visitors since Sat. I have been checking the area at school where we have observed them in prior years. We have a large number of blooming liatris so there are monarchs nectaring, but not nearly the number we had last year. I monitor monarch larva with some students each summer and our numbers this year have been very low.
About 10 monarchs sighted in neighbor's tree at first but the number soon grew to almost 50!

Aug. 26, 2012 Evening roost forming 3-4 miles east of Stewart, Minnesota along State Highway 212 just east of where it intersects with Unit Avenue.  About 150 butterflies are shown in the video, but by sunset the cluster had grown to 300 butterflies.  There were also small clusters of 25-50 in the same grove for a total of 400 roosting butterflies. Roosting in oak trees

This was in my backyard, last night (8/27) and they were flying around seemingly at random. I have seen roosts of 100s there previously (Sept 5, 2010) and there were only about 25 monarchs there last night but weather is similar: cool at night (13 degrees), clear, winds N17Km/hr. I live about 100m from Lake Ontario so I suspect they're waiting for good weather to make the crossing. This morning (8/28/12) there are about 10 back there. Maybe more will be back tonight?

September 4 Update
Since August 27th I have had 10-15 monarchs everynight and morning. Today, however, the remains of hurricane Issac passedover the area and its raining and windy so clearly no butterflies. Let'shope they are back when the weather clears up.I live very close (about 100 metres) to Lake Ontario and there are islandsbetween here and the US. So I suspect this is a good place to cross thelake, particularly if the wind is blowing in the right direction. I thinkthis is why I'm lucky enough to have so many visitors.

We live on a hilltop in the hills of the finger lakes on the highest elevation in Yates County. We have only noted one other migration about 20 years ago and have lived here since 1970. The previous overnight roost was huge, covering our entire yard and included many thousand Monarchs roosting in every tree after fluttering in the yard in the late afternoon. It was a magical day, Monarchs flying all around us and at times landing on us. This small roost included just a few branches in 2 treetops. It had been a warm sunny day yesterday with a high of about 80 degrees F and at 6am today 8/30 it was 52 degrees with almost no breeze. The group left midmorning. Weather conditions were similar to the previous sighting 20 years ago

Tonight I spotted 3 large Monarchs at 7:30 P.M. I startled on of them, as they were starting an evening roost.Overcast day 75 *, little wind. Hope the numbers will be back, and l will see my beautiful friends.3 small roosts
Monarchs clustered in deciduous trees at dusk, beside a clover field where they had been nectaring during the day.

Our beautiful friends are here!  My friend phoned while I was away. To let me know that he had just startled hundreds of Monarchs,whilst he was mowing the lawn!  I got back to Padua at.5. : P.M today, and started the countOf Monarchs blessing our.tree's. Oh the joy of them, swooping, and kiting over me. 30 or more roosts.

We have scattered "small" roosts starting along the acreage grove and in the yard.  We started looking a little too late, as it was getting dark but found 3 small groups of Monarchs on lower Silver Maple and Green Ash branches.
some Monarchs appeared to have roosted in my cherry tree and others kept flying West.

Beautiful, windy day at PaduaRoosts are every where, and with the high wind in all types of trees And bushes! Roosts of 10, looking like beautiful lollipops on a stick. Will try and send this photo!  30+ roosts of 25+

Dozens of butterflies flying up to roost in trees on the eastern side of a field of milkweed. Butterflies continually streaming in to the area and joining the roost just before sunset.  Have found 12 larva and 1 chrysalis in this field in the last two days.  Many adults nectaring in the field and community garden.
school: Susan odell taylor school for children

comments:
Saw perhaps 20-30 monarchs roosting.

Monarch Roost Video

started see 5 to 6  at a time then they stared landing in a large willow tree 2 to 3 hundred inthe trees first time the neighbors and i have seen this called 83 year old father he never saw this either

Delighted to have 6 visitors today fron Sauk Centre!  Morning visitors had news from. A call I had made earlier to a special friend ;) I have them a little tour of the favorite roosting spots of our Monarch visitors.  Over 50 Monarchs came when I called them. EVENING, another friend came with her husband. I again went into the little wood, to call my. friends. They too had some nice photosAt sunset the roost gathered 8:30. Videoed a roost 0f 300 beating fiery wings,Monarchs night.

80-100 monarchs roosting in the shelterbelt at 7:45 p.m.  Largest group I have seen this year! All but about 20 were gone by 9 a.m. today (9/4/12)  They are really enjoying the flowers in our yard this year.

Night roost of 9/3/12 were still in place this morning.at 6:35 amThere were still about. 100 still clinging to the bare branches It was quite chilly, and they were hard to spot.About in the upper 50's low 60's,with noWind.The moved their wings only once in a great while.  Came back at 9:30a.m.,theyhad moved.  Walked on top of the bern, andthen spotted they had moved to the.willowtree!  As I called.to them, they flew overand aroundme. Spent.of the.rest of the day counting roosts.Higher wind later I'n day. 60 small Roosts,Monarchs were flying through the corn rows, and to the.wildFlowers. Night roost mpved.to pine, elm, cottonWood trees. Numbers still around. 300 inScattered roosts

7:00a.m. did brief check on a few overnight roosts.It was misting and cold. Very light rain. They wereVery hard to spot, against the soft pink horizon, with theLight powder blue sky. I took my flashiight and spotted themSnuggled amonst dead curled leaves on the trees.There.  Were about 7 + little roosts, I could seeWith the aide of my flashlight Went inside, and left woods for morning..

sorry am not a teacher just wanted to report seeing our monarchsand may be a little early just 150 usually the trees are full and its just a wonderland of butterfly's,but with the dry weather was afraid they would not come this year.lived here 20 years and use to have have thousands and  very s  to years  hoping for the wonderland this year
Took a few moments just before dusk and walked the yard and grove.  Did count 35 in a handful of very small roosts.  Each roost only had 5-8 individuals.
Only 3 small roosting groups tonight with 17 individuals.

Still seeing individuals but very few...don't know if it could even be considered a roost, but they were all seen seeking a branch to stay the night.  I certainly hope this is not a normal count for others this year!
Flocks of Monarchs in my large pine tree...never seen so many at one time...Awesome

September 6
About a 100 or so came in tonight. I was really surprised to see them this late.

September 4
We still have a few in the ditch.

August 31
We have seen very few here this year. Just maybe 10 or so in the ditch.

There were more than one could count, located on my private habitat resting area. They stayed for the night. I would guess as it was around 7:30pm EST when I saw them. There is around twenty acres here of Golden Rod, Canadian Thistle, Boneset and Iron Weed. The majority of nectar is Golden Rod then maybe even on Boneset and Iron weed. Maybe 90/05/05.This is the second time in past three years I was able to see them at the right time.
Observed the Monarchs flying in at dusk to roost for the night.
This was the first night of many the Monarchs roosted in my trees this August.So amazing to see them all come out of nowhere about 8:30-9:30 p.m. and roost, then I watch them leave in the morning.

decidedly fewer than last week, possibly due to the heavy storms this weekend and colder weather; still many more monarchs and others than last year ... all in great shape, too!

They were roosting overnight; seemed to be both in the dense trumpet vine and a honey locust tree. The last two nights (9/10 & 11) have dropped to the upper 40's, but the days are sunny and warming to the mid-70's. It's neat to see them get up and moving to the nearby butterfly bushes with the warmth of the sun!
Three roosts of 35 (monarchs) and 2 roosts of 15 (monarchs) were found at Hawk Cliff (near Port Stanley, Ontario) today (for a total of 135 monarchs).

I have a report by the AuSable Valley Audubon that a very large number of monarchs are roosting at Tawas Point State Park, East Tawas, MI., which is 40 miles south of Harrisville, MI.

I contacted Ed Cole of the AuSable Valley Audubon that helps tagging monarchs. He estimated 400 roosting on both Sunday and Monday (9 & 10 Sept). The first roosting (6:45 to 7:30 PM) occured right at the point with a light SW wind. But on the next evening (6:30 to 7:15 PM) they were 1/2 mile from the point and more scattered with stronger wind from the SE. Maybe this was the same monarchs from the previous night? Again the estimate was 400. The point is 1 mile long and has a two track road down the middle. It has mostly low vegetation of small trees, pines, shrub. Sorry no photo. 13 monarchs were tagged for both days.

Two days after the east coast was pummeled by torrential rain, the monarchs fall migration begins. Today was sunny in the mid 70's with a brisk NW wind, approximately 750 monarchs took to the sky and roosted at Robert Moses Beach. They looked very healthy and congregated in many of the large pine trees. This is about a week earlier than last year that I spotted such a large number of monarchs. Tonight the temperature is supposed to be in the 50's. As reported earlier, food sources in the immediate area are scarce, however within the three mile radius, there is ample golden rod and other nectaring plants for the monarchs to feed on.

I was at the beach from 3:45 pm to 7:30 (dusk). The monarchs are flying over the beach, ocean and boardwalk and they congregate in several large pine trees not far from the beach/ocean. It is wonderful to watch them fly and spot other monarchs and try to find a spot among the other monarchs to roost for the night. The photos were taken between 6:00 and 7:15 pm. Some of the monarchs start roosting as early as 4pm with the remainder settling in the coming hours until sunset. The night temperatures have been in the 50's.

The black pines have died on our property these past two years so we thought that might limit our sightings, but they have found another shrub that they seem to like and for the past few days we have noticed significant numbers of Monarchs.

Another beautiful day, sunny 77 degrees with a light SW wind. Late afternoon I was at Robert Moses beach and spotted over 200 monarchs. Similar to previous years when the wind is out of the SW, the monarchs roost in smaller groups (2-10) in pine trees closer to the road and away from thr ocean.

There were a couple of small roosts seen at Cape May Point State Park by a local birder on Tuesday morning and  a roost of over 100 Monarchs seen by Pat Sutton (noted on her website) on Monday evening at East Point Lighthouse, Heislerville, NJ.

There were a couple of small roosts seen at Cape May Point State Park by a local birder on Tuesday morning and  a roost of over 100 Monarchs seen by Pat Sutton (noted on her website) on Monday evening at East Point Lighthouse, Heislerville, NJ.

Another beautiful sunny day with temperatures in the high 70's and a SE Wind. I spotted about 90 monarchs today at Robert Moses Beach and flying along Ocean Parkway. Similar to last night, the roosts were small (2-10) monarchs located on large pine trees. The monarchs continue to look healthy and very active, Night temps are expected to be in the low 60's slightly warmer than the last two nights.
I was amazed by this sighting.
We seen around a hundred monarchs nesting in a willow tree towards evening on a farm.

Observed lots of monarchs flying in the evening sky. Followed a few and found a roost area in a large red maple near our home in Canaan Valley, WV, elevation 3250 feet. We are still seeing stragglers fly over the house towards the roosting tree. Have seen monarchs roosting in different red maples around our neighborhood in past years.

Still getting very small numbers each evening in the yard trees.  6 is pretty small for a roost!  Still hoping for more. A cold front a couple days back has possibly pushed things south now...hard to say?

We had a small roost of 50-60 monarchs last evening (9/14/12). We are happy to report even a small roost since we had none last year. It was chilly last night with temperatures in the upper 40's. This morning the butterflies were clustered together high in the branch of a maple tree. They should have good weather for flying today with bright sunshine and light northeast winds. My photo from this morning is not very colorful since their wings were still closed. I took the photo before the sun was shining on the monarchs. Had to go to work early!

Monarchs roosting in trees by the barn at St. Michaels Preserve. They were settling down at sunset (9/14/12). Went over again the next morning. They were shifting to sunny side of trees and moving around fields.
10 roosts discovered at Hawk Cliff containing from 15 to 100 Monarchs.
I noticed the Monarchs swarming in the maple tree in my neighbors' yard here in hampton.
Clustered on trees overlooking Rachel Carson Wildlife preserve to the west from our condo at Moody Beach. What a magnificent surprise on our vacation. Joan & Keith Boeckner (hometown - Quebec City)
A large roost consisting of approximately 150 Monarchs was discovered at Hawk Cliff this morning 9/16

I saw several large clusters of monarch butterflies today. I saw a single butterfly or two over the past few days, but discovered the hundreds (at least 200) butterflies clusted together in the trees in the vacant yard next door. It was an amazing sight to say the least. I am located on Tangier Island,VA, a small island in the middle of the Chesapeake Bay. Temp-70's and sunny.
Roosting Monarchs!! Absolutely Amazing!!!

So many I have no idea the number but such an incredible thing to be able to see. Loved it.

September 19
I really have no idea how many. It was probably less then 10,000 but it there were loads I've never witnessed anything like this sorry for my vagueness it was definitely thousands. I went back to the same spot 3 different times and they were still there. I will return next Saturday to see if they are still in the area.

September 22
I did go back yesterday and there wasn't one monarch to be seen, it feels like it was a dream because there wasn't even one straggler. I feel like I was so lucky to see that. Hopefully my timing next year will let me experience it again.

Our annual spotting journeys to Robert Moses didn't yield too much other than a fair number of singleton flyers and then on our slow ride home we spotted this roost on the  NB side of Ocean Parkway - bay side line of shrubbery. Returned again on 9/17 - saw many more flyers but nothing else. Mosquitoes are horrible there so be prepared if you go toward sunset.

On Sept 9th, we noticed monarch roosting in the same maple grove we have observed in previous years.  They were lighting and re lighting on tree tops, in the sun.When observed in the early morning, we could not see a group or real roosting, but due to small numbers, they were likely dispersed.  This particular site has been used in the past - both big roostings were in August. This summer the migration moved through early, so we were surprised by the late roosting activity.

We had a very windy day and we had 50+ adult monarchs resting in our loblolly trees waiting out the weather. Really neat site and got a couple of good representative pictures.

I am on the Chesapeake Bay (well close - actually the Chester River and Jackson Creek) the map coordinates (of the trees!) are: lat= 38.968035 and long=-76.224979

Time of Day:~5:00 the pics were taken, they had been coming in for an hour or so before that.

Weather:definitely a factor - overcast and quite windy (15-25mph all day)from the SSW all day (western shore of MD had big rainstorms, that we got a little bit of rain from right after I took the pictures) temperature, don't have any data handy, but I was out there in shorts and light t-shirt and was slightly chilled - maybe low 70's or high 60's?

I do not know that they spent the night and either way the next day they were gone when we checked. From the conditions at the time I wouldn't be surprised if they did spend the night though.

This has happened before, not every year, but at least a couple of times. We do seem to be in a fly way for them and our lot has a large population of bacceris bush that they seem to like to nectar from. It is neat that they take advantage of the trees and it makes me love the trees more!

I was taking the dog out for a walk in our backyard and they were everywhere in the trees, flying back and forth acrosss the house, hundreds of them. It was the most beautiful thing we ever saw...

Editor's Note: Based on the observer's comments, we have estimated the number of butterflies as 200. We have contacted the observer in hopes of clarifying the estimate.
5 overnight roosts with 15-30 Monarchs in each sighted at Hawk Cliff near Port Stanley, Ontario, Canada.

Probably 1000 adult monarchs congregated in trees and late summer flowers at oceanside trail.

It was amazing to see them all! I was walking in an ocean-side park called Fort Foster. This is directly on the Atlantic Ocean, not on an inlet or bay, etc. I saw the large group on Wednesday, September 19, 2012 at 4:15 PM. The air was very clear and the temperature was about 65 F. I think there was a light wind, but the area where the monarchs were congregated was protected from wind and was calm. I met some other people that day who said there was also a large congregation of them about 1/4 mile further along the path in another sheltered area, but I did not find them.

A friend told me they were also there (hundreds) on Saturday, September 15, 2012. I went to the same area today, September 23rd at 5 PM, and saw perhaps 400 in the very same sheltered trees. Temperature today was about 63 F, sunny, very clear air with low humidity, very light wind off the ocean.

I walked on Thursday, September 20th, and saw perhaps only 3. It was early afternoon that day.

On Wednesday the 19th, a friend told me he had seen a large number in an area at York Beach, Maine, which is about 5 miles along the coast North of here.

I saw a large congregation of Monarchs at Fort Foster park several years ago, but I can't remember exactly when. I mention this because I've heard they have been passing through here for many years, at least some years!

About 20 Monarch's sited at Camino Real Park in Ventura. Hanging out in the eucalyptus groves along the barranca. Plenty of fruit trees and natural flowers for nectar. I also see them flying around the city of Ventura daily now. I had two adults lay eggs three weeks ago and I have 22 caterpillars now. They are hugh. I plan to release them at the park when they hatch from the chrysalis. The ones I have seen look healthy and big.

These are the first to arrive. There haven't been that many Monarch's at the park for the past few months. Even though I have been raising them for the past 6 months. I still have 11 large pillars that are eating like mad. I am at the park walking my dog twice a day and see them flying around the eucalyptus trees where they like to winter.
Approximately 25-30 Monarchs roosting in a Cedar Tree approximately 50' in air.
Observed the Monarchs awakening from their night roost in my shelter belt. Took a few pictures while they were warming themselves in the sun.
Lots of Monarchs roosting in my shelter belt tonight. I took way too many pictures and it was hard to choose which to post.
Took some more photos of the Monarchs warming up in the sun from their nightly roost.
Monarchs roosted in our shelter belt again.
Many flying around the roost which contained approx 300 Monarchs
Witnessed thousands of monarchs at this roost every night since last friday (9/14/12). Last night (9/19/12) was by far the most. Here is a link to pics. I also have video.

I watched hundreds of Monarch Butterflies feeding on mostly Goldenrod in some fields near the Gay Head Cliffs on Martha's Vineyard Island late in the afternoon on Sept. 18th. I then found the trees they were roosting on and watched them gather onto some privet trees. I'd say there were somewhere around 1000 butterflies. The trees were covered. I returned the next morning (Sept. 19th) to watch them all fly off the trees as they warmed up. By evening it seemed most of them had moved on.

The Monarchs have been here for days nectaring on red clover and other flowers as they flitter around us to trees and over a dirt road. It was difficult to drive on the road because of them. We are finding tons of cats of various sizes and a few eggs as well.

I watched hundreds of Monarch Butterflies feeding on mostly Goldenrod in some fields near the Gay Head Cliffs on Martha's Vineyard Island late in the afternoon on Sept. 18th. I then found the trees they were roosting on and watched them gather onto some privet trees. I'd say there were somewhere around 1000 butterflies. The trees were covered. I returned the next morning (Sept. 19th) to watch them all fly off the trees as they warmed up. By evening it seemed most of them had moved on.

I am 86 and a retired teacher of Junior High students. I have lived on Martha's Vineyard for 65 years and have only witnessed this large a gathering of Monarchs once before - in 1973. I then borrowed an 8mm camera from my school and filmed hundreds, maybe thousands, of Monarchs coming in to roost for the night - and again, leaving early the next morning. Our local Audubon camp has a copy of that film. When my younger daughter was twelve, we collected the caterpillars (sometimes even an egg) and in her bedroom watched them transform from egg to caterpillar to beautiful chrsylis to butterfly - a high point in my life.

I am 86 and a retired teacher of Junior High students. I have lived on Martha's Vineyard for 65 years and have only witnessed this large a gathering of Monarchs once before - in 1973. Two nights ago I witnessed the tail end of their overnight rest in Aquinnah, at the western end of the Vineyard (formerly Gay Head), but in 1973 I borrowed an 8mm camera from my school and filmed hundreds, maybe thousands, of Monarchs coming in to roost for the night - and again, leaving early the next morning. Our local Audubon camp has a copy of that film. When my younger daughter was twelve, we collected the caterpillars (sometimes even an egg) and in her bedroom watched them transform from egg to caterpillar to beautiful chrsylis to butterfly - a high point in my life.

I took these pictures on September 13-14, 1973 - the next week I drove my daughter Sarah to college in Painesville, Ohio - the sides of the highway were littered with orange butterflies, no doubt hit by the fast moving cars as they flew low over the road.
I witnessed two tree's full of monarch butterflies.
Monarchs are migrating through my garden in large numbers...they are roosting in a branch of our pin oak tree.  We counting 55 last night (9/21) after we took this picture.

The trees were loaded with the monarchs. Thousands of butterflies located at the southern end of Jamestown at Beavertail State Park. It appeared that they were pairing up for mating. The entire park was engulfed with them. They were flying east to west and I also saw many of them in Narragansett Bay in the area of Narragansett beach also flying east - west. I have never seen this amount of monarchs. The park was filled with people watching the event. As soon as someone walked into the brush they all flew.
Lot's of Monarchs roosting

Monarch numbers built up over the course of the day, with the heaviest migration in the afternoon.  Members of the Monarch Monitoring Project found 4 roosts in Cape May Point totaling 2,500 monarchs.  Many monarchs were still coming in to roost as late as 6:30pm.  The roosts were made up of small clusters anywhere from 20 - 100 butterflies on English Ivy (which is in bloom now) and deciduous trees.  The previous night 9/22/12 one small roost of approx. 60 monarchs was found.

Consistent influx of monarchs today all around town. A walk at Cape May Point this morning indicated that those individuals we saw two days ago went on their way; it was quiet there. Later in the day along the beach new arrivals were dropping out of the sky. This evening I watched a large roost develop in several tall deciduous trees behind our cottage from around 4 pm until 7. Stopped counting after 500. Very difficult to see them once roosting. Exciting though-I will be up at dawn to watch them wake up....I expect many will stop in my monarch way station before moving on!

Millions of Monarchs migrating along the south shore beaches of Long Island, New York.

My Wife Donna and I were out at my aunt's house on the ocean in Westhampton Beach for several days. On Wednesday morning, the 19th, There were small groups from three to ten at a time. By noon time there were larger groups, and it was fairly constant. About 2PM, we went for a walk down the beach road, and the numbers were noticeably increasing. There were literally hundreds of Monarchsat a time heading west through the beach and dunes. There were large swarms at times, and it reminded us of the movie "The Birds". It was quite an impresive sight. I had heard about this happening in the past from my Aunt, We were amazed!! About five thirty or so, we were heading back and noticed that the Monarchs were settling down for the night on the trees. The trees were covered with groups from three to twenty at a time. A very unusual sight.

I would conclude the numbers were in the hundreds of thousands, maybe not a million. I'm pretty good at math and estimating, but this is a tough estimation. On our walk back later in the day, the mile long hike had thousands of the Monarchs settling in the trees everywhere for the nights rest. Possibly 50,000 to 100,000. Best estimations that I can give.

LOTS of monarchs were migrating into Cape May today along the beach and dunes.  Some were stopping and resting on the sand.  Most stayed in areas around the dunes on trees with ivy blooming to nectar. They were in deciduous trees tonight to roost.  Amazing sights all day!!

Hawk Cliff Hawk Watch, Port Stanley, ON

Sept. 22/12
Excellent roost of approx 40-50 Monarchs on a branch to the left of thecounters! Green Darners, Black Saddlebags

Sept. 23/12
”Lots of Monarchs in the air around the observation knoll and all aroundthe hawkwatch...though we never did any actual count today.”

Forwarded by Don Davis

Finally, a decent number of monarchs at Pt Pelee tonight!

Monarch Count – September 19, 2012...800 Monarchs tonight. A roost of ~700 just east of the shipwreck display.

Perhaps the Canadian monarchs are beginning to move from more westerly locales. There was also mention of frost in Northern Ontario last night - that should hurry them along.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Significant numbers came in again today and were roosting throughout Cape May and at the point. My garden was a busy stop over for those that had roosted nearby from 7 am on and then those who arrived throughout the day.  Most looked to be in great shape.  An am walk through the blue trail at the point indicated there was likely a large roost near the end of the trail where many monarchs were still flitting about, many on the English Ivy.  Monarchs en mass were flying along the dunes in the am but did not appear to be leaving. At the point this eve Stites was magnificent with many trees on the block covered with monarchs.

I went by on Saturday 9/22 and there wasn't a butterfly in sight, so I thought they were done for the season but before I left the area, I had an urge to go check once more. When I got there it seemed as if the butterflies were back and starting to land for the evening but I had to leave....bummer.
4 roosts of 101 roost of 251 roost of 30

We saw at least 50-60 (or more) flying around several of our tall oak trees. It looked like they might be trying to find a place to sleep for the night? Quite a few had already landed. We all went outside and watched them for 10-15 minutes. It was great to watch!

While visiting my friend mentioned that she saw Monarchs coming down to a tree in her back yard the previous evening as it was getting dark....over a dozen.  She tried to get a photo for me but they had disappeared in the leaves so it was too difficult.

Another glorious Monarch day. The monarchs slowly arrived around 1 pm and, as the day went on, their numbers increased. On a sunny day with temps in the mid 70 and a fierce NE wind, I spotted approximately 2300 monarchs. As previously they were escorted by hundreds of dragonflies.  About 5% of the monarchs were stopping on the beach on the wet moist sand and if they were taking a drink. The strong NE wind seemed to tire the monarchs and had them fly lower to the dunes and ocean. They flew up the shoreline and dunes and as if like magic at 4:40 they made their way to the pine trees and started to roost for the night. I counted approximately 1700 roosting in many pine trees. There were many smaller roosts than in previous days.

Over 3000 monarchs are roosting at Morgan's point in Wainfleet Ontario, along lake Erie's northshore. The butterflies have been increasing over the past few days, and the wind conditions were not favourable. Tommorow is rain, but Thursday's forecast is clear, warm and with a North-East wind so the Butterlies will be making their journey in the morning what a sight it will be.

They were flying all around our yard which is butted up against a nature preserve. I came home to find my son with one sitting on his finger! The butterfly walked up his arm and perched himself on his shoulder. They were all over town, but especially concentrated near the preserve and our yard which is across the street from the sea. I even saw them while out in the ocean surfing, which makes sense since the winds were northwest.

It was another night of spectacular roosting in Cape May Point.  Several people found roosts in other areas of Cape Island too.  The numbers I've been estimating are probably low due to many roosts scattered about the island and only a few folks out looking and counting.  On daily walks many folks are coming out and telling me about roosts in their backyard trees.  All we know is there are LOTS of monarchs on the Island!!  So glorious!!!

Tonight I only had time to visit one roost site but it was amazing with clusters of monarchs looking like fall leaves on the deciduous trees.  I estimate about 2,000 there.  At another site a friend of mine took photos and it looked to be in the thousands also.  Not sure if the weather will hold them here again tomorrow.....
Large roosts again this evening among English Ivy laden trees at the point.

Many monarchs left today, however, quite a few came in.  They are roosting all around the point this evening in smaller groups, most seem to going for deciduous trees, although the English Ivy B & B is still popular too. Looking forward to the next wave of them!
Quite a few monarchs sailed over to Delaware today.  The ones that settled back in were roosting in smaller numbers in a few areas around the Point.
Only one or two roosts at the Point tonight.  One of about 300 monarchs and a few smaller ones.  We hope we get another wave of them on the N winds this weekend !

Sept. 26/12Point Pelee National Park

It appears that both last night (9/25) and tonight, 500 monarchs roosted in the park – at the tip and then on the west side as per Point Pelee Twitter.

Forwarded by Don Davis

Today, a friend and I left the Eastern Shore of Virginia by boat and visited Tangier Island, located in the middle of the Chesapeake Bay.  We headed to the south end of the island to the beach when at the road's end, we spotted hundreds and hundreds of monarchs circling and roosting in an area of trees just in front of the marsh area.  It was the last "shelter" spot before the beach and open water, and I suppose they were trying to hunker down because of the cool, windy and overcast day. (This was around 2:00 PM)  It was especially exciting for me, because it was my first real "mass" observation!  Yay!  What a gift!  I'll plan to head to Assateague Island tomorrow to see if the Cape May "visitors" have started to arrive! The ones today seemed to be following a "shortcut" route!

Lots of monarchs roosting around Cape May Point.  They started roosting early in the day 1 pm.  The team found 5 roosts and counted approximately 8,000 butterflies.  I'm sure there were more that we didn't see considering the numbers that streamed into town today.  The roosts were found on cedars, pines, and some deciduous trees and were mainly located on trees in the dunes.  We'll see if they leave tomorrow or hang around to feed and fatten up.

Large roosts all over town, especially at the point.  Dunes had large roosts on pines but there were impressive roosts on deciduous trees throughout the point as well as in the state park.  An incredible day!

Many of the 10,000 roosting monarchs from last night warmed up in the sun this morning, some flying across the Bay, others heading into the gardens at the Point to feed, some flying in the dunes feeding on the goldenrod, and some staying in small roosts on the pines and ivy.  More monarchs arrived in Cape May today on the light W winds.  Tonight was a warmer night and so the roosting was in smaller clumps scattered throughout the Point, 50 and 100 here, 1,000 there...  Another amazing day with these magical critters flitting everywhere you looked!!!
Got there when the sun already set. I've been seeing butterflies here since September 12th. Definitely less but still quite awesome.
Small flock came in late in the evening; we have had several days of rain, now slight north breeze.

October 1
My first sighting was on a 8:30 A.M. (on 10/1/12) walk through tall live oak trees around a small lake. Individual Monarchs were seen flying. Then after searching through the trees small groups were found clustered together. The still morning was cool and crisp after days of rain. This is the same location that was covered with Monarchs roosting for days last year.

Editor's Note: This roost was discovered the morning of October 1st. We are assuming the roost formed the night before so have dated the report September 30th.

October 8
After initial reporting of a roost, few monarchs remain and even fewer are flying through. It appears that activity stopped and now we are waiting to see what happens.

Monarch started arriving Sunday afternoon, all gathering on the mulberry tree. After spending the night, they were all off again by 11:00 a.m. this morning (10/1/12). There were about 25-30 Monarchs in the mulberry tree, apparently needing a good rest.

There were many monarchs in Cape May today feeding on the seaside goldenrod filling the dune areas with their glorious orange and black colors. But with all these monarchs around today the roosts were very small and scattered around the Point, I believe due to the warmer night.
Five Monarchs were noted roosting in the trees for the night.
Noted 15 Monarchs go up into the trees to roost for the night.
50 Monarchs were nectaring in a pasture, and went up into the trees for the night.
First roost sighting

October 6: 7 monarchs
So happy to monarchs roosting over my garden in a sweet gum tree.

October 7: 12 monarchs
Another small roost this evening.

October 9: 4 monarchs
5:00 pm saw 4 monarchs starting to roost in same oak tree on the north side of my garden as last few evenings.

A friend saw two small roosts at her ranch near Junction, Texas. There were around 200 monarchs in the two roosts.

Editor's Note: Observer clarified location as 20 miles north of Junction, near London, so lat/long were adjusted accordingly.

This is the first time this fall I have noticed Monarchs beginningto cluster. There were only two dozen or so and they must have come in on the cold front passing through the area October 5th..This front brought much cooler temperatures and a little drizzle.Hope to see many more by the 15th.
I put in that I saw 2000, but I can't really guess.  It was a good crop of Monarchs, clusters by the dozens (2-4 dozen per cluster) on scattered tree branches in a small pecan grove near Pinto Creek.

The monarchs are very pretty, we have seen them all day (Wednesday). We noticed the butterflies here on Tuesday afternoon.

Editor's Note: Since butterflies roosted on Tuesday we have edited the date to October 9th, presumably the day they arrived.
Passing on this report from Schleicher County, south of Eldorado, TX.  Hundreds on monarchs arriving and roosting this evening.

At the Doeskin Ranch of Balcones Canyonlands Wildlife Preserve there were a couple of small size roosts.  It was an overcast day and the Monarchs had not come down from high up in the trees.  The estimate is more in the "small" range of 150.

Spent all morning out on the Cunningham Ranch north of Eagle Pass and drove about 1.5 miles and saw about 60 monarchs. Came home to my house in town about 16 miles south and my back yard and the trees next door had 2 clusters: 50 in one 30 in another, then at least 20 flying around through the trees front and back. It had rained .5" between 11:30 and 1:00 in town and I think it caused a fallout. I watched the rest of the afternoon and the clusters have just kept growing.

I don't have a precise number. Anything over 400 would be too many, and anything under 300 too few. I blew the photo of 41 monarchs up in Photoshop and actually counted them. That enabled me to section off areas in the rest of the trees and make a  guess-timate.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: I observed  8 monarch butterflies feeding on my in bloom alfafea field.Later in the evening I observed the monarch butterflies roosting for the night on two 30-40 ft blue spruce trees

I am reporting for Patsy Ransom who lives on Johnson fork Creek approximately 9 miles East of Junction. Here is what she saw:

Patsy called to tell me that she had 100's of Monarchs----at least 500 butterflies--roosting in her trees for the past two nights (beginning October 15th). Her description was they were mainly on the Arizona Ash and the elm and seemed to prefer them, but also gravitated to the Pecans.

She described a solid 3 feet of butterflies on one limb. She also said that this was the most she had seen in 5 years. She lives on Johnson Fork Creek in Kimble County and she does have regular roosts during migration. All of the butterflies left this morning (October 17) as soon as the sun hit them. A cold front is coming through tonight. She'll let me know if she gets some more.

Wind south all day.   Check for roosts at sunset.  I'm calling these roosts since the Monarchs were clustering, even though small numbers.  This is the first time I have seen anything "roosty" this year, in spite of numbers on liatris during the day.  Previously I have seen a few around trees, but not clumped.  Most appeared to be sheltering from wind. Image shows two different roostlets in different groves over 1000 feet apart.  One under Live Oak, the other under Ashe Juniper.

Thunder storm overnight with wind shift to north. Not much temperature drop - still in 60's at sunrise.

At 0830 same two roostlets were in place. Both had picked up one additional member.
Just the one small cluster in pecan tree. Very light numbers.

Just got home after a week in Colorado and was welcomed by a small roost of monarchs in pine trees, on the dunes, in The Point.  I thought maybe I was going to have missed the last ones but was pleasantly surprised to see about 75 or so.

Winds from the South Stall Migrating Monarch Butterflies on the Llano River in the Texas Hill Country....http://www.texasbutterflyranch.com/2012/10/22/winds-from-the-south-stall-migrating-monarch-butterflies-on-the-llano-river-in-the-texas-hill-country/

He aquí una prueba de que las monarcas han arribado a Muzquiz, creo que este frente lluvioso las ha aletargado y ahora hemos visto varias perchadas.

Courtesy of Correo Real

We had 400 monarchs in the trees in front of my house this morning! They began to arrive Monday week, but I had to leave Thursday and didn't get back until late yesterday evening. I drove 300 miles straight N through the flyway and saw fewer than 50 monarchs the whole trip up and 300 mi. back from Abilene. From the carport to the front door, I had a cloud of 50 explode from the banana trees as I pulled in. Then noticed about 300 in ONE tree beside the corner of my house as I approached the door!This morning the numbers had grown.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments:
Les comparto que hoy amanecieron acá en los Pinolillos unas 20 o 25 Monarcas. Aparentemente acá pasaron la noche (10/18) y hoy continúan aquí. Después de ver una o dos al día durante estos 15 días, comprenderán la sorpresa tan agradable que me llevé ir descubriendo 2 o 3 de ellas en varios de los árboles que hay. Espero mañana poder cuantificar mejor la visita. Hoy temprano en los Pinolillos. (9:30) Llovizna, sin viento, un poco de bruma.

Varias veces intentaron despegar pero volvían a posarse en las ramas. A veces juntas 2 o 3... otras no. En varios árboles encontré parejas o tríos.

Courtesy of Correo Real
On the Loop Trail of Enchanted Rock, there were hundreds of butterflies covering the branches of a single Texas Oak Tree.

My plumber called just after 4 p.m. to say he and his family had gone out to check on their stock and found the south boundary road of their place covered in monarchs. I grabbed my camera and ran for the door! Had to have been at least 3000 monarchs and I kept remembering that he'd driven his truck down the road 3 times by the time I saw them! Many were in the thicket to the left as well, but disbursed among the trees. Breezy from the SSE, 7-10mph. Still not weighting the trees down like 30 years ago, but the best monarch numbers I've seen in 5-6 years!
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: At Camino Real Park there are at least over 100 Monarchs starting to come into the park to go to the Eucalyptus Groves.  I have seen some with tattered wings.  There are plenty of flowers there for nectar.   In the Ventura Keys they are flying around the neighborhood also drinking nectar from the plants.  No mating.  Just hungry.  I have seen tattered wings on them also.

Este maravilloso avistamiento fue observado por los buenos amigos Ing. Juan Martin Bernal Rivera e Ing. Ariel Treviño, Rancho Ojo de Agua, Mpio. de Acuña, Coahuila, el dia de ayer (24 octubre) al amanecer, las condiciones las puedes ver en el video.

Editor's Note:Based on the video we are temporarily estimating the number at 200 butterflies, but there are most likely far more. We have written for more information.

Sighting courtesy of Correo Real.

The Coastal Flyway opened nicely late this afternoon.There were as many as eight passing the Tahoe in less than a minute and a couple of times I could see six out the front window at the same time coming at me along the edge of water.

There was at least one cluster that we knew of that was forming and we went back an hour after sundown ... Altus picked the pockets of all eighteen monarchs in that cluster.She had also netted thirteen off camphor daisies between four and five ... that was doing it the hard way. Very few camphor daisies and the flow of monarchs weren't very interested in nectaring on them ... did see a couple of monarchs on stunted coreopsis. Tomorrow may be the best day and then the east wind returns until the weekend.

Monday, Oct 29:  Monarchs continued on the Coastal Flyway, crossing Lavaca Bay at the causeway Monday (midcoast of Texas).  Altus and I were over on the peninsula to the Lavaca Bay Causeway in the afternoon twice and she netted 20 that were nectaring on camphor daisies.  We watched as clusters were forming late in the afternoon.  We went back after 7:30, and found two clusters that Altus could walk thru the weeds to.  She used her LED head light and finger picked 87 monarchs from the two clusters in thorn brush/trees just before the edge of water for a total of 107 monarchs captured for the day.

Me acaban de reportar racimos en nogales en el parque El Chapulin de Saltillo unas 1000 mariposas.

Anoche se formaron (30 octubre) en ese parque los racimos, teníamos varios días buscándolos en ese lugar en que cada año se perchan las monarcas y hasta hoy por la mañana (31 octubre) los encontraron.

Courtesy of Rocio Trevino, Correo Real.

They're Here!
On the way home from school on Monday, Estela and the children discovered hundreds of monarchs. They were excited to announce the monarchs' arrival!

Esta foto es de hoy (31 octubre) en la mañana en el rancho El macho del municipio de Zaragoza, como a 300 km. al norte de Saltillo.

Editor's Note: We are assuming the roost formed the previous night, so dated report as October 30, 2012. We count about 30 monarchs in the photo so estimate the roost to be at least that large.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Esta foto, aunque de mala calidad, porque fue tomada con un celular es de ayer en el Rancho la Zorra del municipio de Acuña.

Courtesy of Correo Real.

Based on this picture, we are estimating the roost to have at least 100 butterflies.

After some thunder storms went out into the Gulf west to east late in the night we had a light north wind ... good monarch wind along Lavaca Bay on the midcoast of Texas.  Our daughter texted us about four this afternoon that she had counted seven monarchs flying to the SW when driving to the NE across the Lavaca Bay Causeway.  We waited until 6:30 (dark now) and went across the causeway to the two thorn trees at the edge of the bay where the monarchs stop when they decide they aren't going to attempt to cross the bay.  Using the long range light we could see clusters in both trees ... Altus made her way thru the weeds with her LED head-light and was able to reach 15 large, plump monarchs ... about 10 were out of reach.  There is supposed to more north wind and cooler temps and we hope for a repeat Mon and Tues.

I saw a very big flocks of monarch resting on trees en Jaumave México. It is a spectacular event. I had only my celular camara for photos, for that my attached picture is not good.

Editor's Note: This observer is the Director of Natural Resources for the state of Tamaulipias. We believe the estimate is as accurate as possible.

I released a female Monarch I had raised at camino real park this morning.  She hatched yesterday. I was amazed to see over 1,000 Monarchs clumping.  The roost is on 4 different branches.  This female was happy to be there.  I have 4 more chrysalis and two medium cats yet, so they all will be taken there.
roosting on a tree Popolus sp.

<object width="640" height="360"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/vdh8FvFfI0I?version=3&amp;hl=en_US"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/vdh8FvFfI0I?version=3&amp;hl=en_US" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="360" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>
