<object width="640" height="360"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/-Yrb4OWPKFc?hl=en_US&amp;version=3"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/-Yrb4OWPKFc?hl=en_US&amp;version=3" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="360" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>
I saw a bunch of monarchs this evening in my woods around dusk.
only saw 10 monarchs roosting in one tree in the evening about 7:30pm.  There would usually be hundreds.  The landscape has also changed this year so maybe there won't be as many for us.

Found and photographed a small roost south of New Richmond, WI and west of Baldwin, WI.My last photo shows 20 monarchs on two or three near branches.  The roost was facing east so the lighting was difficult, but I am confident in my numbers. There were more of them than i counted in the photos, though.........i'm thinking 30+There were also a few scattered monarchs on a north facing tree edge so there might have been 3 dozen or more monarchs in all in the immediate area.Again I give thanks to Tom Murphy of Cannon Falls, MN for the best advice in finding a roost:  locate a good food source, the bigger the better.This year, the "bigger" part is especially apt.This afternoon I was able to spot, using binoculars, only 2 or 3 monarchs at a time from various viewing spots.  However, the field was many hundreds of acres in size so I was hopeful of finding dozens or even hundreds of monarchs roosting.Turned out to be an overly optimistic estimate, but it is possible that other areas surrounding the several huge blooming red clover fields might have held other clusters.  If I could only stop the sun from setting for a few hours..........Might go back tomorrow morning for some sunny shots.Prediction is for a north wind tomorrow so don't know if the area will empty out and then restock with new monarchs.  If I get back there tomorrow night, I will give that report.
many monarchs resting in our ash trees overnight, saw some sunning early on clothesline.

Found another roost about 1 mile northeast of last night's sight.This one was in the yard of Carl Roehlke.  My thanks to him for letting me walk around and shoot photos. (And thanks to Jerry and Jim Emmert for giving me permission to walk their wonderful red clover fields.  If only monarchs could always find such nectaring sites on their migrations........)This roost was similar to last night's, probably 20-30 monarchs by sunset.  One photo shows seventeen at an earlier stage.  With the other scattered singles and smaller groups around the pines and trees of Carl's yard, I estimate 50-75 monarchs total.In addition, I checked last night's site, but found no monarchs around last night's roosting tree.  I suspect there were some monarchs roosting in the area, though....hard to believe there wouldn't have been another dozen or two along the south field edge.I also saw quite a few flying monarchs on a high ridge on the east end of last night's field; they were looking to roost around the houses there.Farther northeast, I also saw monarchs earlier that probably roosted along a westerly windbreak.......smaller numbers there, I think, maybe 10-20.Not great numbers for nearly a square mile of red clover, but this year we'll take what we can get.
Observed five in the late afternoon followed up a group of about 50 roosting in the early evening.
It's 88 degrees, hot & muggy. Eight monarchs roosting.

Fresh Monarchs were found mainly roosted (singly) on the low leaves of small trees in and near the butterfly garden and the creek bed that runs through it.  10 sighted and 5 tagged.  These are the first monarchs we have been able to tag since the 2010 tagging season!!  The last two years we have not seen 1 monarch roost in a local tree so this is a VERY good feeling.  Abdomens are small so we hope staging will bring us a bunch more.
Edward Cole and company observed 32 monarchs at the tip of Tawas Point State Park in the evening which is about 30 miles south of Harrisville. No other info available.

Tagged 18 in an alfalfa field this morning, 26 from a group of trees that they were circling.  They would try to roost singly or in pairs but then fly around some more.  They were still unsettled at sundown.  50 is a conservative estimate. There were quite a few coming in from surrounding area. Great to see Monarch activity again!

We tagged 16 monarchs this evening.  The roosts were again just 1-3 monarchs but they had moved from the smaller trees, willows, in the lower portion of the creek to the larger cottonwoods, maples and walnuts of the upper portion near the butterfly garden. mid 80's, no breeze.

Tagged 25 monarchs tonight. Photo below is a roost of 11, largest roost we have seen since 2008 or 2009!! High 84, Low 67 no breeze. Monarchs were floating through the trees everywhere, couldn't really get a good count. It rained 0.2" overnight. They have been nectaring exclusively on the nearby alfalfa but today I saw my first 2 nectaring on the New England Asters and 1 on Goldenrod. Netted a monarch we had tagged on 09/09/13 indicating that the monarch population is local and staging. I expect the monarchs to leave for the season when the next High Pressure moves in. Update: September 12As expected, the morning wind was 5-10 mph out of the north changing to northwest and the monarchs we have been following have started their migration! We will see very few now but will continue to tag what we can. Though numbers were low this year, the normal staging and migration cycle is back again. Go well my friends. We'll be waiting for the return of your grand children next year.

Finally! While waiting and watching my trees, they came in one by one. I counted at least 20 flying and settling down for the night. I found 2 roosting by themselves singly, a pair together and 11 in one tree together. They came in around 7:30,  partly cloudy, temp 77', wind NNW 8 mph, dew point 46', humidity 33%, barometric pressure 30.09 inches, with a temp for tonight of 58'. All roosted on the downwind side of shelter belt, which runs east and west. This is the same shelter belt used last year, mostly ash, cotton woods, honeysuckles and cedars. Previous nights were singles roosting.

Here's the roost I reported on last night, warming up in the sun. They roosted from 7:30pm on 9/11 to around 8:30am on 9/12. The weather at 7:55am was 54', wind NW 6 mph, dew point 48', humidity 80%, barometric pressure 30.25, clear and sunny. Beautiful day. Had a low temp of 52' at 7:30am. The weather the next few days are to have lows in mid 40s and highs in mid 60s to low 70s, with a chance of rain on saturday. I saw a few out in the joining alfalfa fields and some at my new england asters and purple coneflowers.

A cold front came through this morning so I tried looking for roosting activity...just at sunset (9/12/13) we were able to find 20 Monarchs about 25-30 feet high in an old red pine here on the acreage.  Many had settled together while others were still picking their perches...at least we had a clustered group together settling in for the night.

A strong NNW wind today sent yesterday's monarchs many miles.  I found a small roost at last week's location southeast of New Richmond, WI and NW of Baldwin, WI.....actually closer to Hammond, WI as I recently discovered.  Had almost given up.  Had checked several blooming alfalfa fields around Osceola.  Then checked the red clover fields near Hammond this evening.  Did not see a single monarch.Was driving off when a single monarch flew off the last field I checked.  Soon there were more.  They came as if on signal, just about an hour before sunset.  One roost was at least 27.  Another was at least nine.  There were a few other small ones, but I could not verify any larger roosts at that spot.I talked to Carl, who lives where I was looking.  I asked him if he saw many butterflies yesterday.  His response indicated there must have been LOTS.  Today they were mostly gone, but I got to see one more very pleasant show.

WE HAVE HAD 1,000+ MONARCHS IN OUR TREES FOR OVER A WEEK NOW (as of September 13). WE LIVE ON A SMALL FARM WITH SEVERAL DIFFERENT SPECIES OF TREES.

Editor's Note: We are estimating the date of arrival as 7 September.

I tagged 4 Monarchs this morning. There were at least 4 more that I failed to tag.  This is the first day I have seen more than a single Monarch.  This evening I went to the north side of the trees where the Monarchs roost and saw 4-5 (untagged) Monarchs clinging to the leaves of the trees.
About 400 monarchs roosting in cedar trees.

We were back on the wildlife area along the Missouri Riverthis evening tagging Monarchs & looking for their roosts.We were rewarded right @ sunset as we found a cottonwood/willow grove holding 200+ Monarchs with more coming in byminute!...:)

The weather was cooler here, in the seventys and there was a slight breeze. Around seven pm we saw monarchs landing in the tops and sides of 30+ foot trees on our farm, around the house,barn and paddock near the house.

After tormid rain showers last night, the day was 75 sunny with a WNW wind. I spotted 73 monarchs through out the day and into the early evening. This number is down substantially from the same date last year when I spotted over 750 under similar weather conditions.I counted 7 roosts, however they were very small one to two monarchs per roost. Also there appears to be a decline in the number of migrating birds this year. I don't know if there is a correlation between the two?Not much of a migration so far compared to previous years. I hope this coming week brings stronget numbers.
We live on the Lake near Point Pelee and have seen about 20 Monarchs resting for the night in our trees.

After an inch of rainfall this morning and steep rise in temperature and humidity and brisk wind from the South all afternoon, I checked our grove of trees late this afternoon.  There was a total of 13 Monarchs roosting on the north side of our walnut, and fir trees and dogwood shrubs.  I tagged 6.  Cathy Irvine

Earlier in the day I saw 30-50 nectaring on the alfalfa and asters. I knew there was a cold front coming through with rain in the morning, I went out around 7:30pm to find the roosts. Everyone was clustering very loosely and spread out on the north side of the chinese elm trees. Temp at 7:30pm was 81', SSE wind 8mph, dew point 69'F, barometric pressure 29.62"
We followed about 7 into their roost in our cedar trees.  They feed on our late blooming sedums during the day.

We noticed the dark cloud of butterflies coming in from the North of our property.  As they flew in we noticed it was Monarch butterflies. The temperature had suddenly dropped significantly and there were some scattered thunder storms scattering our area.  The Butterflies roosted in one of our tall pine trees, seemingly hunkering down until the storms passed.  (The storms all missed us)  This all occured at dusk.  We observed until dark.  When we woke in the morning they were gone.

A volunteer with our MMP Team found a small roost of approximately 25 monarchs on Ivy, on Stites Ave., in Cape May Point.   We've also been seeing lots of eggs, larva and chrysalises still.  There is hope!!!

This afternoon the migration movement seemed to pick up, so we were hoping to see some roosts tonight.  Again, just small roosts of butterflies in Cape May Point; 12 here, 5 there...  totaling about 30 or so.  Not big numbers as in other years but numbers non the less.  Yea for hope!  Crossing fingers with the weather/wind predictions we see more migrating monarchs this week !!

After seeing the monarch numbers steadily increase today we were excited to see a roost of about 100 monarchs tonight. Again, on Stites Ave. in Cape May Point on the English Ivy vines. Yea ((-:

October 8 update
Unfortunately, it's been pretty slow since our September 24th update. We've had some monarchs moving in but not a big push yet and no other roosting. There have been lots of days with south and southwest winds which means not as many monarchs either. We're still hopeful that with as many caterpillars as we've seen that maybe it will be a late season for them this year. I've gotten on your site and noticed how few reports there are compared to other years. But, I had been hopeful when someone in Ontario was reporting monarchs after we had the 100 here, thinking maybe they are still on their way. I"ll let you know if they arrive.

After thunderstorms during the night, Sunday was a sunny day with temps in the mid 60's and a strong west wind. I spotted 133 monarchs through out the day. As previously they were accompanied by almost a thousand dragon and damsalflies. The monarchs were flying from east to west, however the strong west wind was a challenge for the monarchs. They started roosting about 4 pm with sunset @ 7 pm. Similar to my last posting, the roosts remain small with the majority between one and five monarchs. They looked very healthy and there was an abundance of food. The numbers sadly remain well below previous years. I was also out observing on September 11,12 and 13 for 1 1/2 hours each day at 6pm and did not spot any monarchs. This is a very disappointing season. While looking for monarchs, I received alot of comments from people who recognized me from years past and were also disappointed in the lack of monarchs this season.

Six thirty to seven pm in clusters of four or fivemy wife and I walk the ash timber line from each end   three times and unfortunately  this is an accurate count.every year they have dropped in numbersbut this count is heart breaking

We observed about 15-20 monarchs each evening at a roost spot near Princeton, Kansas on Sept. 25 and 26.

It rained most of the morning today (9/28), but by late afternoon the monarchs were on the move from Ottawa, Kansas through Richmond, Kansas. I observed a cluster of about 15 this evening with approximately 40 more milling around. They were much too high for tagging.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

We observed about 15-20 monarchs each evening at a roost spot near Princeton, Kansas on Sept. 25 and 26.

It rained most of the morning today (9/28), but by late afternoon the monarchs were on the move from Ottawa, Kansas through Richmond, Kansas. I observed a cluster of about 15 this evening with approximately 40 more milling around. They were much too high for tagging.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

I pass this area frequently to go to the lake. I do not ever recall seeing these cottonwood trees at this intersection being used as a roosting areas. There are several different kinds of trees, Osage Orange, Bradford Pear, winged elm, and redbud, however the butterflies were lingering around the cottonwood trees. When the breeze blows through the leaves, it's hard to tell the butterflies from the leaves, the way they quake like an aspens. The butterflies took up their positions on the Southern sides of the trees facing the setting sun. This intersection is a bridge that goes over I-240 highway and into the Draper Lake area. We counted many more monarchs earlier that day on the West side of the lake--which will be recounted in a separate entry. This was a complete surprise, we did not expect to see this at all.  We revisited the site the next night (9/30/13) . The butterflies chose a different cottonwood in that area, and there were many more in that one tree than counted in both trees the previous night.

We returned to the area where butterflies had roosted the night before, and there were more, roosting in the cottonwoods by the road. The fields along these roads are covered with sunflowers and goldenrod, and if you follow the lake roads those nectaring sites go on for several miles to the south with patches of agricultural fields that lie fallow with blooming weeds.

A total of approximately 200 monarchs seen in scattered small clusters in pecan and other trees at South Adams Park  in El Reno, Oklahoma on Sept. 27, 2013 at 4:40pm - a day of steady brisk winds from the South and high temperatures (88-90 degrees F in the afternoon) - a combination which tends to motivate the butterflies cluster in the shade during the afternoon heat.  The specific wooded area I am referring to is located at the western end of Park Drivein El Reno 35.534859 -97.981218 Here is a 3 minute video of some of the clusters I saw plus footage of some individual butterflies nectaring on the maximilian sunflowers in the park.  This area of the park was formerly a pecan nut tree orchard and a several dozen of  pecan trees are still standing.<object width="640" height="360"><param name="movie" value="//www.youtube.com/v/shcL4N9XUyc?hl=en_US&version=3&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="//www.youtube.com/v/shcL4N9XUyc?hl=en_US&version=3&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="360" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>

Like some others, I have been seeing more Monarchs this past week than at any time in the last year. Each evening, I've counted from 15 to 31 Monarchs at the roosting site on my property. During the day there are always about a dozen nectaring on the asters. Last year at this time, I had seen only one Monarch.There have also been more butterflies of other species, probably due to the unseasonably warm weather we've had. I've seen all the usual painted ladies, red admirals, mourning cloaks, question marks, , blues, pearl crescents, whites, and various swallowtails. I was also excited to see three giant cloudless sulfurs that strayed northward (44* latitude). I hope the Monarchs have good traveling conditions.

I used to have a spectacular number of monarchs roost on my property - thousands of them. Last year, I saw one, yes one. This year it is better, but not wonderful. i only hope they can somehow recover. Sept. 11 was the first night I saw the butterflies roosting.There were about 2 dozen that I saw, but there are 6 acres here that I devote mostly to butterfly habitat, so I'm sure I don't see all of them. From sept. 12 to the 22nd., I only saw a few each evening - less than 10. On the 23rd., it picked up, and there were 2 -3 dozen each night through the 28th. Last evening (9/29), numbers were down to just a few. It was s chilly day with strong wind. The nectar sources I have blooming right now are lots of asters, late phlox, cosmos, zinnias, goldenrod, black-eyed susan, and d few late purple coneflowers. The Monarchs favor the asters.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
a small roost of monarchs found in bayberry and grounsel tree at Stone Harbor Point near the second observation platform

There were half as many butterflies on the cottonwood this evening. In addition I noticed cat faced spiders building webs near areas, where monarchs had roosted on that very tree the night before--a little insect opportunism? The monarchs avoided the webs easily. They were drawn to the boughs occupied the nights before, but eventually settled in other areas not inhabited by spiders. We counted many more monarchs in that field just prior to sunset, and some seemed to be flying to other trees, or simply roosting low on stalks of flowers. The humidity was starting to rise last night, we are expecting bad weather on Friday. I wondered if this change in the air also affected their behavior. I suspect there are other trees used for roosting in that immediate area, however there is a lot of area to cover and much of it is tall, weedy, scrubby--a place where you want tick repellant and long pants and full shoes.

old farm houses and building removed, leaving pine, spruce and other horticultural trees to grow to their limits. Lawn area is weedy wit daisy fleabane, goldenrod and aster. Road maintenance only cuts adjacent area.10m up in the trees were 12 monarchs roosting on the east side of upper parts of these trees â€” and one hummingbird as the sun was setting! I watched 2 new arrivals in the twilight circling the tops of these trees and joining them on the  side opposite the setting sun. Total monarchs thus 14 (may be undercounting)

We were able to tag 25 monarchs this evening at a roost spot near Princeton, Kansas. We had light breezes this afternoon. Didn't really see that many during the day but observed around 30-40 at the roost location.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Late flow - day 9 (Oct 3). Cloudy, rainy with bursts of wind this morning so monarch activity is a zero but should pick up later in the day.

The numbers of monarchs in the garden and feeding on the flowers in front of the building were quite good throughout the day with combined numbers ranging from 20-35.

A loose cluster of >20 monarchs formed on a Japanese maple in front of MW at the end of the day (10/02). This was a first for two reasons - I had never seen a cluster by the building before and this is the first cluster I've ever seen in KS in October. Clustering generally peaks here around the 16th of Sept with few clusters seen after the 25th. The fact that Todd M also spotted a cluster not far from here last evening suggests that good numbers of monarchs are still moving through this part of KS - albeit later than such numbers have been seen previously.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

There were three separate large roosts and several small mini roosts near the tip area of Point Pelee National park.

In one tree, the largest roost had about 1200 Monarchs. The second large roost in the same tree contained about 300 Monarchs. In addition, in the same tree also there were several much, much smaller roosts specking this same tree each of these "Mini" roosts contained anywhere from 5-20 Monarchs each.

In a separate tree further along, closer to tip area was a third roost approximately the same size as the smaller of the two big roosts in the first tree.

It was gorgeous here Wednesday. Being too nice to stay inside, I went to see if I could see any Monarch Butterflies. Absolutely STUNNED by what I saw! Certainly did not expect so many!!!I am wondering if because it has been so wet & the weather had been warm & cold, they may just be late this year.

I am an avid nature lover who goes out here often for the love of nature, get in some exercise & to practice my amateur photography skills.I have been watching for Monarchs off & on throughout September and into October. The Photo is from the beginning of the sighting at 6pm the numbers quickly grew from here.

A lot fewer butterflies taking up to this cottonwood tree near I-240. A lot fewer sighted in those fields in general too. Counted at dusk--around 7pm as butterflies were settling into the tree for the night.
First roost we have seen this year. There may have been a few more drifting in after we came inside.

We are still seeing lots of monarchs nectaring on cowpen daisies. I suspect that the majority of them are roosting somewhere near, only a few were found in the area with the flowers. The trees are so tall, that it's difficult to tell if there are butterflies or leaves fluttering in the wind at dusk. The few butterflies I saw roosting were on winged elms.

About 400 fall migrant monarchs were clustered in a small clump of eucalyptus and cypress trees located behind a residential backyard along D Street in the coastal town of Cayucos, California on October 2, 2013. I just happened to be there on Oct 2. The first roosting probably occurssometime between Sept. 20-25.


Uploaded with ImageShack.comVery near this roost were hundreds of monarchs nectaring on english ivy flowers as shown in the 4 minute video below:

Under near perfect conditions (sunny, high 70's, mild wsw wind) the monarchs migrated through the south shore of Long Island. Through out the 4 1/2 hours I spotted over 250 monarchs fluttering by and feeding on golden rod. Usually they feed until 4 pm / 4:30 pm and then leave to roost for the night, however today most of them were feeding until 6 pm with sunset @ 6:30. Some monarchs fluttered away and returned back to continue to feed on the golden rod. They looked very healthy. As previously this year, the roosts were relatively small 4-6 monarchs and many single roosts. Some monarchs choose to roost on the golden rod instead of the pine trees. Tonight is expected to stay warm in the low 60's. What a beautiful sight.

Despite a very cloudy, overcast and foggy day with temperatures in the mid 60's, a moderate SWS wind and hurricane Karen expecting to arrive tomorrow, I spotted 44 monarchs who arrived on the south shore beach on Long Island . By 3:30 they were roosting. The strong wind was a challenge for them and initially made it difficult to settle into the trees and shrubs. Any movement resulted in them taking flight and finding a new tree or branch to roost. Similar to previous days the roosts remain small and are primarily single to four monarchs.Temps tonight are expected to remain in the 60's however tomorrow torrential rain storms are unfortunately expected.

We've monitored this location for the previous four weekends and tagged good numbers of monarchs during the day. Each night monarchs were scattered among a large number of trees along the creek. But Friday evening when I walked by the east side of the large willow trees near a thicket of thistles, approximately 10 monarchs startled and began flying in circles then returned to nearby branches. We stepped back and watched the area and could spot 18 monarchs in singles gather near each other on the tips of branches about 12 to 18 inches apart. The largest concentration was near the southeast portion of the tree. Another cluster of trees (willows and cottonwoods) further south along the creek on private property had another 12 monarchs for the night. Saturday morning we arrived early when the temperature was 42.3 degrees and watched their wings open at 7:45 at 52.3 degrees as they sunned then began to fly down to nectar on the thistles and sip the morning dew. We went again on Saturday evening but this did not reoccur and Sunday morning there were very few monarchs in the area, mainly just a couple of ragged breeders left with 2 or 3 fresh and new along the entire creek.

This photo of a monarch sipping water during migration was taken Saturday morning (10/5/13). Monarchs dip down from the trees in the morning and then drink the dew along the creek bed before nectaring on thistles nearby. This was at 8:30 a.m. with the temperature of 67.3F. See photo. We noticed this also the week before but the photos are not as clear.

Have been seeing Monarchs in the yard for a few weeks now so decided to drive around town to see if I could spot any others. This is a fruit tree (why it's blooming in the fall I have no idea). The entire tree (only a section of it is shown here) was alive with Monarchs, floating, fluttering, hanging, really was quite a sight! I counted approximately 70 butterflies on the tree but many others were flying within the area. Tree was in a vacant lot close to downtown Lake Dallas. I don't know the name of the tree.

The Monarchs reported in Peak Migration (October 6) did not remain on flowers overnight. At 22:00 I found about 100 in small roosts plus a few more of 1 to 5 individuals. Temp at sunset was around 70. When I check had dropped to between 60 and 65.

There are 47 in this image on under side of canopy of a large Ashe Juniper. There were a few more on this tree, out of frame. This was the largest group I found, but I didn't try to find all of them. Flash is harsh but time was 21:59 so no choice.

In general Monarch "roosts" here favor larger Live Oak (Quercus fusiformis not Q. virginiana) and Ashe Juniper (Juniperus Ashei) trees or groves. Sometimes mixed groves, or with other species. Typical of savanna trees, both these species when mature are wide and rounded and have most of the of the leaves on the outer canopy, leaving many bare twigs and branches underneath to grasp. Of course Monarchs will also use vines growing on the trees. (Dead greenbriar leaves look annoying like perching monarchs). And monarchs will roost on other trees that are available. This includes smaller trees and shrubs. Or tall grass and forbs. "Roosts" here do not seem to be the popular notion monarchs deliberately seeking other monarchs, but rather mostly seem to be the coincidence of individual Monarchs seeking the same type of shelter.

For night between Oct 7 and 8. The number I entered is what I actually saw. Total is really much higher. An hour or so before sunset I saw a few Monarchs already flying near trees that are typical roost sites. But most Monarchs were still on flowers at sunset. One-half hour after sunset none were obvious on flowers, but there was no obvious mass exodus either. I did find some perched in larger Live Oak and Ashe Juniper trees, but not enough to account for all that were feeding. I did not check every tree. I found a couple roosting individually on tall forbs. Wind had gone calm at sunset and remained so until sunrise when it rose quickly. So they all "roosted" if I define roosting broadly, as anything that does not involve flying, eating or reproducing, ignoring whether they aggregated.

The image shows a small roost still under a large Live Oak at 8:30 the next morning (Oct. 8). A few seconds after I took this picture they all flew off simultaneously.

This discusses overnight between Oct 8 and 9.

Oct 8 19:15. No obvious aggregations. Saw 4 under typical roost trees. All appeared to be males. Wind continued to blow to SE until around 22:00 then dropped.

Temperatures below are from truck built-in thermometer which has tested as accurate.

Oct 9. 7:30-8:00. air 55 degrees. At this date the sun rises from behind a nearby ridge to our east, and occurred from 07:25 to 08:05 varying due to terrain. Distinct shadow cut-off moves from west to east on ground and from top of trees to bottom. I saw a handful of monarchs under two typical roost trees. No aggregations. None on flowers. South wind started to increase at sunrise.

Oct 9. 8:45 - 9:15. Air 57-8 degrees. Light south wind. As I left house in truck, I saw Monarchs flying, mostly 10-25 feet from ground, from a number of large Live Oaks and Ashe Junipers. As I crossed the large meadow on the way to our largest tree grove, I saw a few Monarchs either flying low or on liatris. None were there at 7:45. When I reached the grove, I saw Monarchs leaving as described above, and also within it flying and perching. I had visited it an hour before and saw no monarchs. So they must have been well concealed, widely distributed, and probably well up in trees. That would make sense since the sun hits the tops first. Many were perched on green foliage in sun 15-20 above ground. Some that I disturbed from lower twigs in shadow flew up to perch in sunlight. Monarchs were also drifting out of the grove steadily.

I have been asked to comment on plants. This grove is mostly large Ashe Juniper, plus Gum Bumilia, Live Oak, Sugarberry, Pecan, with Greenbriar, Grapevine and several other vines. Understory shrubs Elbow Bush, Prickly Ash, American Beautyberry, Sumac, others, plus forbs and grasses.

While returning to house across the same meadow, I saw more monarchs than on the way out, flying and perched feeding. No obvious directional flight and all were less than 5 feet from ground.

So it seems that the monarchs were here overnight, roosting cryptically and not aggregated.

I did not attempt a careful number estimate. I will do that later in the day.

Image is of one of the easier to see Monarchs in the sun on the second trip to the grove. On Ashe Juniper limb.

A roost of about 30 monarchs was spotted along the West Shore of lake Michigan.  I have been watching off and on every weekday this month.  In the past we have had thousands of monarchs pass our observation point as Concordia University Wisconsin during mid- October. This year we had very few during the normal peak in mid Sept. Our October numbers are higher than the Sept numbers this year.  We have about 80 students monitor migrations along the Lake Michigan lakefront from late August through October.  With brisk northwesterly winds the monarchs are funneled right over our campus which is on the westernmost edge of lake Michigan.  They are blown to the lakeshore and fly south along the shoreline.  We reported a late roost from this site a couple of years ago.
I spotted 30 to 40 monarchs roosting in a tree by the creek behind my house today.

In the early morning of October 9th the roost count was 59 monarchs.  Early this morning (October 10) the count was 97.  The Monarchs here seem to be staying for now (as of noon). On October 8th, the count for flying past on part of the sky was 197 in 1.5 hours.  I am 1.5 miles east of Cherokee, TX.  I have not seen nearly this many in the 10 years we have lived here.  On our place they like Dwarf Crownbeard instead of the Golden Crownbread others tell me they like.  We have both. This is the best picture I've been able to get so far; it's windy here and the lighting is problematic.  I will try to get more. 

Editor's Note: We are dating this report 8 October, assuming the roost formed that night but was not discovered until the morning of 9 October. We use evening dates for consistency.

Early this morning (October 10) the roost count was 97 monarchs.  They seem to be staying for now (as of noon). On October 8th, the count for flying past on part of the sky was 197 in 1.5 hours.  I am 1.5 miles east of Cherokee, TX.  I have not seen nearly this many in the 10 years we have lived here.  On our place they like Dwarf Crownbeard instead of the Golden Crownbread others tell me they like.  We have both. This is the best picture I've been able to get so far; it's windy here and the lighting is problematic.  I will try to get more. 

Editor's Note: We are dating this report 9 October, assuming the 97 monarchs reported for 10 October were present that night. We use evening dates for consistency.

Roost Oct 9-10.

Rather than look in the evening, we drove to the large grove 30 minutes after sunrise Oct 10 to observe what happened. 63F and gusty south wind was already blowing. On the way to grove we saw Monarchs leaving trees, but none yet on flowers.

In the grove there were no large clusters, and none flying unless disturbed. They were distributed throughout grove, except for upwind end. Over the next half hour increasd numbers flew out of the grove or to tops of trees to perch in sunlight. By that time I could also see Monarchs in the distance on liatris, when they flew from flower to flower.

When we left, many Monarchs did not appear to be preparing to leave the grove. They remained perched on bare twigs in the shade, 5 to 10 feet from ground. If disturbed they resettled nearby. I will check status later today, but it appears that some are going to remain in the grove all day, just waiting for the wind to change.

I again entered number as 50 as placeholder because the input screen will not accept blank or text. The “correct” number depends on the definition of “roost”. If extended inactivity is enough, then my number should be higher, and some are roosting in the daylight. If a Monarch roost requires clusters and night, then the number is almost none.

About 15-20 Monarchs arrived at my house along Johnson Fork Creek in Eastern Kimble County this evening 10/7/2013. They began to roost in one of the large Elm trees near the creek and appear to be spending the night.
monarchs gathering and clustering in the cedar elms and pecan trees along the San Saba River
Riverside Nature Center, Kerrville, TX: Observed 5 or more Monarchs leaving overnight roost (Pecan Tree) about 9:30 a.m.

Roost for night of Oct 10-11.

We checked the large grove, arriving about 1735. Passed some Monarchs still on flowers in meadows on the way out. There were more Monarchs in the grove than we had seen yet this year. Most perched, but flushed immediately when approached. All through the grove. No large clusters. With them moving from perch to perch, a direct count was impossible, but at least 100. When we left the grove about one hour before sunset, Monarchs had cleared from flowers in meadows. We then checked several other sites on the property and found Monarchs behaving similarly in and around almost every large Live Oak or Ashe Juniper tree or grove that provided a decent wind break. Those further from liatris had fewer. The second largest grove, which is dominated by Live Oak, had at least 50 and I guesstimate the rest at 50 for total 200. Did not check again after dark.

I have been shooting mostly video rather than stills. I will send links once I get a chance to edit. My video and NLE skills are rusty.

The image is one of the occasional hazards of hunting butterflies in the bush. Crotalus atrox, the Western Diamondback, sunning in the large grove. Shadow was moving over it as sun set. Its head is a bit over 2 inches long. I changed route and it never moved.
Dozens between Branson and Springfield near US 65

On a sunny mid 60 day with a harsh east wind blowing at 25 miles per hour, 28 monarchs were spotted in the dunes on the south shore of Long Island. The strong wind beat up the monarchs resulting in them roosting on lower limbs of the pine trees and also roosting on the golden rod. Similar to previous days, the roosts were single or up to 3 monarchs. The monarchs starting roosting early with some looking exhausted. Tonight temps are expected to remain in the mid fifties with no rain expected until the end of next week.
Noticed many flying by my house for the last few weeks. Yesterday walked through an undeveloped area just north of my house and found this roost.

On a sunny day with temps in the low 60's with a strong east wind @ 18 mph, I spotted 11 monarchs. The monarchs looked very healthy. With the strong wind the monarchs took to roosting around 3 pm. Tagging along with the monarchs were buckeye butterflies, who also roosted in the pine trees. Temps tonight are expected to be in the low 50's / high 40's.

For night of Oct 11-12.  Checked two larger groves starting at 2015. The image is from a grove dominated by Live Oak. The monarchs are mostly on a small Live Oak underneath several much larger ones.  The larger heart shaped leaves are Greenbriar, an abundant vine. There are 50 Monarchs in the image and a couple more just out of frame.  A few smaller cluster in this and other groves and trees, but also many, many singles, twos and threes widely distributed.  Some singles can be seen near the edges of this image.

For night of Oct 12-13.   I didnâ€™t physically check roosts this night. Based on daytime sightings previous and following day and that flowers were clear before sunset, no reason to think there were less than previous nights.

Monarchs in Utopia, Sunday Oct. 13th, 5:30 pm. About 100 in the Sabinal River bottom, roosting in cypress trees. Singly, orin groups up to fifteen.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLY

We saw roosting in mesquites early am but mostly on gayfeather during day. We tagged 175 monarchs in three hours today (Oct. 11) at ANC. We are hoping the weather holds tomorrow.

Editor's note: We are dating this report for the night before when the roost formed.

Today was a partly sunny/cloudy day with temps @ 60 degrees and a moderate South wind. I spotted 22 monarchs from 3 pm to 5:30. Although the temp was 60, the cool wind effected the monarchs, some shivered their wings to increase their body temperature while others took to roosting in a sunny spot in the pine trees to warm their wings. They looked healthy, but took to an early roost starting at 3 pm.Temps tonight are expected in the 40's.

I had just about convinced myself that the days of a robust migration were over. Seeing the creatures lilting in the breeze, floating above the persimmons and cedars, and lighting on pecan limbs along the Llano River banks gave me hope that perhaps they would be OK.

The clusters were small compared to previous years. The largest group we saw numbered only 20 â€“ 25. Most swoops of the net garnered only one Monarch at a time. In the past weâ€™d often capture several in one swing.

They moved around the trees and we tagged more than 100 by dinnertime Saturday (October 12)â€“again, in ones and twos. Most appeared healthy and we recorded an equal number of males and females. The butterflies seemed uninterested in the abundant nectar lining the riverbanksâ€“Frostweed, Goldenrod, Water hemlock, Cowpen Daisies, Purple Aster and even a Cardinal flower or two. But Monarchs stayed in the trees, as if resting for their long journey.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Jenny S in Menard reported monarchs roosting but no huge roosts. She and her gang tagged 310 over the weekend (October 12-13), chasing them at three different ranches including her place on the Sabinal River where she usually tags 1,000-plus.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

In Kendall County park, Kreutzberg Canyon Natural Area, along the Guadalupe River, a huge roost was discovered.  We reported 100 Monarchs, but are sure this is a low estimate.  Monarchs were dropping out of trees down to extensive stands of Frostweed (Verbesina virginica) to nectar then going back to roost.  The trees included Pecan (Carya illinoensis), Sugar Hackberry (Celtis laevigata), Bald Cypress (Taxodium distichum) and others.  The roost size was estimated to be 8-10 acres.

For night of Oct 15-16. 1730 to 1800.

Large grove. temp 53. wind north 15G25. 100% humidity. Raining.

Since I saw so few at this location at 1430, I was surprised to find many roosting monarchs. (They were hard to spot so I might have overlooked them at 1430.) I suppose in spite of north wind, the rain kept them from flying off and then the temp dropped too far. I saw 3 or 4 gliding at 10-15 feet which landed in trees. I found many already folded up roosting, mostly appx 15 ft from ground on south side of trees lining an interior space in the grove where some had been earlier in the day.

The attached image taken at 1745 is looking up into a small live oak. Taken with flash, so the light colored underside of the leaves show more than the dark upper sides. Image contains 63 Monarchs. In total I counted any others I could see in this grove, but not any location.

Our wonderland visitors arrived Oct 1 and departed Oct 4, 2013. I would guess around 600 to 700...however my photographer was out among them and feels more like 1,000 monarchs....They appeared to be interested in the alfalfa field in bloom. I know nothing about them, but can only hope we can provide a stopover next year for them. I'll put out a welcome sign on Sept 30.
oak tree in grove

I am reporting for Patsy Ransom who frequently has fall roosts on her property. She is located east of Junction on Johnson Fork Creek.Last night 10/17/13 she had approximately 200 Monarchs roosting in her Elm trees. They spent the night there, then began to leave as soon as the sun hit the trees. All were gone by noon. This evening, more are coming in again, but not very large numbers. A cold front is expected later this evening, which may bring in more.Last year on 10/15/12 she reported at least 500 roosting overnight.

Keith Graves reports, "Temperature at 78 degrees , with wind a 8-12 mph, with 15+mph gusts. This 'Grove' is made up with 6 Pines, 1 Mesquite, 1 Sissoo (Dalbergia sisso, also known as Indian Rosewood, and native to India, Nepal, and Pakistan),  and a single Lupine.  The monarch were high in the Pine and Sissoo with a few exposed but most of them well concealed within the foliage. When I attempted to net on roosting up to 6 others, most was 12+, would flush out of the foliage and fly all around the “grove” and back into the tree leaves and needles.  I estimated that there were well over 60 within this grove, and one mating pair that were united the entire time I was there." (Reported to SW Monarch Study)

Moore Park in Del Rio, Tx. had several 100 monarchs clustering between two trees on a spit between a canal and the San Felipe Creek between 2 and 4 p.m. It was breezy (12-17mph) and the monarchs in front of the main migration wave were traveling through the trees surrounding the creek. When they hit a stiff breeze, the smell of the cluster down wind would bring them back to one particular spot. I counted 76 in one small area (2'sq.). Then we noticed a more sheltered huizache tree east across the creek and about 250 were clustering there.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: Woke from a late nap and found my backyard filled with monarchs by sunset they had all settled into the big pine in my backyard, directly over the swimming pool and about 20-25'in the air.They were loosely clustered over an area of about 12'x 5'; and then in 2-3 other places in the tree. The morning of the 20th, I set up the camera and filmed the cluster as the sun came up and warmed the group. By 9:30 they were all gone and it was easier to estimate their numbers in the bright daylight. Close estimate: 300. Then around 3a.m. the morning of the 21st, I went out with flashlights and didn't see a single one, despite there having been a few coming into cluster in the late evening. Evidently, the wind changed and they moved.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: Fifty monarchs clustering in the Live Oak trees around a pond.

On a sunny day with temps in the low 60's and a moderate west wind I spotted 23 monarchs nectaring on golden rod. With the recent drought, the golden rod has been drying up and dying. Many of the monarchs were congregating on the same plant. They lingered feeding on the golden rod until almost 5:30, with sunset @ 6:10 pm. Nothing could distract them from nectaring. They all seemed famished. Once 5:30 came, one by one they found a pine tree to roost for the night. Although the evening temps dropped to the low 40's the roosts were still single and pairs of two. One tree had five monarchs, though they were spread out on the tree.

El día de ayer (20 de octubre) estuve recorriendo caminos y senderos en el municipio de Jaumave y vi mariposas perchadas, pero solo eran 5, hacía mucho frío y llovió varias veces. Vamos a seguir haciendo este tipo de recorridos para detectarlas oportunamente.

Courtesy of Rocio Treviño of Correo Real and El Monitoreo de la Red de Tamaulipas
Desde el año pasado (2012), varias instituciones de ese estado formaron la red de monitoreo deTamaulipas y empiezan a tenernos informados del paso de las monarcas por su entidad, delcual no teníamos muchos datos.
school: Apff laguna madre y delta del rã­o brave

comments:
10/20 A substantial flight of Monarchs is in progress on the Point this afternoon . . . Moving thru about one every 90 seconds; many are starting to seek roosting sites in the bayberry and fluffy goldenrod seed heads. Watching one roost of about 20 forming right now on a bloomed-out boneset. Numbers are easily on par with many previous years here.

Just as I had expected-- a late flight of monarchs coming down the Mid-Atlantic coast on WNW, NNW and NW winds. Denise G.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Hoy por la tarde me avisaron que estaban pasando las monarcas, salí incrédulo y vemos que estaban pasando a unos 3 metros por encima del  techo  de la  casa la mayoría, otras mucho más alto, 8 o 10 metros, pero bajando. Inicié el conteo a las 6:12 y lo cerré a las 6:32 Contabilizamos 225 en esos 20 minutos. Antes ya había pasado un grupo de más de 25 y después siguieron pasando unas y llegando otras. Deben haber pasado más de 300 y se percharon aproximadamente otras 200 en la ceiba que está, al lado del estanque. Las últimas que vimos llegar se percharon a las 7:25 PM. Parecían conocer el lugar exacto donde llegarían. A las 7:30 pm había poco más de 20º Centígrados (menos de 21) no se sentía viento pero en lo alto se veía que a ellas las arrastraba una corriente de aire que no las dejaba volar directo a la ceiba. Para esa hora el cielo estaba muy nublado, parecía que pronto llovería. En este momento (10:15 PM) el cielo está despejado y hay 18ºC espero mañana tomar una buena foto. 

Courtesy of Rocio Treviño, Correo Real.

Hoy a la 6:30 pm se vierón por primera vez mas de treinta mariposas Monarcas buscando donde dormir entre encinos y nogales, en la orilla de la Presa la Boca en Santiago, Nuevo León. Que alegría ya les tengo montones de asclepias en flor.

Courtesy of Rocio Treviño of Correo Real

Hoy a la 6:30 se vieron por primera vez más de treinta m. Monarcas buscando donde dormir entre encinos y nogales, en la orilla de la Presa la Boca en Santiago, Nuevo León. Que alegría ya les tengo montones de asclepias en flor.

Pismo Beach butterfly grove, 63 degrees, approx 12 pm, winds calm, partly cloudy. Butterflies roosting in eucalyptus grove. Several thousand observed in many clusters. Butterflies became more active as temperature rose, nectaring on native plants along stream bed leading to the beach. Butterflies appeared healthy and active.

Saw many off and on all day while working outside.  Caught this picture late as many were stopping to roost high in the trees.  This one was about 12 feet up.  I stood on a ladder and zoomed in for the picture. They have really been amazing this year.  What a difference a little rain has made for us this year verses the past 3 years.

Went to Del Rio (64 mi. N of Eagle Pass) today and visited Moore Park just north of the swimming pool on San Felipe Creek, where last Sunday we saw about 500 monarchs.

This afternoon at 3:30 there were 50 monarchs in the same wind shadow. That count was in a 20 minute time period.

"Resting in the trees" for me is a roost because the exact same branches are used night after night and year to year. When the number of monarchs is large and up wind, the speed with which the still flying monarchs do a 180 degree turn, fly back up their path until they cross the scent stream of the already clustering/roosting body of monarchs, then zip straight over and alight, with all the nearby 'roosters?' ( or would that be 'roostees?') flashing their wings, is remarkable. For me cluster and roost are interchangeable. So does a roost imply only sleeping or resting over night?

I think our definition of "Roost" must vary somewhat. A matter of semantics. There is more a component of time, action, and stasis in your interpretation. My idea of "Roost" is a locus used year after year because of prevailing wind patterns &/or any time there's a number of resting monarchs in a confined area for any length of time (a noun). This is a hangover definition from childhood for me of "Chickens coming home to (the) roost. Do you see the action of "roosting" or "to roost" (verbals) as paramount?
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

Miles de Mariposas monarcas descansaban en un gran mezquite y se alimentaban en un campo de cultivo abandonado sobre flores de falso girasol. Por observaciones de los lugareños, estas mariposas ya tienen al menos 4 días [estimating 22 October] en el sitio esperando un fuerte viento del norte para migrar hacia el sur. Mas hacia el sur sobre esa misma ruta no se han observado mariposas.

EL sitio de las fotos corresponde a la siguiente posición geográfica23.451470 Latitud Norte y -99.473307 Longitud OesteEs un sitio que tradicionalmente año con año gran cantidad de mariposas perchan.Durante ese día 26 de Octubre, hice una inspección en la zona y no hubo otrositio igual que tuviera muchas mariposas.El sitio se ubica al Oeste de Jaumave Tamaulipas.El cañon del Novillo se ubica al Este de Jaumave a 60 kilómetros. Este sitio está mascercano a Cd. Victoria, Tam.

Mis técnicos me reportan una gran migración de mariposas desde el 28 de Octubre a la fechaen la posición geográfica 23.368847 LN y -99.473307 porviniendo del norte franco hacia el sur. Este punto se ubica al Oeste de Jaumave a 10 kilómetros sobre la carretera que va de Cd. Victoria,luego pasa por Jaumave y luego se continúa hacia San Luis Potosí.

Mi apreciación personal, es que en este sitio se registra la mayor migración de mariposas monarcaen Tamaulipas. Estas cruzan del Estado de Nuevo León hacia Tamaulipas en la cercanía del poblado de Zaragoza.

Editor's Note: This roost was reported on 26 October and says monarchs were present for at least 4 days prior. Therefore, we dated the report 22 October.

About 2,000 monarchs total seen clustered at the San Leandro Marina Golf Course (also known as the Monarch Bay Golf Course) in San Leandro, Calif. just south of Oakland, Calif. <object width="640" height="360"><param name="movie" value="//www.youtube.com/v/ti5shZ2e1dI?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="//www.youtube.com/v/ti5shZ2e1dI?version=3&hl=en_US&rel=0" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="360" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>

November 6, 2013
10:00 pm EST

Very Dear Friends,
The first monarchs are here at last!
They just jumped up today after noon time. The weather was rather sunny and fresh and, by noontime, a kind of sixth sense told me monarchs might appear today.José Alberto, Rosa Isela, Erika, Javier and I jumped into the car and left towards El Cerrito longing to see a Monarch somewhere on the way.

The first Monarchs were majestically flying over the northwest side of our town not looking in the least affected by the very bad weather we have had in the last days.

Later in the afternoon, we went back to El Cerrito just by sunset, since we wanted to confirm their staying overnight there but, by that time, there was not one single butterfly neither flying nor on the trees.It seemed they would spend the night somewhere else. It all points to the likelihood that within the next 2-3 days the colonies should start to forme in El Rosario and Chincua Sanctuaries, which will be officially opened next on November 22nd.

This coming weekend, we will be confirming Monarchs' official arrival from the way up to "El Rosario" and from "El Rosario Sanctuary" itself, so that we can officially announce their arrival

Meanwhile, we can indeed say that today, Wednesday, November 6th the first monarchs have arrived this year to their overwintering region in Central México!

José Alberto, Rosa Isela, Erika, Javier and Estela.
Angangueo, Michocán, México

Saw several clustering roosts just southeast of Osceola, WI tonight (8/25/14) . Temperatures were in the 60s and are predicted to bottom out at 52 by morning. Conditions were brisk wind from the west until dusk, clear skies, falling humidity.

This afternoon, I found a good sized alfalfa field in full bloom. From one spot, viewing just a small portion of the field, I counted more than a dozen Monarchs so I knew there could be many dozens or even more than a hundred in the whole field. The owner had cut half of the alfalfa today (and plans to cut the rest tomorrow). Luckily, last week's wet weather had postponed his cutting.

I was fairly confident that the Monarchs would go to a small hill of trees near the center of the field; not so. I gave up watching that spot at about 6:45 and drove out to the road, then north. I saw two Monarchs flying north along the ditch, so I slowly followed them, figuring they would lead me to the preferred roosting spots, which they did.

That spot was an assortment of trees on a high point near the northwest edge of the field. The owner gave me permission to photograph on his property and for an hour and a half, I watched a hundred or so Monarchs trying to settle in for the night at various spots around his acre or two woodlot and yard. Most of them probably ended up as singles or small, loose clusters. The clusters I ended up photographing were located on an oak tree along the wind belt and in a tall ash all by itself in the open yard.

I would not have found the roosts if I had not followed the Monarchs; live and learn.

The owner watched with binoculars and helped me count and verify that we had at least three branches with ten or more Monarchs. At one point I counted 20 as I panned the video camera.

Northerly winds are predicted for tomorrow (8/26/14) and the farmer is cutting the rest of the alfalfa; I suspect all of these Monarchs will be migrating as far south as the wind will take them.I thank them kindly for the show. What a joy to see so many brand new, bright Monarchs. They are a thing of great wonder and joy.........

Update August 26Monarch numbers have been far better this summer. I haven't seen as many Monarchs for a long time. Lately, I've become worried by the lack of caterpillars in my immediate areas, but yesterday's alfalfa field numbers and last night's roosts are very encouraging.

The weather has been wet for the last week with very few if any days with good north winds. We've had a mixture of cold days and then hot and muggy days. Temperatures ranging from 60s to high 80s, depending on the day and specific area.

Yesterday (8/25/14) the humid weather was pushed out when a high pressure moved in, bringing drier air and strong westerly winds.

I was actually surprised to find so many Monarchs yesterday afternoon. I cannot say whether they were mostly "locals" or not.

I do know that wind and weather has not been conducive to migration, but that has changed. Today's northwest winds will almost certainly move Monarchs all over the area. I will be checking for feeding Monarchs later this afternoon, but I suspect any that I find will not be those I saw feeding and roosting last night.

The three photos were taken this morning (8/26/14). Near 50 degree temps and cloudy skies kept the Monarchs roosting long after daybreak, and a widespread cloud cover discouraged any early activity.

But the sun is shining now, and the temperature is 62. After feeding, the Monarchs will be migrating. No doubt in my mind.

A television station did a story about Lowell Seibels observing monarchs clustering on his property in rural Harwood, North Dakota . The number of clustering monarchs is not specified, but the photo provided suggests at least a few dozen:
5 adults sighted at dusk preparing to roost in a tree at the lakeshore in St. Catharines Marina

While at my son's cross country meet last night (in Mankato, MN), I was drawn from the course to a beautiful prairie planting.  I was richly rewarded with the sights and sounds of the grassland, most especially the splendor of numerous monarchs nectaring from blazing star.  Then to my delight I spotted several clusters of butterflies roosting in the trees lining the edge of the prairie.  What a spectacular sight!  People covered the grounds watching cross country, football and soccer - unaware of the incredible natural phenomenon taking place so silently and magnificently just steps away.
10 roosting monarchs, others flying around and possibly roosting in a neighboring birch tree

We had a small roost under the sycamore tree along the Monarch Trail in Wauwatosa last evening (8/29). only about 25-30 in various branches--groups of 8-10. Since last year was so bleak, we are excited to see them relating to this protected area once again.

I observed a fall roost on 2 locations on our farm near Barnesville, MN. About 50 monarchs were near the garden on a bur oak and 150 on a cottonwood tree in one of our tallgrass prairie remnants. A good number of individual monarchs were still on the prairie the same day (8-29-14).

Only about 5 monarchs in the area where I used to see hundreds.We have had lots of new houses being built around us this year and the developers have taken out many of the trees.  We still have one shelter belt left where we have often seen many monarchs, so I have been curiously watching.

Cool and damp/misty  @ 5 p.m.We have had lots of new houses being built around us this year and the developers have taken out many of the trees.  We still have one shelter belt left where we have often seen many monarchs, so I have been curiously watching the last few days.  I saw 3-8 fluttering in the trees where they usually roost the last 2 days, although I’m not sure if these were roosting, or just passing through.  We just checked the area tonight (8/25/14), and there weren’t any in the same area, even though the temperature has gotten quite cool.  I will continue to watch and try to report on the Journey North site.
Thirty monarchs roosting in my mountain ash tree!  Very windy tonight with storms coming.

Had a fall roost yesterday evening (8/30), only 9 individuals but they were in the tree branches settling in for the night.  Counted nine individuals today but a storm front moved through so detecting roosting tonight was not possible tonight.
Very small roost tonight (4 monarchs) in my mountain ash tree.

Report on a roost at the Big Lake section that I watch:I watched monarchs flying singly to the western tree edge of the 40+ acres of prairie grass, milkweed, and goldenrod.  I spotted only two single monarchs after they landed.  Just before dark, I walked out to the north along the trail and spotted another flying monarch near the top of an elm tree.  I used binoculars to verify that it had indeed landed near other monarchs.  Luckily two or three other monarchs were still coming in from feeding, and one of those found the roost, bringing about the characteristic welcoming flutter that monarchs exhibit.  I was shooting video at the time but thought I could count about eight monarchs for sure.  The still photo I took a minute later shows at least eight and possibly ten or even twelve monarchs roosting, so I am going to claim credit for my second roost of the year, one week after the sighting last Monday.Even more importantly, this particular section has had a very nice population of emerging and feeding monarchs the last few days.  I believe many dozens or even hundreds of monarchs will owe their lives to this piece of land.....and in large part to the people who created new milkweed growth patches by cutting down thistles (and milkweed) on July 19.It is a wonderful piece of land and a wonderful piece of land management............I have photos, of course, but tonight I'll just show my roost : )

At around 9am I observed 20-30 monarchs in a small prairie area in west central Minnesota. After observing a few flying around nectaring on liatris and goldenrod, I moved closer to a small cottonwood tree in the middle of the prairie area and the rest of the butterflies flew from the tree. Small clusters were observed again the morning of 9/1 in the same tree and other small bushes.

There were at least a hundred butterflies perched in the trees on our farm in rural southeastern ND. We spotted them about 18 hours ago for the first time and they are still here today (9/2/14).

Editor's note: We have dated this report to September 1 since the roost was sighted 18 hours prior to 9/2.

I am fortunate to have been where I was Monday morning, 9-1-14.  I got to one of the main roost sites just as the Monarchs were starting to warm up in the sun. I can only estimate the number of 500 or more on several smaller Eastern cottonwood trees. The cottonwood tree grove is in the middle of a Tallgrass prairie remnant on our farm. This has always been a good staging area over the years because of the food source (wildflowers) and native grasses.After the Monarchs warmed in the sun they began to move into the prairie remnant to forage on goldenrod, sunflowers and blazing star. I was surrounded by Monarchs just going about the business of fueling up for the flight south.I would estimate the number of Monarchs on our farm this weekend at well over 1,000. I know of 3 roost sites that had close to that many and I saw many individual Monarchs on our grasslands from 8-29 to 9-1-2014, they were not all in the roosts.Milkweeds are vital but so are undisturbed grasslands with a season long food source. We have about 200 acres of Tallgrass prairie on our farm, some native some restored. There are tree groves throughout for protection on the windy days, this weekend the Monarchs waited out the south winds in the trees and foraged on the native species.From my standpoint in western Minnesota it looks to rival 2011To see more of our Monarch habitat go to www.bigbluestemprairie.com
The branches and leaves of the tree were covered with monarchs.

Multiple clusters in 5 areas within our habitat on the Monarch Trail. The clusters are spread out and difficult ot photograph.The monarchs utilize the exact same branches as they did in past years. they are partial to dead limbs low and under the canopy.
Many butterflies were flying around the trees
saw these about noon today.  The day started with warm, and humid with a south wind. About noon the wind switched to the east and temps dropped.

While watching my sons football practice, I found a small roost of 11 in a single row of trees joining the practice field. They are getting nectar of alfalfa and clover from across the road to the west. Current temp is 72 with NNW wind of 13mph. Picture isn't the greatest quality with my cell phone and the cluster is down to 8 now with a few more trying to find a spot in the trees. They are roosting on the east side of the trees.
4 trees(willow)along a small creek were covered with resting Monarchs warming up from the chilly night.  Estimate maybe be low at 450.
More monarchs arrived late this afternoon !

As of today (9/7/14), the monarchs have been roosting here for a week (since Monday night, 9/1/14), and flying around and feeding for about 2 weeks total. The first time I saw them roost was Monday Sept 1. For about 1 week prior to that, I saw many monarchs flying around in our yard. I didn't know anything about "roosting" and their migration until seeing them and finding your wonderful website.Here's a summary: Monday September 1:- first roost sighting - between 6:30 and 8 p.m. - 1 cluster on edge of grove = 80Tuesday September 2:- lots of activity inside the grove of trees. That's when I noticed they were forming more than one cluster. They had increased to = 125-150. Mostly at edge of grove, maybe some inside.Wednesday September 3:- multiple clusters at edge of grove - increased to about = 200.Thursday September 4:- the most I have seen - 5 clusters at edge of grove - about = 300+. (If I could visually see 300 there were probably more). It was very warm, humid and windy with wind coming from the south. Was warm all 4 nights.Friday September 5:- Sadly no roost sightings. I did see them in the alfalfa field, and saw at least 10 flying near the tops of the trees in the grove but heading to the other side of the grove. I could not find any roosts. It was cold, and wind now coming from the north.Saturday, September 6--  They're back! It was warm and the wind was from the south. They were roosting in two separate groves this time. - 500 roostingSunday, September 7 - They were forming roosts in two groves again.- I'm estimating at least 400.We are blessed to be a hotspot for monarchs right now. An 18 acre field of fully blooming alfalfa and prairie grasses backs up to our property. The monarchs feed there by day.  Hundreds of them right now. It is difficult to estimate how many are in the field right now (9/7/14), I'm guessing more than 400 - but that's what I could reasonably report. They roost in our tree groves at night. A dozen are free flying around our property at any given moment. It was a labor of love to go out into the field this morning to observe them. The flowers are taller than my knee high boots, and the honey bees and bumble bees love the field too. Didn't need one of those down my boot.Here is a brief background of our property: we live on 3 acres. I have a large organic vegetable garden, and several blooming perennial gardens. We try to use mostly natural and organic yard products. Our backyard faces south and backs up to an 18 acre field of mostly alfalfa. It is cut and baled twice per summer/fall by a local farmer who leases it. Right now it is in full bloom with purple alfalfa flowers. The butterflies can be seen there during the day. The west side of our backyard has a perfect little grove of trees - mostly volunteer elm and ash. After reading your site, sounds like a perfect place for them to roost. My husband and I do a little "walkabout" on our property with our dog most nights during sunset. I observed the monarchs each night this week. They roosted on the edge facing our yard.

Ever since we bought our acreage 19 years ago we have had monarchs roost in our yard in the fall. Some years there are more than other years. You can see alfalfa blooming in the background. This fall they have been showing up since about Sept 1st. Finally on the 4th decided to go shake a few branches to see how many were here, and to my delight found hundreds roosting in the trees.
We saw several hundred butterflies on each of at least three evenings.  They would fly around until sunset and then land in the trees.
Had a roost going in the yard with several groups of 4-8 individuals together on different branches...also individuals still pollinating in the pasture.  I counted them roosting this evening.

Observed at least 200 adult monarchs fluttering around in the trees.  Since it is evening, we assume that they are roosting.We see them every year about this time. Some times just a few and sometimes thousands of them.

Small roost (16 or 17) on a tree to the west of a field of goldenrod.  Six more on the other side of the road nearby.  Field is large so there could have been several small roosts.  Numbers of monarchs are much less now; today's northern winds moved many on their way.  I suspect those I saw tonight were mostly migrating from further north of here.  Southerly winds tomorrow and Sunday could create higher numbers as low flyers find good goldenrod areas.  Farmers have almost all cut their alfalfa before it blossoms.  Very cold tonight (predicted 50 or lower) and so the monarchs roosted early and certainly.  No fooling around when the real cold comes..........

I was out by my grove of elm trees yesterday. As the day went by more and more appeared.They seem to be resting, and chasing each other around. This has happened before in 2011, I have photos of both gatherings.

Attending boys football game in Elkton this morning.  There has been a steady stream of Monarchs flying south since we left Bushnell. There had to be a large roost in Elkton last night with this many flying over the football field. I have heard of two other roosts in the last few days. One large roost in Ruthton, MN at a friends house since Tuesday, she guessed there to be 100 in her pine tree. The other roost was near Bushnell, SD at my folks with about 30 in one tree last night.

Went horseback riding in Union Grove State Park, South of Beresford, SD in SE SD last evening.  Monarchs were everywhere and starting to gather on the oaks, sumacs, and junipers.  It was amazing!  I'm sure we saw more than a 1000 of them.

On a sunset walk through an alfalfa field as we approached the surrounding woods (large old oak trees), we looked up and saw a small swarm of monarchs seeming to roost on the trees. They seemed to us to be pairing off and flying high above the field and into the large oak trees.  These were the first monarchs we saw this year.  Feedback appreciated from observers who know monarchs...

Our farm has been a roost for years. Last year was so very sad. I was afraid this year we had been passed over, but tonight they came in nicely. Calm winds, no rain predicted.

More of the new flock from last night (9/7). It seems like a few more than last year, but not nearly as many as years before. One year in particular we had literally thousands each night.

We were eating a late supper when our grandson noticed some Monarchs flying around.  He started counting them.  When he got to about 12 we thought he was double counting since they were moving about.  As we continued to watch we realized there were a few dozen in the birch tree.  Approx. 4 hours later and they are still there.  No idea what attracted them to this tree but so glad to have had this experience.
Wayne from Welcome, MN, reported 100 Monarch butterflies roosting in an evergreen tree in his yard this evening.

We had 5 or 6 roosts in our big black willow trees overnight (9/6)

So here are just two of the roosts -- will try again tomorrow for better photos. We saw many butterflies gathering to roost in the dusk this evening (9/7) so fingers crossed! It was very thrilling this morning to see them waking up as the sun touched their wings and then to see them fluttering and flying off!

Many in tree by house at about 8:30 AM.

Editor's note: We have changed the date of the report to 9/2 since the roost formed the night before.
Large number settled in for the night on two trees by the barn around 6 PM.
Large group settled in for the night in two trees.

Although I have seen few Monarchs this summer, this past few days there have been several accumulating around our stand of tall poplars.  On Sunday Sept. 7th there were more than I've ever seen in a roost.  They just kept coming!  About 7 -7:30 p.m. I took some photos of 3 different places where they were gathering, and counted 50 or more.  I could see that the tops of the trees quaking as they were filling with them also (80 - 90 ft up), but my camera could not distinguish them from the leaves that were flame-coloured due to the sunset.  Hope tonight there are more!  This is very encouraging, as for the past few years there have not been many at all.
