My husband and I do a little "walkabout" on our property with our dog most nights during sunset. I observed the monarchs each night this week. They roosted on the edge facing our yard.

They're back! It was warm and the wind was from the south. They were roosting in two separate groves this time. It's amazing to walk around during dusk as they are coming in from the alfalfa field. So many - racing all around, trying out different trees, getting into groups. They roosted much higher in the trees this time. It was wonderful having my best friend and her husband over for dinner to see this wonderful sight. We figure there were around 350 roosting in each grove, but they were higher and the 2nd grove is out a little further with taller trees - they kept coming in from the field even as it was getting fairly dark. I conservatively listed 500, but think it could have been more.

Sometimes it's like being in a Disney animation around here. At dusk, there were Monarchs flying all around, racing past my head, circling around each other - I could hear their wings. I gave up trying to take pictures and videos and just walked around and enjoyed it. They came in from the field and  grouped up in various trees - love how their wings start flapping like little flames as new ones come into the group, then go suddenly still, then they would all fly out from that tree and fly around to another group and and another tree. Takes awhile to get settled I guess. They were forming roosts in two groves again. I'm estimating at least 400. It was very windy when I got up this morning (Monday 9/8) and I found several groups of them on the north side of our near grove still. Didn't get a chance to look for the others in the further out grove.

Saw 50-60 warming up in the morning sun (9/6).

Editor's Note: We are dating this report for the evening of 9/5 when the roost formed.
Monarchs are roosting in our oak trees.

There is a roosting site on my mom and dad's farm East of Yankton. The Monarchs are grouping mostly in Mulberry trees but also in Ash and Elm. They are clustering in large groups of 50 to a 100 with over 1,500 roosting in multiple trees (on 9/6/14). Once the sun hits them in the morning they start to open their wings and flutter around but mostly they seem to be resting. The butterflies started arriving on Thursday the 4th of September.  Mom noticed them after work, around 4:30PM. More arrived on the 5th and the maximum number arrived on the 6th with the total count that day being around 1500 butterflies. It was a windy day on the 7th and my mom thought they had gone but they had retreated to the grove of trees where there was more of a wind break. The Observer newspaper came out and took pictures. Here's a summary of evening counts:9/4: At least 100 monarchs9/5: 400-5009/6: 1000-15009/7: 1000-1500 they moved out of the wind to the grove of trees.9/8:  5009/9:  200-3009/10: 2009/11: 50 they are not moving due to the cold front that has come through.9/12  500Update September 13I came out to the farm today (9/13/14). There is a 25 mph south wind and there are at least 500 Monarchs on the edge of the grove. It got down below freezing last night (9/12/14). At 10:30 AM, the butterflies that were warmed by the morning sun were flying around and the ones in the shade were still hanging in the trees.

Observed approximately 100 monarchs resting and flying around the east side of a small group of oaks and and brush. Cool overcast morning, about 10:30 am Sept 5th. I was at Crow-Hassan Park Reserve which has a restored prairie. Lots of liatris and goldenrod blooming.

There were monarchs in the oaks above these bushes, again camera wasn't able to get a shot where they would have shown up It was a cool morning I assumed they had roosted here there were so many and hadn't gotten warm enough to move on. This was at 10:30 am, I was back out there in the evening it was warmer. There were none where I saw them in am, but saw several trees where they were high up in the branches of oaks. Fewer than 10 per tree.

Editor's note: We've dated the roost for the night before when the roost was formed.
About 75 monarchs have spent the last 2nights in our trees. First monarchs sighted Sept. 8. Roosted for 3 nights. We have plenty of flowers with nectar and milkweed.

Observed an estimated 100 monarchs on the north side of a farm shelterbelt (cottonwood, elm, hackberry, redcedar)around 10AM. Most were active in flight; some still roosting in trees. Difficult to get an accurate estimate because the monarchs were loosely clustered. There might have been more that were undetected.

Some started roosting early tonight.- around 6 pm.  Windy all day, probably takes a toll on their energy. About 150 in one group - the early ones, 100 in another, 50 in the pine trees, and at least 50 still flying around when I went in for the night.

From Sat. through Tuesday (9/6-9/9), our family has been noticing the monarch migration. We went to the Korean War Memorial by Lake Pacawa and saw them feeding at the clover patch across the street before heading over to take cover on the trees for the evening. We noticed this roughly four years ago there when the monarch population was dense, but thereafter noticed they had significantly decreased in numbers. This year they are finally back in substantial numbers, which brought joy to us knowing they are flourishing once again. We even acquired a pet monarch that I found injured on the side of the road (most likely hit by a car). My oldest daughter Ayla named her Luna, and we have been trying to give here plenty of flowers, fruit and sun to get her strength back. Unfortunately, her wings are scratched and she rarely flies. She will be taking a day trip to school so that the class may observe, write and learn about the migration.

This week the first migrating Monarchs arrived at our grove.  On Sunday, 4-5 Monarchs were roosting.  Monday the 8th, there were a few more and yesterday, Sept 9, there were several clusters of at least 10 Monarchs.  We had 24 hours of rain and cooler weather has arrived so I will check on them later today to determine whether these Monarchs fly south or hang out until more agreeable weather.  Chip Taylor was correct in his estimation of Monarch numbers--I tagged only 24 Monarchs last year and I have already used my 50 tags this year.  Cathy Irvine

I have seen many more Monarchs over the past two weeks than I saw during the entire summer of 2013. There are usually 3 to 6 nectarine on phlox, Joe Pye weed, zinnias, and asters. But the best news of all is that I am getting a few roosting in my small woods. Last night, (9/9) I estimate about 3 dozen.The night before, (9/8) there was a similar number. Iâ€™m hoping numbers will increase over the next week. Itâ€™s just good to see them at all after last year.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch

Several dozen monarchs were seen in a black walnut tree along the Lake Ontario shore. While watching the lake for several hours, approximately 100 Monarchs were observed throughout Hamlin Beach State Park with several more seen on our ride back to Rochester.

Roosting in trees along a small drive with more in area trees. Calm cool AM

Another roost from 3 miles west of previous roost.

My husband spotted hundreds of Monarch butterflies in the tree line along side a creek and cemetery east side of Kiester, MN. Which is located south central Minnesota...about 2 miles from Iowa border.  So I grabbed my camera to go check it out. Hundreds...some in the sky, some on the trees. Great thing to see and experience them fly around you!

Last night, the monarchs began roosting in the trees of the Monona Butterfly Garden.  This morning I found a group of 12 and several smaller groups  of 1-4. All together, there were 21 monarchs roosting within 15 feet of each other.

The monarchs were roosting. They were in all the trees lining the Nature Center driveway and many were high up. I didn't look at every tree but they were in at least 10 trees. I'd see one open manarch and then look and see a bunch of closed ones around it. Usually clusters of 5-10 monarchs. When the early morning light would hit the branch they'd flex their wings and take flight. Amazing. We estimated 100-200 but I bet if we looked at all the trees and actually counted there were more.

Last year we saw a total of TWO monarch caterpillars at the nature center all summer. This year they were present in great numbers. All the summer campers even got to see a female ovi-positing.

I was wrong!  Tonight around 730 I went out and looked in my trees and they were there!  I attached a quick photo I took to show you.  I hope it comes through okay and you can see the monarchs.  They are bunched together (probably to keep warm!).  It is going to get cold tonight maybe in the forties....brrr... Friday night we are looking at a low of 36 degrees.  I hope the little buggers get a lot further south so they stay warm.  Enjoy the photo, sorry it is so dark but it was later in the evening.
Saw eight in the Maple last evening.

Didn't see very many this year. The monarchs didn’t alight for very long but their activity was consistent with the roosting process.  We will keep an eye on their favorite roosting area to see if we have another wave coming through.  There is a bush in a shelter belt with leaf/seeds that resemble roosted monarchs when they get dry later in the season.  We have had a late fall so the leaf/seeds are just now starting to turn “roosted monarch color”.  I have always assumed they like that spot because it helps to camouflage them while they roost so our hope is that more may be coming through.

Counted 110 monarchs roosting throughout the trees at the tip of Point Pelee between the hours of 10:30am-noon (9/13). Weather was cloudy, cold, and windy so they weren't flying too much.

Editor's note: We re-dated this report to 9/12, the night the roost formed.
Saw a lot of butterflies I have never seen it before

We went on a short road trip today and saw 13 monarchs crossing the road.  The predominant flight direction was south.  When we cam home, 4:30 pm,  we went down to the Butterfly Garden and observed many monarchs flying around the trees and a few that had settled.  We went back at 6:00 pm and tagged 22 monarchs.  There were a lot of small groups of 2-3 and we scared up a group that was 10+ monarchs.

The three monarchs were flying around our backyard and our butterfly bush.  They stayed for the night in the leaves of a birch tree and were sighted again in the morning until the sun hit their wings.

Had 38 in a roost here this a.m.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 9/14 to 9/13, the night the roost formed.

Saw about 400 monarchs roosting near the lighthouse grounds on South Bass Island in Lake Erie. See story and photos here.

It was cold Saturday. On the lighthouse grounds, the car thermometer read upper 50s during most of the afternoon/evening. The night the roosts formed (9/13/14), it was miserably cold all day, steady winds of 5-10 mph, and earlier in the day they were 20-30 mph. The windchill had to be much lower than mid-50s when we first arrived to the island at around 11:30 am. We very quickly drove by the sunflower field, little activity, just a few monarchs nectaring in the sunflowers that we could see from the car. We did not check the private drive at that time. We had lunch and then went to Jackie's, etc. When we returned to the lighthouse grounds around 3pm, the roosts were visibly beginning to form. It was upper 50s.It wasn't hard to spot the roosts. I just watched nectaring monarchs exit the sunflower field, and followed them as they flew toward the trees along the private drive. Lone monarchs would fly up to the trees, then fly horizontally along the treeline until they spotted other monarchs. The lone monarch would then attempt to settle in--sometimes the receiving cluster did not move; other times cluster members "flashed" the new arrival, but stayed put; other times the cluster broke up, everybody scattered/flew about 5-10 ft, then they all circled back and regrouped together back on the tree branches.Kasey was on the lighthouse grounds, where it was still windy. You can see the tree branches moving in his video, whereas the other video was made on the private drive where it was much calmer. I did video all the roosts along the whole length of the drive, but did not post the video--it is long, I couldn't zoom in well with Kasey's cameraphone, and I am hesitant to reveal too much to the public.I had a hard time photographing them at first. The crunching noise my feet made on the gravel path was scaring them, and monarchs in the lower bushes kept taking to the air as I got within 10-15 ft of them, then they quickly resettled in the same area. It took about a half hour for them to get comfortable with my presence. Along the private drive, there was no breeze (leeward side of tree line), it felt slightly warmer, and was quiet. Birds were beginning to roost too. Most of the monarch roosts formed between 3-4 pm, some monarchs did move higher in the canopy until about 6:30 pm, trying to catch remaining rays of sunlight that still hit the tops of the trees. They were in apple trees, honeysuckle bushes, and really any protected tree/bush along that treeline. But most settled in about 15--30 feet off the ground, in common hackberry with red maple around http://www.illinoiswildflowers.info/trees/plants/hackberry.html. They were settled in by 7pm, it was 52F on the car thermometer at that time, parked at the lighthouse grounds.The next morning it was quite cool. They did not leave the roosts in significant numbers until the temp reached 57F. Then many nectared in the sunflower field and along the cliffs next to the water. When we returned later in the evening, most all were gone. Just a few tiny roosts left.

Roosting in trees along Blanchard River. Temps in 40's overnight. They left yesterday (9/15) after the temps warmed up. I had only seen a roost once before, and that was probably 40 years ago! Is was quite a sight.

We observed and counted 30 monarchs gathering to roost for the night.  There were about at least 15-20 more that were still fluttering about trying to find the perfect spot in the trees along the break wall.I shot a very short video clip that is a little less than a minute long.The attached photo is of just a few of the monarchs observed. I didn't have my wide angle lens available as I was shooting photos of various birds at the time we spotted the monarchs as they began their roosting for the evening.

Hundreds of monarchs were gathering along "Sunnyside Park" in Toronto. The park is on the north shore of Lake Ontario. As the day became cooler the monarchs were collecting in the upper branches of the willow trees. I had observed them throughout the day floating through the south end of the city, just above the lake. I had counted 72 and then decided to head to the lake where I was sure I would see more. And I did. Can't help but feel that the numbers will be better this year. I had counted 21 throughout the summer and was happy with that. But this day was spectacular.

Editor's note: Also in PEAK Migration

We were told by a couple of cyclist that in the small park behind the Arts Council there were hundreds of Monarchs gathering in the trees. This was something yours truly had never witnessed before. So off we all went down the street. Oh my, what a sight! A mini version of Mexico!

The park that they were in is Harrison Properties. The coordinates are 43.694403, -79.258525

Was watching monarch & upon landing in our elm tree others fluttered alerting me to their roosting. About 7 roosting. Saw day before about a dz pass thru. I still have monarch caterpillars in our sanctuary :)
I started seeing monarchs circling in the yard, around 7:00 last evening. When they started roosting, I ran and got my tagging kit. I tagged my second monarch! So exciting!

There is a prairie next to the Ney Environmental Learning Center 1 mile east of Henderson MN.   For three nights in a row, 100+ monarchs roosted in the walnut trees near the prairie....a small number compared to the sightings of past years... 3rd, 4th and 5th of September.  However, on the 7th and 9th of September,  H U G E numbers (close to a thousand) nectared on a red clover field (sunny afternoons, temp near 70 degrees) taking our collective breaths away.  Only a video camera would have encompassed the sight.  (Oh, to have observed THAT roost!!!!!)In autumn 2012 and 2013, the number of Monarchs passing through our area was pathetic.
Although very few,this was at least equivalent to last year the seem quite hardy and lively

On Saturday (9/13) morning I was at the Black Swamp Bird Observatory banding station, which is behind Davis Bessie along the lakeshore. I saw dozens of monarchs roosting and feeding while driving the along the stretch of roadway right up against the lake. - isn't Nature awesome?

Editor's note: We are dating this roost at 9/12 the night it formed. Courtesy of Candace Sarikonda
gathering at edge of lake ontario, numbers increased but then appeared to go inland together and not across lake

Along the main trail to the tip they started gathering around 6:45PM.  We kept finding roost after roost; with so many fluttering about it was impossible to count.  It seemed as if they were just falling out of the sky.  I counted at least 5 roosts.  The branches were just dripping with monarchs  It was difficult to count, as this is a National Park and we had to stay on the trails.  WHAT A WONDROUS SIGHT.  My 8 year old son and I have been going periodically for a couple of years hoping for this!  When I saw the numbers over the past few days in the Toronto area northeast of us and with the sunny, 18C low wind conditions and seeing a few about in our yard I called the park and they indicated that they were seeing some flying through all day; I thought we might get lucky and we did!

About 6:30 p.m. I noticed there were about 10 butterflies all in the same general area of our yard.  The monarchs were roosting predominantly in one pin oak tree, about 25-30 feet off the ground.  They sort of bunched themselves in groups of 20 to 30 on different parts of the branches.  All of the butterflies were on the west side of the tree, getting the last of the sun's rays.  The majority of the monarchs had their wings closed while the rest had their wings open, showing their wonderful rich colors.  When the neighbor children came close, chattering & talking, some of the butterflies flew around briefly but soon settled back onto the tree.

At Hawk Cliff, just east of Port Stanley 6 roosts of 10 Monarchs, 1 roost of 15 Monarchs and 1 roost of 25 Monarchs were sighted just after 7:00 a.m. (9/17/14) -- for a total of 100 monarchs.Editor's Note: We date all roost reports for the night the roost formed. Therefore, we are dating this report as 9/16/14.
Observed several large groups roosting in and around a Sycamore tree on the Monarch Trail.

Went to visit Point Pelee national Park  on 9/17/14.  Spotted  five roosts. Conservatively the largest roost had about 1800-2000 monarchs the  next one noticeably smaller, about 1500 the smaller three roosts approximately 500 each, a handful of smaller roosts along the East beach right at the tip. with no more than 15 butterflies in them and a speckling of independent butterflies all over the trees between the first roost and the tip. Watched them for two hours. The monarchs started in the tops of the trees, as the wind picked up and the sun set they moved down the trees a little bit and into the interior of the tip area for shelter.
Monarchs were roosting in shelter belt after feeding on goldenrod flowers. Time was evening 5:30-7 p.m.

Cold front hit this morning (9/13/14) - had an early frost. Found 17 monarchs roosting about 50 feet up in our old red pine. Took a photo with the waning gibbous phase moon descending behind them.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report to 9/12 when the roost first formed.

Hundred or so resting in trees during early morning hours.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 9/17 to 9/16, the night the roost formed.

As described in my peak migration report, they started roosting at about 6:15PM on the east side of a large Cottonwood about 40 feet off the ground on a branch hanging out over the soybean field (potential thermal heating as the beans are still green.)  Overnight temperature forecast at 5C but I think only got to 8C.  At 7:15PM when I last checked they were still fluttering as new ones arrived.  I went out at 8:30AM this morning to watch as the sun warmed them up. In ones, twos and threes they fluttered out and immediately started rising out of sight; some went south and others southwest.  They almost seemed to be kettling while still fluttering just like the Turkey Vultures do.  I'm glad they went high as the Blue Jays have started moving through on their way to Holiday Beach Conservation Area.  Never in 20 years living here have I seen anything like this year; I hope this a good sign.

Tonight is the first evening that our team has spotted any roosting activity.  It may be a small number, 30 or so individuals, but it was great to see the monarchs gathering together!  There was a gentle N wind today.  The hawk watch counter tallied 160 monarchs coming down the dunes in about 5 hours, this morning.

Ed Cole of the AuSable Valley Audubon Club called me today and stated that the monarchs he reported last night (9/17) were still at the point at Tawas Point State Park this morning (9/18). The cold front is passing through today with winds from the north at 12-15 mph and the temperature was 51F. I would think that some of those monarchs were from my observations at Harrisville State Park a couple of days ago which is 30 miles north of Tawas. Today (9/18) I had no sightings at Harrisville State Park or Harrisville town.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 9/18 to 9/17, the night the roost formed.

There were about 500 monarchs roosting in the weeping willow and spruce trees in the middle of the day. It was 57 degrees and raining, so they likely had been there since the night before (9/14) and would stay another night.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 9/15 to 9/14, the night the roost formed.

Monarchs are alive and well in Hesston, KS. and the migration is here! I am a tagger for Monarch Watch, and have been since it's origination in 1992. Based on last year's migration and having to return most all of my tags because they were unused, I unfortunately ordered too conservatively on tags for this year. I tagged 42 yesterday, which, with the 8 from the day before, used up the 50 tags I ordered for the year. This morning (7-9am; September 20) I saw 75-100 roosting monarchs in my usual tagging places, but had no tags to use. I re-ordered a small amount of tags just in case monarchs will still be passing through here, but if it takes the 3 weeks customer service said it might, that will likely be too late, even for some stragglers.

Yes, the monarchs would have settled into those areas the night before I saw them (9/19).

We have seen only a couple monarchs this week until today. Returning home from Rochester MN, we saw over 10 monarchs all flying low across the highway in a southerly direction.  When we got home, we grabbed our nets and tags and went to the butterfly trail.  We could see several monarchs circling the trees, looking for a roost.  After watching for a few minutes, we saw a roost about 12 ft up in a tree of about 15 monarchs and were able to tag 9. This is the latest we have seen monarchs roosting here.

First report to this site.  This evening I saw many butterflies hanging on leaves on the lower branches of a locust tree and two other deciduous trees in a yard surrounding a farmhouse, protected by cedars that surround the house for a windbreak on the north and west.  I saw them at least once last year and have just returned to stay at this farmhouse while I help with corn harvest.  I will try to keep track of how many I see over the next month, each day.

I'm thrilled to report a roost of 50+ monarchs. I watched them gather tonight on the edge of my neighbor's 10 acre clover field that's in full bloom. I'm sure there were 100+ nectaring today throughout the field, but they didn't all roost in the same place. I found singles and doubles along the tree line. The roosting process was fascinating to watch: A butterfly would scout up and down the 100 yard tree line, back-and-forth. If it came close enough (within ~ 5 feet) to the group I was watching, the resting butterflies would flash their wings in unison-- and the monarch would circle around in join in (--or not). The butterflies were clustering loosely at the tips of a low branch of a tall ash tree, about 15 feet above the ground. The tree is probably ~80 feet tall. The branch they selected extends out from the tree line more than any other. (See branch at left in picture.) The roost was on the north side of the tree; a strong south wind was blowing all day, but had calmed by 6:00 when I was watching. At 10:30 pm I heard the wind howling and rain pelting against the windows. Would they move to the south side of the trees? Would they fall to the ground? I went back this morning (9/22/14) at 7 am. Temperatures had fallen to 49F, the wind had shifted to the west and was blowing 15 mph. To my amazement, the monarchs were still gripping onto the leaves of the ash. The wind was tossing the branch to and fro and the monarchs held on for the ride, swaying at least 5 feet back and forth. I did find one monarch on the ground. It was shivering to reach flight threshold and clumsily tried to fly when I approached.
Near the tip at Point Pelee National Park, on an interior treetop we observed about 100 monarchs roosting with about another 50 unsettled  flying nearby. It was around 7pm.

There were about 100 in the cedar trees at approximately 4:15pm CT. They seemed to be resting.

Sept 23: I will check to see if they are still there and try to get some photos.
11 adult monarchs fed over 2 days in the garden...first appearance afternoon of 9/20, roosted in red maple tree at night, and continued feeding 9/21/14. No sighting on 9/22, cooler & windy.
Many more monarchs than could actually count - nectaring and roosting in shelter belt of honey locust and red cedar. It's harder to count them in the roost because they're so well camouflaged.

Many more monarchs than could actually count - nectaring and roosting in shelter belt of honey locust and red cedar. More sighted than on Friday, Sept. 19. It's harder to count them in the roost because they're so well camouflaged.
Five roosts sighted at Hawk Cliff just east of Port Stanley, Ontario on the morning of Sept 23/14. 1 of 25 Monarchs1 of 60 Monarchs1 of 10 Monarchs1 of 20 Monarchs1 of 25 Monarchs

Todays weather, a gentle N wind, starting bringing monarchs in to Cape May Point late in the afternoon. I was hoping to find some roosts tonight with the chillier temperatures and we did!  There were about 200 monarchs seen settling down in groups around Cape May Point.  One tree I found had 50 clustered together while other trees had multiple groups of 10 - 20 monarchs.  I only checked a few known spots so there could have been more.
Watched Monarch come off sunflower bushes and roost in trees above me.

Another good night with up 2500 Monarchs observed at the Tip. Winds will be good for crossing the lake tomorrow - expect many to leave.

Courtesy of Don Davis

There were about 30 to 40 monarchs feeding on clover in a 40 acre plot of land next to my office.  I photographed for about an hour.  Once sunset came, I could see them landing in a Bradford pear tree next to the building.  There was an additional sighing on 9/23 as well.  Will report if there are additional sightings this week.
In the evening, 40-50 Monarchs roost on north side of pine tree on the edge of a CRP field.  This has been occurring each evening for past 8 or so days (approx. September 17-24).
Beautiful monarchs migrating through our backyard. They nestled in our pine trees, directly next to some fruit trees, for the night. They are still here the morning of 9/26/14.

This was in our paper yesterday:"These Monarch Butterflies were gathering in a tree on north Sherman Sunday evening (September 21), taking a breather before continuing their long trip to Mexico where they will hibernate for the winter before heading north again next spring. Monarch butterflies are not able to survive the cold winter of most of the United State so they migrate south and rest each autumn to escape the cold weather. The monarch migration usually starts in about October of each year, but can start earlier if the weather turn cold sooner than that."

Sunset at Long Beach (6:45 pm). At the beach entrance, there is a single ash tree surrounded by goldenrod in the beach dunes. More than 20 monarchs were feasting on the goldenrod; as the sun set they fluttered up into the ash tree to roost.

Estimate count of four hundred Monarchs on 40 acres plus of aster and sunflower. Across the hill, a Maximillian Sunflower patch planted into a water way has count of 100 Monarchs. A patch of .6 acre of Maximillian estimated at 500 Monarchs. In total 1000 Monarchs at the farm late this afternoon (9/27/14). Presume roosting has been occurring each night for several weeks (September 17-28), in varying numbers; I have not looked each evening, but when I have there was roosting. Monarchs roosted on the sunflowers, as seen in the video. In addition to the roosts on sunflowers, monarchs were roosting in the maple tree and pine tree.Editor's Note: Video and photo were taken 9/28/14. Roosting on flowers -- instead of in trees -- is a valuable observation and could be temperature-related. Overnight low temperatures were 55F both nights (9/27/14 and 9/28/14).

Just before sunset last night (9/28) there were 41 Monarchs at this site. This morning (9/29) , in the dew I would count 37 plus one Painted Lady. While the Monarchs chose passive heating, the PL trembled and shook, burning energy with its muscles to both shake off the fine droplets and to warm up to flight temperature for departure. (Photos avail). These butterflies are NW of Point Pelee and were flying from the NE and the soybean fields at dusk (advanced by heavy cloud cover). Asters were food choice here.The willow trees here are in a drainage ditch at the edge of a highway.
Roosting in my brothers back yard

Large treed suburban yard has 500-1000 Monarchs roosting, observed since yesterday by owner. I have no idea how to count actual numbers. Butterflies are roosting in clusters of 20 or more in Sycamore, Maple, Pine, and Lilac shrubs.

The owner discovered them on 9/29/14. I'm not sure what time. I saw them on 9/30/2014 about 3:30pm for close to 2 hours. I was told they had a similar roost there two or three years ago.

October 7:The Monarchs are no longer there. There were a few small clusters on the morning of Friday, October 3rd, maybe 100 total. The owner posted that they were all gone by that evening (10/3).

I saw them at 5:30pm. Small clusters of monarchs roosting in several trees in suburban neighborhood.  The property is heavily treed with open lawn and there is a butterfly garden near by.  The Monarchs roost singly or in clusters of 10 or more.

Monarchs were seen roosting on a willow tree on several different occasions throughout the week prior to the 13.

We first saw the Monarchs in the early evening on September 1, 2014. I would estimate about 250 total at that time on our willow tree and another maple tree in our backyard in northville, SD. We noticed them each evening for about 4 days. We all are gone to work and school all day but I did notice them on the morning of September 3. I honestly can't say if they were there every morning that week because I didn't go out to the backyard any other mornings! The evening of September 1 had the largest roost and each evening there were fewer but still an impressive number. I would estimate around 100 the second two evenings and then probably 40-50 the next evening. The count on September 3 (morning) was probably around 100 like the evening count. The following week (9/7-13) we noticed about 10-12 monarchs around some of our flowers....we enjoyed watching them but it was nothing after seeing such a large number the week before! It's been about 7-8 years ago but we noticed back then a large amount of monarchs at around the same time of year. At that time they were on the trunk of a maple tree in our backyard.

Photo credit to our daughter, Hannah Schentzel (Northville, SD. Age 11).

Just before 6:30 I was outside walking in our yard. Which is a rural farm in NE Kansas. There were hundreds of butterfly's flying through the tree tops. As the sun started to set, about 15 min later, the butterflies clustered together and were hanging by the hundreds on the tree branches.
6:30pm  they were looking for places to roost..some chose a tree that already had dried up brown leaves..they camouflaged themselves very well..

While on break at work, eight monarch came floating down to the trees, followed by a second group of eight into the trees. Time was 5:00 pm. Temperature 74 degrees. SW headwind at 5 - 7 mph. I figure it was time to rest for the night. Activity was great for the short amount of time I actually got to observe.
1,200 yesterday about 350 today after all the rain.

The sight of all the beautiful Monarch Butterflies flying all around me took my breath away. The wind had turned strong out of the north and they were landing in my large pecan tree. It was hard to tell just how many due to the size of the tree but they were everywhere.

Yesterday(10/2/14) a front moved through dallas changing wind directions. Thi(10/3/14) morning I started observing monarchs flying south as early as 8am north of Frisco in some open fields, my count reached 70 by noon. I stopped counting but i estimate seeing 150-200 directionally flying.When I got home I checked for roosting at the creek near my house ( this is where as a child I witnessed 1000's of monarchs roosting one year). I observed an estimated 12/20 monarchs roosting for the night.Extremely excited to see the start of the migration through dallas, will update if numbers continue to rise!

There are probably more than 10; however they are roosting in my next door neighbors pin oak tree.Unfortunately I am unable to zoom in enough to get a photo.This is the first time I've witnessed this and it is amazing!

Had a cold front pass through the area yesterday (10/3/14) dropping the temperatures from 95/75 to 83/49. They must have come in on the front.I always watch for the Monarchs and was surprised to see 24 clustered in pecan trees today; haven't seen this many in two or three years. Hope the numbers increase.

I believe the roost formed the evening of 10-3 but can't say for sure. I first saw the roost about 9:30am 10-4. On 10-6 saw 25 to 30 Monarchs through the day and could not find a roost; they were very scattered.
It was evening. They were fluttering in the trees.

Saw many individuals coming in to roost on the willow trees along edge of park.  Cold front just came through the area.<center><iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/SpfA1OrRDlE?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe></center>

We saw monarch butterflies swarming around our house and landing in trees about 1:45pm. We've never seen that many at one time and couldn't count them because they kept flying and sitting in so many trees in the yard.I saw them before dark also but it didn't look like as many. There could have been 50. We're surrounded by trees so it's hard to tell. I'm attaching a photo that I was able to capture.

I then got a phone call from my friend in Duncanville TX when I sent her an email about my sighting and she said that they had a fire going in their backyard on Saturday, Oct. 4th, in the dark, and they had a lot of monarchs flying around them AND over the fire and even landing on her husband and ground.

I just stopped writing this and went out to see if they're still there (10/07) and they are but not as many.

Checked between 1830 to 2000. Sunset is about 1915. On the way to check the first grove, Monarchs were still on the Liatris patches feeding. In the first grove I checked, clearly different individuals from those feeding, about 50. No more that 25 together, distributed the grove mostly 5-10 feet from the ground. When I left that grove just after sunset, no Monarchs remained on the liatris. Checked several other past roost spots. All of them, plus individual large trees, had monarchs in varying numbers. Call it 50 more for a total of 100.

Picture shows between 20 and 25 on Ashe Junipers, just after sunset, with flash fill in foreground. (Sunset is behind the camera.)

Low Humidity. Strong south wind. Temp 80F.

Monarchs are resting in trees, so I called it a roost, even though it’s in the middle of the day. All usual roost sites and many individual trees had Monarchs perching at 1400. Since other Monarchs were out on flowers feeding intently, I guess these had fed enough and were sheltering from the high wind and low humidity. They flushed readily when approached, but returned to roost twigs almost immediately.

The picture is of the largest cluster I noticed. It contains between 65 and 70 individuals. As a photograph it’s not great, because of the low contrast between Monarchs and leaves in the shade. As an example of what they really look like, it’s pretty good. With the bright light from overhead, it was easy to walk right up to them and not notice until they stirred.

Total in all “roosts” about 200. Note that this is additive to the peak migration report for today, which covers only the Monarchs out on flowers feeding.
Observed Roost of about 30 Monarchs on trees on one of the small islands located within Tablerock lake.
At least 100-150 Monarchs clustered in the bush and decorative grasses by the fence in my backyard!

This group of monarchs have been in a group of trees since 10-5. They are roosting in the hackberry trees in the evenings and move over to the pasture with flowers during the day. So far, they have been there on Sun. Mon and Tues. (today)
On October 6th and October 7th extreme amounts of Monarch's roosted overnight in my front meadow. I was very happy to see large migration this year !

There were at least 60 Monarchs in my backyard habitat today.  Couldn't get a good count or picture because of all the flitting around.  But I counted them on the Oak tree this evening and found 60 roosting in the tree.  It is quite a large tree now and I had to count all over it.  They did not light on only the west side as they have done in the past. They were all over it. 60 was the number that I actually spotted. Have only seen a dozen or so eggs so far and no cats yet.  Unfortunately  I will be unable to see what happens for the next three weeks. But usually the third week of October there are about a hundred or more.

Monarchs have arrived at Cleburne State Park. Monarch Butterflies starting to roost for the evening at the waters edge.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch Editor's note: Number of monarchs estimated by JN
at least 150 just beginning to flutter (this morning 10/7) around trees where they had spent the night (10/06) near Brady Creek

strong westerly winds at the tip of Pt. Pelee there were approx 200 Monarchs roosting on the east side of the Point in the lee, mostly on Hackberry and Mulberry trees with some of this count moving rapidly through the trees along the east point beach at ca. 4:30-5PM

The monarchs were nectaring on the goldenrod in the dunes all day today.  Our team walked up and down the beach road looking for roosting and found a few places with groups of butterflies, 25, 50, 75, 2, 10 â€¦ that totaled close to 300 but no one large aggregation was found.  It was fairly warm last night and many of the monarchs were roosting singularly also.  Hoping that the ones spotted up north today will travel this way soon.
1,200 yesterday (10/01) about 350 today (10/2) after all the rain.

We saw several Monarchs for a few days. On the morning of Sep 27 we saw hundreds and i mean hundreds of roosting Monarchs. It was very windy and they were hanging out on the north side of the trees to keep out of the south wind. We have a large butterfly garden with a tree line (about 300' long) behind it. We live in the country and have let several acres return to the prairie. We have never seen so many. We walked thru clouds of butterflies.

They started leaving on Sept 29. After that we only saw 2 or 3 at a time, the last sighting was Fri Oct 12 and we saw 2. I have many photos.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 9/27 to 9/26, the night the roost formed.

20 to 30 monarchs were roosting the the trees along the Shore of Lake Michigan.  They were on the east face of the trees facing the sun.  Temp. was in the forties. Today, 10/09/14 20 monarchs were sighted feeding on red clover around the Environmental Science Bldg. on the Concordia University Wisconsin Campus in a ten minute period.
For the 3rd night the Monarch's have roosted in the Trees and shrubs in my front meadow. They feed on Frostweed and Gregg's Blue Mist . I do have Milkweed also, they didn't go for it!

Nice roost last night (10/09). Many more than last year. Have roosted in same area for 50+ years. Little nectaring, are getting water from creek. Not as clustered today (10/10), some may have left.

October 14
Rather strong norther and rain came in last Saturday morning (10/11). Monarch roosting have gone. Still have 30 or so nectaring. The main plants they are feeding on are 5 foot tall celosia. I've seen as many as 30 monarchs on one of these plants.

I estimated the number of monarchs in a given cubic area and then estimated the number of cubes that had butterflies and figured from there. It was a truly magical place for a few days.

Editor's Note: The other roost reported from Ponder, Texas on 10/10 is a separate roost, and about 7 miles from this one.

We went to Corson's Inlet State Park around 5:30 to look for roosting monarchs in the dunes. Small clumps of monarchs nectaring on the seaside goldenrod and groundsel bushes. Most clumps contained 2-10 monarchs. Beautiful, picture-perfect weather with temperature in the upper 60s to low 70s and a light westerly breeze.

Midday yesterday the Monarchs began arriving to roost in a maple tree in the middle of Old 86 Campground.  I wonder if they knew the weather forecast - that thunderstorms were headed this way? While boating on Table Rock Lake, we saw a few crossing the lake in the afternoon as well, but not as many as in previous days.
9 October there is a gathering of about 50 or more individual Monarch Butterfly's roosting in our neighbors tree for the night! It's quite the sight to see. Very Exciting!

This evening we counted nearly 100 roosting in our yaupon holly trees and our neighbor's live oak. We saw two clusters of 30+ and many other smaller groups. I have never seen this many in my yard since I started mu butterfly gardein in 1995. This is amazing!

We have been witnessing dozens and dozens of Monarch Butterfly's in our area. There are probably at least 2 dozen roosting in between my neighbors and my house each night. We first started seeing them last Saturday, October 4th. This site will only allow me to upload 1 pic...there are 6 I think in this photograph, they are beginning to settle in for the night, plus there is a storm approaching...:(

Monarchs rest in our pecan trees every year. They came in on the weekend of 10/04/14 on a north wind. They are still here as of 10/10/14. This is the highest number of Monarchs we have ever seen. There are thousands. We are located on a ranch 3 miles S.E. Of Paint Rock , Tx. I have a video, but no picture.
They roosted again on Oct.9th .

This is the third day of this week that I have tagged and seen Monarch Butterflies in this location. At around 7:00pm, the Monarchs came in with the evening breeze to roost along the trees by Lake Wichita (now almost dry from the drought).

We have a group here in Wichita Falls that look for the Monarchs every year at this location by Lake Wichita. On Saturday, October 4, we noticed the Monarchs coming into the area and I posted a roost report. We went back out on October 5 - my friend Jane posted more sightings. I went back on Monday, October 6 - again more Monarchs coming into the trees. On Wednesday, October 8, we saw even more coming in. On Wednesday, October 8, I was able to net about 10 per "swoop" as they came into the trees to roost. Even though Lake Wichita is almost dried up, we are still getting good groups of Monarchs coming to rest in this area. Hope this helps!

There have been 100+ Monarchs roosting in my Elm tree and feeding all over my flowers on 3 acres next to the Brazos river all week. I first sighted the roost 10/05/2014 in the evening and they have roosted every night with more and more arriving all week. Today (10/11) there are still dozens remaining on the roost tree. The thunder storm last night (10/10) and cooler temps this morning (10/11) have them in a torpor.

Thousands of monarchs by in a grove of trees by our pond.

Editor's Note: The other roost reported from Ponder, Texas on 10/09 is a separate roost, and about 7 miles from this one.

The monarchs first roosted the evening of October 7th (reported). They roosted the night of the 9th (100 butterflies) and through the daytime on Friday the 10th, but were mainly gone by yesterday the 11th. In fact there were only 2!  And they are still there. We had a rainstorm Friday night (10/10) and it is now (10/12) much cooler, so it made sense that they would move on. This was so amazing. Do you know if Monarchs roost in the same places year after year?  We had a few last year, and I didn't know if they somehow marked us as a safe, good place to rest on their journey.

Monarchs has been gliding into my backyard since 10:00 this morning. It is now 4:00 in the afternoon. I have a roost of about 50 in the bamboo plants.

October 14
Most of them left yesterday (10/13) afternoon. The rest left during that night. There are 5-6 flying around the backyard now (10/14), nectaring on milkweed and Greg's Mist. I had a roost about 6 years ago of around 1000 monarchs. They stayed for 5 days. We had winds up to 25 mph yesterday (10/13), so maybe that had something to do with them not staying.

We counted over 250 in one hour between 6-7 pm. They were starting to roost in the trees on our ranch. The sky was filled with large adults arriving just before a cold front we are expecting later tonight. Spectacular!!!

We have Monarchs all over our back yard.  I would guess between 100-200 have taken refuge in our trees. Oh it was awesome to watch!  We're located in Mexia, Texas. We're not sure when they arrived. We seldom go in the backyard. But we had a terrible storm this weekend (Oct. 11/12) and it blew down trees.  When we were trying to get all the trees up, we saw them.  Needless to say, we left everything alone and want them to stay as long as they like. So peaceful. Right now, they cover about half the area of our back yard fence, and we were out there about 5:15pm.  We will keep an eye on them and let you know how they do.  They were coming in as fast as we could take pictures.Editor's Note: This roost was reported at 7 pm on October 13. We are leaving the date as reported but, as noted above, we don't know when the roost formed for the first time. We have Monarchs all over our back yard.  I would guess between 100-200 have taken refuge in our trees. Oh it was awesome to watch!  We're located in Mexia, Texas.

Observed thousands of Monarchs Thursday (10/09) and Friday waiting for the cold front to push through. Evergreen Cemetery in Ballinger, Texas, was covered with butterflies as were trees on our family farm that borders the Colorado River. High southerly winds kept them roosting until the cold front that pushed through last night (10/12). They were very active and looked healthy with big, bright wings. I was up close and personnel with many and didn't see any tattered wings but could see their little feet dangling and hear them flutter by! The most I've seen in years!
Around 30 monarchs roosting in trees by my driveway.

Our night time temp last night (10/13) dropped into the lower 40's so the Monarchs that roosted on the ranch overnight were moving slow this morning (10/14). Once the sun hit the trees and the temperature got above 50, the few that roosted started to move. It was hard to get a true count because they would fly from their original roosting spot to either another tree or move higher up into more direct sunlight. However, from 8:00 am to 9:30 am, I counted 50 that took flight, gained altitude, and headed south.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 10/14 to 10/13, the night the roost formed.

I'm looking at the largest group of Monarchs I've seen so far this Fall. Probably 300+ have been roosting in willows and ash trees on N shore at Friendship Park. They're getting up, foraging, and dispersing at the moment. No guess as to how many X000's are around the lake.

Courtesy of TX-BUTTERFLYGranger Lake is a United States Army Corps of Engineers reservoir on the San Gabriel River in central Texas in the United States. The lake is located near the towns of Granger, Texas and Taylor, Texas in Williamson County.

saw ten plus individuals roosting on large, fragrant bush

It was late afternoon when I saw them roosting...probably after 4 pm central time in an undeveloped field next to our local dog park. The plant they are roosting on is called Baccharis neglecta "False Willow" and typically, blooms August through October. It is a very fragrant plant and seems to attract many different pollinators including butterflies and bees.

Last October is when I first noticed Monarchs roosting on them so I tried to remember to check them this year. These plants are not usually found in residential landscapes - mostly in abandoned lots, fields, and along forest edges. I have seen monarchs very late in the day on these same plants in different areas, so I think it would be safe to say they have roosted there all night. This year seems to be a very good year for monarchs. It seems there have been more migrating this year than years past. Another observation is I am not finding as many larvae as I have before. I have an organic rest stop for them featuring tropical milkweed, zinnias, mexican bush sage, echinacea, rudbeckia, salvias, lemon verbena, almond verbena, and hyacinth bean vine. I do not use any chemicals in the garden. Hopefully, the larvae are just hiding.

My husband and I walked our two dogs earlier this evening (between 6:30 and 7:00 p.m. on Tuesday, October 14, 2014) in Mansfield Dam Park, near Austin, Texas, and saw numerous Monarch butterflies clustering on the large oak trees within the park.  Within this half-hour period, we viewed a minimum of 400 butterflies coming to rest on three huge oak trees.  Dozens of other Monarchs were already nestled within the tree branches.  The black markings on this group of Monarchs were strikingly more distinctive than on most Monarchs we've seen in the past, and the butterflies appeared strong and purposeful.  We will return to the park tomorrow and will bring a camera.
light winds, near sun set along the San Saba River in a native Pecan grove. Caught and tagged in big bunches. Was able to tag 159 in an hour.

Witnessed and took pictures of many butterflies who came to a group of trees on our property before sunset on 10/3/14. The next morning most left. I still see butterflies flying by but none are roosting.

Watched monarchs begin settling into a golden rod field about 3:30 pm and still coming in @ 5pm. At about 5:15 pm the monarchs were coming from “behind” the bluff and gathering down in the “bowl” that was made up of primarily goldenrods. There were none in the trees. They had began randomly leaving the “bowl” when I passed by between 9:30 and 10 the morning of the 16th.

October 16
The bulk of the monarchs had moved on this afternoon. Maybe a dozen or so settled in.

Grove of Monterey Pines in Cambria, Caiif. appears to be a temporary roost.

My friend who has lived in Cambria for 26 years says she has seen them roosting in the Monterey Pine grove yearly since she can remember; some years more numbers than others.
At dusk they gather together in the mesquite trees and rest.

We saw the roosting monarchs last Saturday evening, October 11. We estimated there were about 60 in one Cedar Elm tree. There may have been others elsewhere along the creek, but we didn't have time to look for them. A cold front had come through that morning and we had received 1.6 inches of rain, but it was mostly clear by that evening.

About 2,000 monarchs around 2:30 on a sunny day most on the saplings

Forwarded by Don Davis
Feeding on lantana and roosting in backyard pecan trees.  West Point is a peninsula at origin of York River in Virginia Peninsula region.

The Monarchs were in loose groups, a few dozen here, a dozen there, a small cluster of three or four occasionally.  I may have seen 200 Monarchs in total.  They were along Pinto Creek five miles northwest of Brackettville.
Clusters of monarchs roosting in our trees--about 200 butterflies

In an area of about a 20' circle we had one large cluster and multiple small clusters on nearby branches. I swiped my net twice and managed to get about 30 each net-load. Only 7-8' off the ground. This is in a sheltered grove behind a 9' high stone wall, out of the breeze. I think that one large cluster easily had about 100 in it.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: I saw hundreds of Monarchs along Pinto Creek five miles outside of Brackettville, Texas.  They were in clusters of two, three, and four dozen.  There were probably many hundreds more than what I saw.
Monarch Butterfly Grove, Pismo Beach.More then 1000
Our team was excited to find some monarch roosts tonight!!! We located one with approximately 200 butterflies and a second with around 300. Our census total for today was 270 monarchs an hour.

Haven't seen but one or two Monarchs for the last several days but noticed an increase in activity this morning 10/20/14. It is 7:00pm and I have just checked for roost. It looks as if there are about 150-200 in three different clusters; 50?? in each. It has been mostly cloudy here most of the day with an east wind and a slight chance of rain showers. The low pressure system over Arizona may be an influence.

Not as many Monarchs as we had yesterday.  The clusters were about the same size (two to three dozen per) but there weren't as many. Spotted along Pinto Creek five miles outside of Brackettville, Texas.

This observation was made in the Kreutzberg Canyon Natural Area, Kendall County, Texas.  This area includes 117 scenic acres along the Guadalupe River containing six habitats: riparian, oak savanna, disturbed woodland, open juniper - oak woodland, closed-canopy juniper - oak woodland, and old field.The fall roost includes 1,700 feet of riparian habitat along the Guadalupe River with a ground cover of Frostweed (Verbesina virginica), an important nectar plant for Monarch Butterfly. Monarchs were observed roosting, nectaring, and flying about the area.  Clearly, this is a very important fall roost for the Edwards Plateau area.

I saw bigger clusters of Monarchs tonight.  Instead of just a dozen or two here and there, there were clusters of up to 100 Monarchs and one cluster that probably had closer to 200.  There just weren't many clusters.  I only found six trees with clusters of a dozen or more Monarchs.  These were sighted along Pinto Creek five miles outside of Brackettville, Texas.
only 3 Monarchs at tip at sunset with strong westerlies blowing. Air temp is 12 degrees C,

A friend at work saw a roost near a pond on his property in Lorena . He said there were "clouds of them", "tens of thousands".We have been seeing them everywhere in Waco, and drove to Abilene last weekend and saw lots coming and going.

Courtesy of Mike Quinn TX-BUTTERFLY

After shooting a sunset at the beach I observed over 200 Monarchs roosting.

Billy McCord told me that it is a male Baccharis shrub. This particular one is about 4 to 5 foot tall. He further told me that it is their favorite nectar plant in the Carolina coastal region. I tend to think of them as salt water plants as they are usually found along salt water rivers and beaches in our area.

Hoy por la tarde observé cerca de 30 mariposas perchadas en un árbol, en el jardín de mi escuela.

Courtesy of Correo Real
About 50 Monarchs arrived on Tuesday 10/14. We saw them all over our property that day. At dusk they congregated in backyard Oak tree and roosted in clusters.
About 50 Monarchs roosted in clusters in backyard Oak tree
About 50 Monarchs roosted in clusters in backyard Oak tree
About 50 Monarchs roosted in backyard Oak tree
Not as many Monarchs roosted in Oak tree as were there for previous 4 nights.

Checked the roost about 7:45pm and found that there were 75 monarchs, about half the number of Monarchs as reported 10/20/14 (150). They are not gathering to form one large cluster. They are scattered and form several small clusters (photo of largest attached).Have had scattered rain showers beginning last night and continuing through the day. That weather system that has been hanging out west finally moved past us.

strong south wind. Monarchs were roosting on the North side of our pine windbreak late afternoon to dark.

It was Sept 20. I just learned about your site! We had them in 2009, 2010, and a few in 2011, did not see them in 2012 or 2014 so was very excited to see them this year!
Returned for the 2nd day to find Monarchs roosting in groups of 50 to 100 in several trees/bushes.

Saturday night (10/18) I was returning home to the Eastern Shore via the Bay Bridge Tunnel after attending a conference in Suffolk, Va.I made a brief stop at the Grill on Seagull Island and found the buildings next to the parking lot covered in Monarchs, there were quite a few flying in the still air on the downwind side of the buildings and I can say that there were many large groupings of many dozens of insects clinging to the brickwork. I couldn't get any real count, it was getting very dark as the weather was getting really cruddy. There were many more than I have seen in one place since I was young, I was very impressed by the sight and was very glad that they found a place of refuge before the storm.

Courtesy of Monarch Watch
100 monarch is estimated by JN
Observed 54 Monarchs roosting in Cedar Elms, liveoaks and bald cypress on Guadalupe River near James Kiehl Park in Kendall county.

In Cape May Point, NJ on the evening of 10/20/14 the local Project Monarch found a roost in a pine tree along the beach that adjoins the Atlantic Ocean. On the morning of 10/21/14 the tree had several Monarch roosts of anywhere from 30 to more than a hundred Monarchs. It was an awesome sight to see. Mid morning when the clouds cleared and the weather warmed they left for their journey South to Mexico.

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 10/21 to 10/20, the night the roost formed.

Today was the first sunny day we've had since the Monarchs arrived.  They were flitting around all over the place and it was hard to get an idea of how many there really were.  There were a few clusters of up to two to three dozen clusters, most clusters were much smaller.  They were more spread out today than they have been.
Surprised to see about 50 or so that were in oak trees about 6pm in our pasture about 10 mi west of Brady. Wish I'd had a camera!
Still good numbers in the area, but less than yesterday.  I talked to someone today who has been tagging them and I captured a photo of one that he had tagged sometime in the past few days.

Checked for Monarchs at 8:00pm tonight and found that the numbers are up; 150 minimum.There are three clusters about the same size and the clusters are closer than previous nights.Mostly cloudy with SW winds 10-15 mph and temps 58 to 80.

Beautiful day, rained a little this morning, pleasantly cool this afternoon. Roosting in pecan trees along a small river near the largest bald cypress tree in Texas. A truly magical time. I am told the monarchs roost here ever year!

Editor's note: We've re-dated this report from 10/24 to 10/23, the night the roost formed.

Wow. Right on time the roosting  is starting at Gibbs Butterfly Park. We have yet to see the cloud of butterflies come yet but its early. We have about two different sites that they are in. One site is back by the circle of flowers and the other is opposite the circle. I am only counting about 15 now but am sure more will come. Stay tuned. We will be putting updates on our website H.B. Trees.org Butterfly park.

I arrived at Federal Point, Ft Fisher this morning (10/23) a little after sunrise...it was 48 degrees and a little windy...I quickly found that 100+ Monarchs had camped out last night (10/22) in the area's cedars and wax myrtles...there were at least 20 more over the road that passed me on my way back to the aquarium...120+ is a conservative estimate...My next stop was Ft Caswell where I observed single Monarchs floating over the huge lawn area while I searched for birds...dozens more Monarchs but many may have been counted on the other side of the inlet...amazing sight especially with good numbers of buckeyes and Gulf Frits.Total observation time was about 3 hours...would love to hear how many Monarchs others had at other coastal locations and time periods...Photo posted to Carolina Leps Facebook page...

Courtesy of Carolina Leps
More than 100 were feeding on tiny white flowers & then bedding down in this tree.  Have had 4 days (10/19-23) of 100+ flying over, feeding, roosting, along with 2 caterpillars.

Monarchs are still (10/22) hanging out at my son's house in Brackettville. .

the first day I saw them was Sunday Oct 19 . . . I didn't check to see if they were still around today (10/24), but I'll let you know if they are. As of right now, I had them roosting Sunday through Wednesday (10/19-22).

Oct 24: just checked my tree where there were numbers earlier - there is only a single Monarch roosting there right now.
Monarchs were on the sunflowers until dusk. Then they flew into the nearby trees.

Low last night 64 (at 7:30 a.m.), breeze from SSE @ 7mph, very sunny. Only lazy and casual movement from remaining monarchs. Across fence at neighbor's 40-50 remain is a single loose cluster of some 2'x 5' and comprised of 4 minor branches at the tips of an ash tree. 20 ea on 2 branch tips some 8" apart. Others scattered loosely in same small area. 5 monarchs nectaring and elating around my yard. One on sunflowers, other on antigonon vine. Out front 2 monarchs one on mesquite other on durnata bush.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: Cunningham Ranch at far south end of Quemado Valley 18 miles N of Eagle Pass, TX. Yesterday afternoon there were some 300 monarchs roosting in loose clusters of 4-8 and some even 18-20 monarchs throughout our pecan bottoms located at the base of a steep 300'bluff on the banks of the Rio Grande. A small creek runs at the bottom of the bluff and amongst the pecan and ash trees. A dense canopy also contributes to the still air. Two days earlier the numbers were at least in the 500 range. We had several overcast days with still air and mild nights and none of the monarchs were migrating. Now Thur./Fri./ Sat (today) are/were all very sunny and night temps dropped to 65 with a high today of 91 and breezes from SSE at 7-10mph. Report submitted to Rio Bravo Nature Center, Eagle Pass.
school: Rio bravo nature center foundation, inc

comments: About 50 in the large trees in huffines park in Richardson Texas.  They are very content even though a rack bad is playing during an art festival there.  Picture is not that good but you can see the orange specs of color on upper left and in bottom middle.
Counted 17 feeding on the fall sunflowers and then flying into the nearby trees.

I have had a lot of monarchs in my yard and gardens for over a week but did not know where they were roosting until yesterday (10/25).  They are in a crepe myrtle that is in a heavily tree area of my yard.

Attached is an another image of the Monarchs at this location. They are still more scattered than in past years??The weather is clear and 10 mi.. With temperatures in the high 80's during the day; high 60's at night. The winds from the SSW at 10 to 15 mi.. This will be the case until this Tuesday when the wind will shift to the north with a temperature drop of about 10 deg.. I think the Monarchs will stay around until a strong cold front comes through; we'll see.

Was checking for pecans when as I walked under the pecans there were all of a sudden lots of monarchs flying around.  I didn't think much but as I kept walking more would fly up.  I looked on the trees and saw so many that had lit on the underside of the leaves.  The 50 to 100 that flew up where just a small fraction of the ones that stayed lit on the leaves
Upwards of 600 monarchs sighted roosting in live oak tree at the Grand Hotel Marriott Resort and Spa

First morning I have noticed a significant number of Monarchs on trees

In Hunt, TX monarchs roosting in oak trees

I discovered this roost in a tree behind an assisted living home.There was around 100 monarchs and I caught 5 and tagged them. They remained there for 3 nights (10/22-24). Could have been there longer, but those are the three nights after school that I went. We are putting a monarch garden there with the NAMI garden grant.
Sighted an estimated 100 Monarch butterflies roosting in a tree at Skywest golf course a few days ago (10/24) at Hayward, Ca.

About 23 monarch butterflies were observed feeding on a colony of frostweed (Verbesina virginica) in this observers backyard near to dusk, about 19:00.Monarchs were dropping down from the sky near this time and were observed roosting in a hackberry below the frostweed colony. The observers backyard is heavily planted with native plants and trees, and while observer has seen monarchs and other butterflies on a daily basis, she has never before seen such a quantity as this.

El martes 21 a las 15:43 desde la ciudad de Piedras Negras mi prima Renata G me envió un mensaje que decía ya llegaron las monarcas acabo de ver como 50 mariposas posadas en un pino en el DIF Municipal.

Courtesy of Correo Real

Checked the Monarch roost this morning about 8:30am. There were a few Monarchs around the roost; two hours later there were none. They left on the front that moved through this morning.                                                Until next year.

Observations of monarchs totaling over 1,000 in the large trees of the Schleicher County Courthouse lawn began to circulate on October 26th. Arriving at the site that afternoon, many were roosting in the large limbs overhanging the sidewalks and more were arriving on the breeze. By nightfall many of the pecan limbs were weighted by the flock. The monarchs stayed at this location until the morning of October 28th, when winds from the south subsided and winds from the north prevailed. Around 7:30am, the monarchs took flight and continued on their journey.

Video at http://eatonhillnaturecenter.com/monarchmigration2014/
PG Museum  Ann and Allison came out this morning and spotted 505 Monarch's roosting in eucalyptus trees.  Probably been here about 3 weeks, but just found the roosting spot today.

I sighted these along Pinto Creek five miles outside of Brackettville, Texas.  The largest cluster had around two dozen Monarchs and I only saw two large clusters, then several clusters of between three and a dozen.
75 - 100 roosted in my yard overnight (10/29-30), but early in the morning, saw hundreds fly over, Checked with 4-5 friends in SA. They saw them also.

I'm not your usual watcher, but the map in the recent National Geographic didn't list Indiana, and I thought I should mention that we did have some. We saw them in trees in a wind break along the fence line of a field.  It was a bit early for roosting, but a storm was brewing. We rode horseback along the fence line and the butterflies came tilting out of the tree and then went back again.  Lovely!My numbers are all guesses.  I'm terrible at counting moving objects.

The monarchs come through here every year, and still did this year. In the thousands. They hang on the ends of pecan tree branches, filing in line like wisteria blossoms. They were here for 8 days (10/19-28), barely leaving their positions on the trees. On the morning of October 27, a north front hit at 7:45 a.m. We suspected this was their signal to move on. One by one, they opened their wings to reveal their beautiful orange color. Each one would practice flap 2 or 3 times, but within 10 seconds of their unfolding they were taking off. Definitely south. 2 hrs later all were gone.

First noticed the roost 19th of October. So did neighbors on their trees. They left on the morning of the 28th (i-phone date of the pics), definitely as a consequence of a wind change to the north.

Starting around 5:30 PM we started to notice a steady stream of Monarchs circling over our property. We mostly saw them swirling around a few trees towards the back of our property, so I imagine they picked those to roost for the night. We had a hard time telling for sure where they were landing. We have a property with a lot of native landscape left, which also abuts to a greenbelt with native trees remaining as well. By the time I could see enough on the trees, it was too dark to get a photo. It has been several years since we saw so many Monarchs here. The last time we had a roost was about 7-8 years ago, and the tree right next to the house was so full it was completely orange. We hoped they'd roost in the same tree this year, but no.

Editor's Note: The observer estimated this number of butterflies, though the comments comparing to a previous year may indicate fewer.

VERY rough estimate of 3400-5000 adult monarchs roosting in a native Texas pecan tree grove near a creek.  We have seen them off and on over about a 5 year period, so we think it is a regular stop on their migration route.

More are arriving every day. We have at least 4 trees that they are landing in. They are doing a lot of flying and mating. Not to many staying in roost. Guess the warm weather is effecting them still. It is a beautiful sight to see them flying around the grove.
We are increasing in numbers to about 150 now. During the day they are flying around and mating. At about 4:30 they go back to their roosts.
What a magnificent sight. More are arriving and they are in a few other trees now.

Aunque ya cerraste la temporada de monarcas de JN, no puedo dejar de comunicarte lo que se vivió este sábado y domingo en todo el noreste de México, cuando después de tres días de lluvia, aparecieron por el cielo miles las monarcas. Te mando este video tomado hoy (9 noviembre) en la mañana en el Parque Roma de la ciudad de Monterrey.

Editor's Note: Since the video was taken the morning of 9 November we know roost formed night of 8 November so are dating this roost report accordingly. Estimating number as 3,000 since observer says "thousands."

Les comparto nuestra visita el día de ayer (1 noviembre), a unos 30-40 minutos de Monclova, en Lamadrid, Coahuila, para verificar, corroborar y reportar el paso de la mariposa monarca. Antes de llegar al pueblo, por los canales de riego, y viajando desde Canadá, siempre llegan aquí, en su paso a Michoacán y Edo. de México, las mariposas monarca. Había cientos de ellas perchadas en los diferentes árboles de huizache, y comiendo en algunas flores. Es incomprensible su memoria genética dado que se puede asegurar que, todos los ancestros de estas mariposas se posaron aquí antes para llegar a su santuario donde se congregan millones! esto es una pequeñísima muestra de lo que se ve en sus bosques.

Saludos Servando Santana, Imelda Puente y Dieguito

Editor's Note: We are estimating "hundreds" as 300.

El día 05 de Noviembre alcanzamos a observar entre 200 o 300 mariposas Perchadas en los Sauces Llorones que se encuentran en el Arroyo Ceballos que están en la entrada a la sexta sección del Bosque Urbano Ejército Mexicano, también nos llamó mucho la atención, ya que nunca se habían visto tantas mariposas en esas condiciones, el clima era de entre 18º C, poco viento, estaba nublado y eran alrededor de las 8:20 a.m. se anexan fotografía tomada por Carlos Carrera Treviño.

(Reporte por teléfono) Temprano en la mañana se empezaron a ver gran cantidad de mariposas volando a diferentes alturas, hice el conteo, después envío los datos. Como a las 2 de la tarde las volví a ver, pero eran tantas que no contarlas pero puedo decir que eran cientos.
